Didn't wait more than 10 minutes before we had a table for three. While waiting, ordered one of their Scoma pale ales.   Sat down, had some great bread. Ordered the roasted crab with garlic, olive oil and lemon.   Did I mention garlic?   Yeaaaaaah. Finger. Lickin. Good.   This is a dish you better have some time to enjoy; your companions are likely to be done with their meals before you. That's ok. Let'em stare. By the time I was done, I was covered up to my wrists in stuff, and I do NOT like to touch my food. I had crab, garlic, olive oil, lemon and parsley all over my hands like mittens, and I didn't mind one bit.   The crab was meaty and delicious, but the garlic? It does a body good!

h87PLzyihbuIczf04w0r_g.review_text: I wanted to try this place for a while.  I love seafood but I've had better for was less money.  The staff was very nice and attentive.  Probably nice for a special occasion.

i67PU7LKRSS7oZM4WQAmQg.review_text: The food was delicious and the staff was very attentive.  Me and my date had a nice time.    The ambiance was a bit pubby and I felt like I was eating in a mobile trailer.  Sorry Scoma :(      I did enjoy the food and drinks.  The steak and fried oysters were very good.   My whole meal for me and my date was pricey for the experience.    It was just okay overall for me.

m5CB1I83-r3bB2o4vqIAkg.review_text: Thanks to our friend to make us knowing this restaurant. The fried calamari appetizers, the salmon cake, the crab risotto and grilled fish were absolutly delicious. The service is very appreciable and efficient, and the White Scoma's Reserve Wine was delicious.

C0HWZJYKBt4koLpW0jW1Sg.review_text: If you can get over the fact that  parking sucks down at the wharf, some of the waitstaff are pompus a**holes, and that the average meal without drinks will be around $40-50 per person, the food is GREAT! I listed the "Lazy Man's Cioppino" as my last meal on earth...yes that good! I visit San Francisco 3-4 times a year and this is by far the main reason I keep coming back to visit (sorry mother-in-law). If they could lower the prices by 10-15% and hire help that really love to serve, Scoma's would get 5 stars.  Until then, 4 stars is all she wrote.

dl7TdXUL0aybDbSHuwOU0w.review_text: Recommended by friend during recent trip up to SF.   Overall quality of the seafood was fairly good. (8/10) However overall value of food factoring in costs is only average (5/10). We spent over $200.00 for a lunch for four and only two people had adult beverages, so we tried to get the good stuff. However, I've had comparable meals if not better for a fraction of the cost.  In terms of ambience, location is off the water on Pier 47. Location in proximaty to water is nice, but the water was green, and the furniture was a little beat up.   The service kept our water cups and bread baskets full and checked in on us periodically. However, considering their prices, they better be asking me if I need more water to swallow this food.  The misses had the Lazy Cioppino, which I recommend as a good size bowl of seafood. It's really a good size meal, and probably not the best choice of my petite honey as she could only eat half the stuff. Scallops were tender and the ingredients tasted fresh. (Yah, guess who tried to eat the other half...)  I had the salmon with lobster ravioli. Salmon practicalled melted in my mouth. Only four raviloi, so I wanted more.  The blood marys are above average, but not as good as say Mimi's Cafe. They cut a small piece of celery stalk and they don't even coat the rim of your glass with salt or spices. Not worth $8.50, IMO.  I'd probably only give this place 3.5 stars mainly because as a relative value I feel there's better places out there.

y9V6zHX2UhMXulDsqQneXg.review_text: Our experience at Scoma's sets the bar for a 5 star review. The food was incredible, but the wait staff were out of this world. If you can, request Bruce. He was the best waiter I've ever had. He really knew his stuff, knew how to keep our party in a good mood, while also giving us plenty of space. He's been there for over 30 years (despite a successful sales career at IBM), and absolutely made our night!  I took my family here from out of town. I hated the idea of taking them up near Fisherman's Wharf, but had too many locals who have been here way longer than I say its the best place to go. I can completely agree with them. Go here without hesitation if you're looking for amazing seafood in a comfortable atmosphere, with the friendliest and most knowledgeable wait staff I've ever encountered.   As I said, this place sets the bar for 5 star reviews!

FFNbIFieCFnEKelKAcaibw.review_text: My husband and I ate lunch here last year on a short trip to SF. We had done some morning sightseeing and major walking and really wanted some delicious and fresh SF seafood. Scoma's was out of the way and almost off a dock on the water behind the main action of Fisherman's Wharf. We chose the restaurant based on Yelp reviews and boy were we happy with our research results! The pacific oysters were INSANE! So incredibly fresh and delicious! Best oysters I've ever had! Decadent Swordfish Con Fagioli and wine! The service was fantastic even though we weren't dressed up. I felt like we fit in. We wanted to stay and sit a while because the atmosphere was so comfortable. Upon entering and leaving Scoma's we walked directly past the small building where they clean and prepare the "just caught" seafood!

v4OSDIDxgwqpa4bvH4QIqg.review_text: Nothing sucked, nothing was great. The simplest dishes were the best. Steamed dungeness crab, raw oysters on the half shell. Even the steamed broccoli and cauliflower were adequate.  But the swordfish piccata and pasta dishes were overcooked and gloppy. Hardly any flavor at all, and even a couple squeezes of lemon and liberal application of salt and pepper shaker could not cure their blandness. The garlic in the sautéed spinach was overcooked and bitter.  Ingredients seemed to be freshly prepared (except the swordfish which was obviously frozen) but the kitchen staff apparently had a production line training and mentality.   The service was friendly and efficient. Too bad the food at this place is far below premium seafood restaurants elsewhere. We will not go back.

-mTVPMopYEhcUuOL1fX2Fw.review_text: We visited Scoma's on Dine About.  We arrived at 5:25 for a 5:30 reservation and at 6:00 we were still waiting, thanks to air-headed hostess.  As we were preparing to leave the "elevated window table" we had been promised at last became available.  Our table was one of the worst in the house, we were stuck in the Ken Venturi Room between 2 Canadian parties. Our waiter was inattentive and did not even know the word service. He was horrible and could barely fit in the tiny closet we were stuck in. He kept brushing against me and I just wanted to go home and bathe. The food was excellent, but we will never return to Scoma's due to deplorable service issues. After posting this review I learned that 1 of our party actually became sick from the food. To be fair, the Bartenders were pleasantly efficient and the Valet was fantastic.

ET8n-r7glWYqZhuR6GcdNw.review_text: Some may call it a tourist trap, but when a restaurant stays open for 50 years, it's for a reason. And that reason may just be their clam chowder. Best ever. I was so grateful that I opted for a bowl rather than a cup because I would have been super sad with a smaller serving. The delicious broth was filled with large, tender pieces of clam. I've never had another clam chowder like it. I don't think I ever will, unless I'm back at Scoma's.  Man cannot live on chowder alone so we also ordered an appetizer that consisted of shrimp dusted in cornmeal and lightly fried. Pretty good, definitely fresh, but not up there with the chowder.   The restaurant is definitely on the hilarious side of outdated but I think they are looking to retain some of their old school charm, and that's fine by me. Since I'm not sure if anything else could live up to the chowder I might just keep this spot as a light lunch destination while in San Francisco.

n_DDU8rBeKQlbBysaEx5hQ.review_text: I'm honestly confounded by the good reviews. While the service was average, the food was bland and tasteless. The food did not taste good. I've dined at thousands of restaurants, and was candidly surprised this restaurant could stay in business with such subpar offerings.  I would strongly recommend avoiding this restaurant on the Fisherman's Wharf. I really felt fleeced for $70 for our two lunches. There are much better options in the area.

nYDYQCOiDm1CpLVCot4kng.review_text: Service was absolutely exceptional!  Thanks Sal!  I had the Cioppino which was the best I've ever had - don't order anything else - you will not have room!

NCHxHfSdx52uzrzja_skAA.review_text: Went here Sunday night for DAT. People aren't kidding about the long wait! We had to bum around for an hour or so before our seats were called, so definitely think about the waiting time if you want to dine here.  Once called, we were seated in a comfy booth and introduced to our waiter, Chris. Honestly, Chris is one of the reasons I'm a fan of this place- he has a friendly, grandfatherly air and will always keep you up-to-date on the status of your food & service. He even managed to help us substitute a DAT entree (this is HUGE) for one of my vegetarian friends.  But anyways, the food. Like most restaurants, Scoma gave us a basket of bread & breadsticks. I wasn't a huge fan of the bread, since I've never liked sourdough, but I guess that's more of an industrywide thing, so nothing you can do.  For the appetizer/"first" course, my friend Alan & I ordered the lobster bisque. As expected, it was very rich & creamy, though a tad salty, in my opinion. My friend's clam chowder, on the other hand, was delicious! Typically, I don't like clam chowder, but this was an exception! Although that might be because the clam chowder reminded me of a creamier version of chicken noodle soup. As Alan pointed out, the chowder wasn't very "clam-y", even though there WERE chunks of clam floating about the vegetables. Regardless, I loved it.  For the second course, I ordered scallops and linguini pomodora. The linguini was all right, not stellar, but the scallops more than made up for that. They were buttery and delicious, with a slight bit of crispiness. Ahh, so good! About halfway through the second entree, I felt completely stuffed and had to stop eating. Perhaps it was the clam chowder I consumed, or perhaps it was the generous portions we were given- either way, I literally had to get up and walk around the restaurant before I could go back and eat.  I also tried a bite of Alan's lamb chops, which were delicious & savory. Funny enough, the spinach was also completely infused with a smoky, lamb flavor, which really made the dish unique.  We finished up the meal with various desserts. I got the raspberry white chocolate cheesecake, which was less cheesy than the usual cheesecake I was accustomed too, but delicious nonetheless. I especially loved the bottom layer of the cheesecake, which was a chocolately crumble with a hint of mint. Mm!  My only complaint: there was a waitress (Irene), who had a completely DGAF mindset. While pouring water or grinding pepper, she spilled half of what she was doing, didn't seem to notice, and just went along her way. A bit annoying, especially when some sauces from dishes she was sweeping off the table dripped onto my Android. Sigh.  But the bottomline- this was a delicious restaurant that I would love to come back and try again! Especially the desserts. I'm still unsure whether or not the dinner was really worth $40, so the jury's still out on the success of this DAT meal.

honeR4cWNeVFgqszcvnk-g.review_text: Lobster bisque soup and Sauté were excellent but Cold dungeonness crab half was just okay. Ex-pensive but great meals with ok service.

4UkA6Sjw-RE-RuZQ1MIcTA.review_text: Went here for lunch with some friends on Friday.  After telling us it would be 20 minutes we checked in at 45 minutes to see if they had forgotten about us and were seated 5 minutes later.   I had decided on the prixe fix menu when I found out the crab was just a salad :/ which it doesnt say anywhere. So, then I decided to split the crab ravioli with another guest.   We all enjoyed the sour dough bread and opted to skip apps since we were all getting a salad or soup. My cesear was a little disappointing. Nothing special about it. The clam chouder was reported as good but not spectacular.   When our main dishes came I think everyone was a little let down except me and my friend with the ravioli.  The halibut was lacking flavor, the deep fried special tasted only of deep fried flavor and the prawns and scallops were good but, again nothing special. Since this place is not cheap you kind of expect the food to be good. :/  The atmosphere of the place was neat and if the food had been better this place could have been a home run but it wasn't so the quest for the best sea food continues.

5QeKxchNNRDmD50447Q_-A.review_text: Unbelievable fresh fresh salmon!  Delicious lobster bisque!  Beautiful views!  Amazing waiter (tony)!  Just the best! Even the bussers were so impressive and prompt!  Worth every penny!

Ih14pDtAlM308G7mcSW5Ng.review_text: Not much I can add to the other several hundred reviews, but i'll throw it a 5star review just in case it sways one more diner.  When I'm in town for Oracle Open World, this is the one restaurant I make sure I have time to visit.  A trip to SF w/o visiting Scoma's is just a wasted trip for me.  Seafood like this just isn't readily available in Raleigh, NC.

ATyxqd8ByxelWrIsCh6nRw.review_text: Delicious seafood with reasonable price.  Order a full size crab if you a crab lover.  You may need to wait at least an hour to be seated on weekends.

vaEnw-xi7h4wrdx7VSD8ig.review_text: A treat. We went for lunch. The waiter was excellent-friendly, unobtrusive, personable. I had the grilled swordfish-as good as I've had. Sweetness had the crab and shrimp Louis salad-it was very good. But the capper was the starter-the best clam chowder I could imagine. Delicious and loaded with clams. I would go back just for the chowder, but everything we had was top notch. A definite recommendation.

hRxu4DCKDIaEYURiahLFtw.review_text: My boyfriend claims that the Cioppino here is the best meal that he has had in his entire life. If you are a seafood lover this is the place for you. Agreeing with my boo, get the Cioppino! The ingredients are so fresh and tasty, and the stew also comes with a side of the most amazing garlic bread to dip in the brothy-goodness. I've had other dishes here and they have always been a huge success. However the Cioppino is truly unique and a once in a lifetime experience. Yes its pricey, but the portions are big and the quality doesn't get any better.

edr0Q9SmudNl_IAzQVFYvw.review_text: BEST LEMON DROP MARTINI ever!   Had the Alaskan Halibut for dinner and it was very fresh and delicious!  The service is absolutely great!  Great ambiance and views.

Q4Tfe4082MOoFUHRnbtaoQ.review_text: Local gals on a search for a great Dine About Town experience were surprisingly impressed with our dinner at Scoma's tonight. We loved all our selections and the old school flair with meticulous care from our adorable waiter, John. Lobster bisque rocked and there was no skimping on flavors or portions with our scallops w/linguine & lamb entrees. I think the tiramisu actually converted one who is typically not a fan ;). Overall superb dinner and the view, free valet parking, and affordable DAT menu were the reasons I'm going with the 5-star rating...get on on it while there's still time fellow San Franciscans!

8GfSTHaj1OJG3Ix77y5qcg.review_text: Great service, good food and fresh fish, lots of specials.   Desserts were all good.   Enjoy, it will be an expensive meal.

vVq6QUi2l2mgx_qHOa6VxQ.review_text: Fairly decent food for a very touristy area, and huge portions, but for some reason i didn't get that 'four star' feeling.  Wait was long for a table, but expected given we had 7 to seat.  Grabbed a drink before dinner and the bartenders were great - probably the best part of the experience.

WjPCTM9TFLlQvhVlezR9zQ.review_text: The lobster bisque is amazing!  But not as amazing as the Scoma's Shellfish Seafood Saute.  I get that EVERY time I go! YUMM!

-slK6EpqPvmjnG8eQNRTsQ.review_text: Best calamari we have ever had. They say Scoma's has it's own fishing fleet. Direct to restaurant. Until I tried it, I did not believe there was a difference.   Nothing fancy on the outside. White jacket waiters and a 1960's decor/vibe. Excellent lobster bisque as well. Many say to go to Puer 47 for dinner. I say grab same meal at lunchtime. Avoid the crowds, and taste some of the best seafood in town.

6FySm4PdV3NGSpxUCCJhBg.review_text: I do not give 5 stars lightly... this place is absolutely top shelf. Be prepared to pay for it, and it's not just a pleasant view - the food is prepared as requested, arrives hot by a very professional server, and was absolutely delicious. On vacation we tend to splurge on meals, and this was no exception. Yes, we had a $25 appetizer. (Mixed shellfish platter, plenty of big shrimp, clams, oysters) Yes, we had some wine. Yes we ordered with no regard for the right side of the page.  Find this place. It's down a very narrow road west of the Wharf that looks like it goes nowhere but a marina.  We had swordfish in a lemon/butter sauce with capers that did not overwhelm the filet. We also had prawns and scallops, expertly prepared so that the prawns were firm and the scallops were tender. That's a tough dish to pull off correctly.  While we were complaining that we could not eat one more bite but we would dearly love to try the chocolate raspberry cake our server just took it upon himself to bring us dessert with two forks "on him".  We managed to eat it.   My full, wholehearted recommendation. If you're in S.F. and you skip this place, you've missed a wonderful meal opportunity.

DrbgTmj0_x51jD_6lXVOrg.review_text: The fresh fish and seafood speaks for itself!!! This restaurant is hidden off the main street fronting Fisherman's Wharf, on a pier alongside all the fishing boats. Its been around for years and is one of the few restaurants I know of that has its own fish off loading facillity. Fresh fish and dungeness direct from the boat into the restaurant!  This place came recommended by our guide book and was the only restaurant packed with people at 4:00 pm. All the food was excellent and service attentive.  Highlights: *Sourdough bread to start - warm, soft, and chewy, just how it should be from Boudin   *Lobster Bisque - This stuff is liquid gold! flavor sweet and rich, and texture smooth and creamy. This stuff is so good you'll wipe your bowl clean with the bread!  *Crab Stuffed Portabello Mushroom - Solid dungeness crab packed on on a portabello! Includes a small pile of greens and balsamic dressing.  Simple and satisfying!  *Romaine Crab Salad - Essentially a whole head of romain, julienne beets, a pile of dungeness, blue cheese, and a light balsamic vinegarette. This guy is a meal in itself  *Crab Cakes - Three cakes of solid dungeness! No filler in these guys. Crispy on the outside, warm and moist on the inside!   *Fresh Fish - We each ordered a different fish and they were all OH SO FRESH! served with a generous serving of pasta and vegetables...Simply delicious.  I guess theres a reason why this place has been around for so long. They're food is without a doubt excellent! Expect to be set back $25-$30 a dish, but its well worth the highquality and great service. Lunch would be a more economical alternative.   Sadly we had no room for dessert.

eKUGKQRE-Ywi5dY55_zChg.review_text: 2.5 STARS WELCOME TO TOURONVILLE! Touronville is where you will find a flock of homogeneous tourons. You know...the khaki, socks with Birkenstocks, and fanny-pack wearing tourists who naively wear their $1k DSLR camera around freely like a puka shell necklace. Like a moron, they overpay for a mediocre meal that ends up hurting more than having your wrists cuffed to your ankles. Sadly, I was THAT touron last night... I've heard great things about Scoma's being this great "SF Institution" serving superb seafood. Well that may have been the case 40 years ago when their only competition was Sizzler's, Lyons, or Auntie Flo's diner (my lame assumption at least) but today it's more like an SF retribution. Craving sashimi, I ordered the closest thing to it on the menu, the Sea Whistle Smoked Salmon Plate. For $19, I got a $5.99 three ounce pack of grocery store quality smoked salmon that had been laid out on a plate to air dry like a Downy detergent commercial with red onions, capers, solidified cream friache, and sliced toasted baguettes. yelp.com/biz_photos/jqEp… Don't worry Costco, Scoma's got nothing on you. For my entree, I chose the highly acclaimed $37 Lazy Man's Ciopinno. yelp.com/biz_photos/jqEp… After having a the most phenomenal bowl of ciopinno from Anchor Oyster Bar on Monday (yelp.com/biz_photos/ZDvI…), I was sorely disappointed when a pho sized bowl of Campbell's tomato soup was laid before me. It was like going from an artisan cup of coffee from Philz to Sh*tbucks coffee. The cioppino was more like a fish stew and a poor one at that. The fish was noticeably "fishy" and there were just 2 clams, 4 scallops, 4 tiger prawns, crab lint and a plethora of bay shrimp suffering from Napoleon complex. With the exception of the scallops, everything was overcooked. The tomato broth was too thick and tasted like diluted Hunt's tomato paste yearning for fresh herbs (garnishing with herbs does not count) and garlic to rejuvenate it from its lonely canned shelf life. Service was equally as unremarkable as the food. Our brusque waiter was MIA the entire night catering to the whims and wants of the obvious tourons trying to get the non-existent San Francisco treat at Scoma's. Sitting in the outdated restaurant surrounded by 70s-80s sports memorabilia and a adorable congregation of those casting to be on Grumpy Old Men Part Deux made me feel like young cub as opposed to the usual cougar that sticks out like a sore thumb in a nightclub. The best part of the meal was the FREE valet parking...now that IS a San Francisco treat! *Woot Woot*

BnBBAR7oao55vAehS2JsXg.review_text: Always make it to Scoma's when I visit San Fran.  The shellfish sauté is a seafood lovers dream!

2h3Sk0xznCYb0qEVUJGs9A.review_text: This place is way over rated, food is Meh, service is Meh, ambience is nice, great view but really, why pay these kinds of prices for ambience.  You can get much better food elsewhere in San Francisco.

kkRwqLxjokMCMrUWxLllRA.review_text: Scoma's is the place to be on the wharf. Drinks, appetizers were good. We ordered the mixed shellfish saute, lobster ravioli and the prawn and scallops alla gannon for dinner, which were all delicious. Normally you kind of expect to get skimped on the seafood, but Scoma's does you right. Sides were even pretty good! They don't necessarily pop out, but accented the seafood pretty well with solid tastes and plenty of color.  Atmosphere is pretty rad too, right on the wharf. Parking was a breeze (valet). Thank god I don't live nearby, because I'd probably have to take out a second job in order to support my addiction...

fwJWf9dvUbZ0aRKcqkCB7A.review_text: Had lunch here after picking up some crab right down the street at alioto lazio fish company. I ordered the swordfish and it was excellant! Mom had the pacific rockfish, hers was delicious to. Both were cooked to perfection. However it was served with roasted root vegetables, and a wild rice, barley, bean, quiona medley which were not so good so if this is offered to you, id pass and ask for something else. Took dad home some lazy mans chippino and it was ok, far from the best weve had. Overall this is a great restaurant you just gotta know what to order. I highly recommend the swordfish piccata!

2GRdLwKs-6oyPzPsB3xC-A.review_text: The clam showder and the dungeons crab are excellent! Get the fudge brownie to close the deal.... Old school restaurant with a nice ambient and ok views it's a little hidden from all the fuzz in the pier but that's what makes it special!

TYVbm4d6b1xJjbZwndfHcw.review_text: My parents and I lived in San Francisco when I was young and have since made our way to Texas. Our relatives still all live in Northern California, so we try to visit at least once a year.   We have been going to Scoma's as long as I can remember, and it never fails to disappoint. Maybe I am emotionally attached, but then again it tastes better than I remember every single time we go.   A trip to Nor Cal is never complete without visiting Scoma's, and I recommend it to anyone that is in the area. Sure the prices are a bit high, but to me, it's worth it.  We have never had anything short of great service and always at least get the clam chowder and calamari, both my favorite I've ever tasted. We always leave completely stuffed, because none of us ever want to stop eating the deliciousness. I also often crave their melt-in-you-mouth sourdough bread and butter.  It is a bit crowded, but it doesn't bother me. The place has character.

R5i-8R4vBov0wfNBGg2MwA.review_text: Went here for dinner with some coworkers visiting from Canada after showing them around Fisherman's Wharf.  They wanted to eat some crab, and this place looked like a good option after reading the reviews and having pretty good yelp ratings.  I gotta say thanks yelpers for not making me look like an idiot in front of my boss, we wound up enjoying our meal greatly.  They had a good prix-fixe menu for $40 that included appetizer, entree, and dessert, which I thought was pretty affordable for a seafood restaurant.  A couple people got the lobster bisque, while the rest of us got the crabcakes.  I gotta say they definitely had one of the better crabcakes I've had (sorry hubby, just *slightly* better than yours).  For the main course, I got the seared scallops.  They were pretty good and well seasoned, though I gotta say it seemed a little rubbery to me and I've had better scallops elsewhere.  Loved the swiss chard though, definitely one of my new favorite veggies.  The portion size would probably be considered small by some (3 scallops) but I didn't mind since we had appetizer and dessert, and I wanted to eat something light.  A couple of people got the "Lazy Man's Cioppino", which they loved.  It was $3 more than the regular Cioppino but it saved them the trouble of opening up the crab in a bowl of hot soup.    Only 3 out of the 5 of us ordered the prix-fixe, but 3 desserts were more than enough for everybody.  We had a couple of the brownies and the pumpkin cheesecake.  Nothing to write home about, but they satisfied our sweet craving at the end of the meal.  We had a fantastic deal on our wine.  We had a bottle of the Stag's Leap Wine Cellars "Arcadia" Chardonnay, and it was a total steal at $42 for the bottle.  Either it was a pricing error or they must have gotten a nice deal from the winery.  I'm not normally a white wine person, but it was a great match for all the seafood that we ordered.  I like the ambiance, it was nice being right on the water, though it's probably even better during the day.  This place has an old school look to it, which is cool for the location.  The service was really good as well.  Their prix-fixe "Triple Play" menu is definitely a great deal (much better than most DAT menus I've had at $35).  Would definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for a nice seafood restaurant in Fisherman's Wharf

d8ZsV4qRQaTwIz6eovdGYw.review_text: It is somehow fitting that although I've used Yelp for a while, my visit to this restaurant finally motivated me to write my first substantive review.  Some context: I've been to San Francisco many times for business and had always looked forward to finally being able to visit with my family. This was that opportunity. As we traveled from our hometown of Vegas for a week-long vacation in the Bay Area, I expressed my enthusiasm to the kids about the great food we'd be enjoying in one of my favorite foodie cities.   After checking into our hotel (Argonaut) at the end of Fisherman's Wharf, we hit the pavement in search of dinner. A quick look at Yelp led us down a sketchy alley near our hotel to the favorably-reviewed Scoma's.   I thought it a good omen when I was informed by the hostess that they didn't take reservations, since I assumed that meant our wait time would be reasonable. After being given a wait time estimate of 25-30 minutes (it was a Monday night), our family waited outside by the wharf, listening to the seals and watching meandering boats.   After about 40 minutes I went in to check on the status of our wait time, and from the look on the hostess' face I knew that somehow she'd forgotten/skipped us. She looked like a deer in the headlights and told me there were just a few more parties ahead of us. (My wife later told me that she'd seen people who arrived after us get seated before us. I don't typically notice these types of things, but if I'd known that at the time I would have made an issue of it.)  Finally, after an hour long wait (there's nothing like blown expectations), our hungry family of four were seated, ordered our food, and...were underwhelmed.   We eat out. A lot. I'm proud of the fact that my young kids have sophisticated palettes and that they're discerning but not pretentious. They've also been instilled with an expectation that there's something to enjoy in every meal, regardless of its cost, location, or name on the menu.   Which is why it was disheartening to see my under-10 daughter, who loves salmon, only eat about a quarter of her salmon and lobster ravioli because the sauce "overpowered" the natural tastiness of the fish (although she loved the lobster ravioli). I also watched as my just-became-a-teen son was first given a salmon with vodka-infused pasta before our waiter returned five minutes later with the correct order (salmon, assorted veggies, and mashed potatoes). Fortunately, his dish had not been touched. Unfortunately, that was because he, my wife, and I were still waiting for my daughter to receive her food.   My wife selected the pre-fixe menu and had chosen an ahi tuna dish for her entree. While she thought the tuna was okay (medium rare) she didn't like the contrasting taste of the tomatoes with which it was served. She also had the Golden Gate cocktail (I think that's what it was called) and said it was just "alright".   And of course, being at a seafood restaurant on Fisherman's Wharf, I ordered the 12 oz. filet mignon. It wasn't as bad as a steak ordered at IHOP (a mistake that my son can attest to), but having enjoyed a great steak the night before, in Mammoth Lakes, the one from Scoma's was not worth the $48.   Lest you think me a perpetual downer, there were some bright spots (actually, they weren't that big, so maybe bright pin pricks might be more apropos): the clam chowder was nice, my wife enjoyed her crab cake appetizer, and one of the desserts we tried (the raspberry cheesecake) had a nice texture/taste to it.   So, in summary, this is what I learned:  - I make terrible decisions when I'm hungry (we should have left when I realized the hostess had somehow missed us on the wait list).   - I know what a disappointing $280 meal tastes like (including tip, family of two adults, two kids).   - Never chase a great rib-eye from a resort ski town with a filet mignon from a seafood joint on Fisherman's Wharf.   - Writing is cathartic, and Scoma's required a lot of catharsis.    In summary, you may have learned:  - Sketchy alleys do not always lead to happy endings.

6isLnxwJO1Ypzw7njpEp5A.review_text: Is there such a thing as too much dungeness crab in December?  I never thought so until we ordered the large louie this week.  As fresh as it gets and bountiful.  The interior looks like one of the tired boats in the adjoining harbor but all that passes once you sit down with a view of the bay, top service and a hearty menu.  It is off the path of tourists - not that that should make any difference - and is as San Francisco as it gets.

TSXhE-W7FF2wQA4SBg0EXA.review_text: My wife had the oysters and I had the clam chowder as appetizers, both were excellent. We then followed with fresh halibut and sole. Again excellent. Very good wine list. Great atmosphere and service though we felt a little rushed. Recommend making reservations as they were very busy.

H-3ALVBtykMjXm2PUb-l-g.review_text: We stumbled across this restaurant today. I was taken back by the prices, but when we discovered the lunch special, all was good. I had the ahi sandwich with extra salad and no fries. The salad was delicious!  The ahi was a very generous portion and seared perfectly.  We will come back as we were pleasantly surprised!

0LGrHM4a1-kWmMEspDUxDw.review_text: My husbands Aunt took us to this delectable hidden gem at Fishermans wharf. I am not a fan of seafood so we usually always go to Boudin at the wharf when we visit--but even Boudin isn't anything special since we have Boudin in So Cal at South Coast and Disney and they sell the bread at Costco now.    Anyways, I was open to adventure this day and I'm glad that Scoma's didnt do me wrong! :) when we first go there they have a free valet service--which is awesome and unheard of near Fishermans wharf.  Unfortunately it was full so we had to park across the street in a structure which actually wasn't too bad for price--even with the Giants fanfest going on.    Upon arrival the place reminded me of a toss between the DelRae and Steak and Stein in Pico, but the cool thing was the dress code ranged from casual to dressy! :)   There was a short wait but we got to wait in the nice bar area.  We where promptly seated with a delicious sour dough bread basket. It was a party of 5--we shared a delicious calamari platter and the shrimp cocktail was dreamy--and this is coming from a Seafood hater!!!!  The shrimp was fresh and firm and didn't smell fishy at all! Yum!  My main entree was an open faced steak sandwich--it was heaven (check out the picture that was posted by me). The side salad with house 1000 Island dressing was amazing as well--similar to Lawrys but way better tasting.  Other people in my party had fish and clam chowder--they all swear its the best Clam Chowder ever--I'll take their word on it since I'm still not a fan of clam :P  Anyways--it was great food with amazing service by our longtime server! I had a great time, and I know that this will become a tradition for my husband and I when visiting Fishermans wharf! :)  I can't wait until we return!

txrANKGe5_pxA9vw4XqyTA.review_text: This place is awesome! I was a little weary to go here since it's in Fisherman's Wharf and I thought it would be too touristy for my liking, but the food made me think otherwise.  The service is awesome too!   THINGS TO GET. Cioppino Halibut Pasta Garibaldi Clam Chowder  *Free valet parking is a definite plus!   There is a pre-fix lunch ($25) and dinner menu (around $40) which includes 3 courses.  It's very reasonable given the quality and taste!

KpGiwKcn53zq1pB-I9CBYA.review_text: Perhaps I went to Scoma's on the chefs' night off.  Plus points, service was fine and efficient, wine list fine, even if the price markup was frightening.  The problem was the food, simply not good enough at these prices, nor some of it good enough at any price on this particular night (rainy, cold January).  The flavor of Dungeness crab cake was of an overwhelming cloying greasiness. Battered oysters were overpowered by the batter and overcooked to a oyster mush. Cioppino arrived scaldingly hot, although the flavor was fine once it cooled, but it was padded out with too much cheaper fish cuts.  Which at $37 is a bit rich.    The flavor of the lobster ravioli was excellent, perhaps the best I've tasted, however, spoilt by the dish arriving with a skin starting to form on the sauce.  Would I go back?  Possibly, there were enough signs that things could easily have been much better.

DpPekIsTAxQzaBd2J9uIig.review_text: I like this place! It doesnt take reservations but it was worth the wait.  The portions were really good.  had the clam chowder soup which was really tasty and on the side they have the salad that tasted really good.  My seared scallop was really really good with the pasta on the bottom. the Pasta didn't really have a taste to it, so I didn't really like that.  I had the cocktail for $14 with the glass to take home, it was a nice little gift and it tasted like lots of orange juice with some vodka. It was alright...  My bf had the lamp chop which he said was really really good too.  My friend had the fish. (cod) she said it was realy fresh as well.   the desserts were ok. creme brulee was really really really good.   overall I really like the seafood there, the size was good and it tasted really fresh.

S9t4DqwbGCDr3fou0zONBQ.review_text: It was nice to go to SF and have a seafood meal at a restaurant rather than on the sidewalk.  My husband too me here on our long weekend in SF.  We had a good time and the food was decent.  Definitely not cheap, but I will say it was worth the experience.  Service was excellent I have to admit and the place ws packed and there's not much room to walk inbetween tables.

q7BxYlrC11GEgWeJGGwgrQ.review_text: I go here for a lot of family dinners. My uncle knows some of the staff and likes to get drinks from the bar while we wait for a table. It's also a good pick because everyone else in the family (besides me) likes seafood.  Being inside is like being inside of a wharf-inspired tourist trap. However, the seafood is pretty fresh and the menu offers everything that should be expected at a seafood restaurant. The crab louie salad is good, especially if the waiter likes you enough to have the chef pile on some extra dungeness.

tzTQtyyfSPiERKvR0qW-sQ.review_text: Great food and the best staff in white jackets giving excellent service. What a treat - every time! I love this place

gOBkinOIsBUSNP8byXKsrw.review_text: It is really to bad that this place has settled as a basic tourist spot.  Now as tourist spots go this is one of the best, but that is not saying a lot.   I have gone to Scoma's for years and it has finally reached the point where we will not be back.  The food has ZERO flavor.   Crab Stuffed Mushroom's - very bland and dry Salmon and Shrimp Sandwhich -  very bland and dry Wait Staff - stuffy and forgetful  So if you are a tourist this spot should be OK, if you are a regular to SF stay away.  There are so many great seafood spots to check out pass on this one

vgHK87dg7LAy8a9nTRWFIw.review_text: I was sadly disappointed in our meal and the room we were placed in for our dinner.  We flew in from Cincinnati, Ohio and made this place a priority!  We were a table of 6 and we were seated in a very small half round booth that we squeezed into and was left facing a large party of 10 in front of us and we were the only tables in this little space.  It was warm in this room and there was not a very good view out of the windows.    What was most upsetting is we had called last July to book a table in the larger room with a view and were told that they would do their best and make note of our request.  To spend over $600.00 on a meal with drinks, appetizers and a meal and leave sadly disappointed was just not what I wanted to do on vacation.   I would not recommend this spot to my friends.  The food was average.  We have better seafood restaurants here in Cincinnati and the service was okay.  Our waiter seemed to want us to keep buying drinks and upping our bill.  He had been at the restaurant for years and did not treat us as special as he could have considering the fact we had never been there before and we wanted to hear all about it.  He rushed us into making decisions and did not give us the warmth and friendliness we expect and receive here in the Midwest.  I wish I had requested to move the minute we sat down as we were all very squished into this booth and it was very uncomfortable.  Not to mention watching another table celebrate a birthday and feeling like we were invading their space.  This place was not what I was expecting at all and do not feel it deserves such a rating as you have given it on Yelp!

2xs2qVVWv-b_hVMPZQXMDQ.review_text: A truly classic seafood restaurant on the San Francisco waterfront. I've enjoyed dinner here on numerous occasions and have never been disappointed. The cioppino has so much shellfish and seafood that it is difficult to finish unless you have a huge appetite. The lobster is the best I have ever tasted, and it is available served at least three different ways each night. Crab perfect, chowders loaded with clams, etc. Warm fresh bread and a variety of salads compliment probably the best dinners available in the Fisherman's Wharf area.   Located a bit off the main drag of wharf shops on Al Scoma Way, this restaurant brings back the memories of what the waterfront use to be like. Great service, nice bar, quality food, in a very clean environment. Wait staff has been nothing short of perfect on every visit. Plenty of small tables in the bar to relax if you do have to wait for dinner seating.  I have also had lunch/dinner at most wharf restaurants and while many of the menus have been adjusted to the tourist crowd and are somewhat disappointing, Scoma's maintains the quality and atmosphere that you should expect of a higher end restaurant along the waterfront. They don't cut corners. Valet parking is available at the front of the restaurant, and by donation.   I usually call in about 30 minutes before arrival to check on wait times and never have had to wait more than 10 minutes on weekends, no wait ever on weekdays. The atmosphere is nice enough for any occasion and the bar serves up a long list of quality wines, as well as your favorite cocktails.

BvPXKwNeVIh9gGATWICm1w.review_text: Came here for my 6 year anniversary with my fiancé. We had reservations for 8 but showed up at around 7:20. We were seated at 7:30. We were given waters and bread with our menus. Now. I know this is a seafood restaurant. But for some reasoned both had a hankering for steak! I had the filet mignon and he had the Cowboy Steak. What I loved about this was that I asked for medium rare, and that's exactly what I got. It's very rare for me to order a medium rare steak and to actually get it. We also ordered soup; clam chowder for me (delicious) and lobster bisque for him (also not bad at all). All in all, I had a really good experience here and would definitely come back soon.

3EIjwSXQHBEI4s0wwiTZnA.review_text: Okay... I had great expectation for this restaurant since the reviews on Yelp aren't that bad.  This restaurant was one of the participant in DIne about Town; it's really a great chance for me to try out this restaurant.  The food, honestly, was okay, not superb.  For the price that I'm paying, I'm expecting a much better quality food.  I ordered the Tuna, and it basically a tuna ahi with no sauce.  So, it's pretty dry.  The service is not that good too.  When the server came refill our water, he poured all overt the table.  I didn't feel that I'm in a classy restaurant, but a cheap chinese restaurant.  One good thing about this restaurant is the valet parking; you don't really need to find parking space elsewhere.  That's a plus for me!

Og5lv2yeSg-JRxbxc5_8PQ.review_text: There are so many amazing things about this place.    1) Free valet parking!! Self explanatory  2) Awesome service.  We waited for less than 5 minutes to get seated.  There is a waiting area with seats and guests waiting can order drinks etc.  Our serve was incredibly nice.  Not only was he patient with explaining and recommending different items on the menu, he also started small chats with me and the boyfriend very sincerely.  3) Reasonably priced.  I ordered the sauteed scallop with pasta etc.  The portion was even bigger than what our waiter had warned us about.  Bf ordered the pre fixe menu so we got to try their clam chowder.  I really liked it so I ordered an additional one.  And we got it for free!!  Love free stuff.  Everything we ordered were very fresh and yummy.    4) Atmosphere/location.  It's located in a cul de sac on Pier 47 and has a very nice view of the bay.  The inside is incredibly huge.  That is also why they can afford to have a small lounge for waiting.  As we sat there, we could hear laughter coming from all over the restaurant and between waiters and customers.  It was just a very casual and friendly atmosphere.   Love this place and will definitely go back again!

U8c5CKdsk40mj-mTnJysGw.review_text: Though I'm hesitant to eat at fisherman's wharf because almost everything about that side of town annoys me besides the free samples of ghirardelli chocolates at the ghirardelli factory....scoma is still one of my favorite places to relax and get seafood. Yes there is Swan Oyster down the street from my house  and Sotto Maro not far away either...but Scoma has beautiful water views, amazing service and really huge seafood louis salads. Yes they are $$, but they are too big to finish and incredibly fresh.. So for ambiance, freshness, service and seafood I battle the tourists and make my way down to the wharf.

4qN6pRVY0HkwNoW82vKMoA.review_text: Old school décor, and old school feel.  You expected the rat pack to walk in.  Great food, and the wait staff was awesome and full of personality.  We had reservations so no waiting.

NTGjlZ4E5KD234lUQ9Yskw.review_text: Best Cioppino I've ever had. My wife said the same about the Calamari entree. Heros was our server and he was as good as the food. If you like the freshest seafood prepared perfectly, then check out Scoma's on your next visit to the wharf.

1G7UG_phJmvqKk2z4zzz9g.review_text: Went here for the first time this past weekend. Although it is a tourist trap due to it's location there's something about it being around since 1965 that makes it worth it.  Some pluses: - Great, attentive, and friendly staff - Free valet parking! - Nice view in the sense that you're pretty much on the water while enjoying your dinner  Some negatives: - A bit pricey for what it is... but hey, it is the pier right? - The food was decent but not mind blowing. Worth to go for the nostalgia of the place only  Overall, a decent place.

96us9i9zB7QIxBtyRlhvDQ.review_text: We were walking the Wharf, fighting the cold, declining the bums, high-fiving the street entertainers, when boytoy proclaims: I want Seafood!!!!  It was a Saturday nite, Dine About Town weekend.  He bee-bu-bop- bee-boo-bop-bops on his phone and next thing you know he tells me that Scoma's is offering a DAT menu- $34.95 for a 3 course dinner.  Guess Rainforest Cafe was outta the picture.  Anyway, we get to Scoma's and they tell us it would be about 45min-hour wait, nothing we didn't foresee.  They tell us there is complimentary valet, if thats helpful.  Dunce caps on, we decided to trek back in the cold to put more money in the meter.  Halfway back to Scoma's I say to boytoy:  "What was it they said about valet?"  "What? I can't hear you." (Dunce cap too long, covered his ears) "Nevermind." (As I readjusted my dunce cap)  Appetizers: Lobster Bisque w/Lobster salad: Meh, bland city.  Dungeness Crab Cakes:  Yummo.  Can't complain. Main Course: Char Broiled Ahi: Slammin. Lamb T-Bones with Parmesan Polenta: Lamb had to be sent back to be "cooked" - Apparently, they forgot that part. Dessert: Ok....here's where it gets tricky.  While we were looking over the dessert choices, the man dining in the table next to us overhears our sweet dilemma: "We had bread pudding earlier at Luna Park..do we want to have bread pudding again here?" Man to be named Mitch later says: If you don't get the bread pudding here you're crazy." (totally not verbatim but it went something like that)  He goes on to say its the best bread pudding he's ever had, he's a regular customer, joke here, joke there, insert laughter here and there...and by the time you know it Mitch and Boytoy are having a bromance and I'm doing cartwheels in front of them trying to get their attention.  Anyway, eventually Mitch calls it a nite, says goodbye to us both and tells us to enjoy the rest of our nite and weekend, etc.     We were ready with our dessert choices when our waitress came up to us,  and surprisingly says, "Mitch, the man who was dining next to you has graciously paid for your dessert- the bread pudding."  GET.OUTTA.TOWN!  We were blushing.  Well, I was.  She then goes on to say that we STILL have 2 more desserts to pick on top of that, since Mitch's was extra.  Oh, shit.  Boytoy decides to "pass it forward" and  compliment his newfound bromance by offering one of our other desserts to a couple at a table nearby.  In the end, we took home a walnut brownie minus the ice cream.  Oh- and the bread pudding?  No joke.  Mitch was right.  Best bread pudding I have ever had.  Overall experience, 3.5 and rounding up.  Mitch, if you're reading this- thank you.  You made our nite :)

DETmN2xUa-6FYSFll8RLCg.review_text: Dined: 2008-06-07  Went for Dine About Town.  A little hard to find, but nice location.  A friend and I shared the crab recipe winner appetizer - basically a crab salad shaped like Coit Tower. It was okay.  I stuck with the DAT menu, while my friend tried something on the regular menu based off the waiter's suggestion.  I had the swordfish with crab ravioli. The crab ravioli was okay - I didn't taste the crab. The fish was good (I think my first time having swordfish) and the sauce was awesome.  My friend had the popular shellfish saute. Seafood galore! Plenty of lobster, shrimp, and fish.  Plenty of items to choose from the menu. I want to go back and bring more friends!

Ew8kipek0LDqEQNqFm6aaQ.review_text: been going here for years..started off with my parents but I always thought it was just a tourist trap....UNTIL i went to the scomas in sausalito, just as good, with nice views, but the food in the city seems better. ha.    i ALWAYS order the shrimp and crab louie salad...dressing on the side (left or right as my servers tells me) and if I feel it, the seafood saute (lobster, crab, scallops, and prawns in a wine cream butter sauce served with rice pilaf and assorted steamed veggies.  service is always on point..best time to go is lunch.  especially on a warm day, order up a salad an iced tea and your set.    a little pricey.  i just went today for lunch.  50.00 (my shrimp and crab louie, so big that i had to take the other half togo, and an iced tea ! oh and there was half an avocado on it too...for an additional 5.00 of course)  will always come back, whether its for lunch or dinner.

HxBRdM7jcVGl4kgRBn0p5Q.review_text: This place was boogee, but not boogee enough.   Calm chowder is delicious however, they don't serve it in a bread bowl like all the other ones at fisherman warf.   Classy bar, so any ghetto drinks like LA water, jaggerbombs, etc..they look at you funny and tell you to get the f*ck out. JOKE!

LCfD_0iAlT3-kl-DGUBzbQ.review_text: I loved the yummy lobster dish. So delish, the one star is missing because our waitress was too busy and the helper was coughing and I didn't think it was a good idea for her to serve the drinks because she was sick.  Otherwise, the ambience was nice and casual, but most importantly the food was excellent!

IJeecoGCQPCcuifxeqac9A.review_text: Been to Scoma's before and it was the same both times, good food and good service. Weekends are crowded and you may be seated really close to others, but I found it nice to chat a little with others near you. Must try items are crab cakes and the garlic roasted crab in season. Did I say I like crab? Okay, the Caesar salad was great too! We had the crab out of season this time and it was good, but it's even better fresh. The sampler appetizer for two is excellent with a small crab cake, calamari and shrimp scampi which was like shrimp in cioppino broth. Nice mix. The food is better than the tourist traps just a short walk east on the Wharf. Restaurant has valet and it's around back on Al Scoma Way, kind of behind Castagnola's restaurant off Jefferson St.

GWaCI4tiGmt0_3Tp5dM-MQ.review_text: Stopped here before our duck tour for a quick lunch. There was a short wait, about 15 mins. The hostess was a bit rude and not very friendly.   I ordered the lazy man's Cioppino. There was a lot of seafood, but the overall taste was mediocre. I was expecting it to be more spicy with more flavor, but was disappointed. The soup is big enough to share for 2 people. It can also be an entire meal for 1 person. I would have to say the fish was excellent.   The service was a bit slow and the place is pretty crowded. I wasn't too impressed with this place and wouldn't mind skipping it to try another place in the future.

n8y91HCg6UDTwK2hvPZVIg.review_text: Simply awesome!  The service, food and the drinks were incredible!  Fish is fresh and very well prepared. Side dishes are also delicious!  The cons:  -The place is small and it gets crowded, so often times there is wait time to get a table.  -Parking is limited if any, although they have valet.

0XXIv9a0LWiaCjAkurjMMQ.review_text: Were we lucky, or inspired?    After a winter storm that sent tourists back to their hotel lobbies and natives back to their living rooms, we took a break in the rain as our opportunity to cruise Fisherman's Wharf.  First we paid a call on The Lot of Ridiculous Parking Specials.  Inspired by this, My Lady of Infinite Parking Karma found not one, but three FREE parking spaces on the curb in the Fisherman's Wharf area.  We just took one, and then walked directly onto the Wharf.    Luck held up, and we were seated instantly.  Out over the water, we paid slight attention to our menus as we sipped Hess chardonnay and pinot grigio, looking out the windows at the fishing boats moving in their docks to the rhythm of the harbor waves.  Seagulls witnessed as we blissed out on lazy man's cioppino and the fisherman's pasta, delicious concoctions of sea scallops, shrimp, calamari, whitefish, marinara sauce, and fettucine cooked al dente.  We wrapped up our delicious meal with two personal pots of tea, a hot apple crisp, and a cream caramel.  Perfect food, perfect service, perfect timing, for $112.30 + tip.    It was a Sunday, between the lunch and dinner hours.  This place is huge.  It looks like they keep adding on to the building.

E-YkBJjXXhuno76au583Hg.review_text: We ate here last week during Dine About Town Week.  This is the second time we have eaten here.  I couldn't remember the name of the place but when I asked a couple of different locals what the name of the place would be they were able to tell me from my very vague description.......its a place on the water in the corner.  Somewhere back in Fisherman's Wharf....serves great seafood.  This tells you how well known the place is.  My friend had the pork, my sister had the linguine and scallops, and I had the lamb.  All the dishes were amazing.  The atmosphere is cozy but can be a little loud because it gets so busy.  But we had the same waiter both times and he was amazing.  Unfortunately I am bad at names and I can't remember his.  It is a must eat at if you are in the Fisherman's Wharf area!

z-oO1tVXUwLt8G1NDZwWDQ.review_text: I had actually heard pretty poor things about Scoma's from family who had visited before, but I was actually very impressed!  Went there with my grandmother, and we got a seat by the window (which is essential). Dining while watching the sun set over the water and sailboats is one of my favorite things to do. So peaceful and beautiful!  The food was delicious! We ordered the Baked Mozzarella for an appetizer -- I kind of thought these would be like mozzarella sticks, but it was literally just a hunk of deliciously mozzarella cheese melted beneath roasted tomatoes and pesto. Delicious.  For an entree, I ordered the Ahi Tuna topped with a butter-soy sauce-- it was a little overcooked (but I like mine RARE). It was delicious. The steamed veggies and garlic mashed potatoes were perfect sides.   Yum! Will definitely be back -- great place to take the family :)

Vkj42md-5O3VoOD9pBg6Sw.review_text: The Fixe Price Lunch Combo for $24.95 is great!  I chose the 3 items as follows:  1) New England Clam Chowder (Cup) - other option was a Cesar Salad  2) Bay Shrimp and Dungeness Crab Louis Salad   3) Desert of the Day (Chocolate Cake)  The cup of clam chowder is good, it's a cup 'tho, not a bowl, so it's so delicious it has you feeling like you could eat more.  The Shrimp and Crab Louis Salad has the Louis (Thousand Island) dressing over a generous portion of Bay Shrimp and Dungeness Crab Meat (no shells to peel or pick at here!) on top of a bed of lettuce with beets, and other garnishment.  This is the lunch sized portion, not to be confused with the full dinner entree portion which costs over $30.  But, make no mistakes here, I'd assumed it would be a small portion, it's actually a very fair and fulfilling portion, that is perfect, it's big enough as an entree to get you filled.  The desert was great, it was a slice of chocolate cake.  Of course, all meals come served with sourdough bread and butter too, so you can always fill up on those carbs.  The service at Scoma's is always friendly and welcoming.  Parking isn't too hard if you're either willing to pay or willing to walk, it is Fisherman's Wharf you know, so the heart of the tourist area as well as it having lots of restrictions to the street parking and a high demand for spaces.

3MeZ2Zl7t0zrhRaVJx75-g.review_text: Its really hard to say something that hasn't already been said before.  Some of the highlights that I noticed; 1.) The parking is great, the valet takes care of everything, and there is no charge in the parking meter infested city.  2.) The lines are usually long, this is a very busy and successful restaurant make sure to make the reservation, don't drop in.  3.) Recommendation that should be your last meal on earth; Pasta Pomodoro with PRAWNS, its about 31.00 but I comment on the following;  a.) the prawns are huge, fresh, and plenty b.) the noodles and mix of cheese and pesto is amazing c.) The sauce is to die for, what you find yourself doing is searching for bread on the table to clean up every last drop of the amazing, attractive, red tomato Poodoro sauce.  You will look like a drug phene completely high on Tomato Sauce.  Go try Scomas, Live Big for the weekend.  Your date will probably want ot get married

tX30yNjriupAW4KvUeP4Cw.review_text: I had NYE dinner at Scoma's and to my surprise the wait was only 5 minutes for a group of five. Scoma's is right on the pier, you have to walk to the back and make sure you watch your footing if you are wearing heels because their asphalt is pretty uneven.   The restaurant has an old feel, old pictures on the walls of celebrities who have visited Scoma's, the lighting is perfect, the service is friendly and even our food came out very quickly.   I ordered the broiled Swordfish, garlic mash potatoes and veggies. The sour dough bread is not too chewy and everything was very flavorful. The food is pricey but what you are paying for is well worth it. Definitely check it out if it is in your budget.

Xoj_CYbHK15f2sUmWDK1FA.review_text: This is my first time in San Francisco and I was told Scoma's was a must go to place to eat...and it definitely is! The garlic roasted Dungeness crab was amazing, very meaty and had superb flavor. The oysters Rockefeller was excellent; the dish consisted of 6 servings and per serving, there was 3 oysters.

aGdItwK2TAH85sTkgSfolg.review_text: We live in the Bay area and this was our first time at Scomas. The food was excellent and very fresh. I had the Dungeness crab cocktail and it was a very generous serving. My husband and I both got seafodd pasta dishes which were excellent. Dishes contained generous portions of dungeness crab, scallops, clams, etc and the servings were big. The only down side is the ambiance. This is an old place, a little cramped and decor very dated. So go for the excellent seafood and not the ambiance. Prices are steep but good seafood on the Wharf is not cheap.

Iovy9ItislQQuQQVYHR1ng.review_text: Went her for an extended lunch on Friday with my fiance and soon to be father-in-law.   The chowder was great! I true test for me of any seafood restaurant is the clam chowder. You could tell this one did not come from a can. It had big chunks of veggies and clams. Delish!!  I got the ahi tuna sandwich, very rare. It tasted like sushi grade tuna. I would recommend it.   It's a little hidden gem off of fisherman's worth and a great place to go to for lunch.

c5jhbG9xsd8Ci_EFX-MyGg.review_text: Best seafood restaurant I've ever been to. The shellfish sauté blew my fricken mind! Buttery delicious lobster, scallops, and other shellfish over rice pilaf. It was unbelievably awesome. The staff obviously love working there. It's clear that the culture there is all about treating you like family. It's believable because they mean it. I don't think I can ever come to San Francisco again without a visit to Scoma's!

eQRZhI7KNxKvIxY7i38vPg.review_text: A west coast staple for me. I'm in San Francisco on average of six times a year and no trip is complete without a visit to Scoma's. Old school seafood restaurant with a mature crowd. A must

pjIkQ4ozCVJV7fi1VT_Dug.review_text: Showed up looking for a snack because the wife and I were trying one item from every restaurant on the wharf.  We told the waiter that we just wanted to share something and asked for a recommendation, but it apparently frustrated him that we wouldn't be spending $100 and he walked away and never came back over ~10 minutes.  Apparently our money is no good to the servants of Scoma's.  It was an old man with gray hair and a big belly - do not use this server if you go!

JcKk7zEd46yj0hnuSQUwXQ.review_text: I have been coming here my entire life! No joke....do the math. This has been a family favorite for years as well as a family tradition. I haven't needed a menu in many years. The food here speaks for its self, staff here is a very regular thing that you can always count on.....however, today my server was CC. The single best server I have ever had here in many years! Great personality and introduced the menu like a true professional. When a very small issue arose she did everything that was needed to do the first time and was very gracious and polite!

slOmADfy2j8EAzwJcyYTZQ.review_text: Best.  Seafood.  Ever!  Located in Fisherman's Wharf, but a little bit off the beaten path.  They have a few parking spaces but also have valet.    The bar/waiting area is ample.  I give the chocolate martini 2 thumbs up!  When our name was called for the table, the host graciously took my drink for me and carried it to the table.  Very nice touch.  The restaurant is divided into smaller rooms, each room has about 3-4 tables.  Perfect to keep the noise volume at a minimum when dining, and to also ensure that the servers aren't taking care of too many tables at once.   Genius, in my opinion.  Calamari, scrumptious.  My Dungeoness Crab Salad was absolute heaven.  A mile-high solid mound of fresh crab-- It was $30 but you really do get your money's worth.  (Except for the extra $4 they charged me for avocado on my salad).  They serve very generous portions, so don't be startled by the relatively high menu prices.  My fiancee had a scallop dish, which were cooked perfectly!    Our server, Elizabeth, was wonderful.  All of the workers seemed genuinely happy and were extremely helpful.  To me, the service was impeccable.      We will definitely be back.

qzDsm_hKogII5g3qM9XilA.review_text: Coming from a vegetarian do not eat here. I ordered the one pasta dish on the menu and it was not good.

wgAK6WsDNqLobWJCuTMafQ.review_text: For those of you looking for a very American take on classics look no further. Portions generous, appetizers (oysters Rockefeller al scoma, spinach salad) were great. Main course of mixed seafood grill and shrimp sauté less so due to the size (way too much) and what arrived on plate not really matching the menu/mind picture. Service was also below par given other reviews. Long wait for drinks and other attention, it was busy but given the prices at Scomas you would expect more. All in all a so-so experience. There are better places to eat in SF.

w2YNH3J0autlqlg35m_iSw.review_text: We had a great waiter (Waiman) and the food, wine and service were faultless.   The crab was delicious but the star was the clam chowder. No surprise to the staff at Scomas there I think.

2_cYY6CX82oblZZDC1MOpQ.review_text: I had to try the San Francisco institution for crab. They did not disappoint. Let me reiterate what others have said -- don't let the fact that it's in the central hotbed of tourist action dissuade you from coming. The food is legit.  The service was also impeccable. I brought my own bottle of wine and made a special request (spinach served before crab), both of which were handled perfectly. Love them, mean it.

OaOBbdWvkAXGk3Jralosug.review_text: Prices are within reason for food qualify and location. Located near main wharf area, just walk a short side street for access. Cioppino was best I had on a 2 week trip around Cali, it was extremely large and with a great balance of seafood variety, in a tomato base broth.   All Apps were well received too, and the bar service very accomodating.

6-US7xMW86ogW4fJ4CWBzg.review_text: Right on the water. The food was great. I got the cioppino and it was awesome.  There are a lot of older people here. Not saying that's a bad thing, but it just seemed to be their target demographic.

pDRTHlNjs0Z8a6JuhW2UCA.review_text: WOW !!!  What a find. I asked a few fisherman at the bar we were at where is the best place to get Cioppino... Both at the same time said Scoma's. I asked where it was and was told ats just around the corner on the right. Walked over in 2 mins and put our name in(always busy here btw ) and were called in 15 mins. WOW !!! one of the best I ever had and I have had it in a lot of places too. Will be back next time in town... WE LOVE SAN FRANCISCO !!! Great city to be in

_XtUYRa8NEVHJjNsvOX0uQ.review_text: YUM!  This was my first time at Scoma's, if my friend didn't drive, I probably wouldn't have ever known of this wonderful restaurant down at the Pier!  Though pricey, the food and the service was spectacular!  This was on the menu:   Calamari Frittie Calabrese $15 (Delish!!) Seafood Salad $33 (Smoked Salmon, Prawns, Dungeness Crabmeat, and Bay Shrimp) Lobster Newburg Alla Scoma $36 1 Glass of Pinot Gregio $7 1 Double Shot of Hennessey on the rocks $30   Tab + Gratuity = $158  Although the prices are a little high, the food and the service is unbelievable.  There is valet in the front as well so no need to worry about getting a ticket.  The restaurant got pretty packed as the night wore on so it's best if you arrive at 6-6:30pm for dinner.  We got there at 6:45 and didn't really have to wait.    The food was incredibly delish and the portions are huge, I couldn't even finish my salad!  The waitress was extremely nice as well, always coming back to check if we needed anything and to refill our waters.    I would DEFINITELY recommend this place!    (it's a casual but nice place as well, so please wear a belt and don't let your pants fall below your derriere!)

z6_9gHID4D04TYU5wIozwg.review_text: The selection of fish could be cooked any way you wanted. Lobster ravioli good! Old time restaurant with old time service. Have the bartender make you a manhatten. I would order the clam.chowder, bread, and an appetizer. A+ service

XYew8zIiR2AgELJKG9qpsw.review_text: This Really Is Worth Your Time And Money.The Service Is Impeccable And The Food Is Outstanding.Their Clam Chowder Is Incredible.I Had Halibut And I loved It Also. The Hubby Had Shrimp And Loved It As Well.

r8mpL8b9pR1Bd4qN_TiwFQ.review_text: Well I have to say it was quite a sight.   I was seated near the window and it was very pleasant, service wasn't that great since I look 16 but its ok he tried. I got was Yelp suggested crab ravioli and shrimp pasta. Both was 4 stars and I have to agree that It was a nice change than sitting near the market where every looky loo can peak inside. Recommend it for anyone that is looking for a fancy time eating seafood :)

wKJRr7O6JPFubTPhmnvbsw.review_text: I had the arancini here, which was great because they don't make it the Sicilian way with all the meat and peas. I can never find a place that makes them like supplis.  I then had scallops, which were also very good.  The setting was nice...I don't think I would go back, but for the night, it was nice.

3_hUWVllRGwj7fVRGbVDjg.review_text: Amazing food. Great service from waiters that aren't there just to sell you whatever's expiring in the fridge. Romantic location by the water or even intimate corners for the couples.  Ordered the Cioppino and Lobster tail. (Was planning to order a clam chowder [cause I heard about the raves] and the polenta [just cause I was in the mood] but the waiter warned us against, even though they were both delish, that we were going to be too stuffed and wouldn't be able to enjoy it all) props to the waiter.  Cioppino was very big! (Thank Tony for the warning!) The sauce was amazing, salty, tomato-y, and full of flavor. Big chunks of fresh fish, crisp shrimp, and fresh clams. Lots of pieces of crab too.   Lobster was a very good portion. Sweet and tender while keeping that crisp crunch you like to see with fresh seafood. Comes with a side of veggies, rice, and pasta.  Service was great. Food was great. Price was on point to the location and food.

BzkXyR-45yc8EJeVySMJWg.review_text: Priiicey.  We did enjoy our visit with professonal wait staff and old style favorites.  Bring your money when you come.  kids fish and chips oysters and bean side dish lamb dish with salad

Qq-0s5rHNZvSys3hbpwB7w.review_text: Never disappoints us!!! Always fresh, deliciously prepared. A must-do on the wharf!! If you like Cioppino (fish stew) you won't likely find a better (more hardy and fresh) preparation anywhere.

4fBGpyoWSY4SzQ7JZoX7vA.review_text: Great food, great service, great place.

XiRtOenP8pJobOcqd-JUYQ.review_text: So I'm already over 2 years over due for this review, but believe me it is not easily forgotten.    Growing up in south Florida I thought I couldn't travel anywhere where the seafood could come close to that of the Florida Keys; I was wrong.  I visited Scoma's on the recommendation of an acquaintance that lived in San Fran for many years.  She said it wasn't to be missed, that is an understatement.  Located on Fisherman's Wharf, I wouldn't have thought to try this place.  I tend to gravitate and investigate where the locals go as opposed to the tourist traps in major city's which are usually mediocre at best.    The experience at Scoma's was far from mediocre.  By far the freshest most delicious shellfish I have had to date.  I ordered the shellfish in a garlic and butter wine sauce over pasta along with the dungeonous crab appetizer.  Truly a heavenly experience.  The service was top notch, the view from the restaurant was beautiful and the food was outstanding.  I don't believe I ate for the remainder of the day as the serving was rather large and frankly I don't think my palette would have been pleased with anything else that day.  When in San Fran this place is not to be missed.  On my next visit to this most beautiful of city's I intend to fulfill my glutenous desires at this little gem.

isQxsxlCjj6P8GQ_uuFwew.review_text: So I'm allergic to seafood (fish oil) so not the best person to write this review.  However the prie fix dinner (lamb) I had was absolutely delicious!  Everyone in my family dinner absolutely loved all their seafood.  The waitress was super friendly, the view was great and I would definitely return!

Zn6_1t5LujJZLkkMOBgntg.review_text: I'll admit that I was a little apprehensive about having my college graduation dinner here (Fisherman's Wharf is not somewhere that you want to go if you actually live in SF)...  ...hoooweeevvvvverrrr...  It was perfect.  They were able to accommodate our nine-person party quickly and with a (basically) private room.  Not to mention that everyone's food was delicious.  I tasted the Swordfish Piccata (so much yum) and the Lazy Man's Cioppino (the most yum I've ever had, that buttered bread is gold!).  Other people at our table had the Sole, the Lamb, and the Crab Louie.  Plates were almost licked clean.    And our waiter (Andrew) was very personable and efficient.    I don't like making the trek over to Fisherman's Wharf very often, but I would totally do it for a dinner at Scoma's.

UUtAJlb539KRlp53csbzog.review_text: Just okay. Noisy and small areas to eat. Not exactly the friendliest server either. Was really just okay, nothing amazing.

szhitaiKPsjC15bveyXRzA.review_text: Like this place needs another review, so here is review #260:   There is no other place to eat cioppino than here. The Lazy Man's Cioppino at Scoma's is incredible, they don't skimp on the crab at all. When the scallops are plump and tender you know they use the freshest ingredients and don't overcook the fish.   A great bottle of wine, some sourdough and the Lazy Man's Cioppino is what I call the TRINITY.

utNHcDwetOEIKUD9xfFPJw.review_text: One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. I live in Colorado but every time I am in the Bay Area, I make it a point to eat at Scomas. The seafood is always fresh and the service is great. The 49er memorabilia on the walls is always fun to look at as well!

3ebLFjWX5cdLOuPSJIyksA.review_text: The best seafood in the city.... So I'm told.  Right when you walk in the door, you see about a dozen parties standing around waiting for a table. The hostess told us it'd be about 45 minutes to get seated... We were seated in 15 minutes.  The menu has plenty of variety from seafood to lamb, pasta to soup. I got the salmon and it was oh so good at first. Got a little dry towards the end but all in all, it was delicious.   The service was awesome as they kept our drinks full and were very attentive to our needs... even on a busy night. They don't take reservations  and the restaurant ambiance feels like you're sitting on a boat somewhere, which is kind of cool. But when you stand up, it feels like the whole place is slanted. Don't forget to bring a sweater!

41HLwXnR0Lm3NUp01cIOQg.review_text: I was decently surprised by the food at this restaurant. I had low expectation when it comes to dining at a tourist area. I followed the advice from the iPhone Yelp app and it brought me to this restaurant with 400+ review and a solid 4 star.   I decided to go full tourist style and went with the prix-fixe lunch menu. What could one possibly get from a $23.95 lunch at a tourist district?  Starter  Cup of Clam Chowder - (5/5 stars) - Their chowder completely blew my mind. I only found out later that Newsweek had named Scoma as one of the five best chowders in the US. While I can't totally agree with that claim, the chowder is still definitely one of the better ones. Solid 5 star quality.  Entree Scallops with Garlic Mashed Potatoes and Mixed Vegetables - (3/5 stars) - A bit disappointed by this. The scallops were flavorful but was a bit too salty and over cooked. I have had better scallops elsewhere.   Dessert  Chocolate Mousse Cake - (4/5 stars) - I usually dislike chocolate cakes but I was managed to finished my dessert. The cake was rich in taste yet light in texture. The strawberry puree paired well with the dark chocolate flavor.  I also managed to 'sample' the other entree. Petite Dungeness Crab Salad - (4/5 stars) - Nothing petite about this salad. There were tons of crab meats. The meat was very fresh. Yummy salad dressing.  Great quality food for only $23.95? I have possibly paid close to that for lunch at some mediocre restaurants in south bay.  I am very tempted to try their cioppino that everyone was raving about. From now on, Scoma will be my default dining spot if I am taking any out of town friends to fisherman's wharf.

ev3ufSElWCrqfi9js5FTmA.review_text: Great food and service. They were quite busy during the lunch hour, but we still received a wonderful experience with their staff.

_LZ_xEirLHQa2NZfEK1f7Q.review_text: And we came back! This time we brought some friends who live in the area. The food was outstanding! Lobster Bisque, Ciapinno, Grilled Salmon,...it was all super fresh! This is one of those places that you will need to make reservations for a couple weeks in advance.

Mk0rlJjiX1NJyvZ4z1Vycw.review_text: Took my sister and mom out to dinner here before a concert. The food was decent, as was the portion size, but it was in no way comparable to the prices. I understand that Fishermans wharf jacks up their prices for the tourists, but jesus. We got the Black N Blu Ahi appetizer(for 18 bucks) and it came with THREE meager pieces of ahi, one of which was bare edible because of the tendons in the piece. Dont get me wrong, I have no problem spending money on a great meal, but I want what I pay for. Service here is tremendous. There are better views on the wharf, which is weird because they are literally right on the water. They have an extensive menu, and two full bars. All in all, not the worst place Id ever eaten, but certainly no reason to return.

HR1wozuAE_3KAHFP1XvIjw.review_text: My mom actually recommended this place since she comes with her girlfriends for dinner whenever they are in the city.  It's a little tricky to get the restaurant since it's down a tiny alley that you have to pay really close attention to while driving, otherwise you'll miss it.    The second time around the block (since we missed it the first time), we drove right down and it was nice that there was valet service to take the car.  Once inside, it was cozy, and the view of the ocean with the ships in the distance made for a real San Francisco experience.    After being seated and looking at the menu full of items that all looked great, I made the smart decision to order from the Prix Fixe menu where I chose the Clam Chowder, a main entree that consisted of a shrimp/crab salad, and dessert.  For $24.95, it was the best deal of all and in the end, all of us decided to order from it.    The low down:  Clam Chowder:  Creamy, perfect potato to clam ratio, and great portion in a little cup.   Main Entree of Shrimp/Crab salad:  Cannot say enough about how good this was.  It was a huge plate of shredded crab, mini shrimp, romaine lettuce, kalamata olives, beets, and thousand island dressing on the side.  I almost couldn't finish it because it was so filling. Dessert:  Chocolate Mousse with Raspberry sauce-  Perfect ending to a perfect meal.

Dp73YMsqLBIIw97o6ruFsQ.review_text: We have been coming here for years and love that it seems out-of-the-way even though it's at Fisherman's wharf. The seafood is the specialty here. The chowder is thick and creamy. If you like shellfish, the sautéed shellfish is excellent and so are the salad Louis' if you prefer a cold dish. The tuna filet sandwich is very good. They also make great bloody Marys. Old school decor with impeccable service too. The servers are knowledgeable and efficient.

OAHmaHq4YZCZpyfyKl566w.review_text: A little gem just outside the crazy main tourist street. Waiter was very friendly, helpful and catered to one of my friends special dietary needs.
