The scallops were extremely fresh and there were a lot of them.   The restaurant sits right next to a docking station and has a relaxing boat feel and decor. I highly recommend this place.

D8RbIwp274MIazomRQ2oDw.review_text: Never knew this restaurant was located here. Tucked away from all the touristy restaurants. Brought our family who were visiting from out of the country.   If you love calamari you must order it here. It was super delicious! One of the best calamari appetizers we have tasted. Lightly battered and cooked just right. Bowl of clam chowder was also amazing paired with the warm and fresh sourdough bread. Tried my husbands Lobster Bisque and was also amazing. As my main dish I ordered the Fried Combo Platter - Shrimp, Scallops, and Pollock - this dish was good but not fantastic. Wish I would have ordered something more interesting. Nice list of wines to choose from.

qjF9JFe4bPiPknz7ZlU_vg.review_text: Want to feel like a sardine in a can?  Well then come to Scoma's!  So we waited for 20 minutes to get a table for three, and when they went to seat us, we were seated basically at the same table as the diner's next to us.  There was like a 1/2 inch gap... seriously.  The one dining room they were using had so many people in it the waitstaff were bumping into each other and the back of my chair.  It was really stuffy and hot inside because of all the bodies in the tight little room.  I can only assume that they were totally breaking fire code regulations by having so many people in that one dining room.  Maybe this is how it always is... but, for such a pricey restaurant I kind of expected to be maybe, like, at least two inches away from our fellow diners.   The food was okay.  Certainly overpriced.  And certainly nothing special.  I have been in SF for a few days now and all of the menus from every restaurant by the wharf are kind of running together.  Nothing particularly stood out at Scoma's.  But man... that seating.  That was bad.

qbZlO17MDbzkYLgVv5Kj5w.review_text: What a treat old fashion San Francisco restaurant on the water. Waiters that no the menu and help you order what you really want. I had the Clam Chowder best in Northern California and a Garlic crab at market price $34. Lots of reviews and the it eally is a terrific place to eat. Make sure you get there early or have reservations. Down side they should open the second bar at 4:30 pm on the weekends. Other then go there ready to get large potions of high quality seafood at great prices for such a high quality establishment. Enjoy

hpGvqKXcgAoKCIOSh1hwnQ.review_text: We had  drinks and appetizers at Scoma. Appetizers and drinks were really good.  Their dips are very yummy and sea food is delicious. The service was quite fast and friendly.

Hj_GF8MnikDy4BQzf0B8Dg.review_text: Some of my most memorable childhood dinners have been Scoma's.   Can you believe it's still standing after 32 years?! From Shirley Temples to Blood Mary's - man this place has seen me grow up!  I kid you not, I got the same waiter (my dad's friend) that waited on us before, Tim.  I wasn't sure if he'd remember us but once he remembered my mom's occupation - I was in disbelief.  Enough of the sap...You should come here if you're looking for the fun, touristic, seafood experience.  Everything is good here, so you really can't go wrong.  Our staples are always the fried calamari, fried oysters, clam chowder, and saute sec (parents fave).  They're flexible with orders, as I asked for a fried oyster dinner, not on the menu, and they're willing with no ifs, ands, or buts.   I'll cherish this place forever.

jtTRoaXpUhwXH8ZFMvU41w.review_text: I've been coming here for 24 years.  I'm giving them 5 stars for consistency and good food.  I've been to many high end restaurants, where there is beautiful decor and true views, but the food  here(and the service) keeps me coming back. Whenever I have a craving for Crab Louie I head over.  Prices have gone up(of course, over 2 decades) and the menu has been shortened considerably.  But the food is always amazing.   By the way, in addition to the food, nothing else has changed(I am pretty sure).  The bathroom is the same, the decor is the same, the tables and chairs are the same, & the paneling on the walls is the same.  Kinda funny, but cool too.  They don't put on airs to make it fancy -- it is just good.  I almost always get the crab/shrimp Louie combo salad.  Not on the menu anymore, but they can do it if you ask.  I wish they had a few more veggies (like it used to), but overall still amazing.  The shrimp is baby bay shrimp and paired with the crab is the perfect combo.  Great dressing. Brought friends and family many times and always a hit with the food.  Parking in back is valet.  Never have had to wait. Give them a good tip - they work hard.  No charge when you are dining. If you are nice for a small charge they will let you leave your car after eating so you can walk around along the wharfs and nearby streets.  Well worth it(we have to get our saltwater taffy across the way before we leave).

86xjsqBxt9JoVLQnp9czcQ.review_text: Was there some time ago, and I'm in SF for and extended weekend, so took the opp to have dinner at Scoma's again.  Arrived on a Thursday night, no reservations, and our group of 4 waited about 20 min.  We had the sampler plate - I particularly enjoyed the Crabcakes and the Calamari Fritti was outstanding.  I had the grilled Petrale which was light and tasty.  I had a taste of the Lazy Man's Cioppino, which was a flavorful combination of shellfish and fish.  I also tried some of the prawns and scallops - the scallops were firm well prepared.  I would easily recommend any of these dishes.

tj5PexVAfowjvoBW4u5y0Q.review_text: Have been here multiple times.  Guaranteed good quality food.  We wanted to get fresh seafood for lunch so we stopped here.   We had oysters, shrimp cocktail, clams on a half shell and lobster bisque soup.   The fresh Scoma sour dough bread is fantastic.    Service is good.   Would definitely return.

hS1i4ZL4RHIAMZHxwDGreA.review_text: Seriously the best New England clam chowder in San Francisco.  Always make a special trip for their chowder.  I know I've eaten other things there, but for the life of me cannot remember because all I can think about is their clam chowder!!  The only thing I didn't like was that you cannot just stop in to the bar for a drink & bite.  So if you want to stop in for a drink and apps, they make you sit in the dining room.  This happened the last time we were there.  We sat, explained to the server that we were just there for a cocktail and chowder, apologized for taking up her dinner table and that we would be tipping her like we were having a regular dinner.  The annoyed look on her face went away and she was very appreciative.  We would have taken food to-go, but they also don't allow that!    Pretty crappy policy for the customers and servers, but great chowder!

Fc_D-qKdOjt5hcvxifKFCQ.review_text: "Still a solid SF Institution.  Try to avoid busy times though.  This is still a tourist trap"  I feel bad for some businesses in Yelp so I try to be fair.  To run a restaurant and then have lay people acting like they are pulitzer price winners all the while being "food experts" commenting on their restaurants must be hard to swallow.  Again, I try to be fair.  I've worked in fine dining as a waiter and went to chef school so I have a little knowledge.  That said:  Scoma's is an institution in SF.  Known for great, fresh seafood, with amazing views.  Tourists flock to it.  I don't go here very often but we decided to go by on a Thursday.  It wasn't too busy.  Remember that if you go during the busy weekends or holidays, it is a mad house and when that happens, food and service can go down a little.  We dont' go during those times.   We had the crab cakes and clam chowder; both to die for.  The chowder was as fresh as the ocean with a clean creamy finish in the mouth.  The crab cakes were fresh and awesome.    The cioppino was to die for.  I sopped up the sauce with sourdough french bread drinking my cold beer.  I was as happy as a pig in sh*t as Gordon Ramsey would say.   We also had the seafood combo platter.  The seasoning was lightly done and good.  Too many people want a lot of seasoning on seafood and it's not about the seasoning, it's about the seafood.   The creme caramel was rich and thick and it was good.   Usually you have to wait in the bar and the bar prices remind you that you are in a big city.  it's expensive.   Pros: -Fresh seafood -consistent food during non busy times -to die for soups and cioppino -amazing views  Con's: -expensive -bar is really expensive -sometimes the food is hit or miss during really busy times.   This is still a staple in San Francisco and probably always will be.  Not my first choice to dine, but it's solid and mostly never disappoints.

-hguvvWqI9qgWA7iW13u7A.review_text: If you're not paying attention, you'll walk by Scoma's and not even know it's there.    Well, that's what we did this past Saturday Night and almost missed out on a great meal.  Fortunately, I pulled up the address off my phone and we got there before the major dinner rush.  Even though it is in the middle of Tourist Trap Central there was no tourists in the  tables surrounding us.  Great sign.  Although the place was packed the service was friendly and efficient.    I can only attest to the quality of one dish:  the Cioppino.  I ordered it ten years ago, then two days ago and I can say it is still one of the greatest seafood dishes I have ever had.  Nice plump shrimp, beautiful pieces of crab, perfectly cooked scallops.  Nice chunk of garlic bread to soak up the well spiced tomato broth.    My girlfriend ordered the prix-fixe menu:  The appetizer was somewhat unmemorable, fried risotto nuggets or something.  The pasta looked great; the shrimp they served over top were more like small lobsters.  It was so much food we had to take the dessert to go, which was a pumpkin cheese cake( excellent for breakfast).    I was going to give them four stars, but I can't think of anything to dock them on.   One word of caution:  go early on the weekend... when we left the reception and bar was packed with people waiting for a table.

xaGHnjxQ-FfaTJZA9c37uw.review_text: Bad experience here.  Had dinner here at 6 after walking around the Pier for a few hours. Felt like we were judged by our appearance.    Our waiter Sergio was horrible. It was clear that he was favoring his other tables more. Never gave acknowledged our needs.   We left feeling neglected with service.  He only came by once to see if we needed anything.    The busboys gave us better service and were personable.   1 star for the food. I will never think about going here ever again.

G43x7mt15BNyQBdpBcE7Qw.review_text: What a way to end a trip to SF!  Good rule to follow: When out of town, ask the locals where to eat. Don't follow the clueless mobs of tourists that don't know any better. Remember the rule of the blind leading the blind?  I decided to avail of the prix fixe menu they have and this is what I had:  Lobster bisque and lobster salad Lamb t-bone on parmesan polenta with caramelized shallots and sauteed swiss chard (main course) Tiramisu and sourdough bread pudding duo (dessert)  Love love LOVE the lobster bisque. I cannot sing it enough praise. The lobster salad was okay, but the lemon wedge made it better.  The lamb I ordered rare and it came out the way I wanted it: nice and bright pink. It was tender and juicy. The veggies that came with it just made this wonderful dish just better.  I liked the tiramisu; I wished there was more of it. The sourdough bread pudding was more firm than I expected from a bread pudding. Oh well, that's ok. It was still good and not bad at all.  The place overlooked the bay, and had a nice view. The staff was uniformed and looked neat and clean. My waitress was nice and polite, and joked back with me when I joked with her.  This place is a seafood haven. You get to splurge a little, but it's worth spending the extra few bucks considering the food and the service here.  My hat's off to you, Scoma's of SF! I can't wait to come and see you again when I'm back in town!

wTe4kWXjAhtNq4litsYVXg.review_text: Everything was great intill we got to the  main course  my wife  halibut was dry  there special the scoma signature dish was horrible

lB5ZDDVEhXzMdbRte_xZ8w.review_text: Went for our friends anniversary. Was a wonderful experience. The parking is a little tricky and the wait can be long but well worth it. Our server has been there for like 25years, he was entertaining and attentive.  My friend had the Chipino and her husband had fish. Both raved how delightful their meals were.  My husband and I had Filet Mignon. Cooked perfectly, flavorful and juicy. We wanted to stay and continue to sit our wine and chat away the evening.  The seating is tight so if you want something intimate this really is not the place but wonderful atmosphere, service and food.

7z-Crwkwo3wyngtjFhdJ9A.review_text: It wasn't my choice to eat here because its MAJOR BANK ... but when my cousin heard I wasn't doing anything on my actual bday, she insisted on bringing me here to try their crabcakes.  Considering she hates crabcakes...but LOVES the ones here, I thought it was in my best interest to see what it was all about (I love crabcakes :P)    They don't take reservations (no idea why) but luckily a friend of ours had awesome hook ups (holler if u hear me) and got us seated fairly quickly.  Note: you can't be seated until your entire party is there.  Yeah, their crabcakes were pretty good...very very meaty and flavorful.  :)  My bf and I ordered the lobster and NY steak, which we managed to stuff into our buldging bellies.  (see picture :P)  I'd highly recommend if you have the cash or for special occassions...def. can't be eating here all the time..  Parking is rough...I'd recommend public trans if you can.

G9cOvWMz0u9wjtKc4sSL4A.review_text: Saw some amazing reviews on yelp and one of my older friends recommended this place. The restaurants been around forever and most of the servers have worked here for over 20 years or more per my waitress however they didn't have good food , well at least our lobster's wasn't good.   It's extremely pricey, it's an older restaurant, older demographic. Nothing trendy or hip. I wouldn't call it classy or elegant either, my chair was uncomfortable and my silverware was dirty, my waitress was super sweet about getting me a new set of silverware.. The servers have cute uniforms.   Our food cost around $150 for two of us, salad, entrees and desserts.   Both of our lobsters were super over cooked. My pasta had no flavor but it was cooked perfectly, no sauce , no seasoning just pasta. My steam veggies were just veggies , no flavor. I asked the server if the lobster is usually over cooked. She seemed offended that I asked her, she got into this whole thing about how they broil the food and how they have been in business since 1960's before I was even born, yeah she said that. She was an older lady and it was cute how she took pride in her job and the food, but at the end of the day we didn't like our rubbery over cooked lobster and the comment about when I was born was unnecessary.  My parents raised me to be polite to my elders, I just smiled and thanked her for letting us know. Anyways we didn't finish our meal and thankfully there is a thing called Yelp :) Despite our lobster experience I wanted to try the Jack Daniels bread pudding, so glad I did.   Personally I won't go back for their food however I might go back for the dessert if I'm in the area, however will never again make a trip to dine here. For us it was a complete waste of money and time.   The Jack Daniels Bread Pudding - 5 STARS - Delicious !!!    Lobster / Food - 0 stars  Customer Service - 2   2 stars overall because of the bread pudding !!

xJu_t3bD-rpdT59Y0KUILw.review_text: Touristy, yes. Institution, yes. Overpriced, yes. 2.5 star for food, 1 star for view, and .5 star for the atmosphere.  Nice to go once a year to just enjoy the ambience.  One of the better tourist joints on the wharves so if I have to frequent just one each time I'm in the City, I rotate among them.  Better food at better prices can be had elsewhere but when all is said and done, it's worth a visit if you've never been.

kaw5D7uuopyCXrrs-x4BcA.review_text: Excellent food, excellent service in a traditional and friendly atmosphere. Thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. What's old style is new again. Generous portions...a popular spot after games so go early if you don't like to wait!

Wxx8xDXJ4_P02Yq1tI92cw.review_text: LOVE this place. My dad has been coming here for 25 years. Lunch is the way to go...same great food and atmosphere at much better prices. Cioppino is amazing, but huge quantity! Could be shared easily. If you like calamari (fresh, and not breaded/fried), ask for the calamari vinaigrette. Not on the menu anymore, but they'll still make it :)

om_CGRtDLCRbG_IvXOU9qQ.review_text: Been coming here for upteen years. Besides, I worked here in my teens. It's all good, but expensive. Oyster rockefeller for starters is my cut. Brings back da days...for some reason, it still does.

YM6Z2255UgCwKKskfIrP_A.review_text: Seafood so fresh they hire boat captains to fish for them and they even have a processing area across from the restaurant. Ordered their market grilled fish and it was simply the best I EVER had in SF. Also ordered their calimari, crab cakes, and shrimp that were just rich. Also tried their lobster bisque which was the BEST I ever had. I appreciate the staff ( an ARMY of them) and guests ratio. It is pricey but u get the very real "fresh" seafood from the ocean to the fork food.

jg17BlZ8CQzGg6UOKE0sVg.review_text: The ONLY place you should pay to eat in Fisherman's Wharf.  Fresh fish caught by their own boats.

xM4V7fNZKm3XrL74YNcgRA.review_text: Great service, Excellent food. Friendly, and helpful staff.

drSF-9GYQkShY5_5SP7vpw.review_text: This place is okay, noting to write home about.  The décor is old,  70's old, you say charm, I say old.   The food was good, but nothing special, for the price, I want special.

CbnrQMM7yi3SU0Q9fqSHNg.review_text: Great service, great food, beware of MSG!!!  We enjoy eating at Scoma's for the delicious seafood and good service.  I recommend the prix fix lunch menu ($25 till 3pm everyday).  The staff cares about your food allergy and special requests.    However, I must warn you that they use a lot of butter and MSG in the clam chowder and pasta garibaldo - my previously favorite dishes.  I can no longer order them because of the extreme fatigue, tiredness and sleepiness that follow the meals.  If you look through their kitchen windows, the Chinese cooks prepare the Italian dishes.  No self-respecting Italian cooks would use MSG in their Italian dishes.   Furthermore, they charge a $4 health fee.  I am against establishments that charge a health fee because of their greed and dishonesty:  they pocket the health fee and sign up their staff for low-cost or free city health insurance (Healthy San Francisco previously and Covered California now).

uouiFFetHG-aCQPBo8luEA.review_text: I went last night & was really disappointed.   ATMOSPHERE: The restaurant itself is really outdated. From the plates to the cheap wood panel walls & so-called "decor", it reminded me of my uncle's 1970s basement (without the shag carpet).  This place is in dire need of a makeover.   FOOD:  The lobster bisque was below standard. Don't expect even a single piece of lobster in the bowl.  The entree I ordered Blackened Prawns over Pasta Vodka (Brown Rice Penne Pasta, Pancetta, Tito's Vodka Sauce) was disappointing especially for its $34 price tag. The dessert was a joke.  When i ordered the "Fudge Brownie with Vanilla Ice Cream" for $8, I again felt disappointment when I received a cheap, dry brownie with no flavor. You get a better brownie out of a vending machine.   With so many choices of restaurants, I would NEVER recommend this place.

N8_PNk2yLMiqD6pbZSQHZw.review_text: This place was a disappointment.  It was right down the street from our hotel and my wife and I had heard great things about it.  We go inside and we are immediately blown away by how tired everything is.  The carpet is old, the walls are old, the photos are of old people.  It smells....old.  It looks like some kind of speakeasy from the '20s that was never once renovated.   We sit down and look at the menu.  It's basic seafood, but a bit pricey.  My wife and I both order something from our (old) waiter.  He is a little peculiar.  I hear him in the next room yelling at another employee about something minor and give my wife a sideways glance.  Oh well, we try the bread.  He brings out our entrees and my meal is not what I expected.  The menu was a little ambiguous, but I didn't return it or anything.  I'm usually one to just man-up play my hand if I'm at fault.  The waiter takes it a bit personally and tells my how beautifully prepared the meal is and that I will enjoy it.  It was an odd tone and I ordered a salad with crab meat on it.  I'm sure it will be fine.  He later returns to ask about the food and says, "Well, I know yours isn't what you wanted."  Whatever.  I guess I had upset him.  We paid and left.  Nothing is really bad about this place, but you can do a lot better in San Francisco.  Go to the dives and eat the seafood there.  Their food is much better and you don't have to deal with the snooty  time capsule that thinks it's "high class."

oNfTTqEybwsDy17JptM3sw.review_text: We have been going to Scomas since 1972.  Have had Birthdays, Anniversaries, parties and just the two of us for lunch.  The food is great.  Chappino is one of my all time favorites along with calamari vinegreta.  My wife loves their fried prawns.  The service is exceptional.  If you go in the afternoon ask to sit in Chris's section.

CoKpm23cOtqq7cPhKhmR2Q.review_text: Good food and portions were definitely fulfilling. However, was really disappointed in the décor. It seemed more of an upscale diner than the elegant restaurant most were touting. For the high price and lack of ambience I probably would not return. Just too pricey for what you get.

gpRL3XO7HlAwhS-9YsAjpg.review_text: Very good place food is perfect waiters know what they doing, nice. I did tried several places besides this one Scoma's place nothing could beat it. I would recommend to visit this place first and then check all other one. The only thing could be as negative I guess this place is not easy to find it located back from main street, just ask local hotels stuff I am sure they whould recommend this place in the first place and tell you how to reach it. Best place I would recommend to anybody who can appreciate good food and perfect service

rnfZmzeWVxlSirBhtWT7Bw.review_text: While vacationing in SF, we dined at Scoma's to celebrate our anniversary. The service was quick and friendly. The food somewhat disappointing. I mean, it was fine but not how others have raved. We started with the crab cakes. Perhaps I'm crazy, but they were in no way as good as the crab cakes at Pappadeaux! We split a pasta dish, which was decent. I personally think there are many other fantastic seafood restaurants in San Francisco in which to choose.

TOVbHGRwDBFQZ95_ykDYBA.review_text: My lovely bestie took me to this gem of a place when I was in SF last weekend.   Let me start by saying that the service was uhhhhmazing. Our waiter was funny, attentive and overall...quite charming.   My bay shrimp dinner salad was flipping delicious. I don't know how the few ingredients of lettuce, thousand island and bay shrimp can taste so much better than it normally does...but Scoma succeeds in the blowing of the mind.  My lobster/scallop sautee was tasty...however it was a bit heavy. I prefer my seafood without heavy pasta AND rice...yep two starchy carbs in this bad boy...but the quality was still excellent. Next time I am definitely getting the ciopino.  The only thing that could have made my experience better would be if they carted me out and gave me a ride to the jazz bar up the way. I had to roll out of there I was so stuffed!   GOOD TIMES!

OaXFrBrJd9cV55W0aLDjIQ.review_text: Tasty, classic presentations of fresh seafood right on the bay near Fisherman's Wharf. Had the ahi tuna sandwich with wasabi mayo - best ahi tuna I've ever had.

n4lyTe0ZUU6meaS4RjB5ug.review_text: Had dinner with the family on new years eve.  Got there at 6:30 and they seated us within five minutes.  Waiter (John). Worked there for 17 years and was very knowledgable and also went the extra mile to make us feel comfortable.  Now to the food...  We had the clam chowder soup which was great.  Wife had shrimp sautéed in a spicy sauce and she loved it.  She is not easy to please when it comes to spicy shrimp but she was impressed.   I had the lobster Thermidor which was one of the best I have had.  The deserts were also fantastic.   I would strongly. Recommend the tiramisu.    Really great food and thanks to the other yelpers for the reviews and pics.

lxOcZ1VZ58nSCFgcunecjw.review_text: I don't typically hang out in the Fisherman Wharf area but after a walk around the city, my girlfriend and I found ourselves here and instead of heading to one of the very touristy dive places, we decided to head to Scoma's.  It was early in the night but the wait was still about 15 minutes.  It was cold inside the restaurant which made it a little uncomfortable but it was very active.  I ordered the prix fix menu and it was pretty good and overall a good deal.  I had the crab cakes to begin, shrimp pasta as the main entree and then a cheesecake for dessert.

zswWYrNJsiSOFmDkqSWjKA.review_text: First and foremost, I would like to clarify that the Scoma's in Sausalito is owned by different people!   Scoma's is always delicious, savoring, filling, and the portions are big. It never seems like they're trying to conserve the ingredients. My favorite dish at Scoma's is the Mixed Seafood Plate. It consists of rice, noodles, scallops, lobster tale, shrimps,..etc. The portions are huge! I usually go to Scoma's for a family dinner (I'm a broke college student, and therefore can't afford food above 20 bucks sighs) and we order about 4 plates for 5 people. We always come back with leftovers!   If you're searching for a place that gives generous portions, delectable taste, and a beautiful view (at the pier), this is the place for you!

czqJEm4LhQpsYUjW8qyviw.review_text: I have never written a review before, but this place had terrible service during lunch today. I went there with 3 other Asian friends and the waiter immediately assumed we didn't know English and had the Chinese busboy come to serve us. He never gave us his name, and had a confused face on when I asked to have separate checks, then hesitantly did it for us. I asked what the catch of the day was, and that busboy told us salmon swordfish. When it came, there was a bunch of pasta, and I'm gluten free. I was never told there was pasta in the dish! So I asked to order the steak instead, and every piece was tough to chew. I will not come back again. Terrible food and snooty attitude.

wyP32RLTYNdFyTT60rx80w.review_text: Had steamed clams and mussels, too die for! I shared with my hubby dungenese crabcake dinner, calamari fritti, sampler plate, lobster bisque and clam chowder. We didn't eat all these in one seating, we were there twice.  Excellent!

wM67zXFIXBzCrRB7EYJ1dQ.review_text: Fantastic, elegant, old school ambiance. The wait staff was attentive, but not overbearing. The food was perfection. Definitely our new go-to spot for fine dining on the wharf.

ZAGGAP4PujmrCvWYhtJrfg.review_text: Went with my family and everyone enjoyed their meals. From seafood to steak - everything was delicious! Our waiter was very nice and knowledgable of the food etc. dessert was yummy too. Make reservations!

rTS_h49Q1Sofn-zUZdf_Sw.review_text: I'm a cioppino fanatic and have tried cioppino all over this city. Everyone always said, "Try Scoma's. Try Scoma's." Okay, okay, I tried it tonight. Not the absolute best cioppino I've ever had (Sotto Mare still takes that prize here in SF) but pretty damned good. I just wish it had more clams and some mussels. it was a lot of fish and bay shrimp. The broth, though, was the best testing I've had.

LR9lb4Qk3Q2s85e5Fsw8sQ.review_text: I got reservations for Scoma's for Valentine's Day through Open Table.  I was sure to reserve a month in advance and we were taken directly to our table when we arrived.  This worked well for us, as the restaurant was busy.  Scoma's was recommended for the view, but we didn't have a view from our seats.  The service and meal made up for it and the ambience was still nice.  I cannot say enough good things about our server.  He was attentive to our drinks, made suggestions and answered questions, and helped my daughter with crab etiquette.  While the service was excellent, it was not stuffy or snobbish.   We started with a bottle of the house white.  It was mildly sweet and not dry-- the way my husband prefers.  He liked it, but I would have preferred a red.  That is my taste issue, though.  I started with a Cesar salad.  The dressing was light and lemony, with the portion on the smaller side for the price.  I think it could have used something extra (bacon crumbles, maybe), but I thought chicken or shrimp would be unnecessary.  There was a prix fixe and I really wanted the lamb, but I couldn't resist the cioppino.  I was not disappointed.  The portion was large, the tomato broth light and flavorful, and the seafood was perfectly cooked.  I have a new affinity for scallops because of this meal.  My cioppino was served with garlic bread which was a wonderful compliment.  My husband got the cowboy steak and said it was "very good".  My daughter got half a garlic roasted Dungeness crab and she had no leftovers.    There was even a children's menu.  My son's chicken tenders were even fresh.  I was happy with Scoma's for our vacation and Valentine's day choice.

77STTiXFySEFv0wtqc0Exg.review_text: This review is based one 1 visit.  I had the Cowboy Steak with Au Gratin Potatoes, Asparagus and Spinach.  I thought the food was very good.  The service was good and the location was good.  The décor was old and outdated but it still works for them.  I wanted to try a Lobster Tail but didn't since my meal was already over $50.

lOu5t9HG51UDqm4ahVatqA.review_text: The location is memorable, and the food is very good.  I had the salmon and thought it was excellent, and the mashed potatoes and vegetables were also good.  Expect to pay a pretty hefty price, the salmon was $34 and there were no entrees under $30.  The service was excellent; Bruce was very nice and seemed like he had been working there for a few decades.

cgAhU-Vi4yV2ncQOf5ECZA.review_text: Ate lunch here a week ago. No reservations but seated very quickly, everyone we met was very friendly. For an appetizer we had the shrimp cocktail, very disappointing as a few of the shrimp were not deveined and one was not fully peeled. My wife had the dry-packed scallops which were OK, nothing to rave about. I ordered the lobster newburg but they instead served me the lobster thermidor, it was just OK as well. It was hard to find the lobster chunks hidden in the mushrooms, onions and cheese. Food preparation and taste were Red Lobster quality at twice the price.

4pzr6KuS85859EICMI7MDw.review_text: I'll put it this way: I've been coming here since I was small enough to order from the kids menu. Thanks mom!  Call it what you want, tourist trap, clusterf*ck, rip off; this place is an old school San Francisco seafood institution. There's almost always a wait, so try to get there early or maybe call ahead to see if they'll put your name down. There's valet on the pier lined with squawking pelicans and tons of hungry barking sea lions below. Scomas is pretty much one big meandering and chicaning hallway and old school vibe is topped off with penguin-suited waiters, retro decor and an overall rustic aura.  You'll find all seafood staples here, granted at a premium. It's a fun place to dine at when you have friends or family visiting from out of town, or if you want to feign tourist, if only for an evening.

gDQQaWyHAMbsfYvrw8mUZg.review_text: Hubby and I go to Scoma's a couple of times a month, sometimes more during crab season. We were there last Sunday and started off with the best  Bloody Mary I think I've ever had. Found out the secret was the Chipotle Tabasco the bartender used. Most places use regular Tabasco.  We had Tim as our waiter, and we sometimes request CC because she is one of our favorites.  I had the Mixed Seafood Saute which is the best! My husband always has the Crab Louis. I don't think we have ever had a bad meal here. Scoma's is the place we recommend to friends and family whenever they are in the Bay Area.

SOUqBPLoX2rj_pZ6hfvYsQ.review_text: Every time I go to SF I come to this place just for the clam chowder. I haven't had anything else, but they get a 4 star because the clam chowder is amazing!  BUT I'm not sure if it's because I don't normally dress up all fancy and nice, and maybe I look younger than my actual age, but either way, the service is not very good, especially the hostess. I went in last week and they gave me some bread and grissini with butter but the grissini were soggy and the bread too chewy and my silverware were a little dirty too. I also asked for a beer and they never checked my ID. I would think that for being such a nice restaurant they would be more professional and clean, but the clam chowder is amazing, so I'm guessing the rest of the menu is too...? Also, first time I went, the bloody mary was really good too.

zRFiCjG6YaO8AvGbvgqlSQ.review_text: I had dinner tonight at my favorite restaurant for special occasions.....  I go there for the Seafood Saute dinner.... Lobster.. Prawns .... Scallops and Crab ..... Oh so delightful.  Started out with the real SF sourdough bread and Clam chowder and then had the entree and ended that wonderful dinner with a great cup of coffee.  But the reason I'm writing this review is that each time we go to our favorite place we usually get one of the male waiters that have been there for many years and they usually have a bit of an attitude but tonight we had the pleasure of having Elizabeth for our wait person and Irene as our bus person.   Can I just say that they were outstanding!  So friendly and accomadating.  Best service we have ever had.  Hope the next time we go Elizabeth and Irene are on duty! Happy Holidays

3tzF8fVMfwDgm6UuM7GGZw.review_text: Great Sicilian style fish, soups and the oysters were some of the best I ever had. Excellent choice if your in the area.

jNsPTMmg9EcqY7q2Q-Rm6A.review_text: For Mother's Day this year, we came to Scoma's in San Francisco. My mom always loved Scoma's in Sausalito, and when I was browsing Yelp, I found the San Francisco location. We have gone to the Sausalito location many times, but never knew about the San Francisco one.  I like that they have their own parking area with valet parking. Definitely a nice service and touch. What  I liked about Scomas' environment is that it's classy, yet not over the top. Definitely an old-school classy and fancy restaurant on the water, something that my mom loves.  We were seated in one of the private, smaller dining rooms with an ocean view. At first, we were seated in a cramped table in one of the other rooms, but my mom requested to be moved, and they opened up one of their private rooms for us to sit in. Very nice.  Our server for the evening, Elizabeth, was wonderful. Very friendly, humorous, never bothered or rushed us. She was a sweetheart. For appetizers, we ordered the Mussels. The mussels came in a clear, light broth. The mussels were delicious and very soft. The broth was really good with some garlic and onions mixed in.  For dinner, we didn't know what to order. My mom, sister, and I kept browsing the pasta section exclaiming what we each wanted, but couldn't find EXACTLY what we wanted. Then our server told us that the "Saute" section of the menu, we could order that and have it come over pasta. Once we found that out, we were SOLD.  So, the three of us ordered the exact same thing - the Shellfish Saute Sec. I opted for mine to come with a creamy sauce, but it usually comes with a white wine and butter sauce.   The pasta was so delicious, the seafood was fresh, soft, and cooked perfectly. Our pasta came with prawns, scallops, lobster, and crab legs. YUM YUM YUM YUM YUM! The other thing that sold me was the garlic, onions, and mushrooms that came sauteed with the seafood. My absolute favorite veggies when it comes to creamy pasta.  Overall, we had a great experience here. All of the service we received from the valet, to hostess, to server, to busboy, was excellent. The food was great, my mom had a great time. We definitely had a great Mother's Day dinner this year.

mcsAPnM42EjISfbEtR5frQ.review_text: Another fantastic dining experience in SFO.  Went for lunch this past week.  We arrived early, because we're losers, at around 11:30 AM.  We and our elderly friends (everyone else in the place) were seated promptly and the fun began.  First off, the view was superb (we were seated at a window looking at a bunch of boats docked).  Second, the bread is amazing.  From there, we ordered a seafood platter for two, which was excellent.  They didn't have crab on the platter that day "because it hasn't come in yet" - somehow I loved that!  the shrimp (prawn?), clams, and oysters were excellent.  I ordered some kind of cod and it was superb as well.  Dessert was some ungodly chocolate thing.  All in all, a great experience - they could have been two notches down on food and the location would have made it up (see my review of the Landmark on Cape Cod somewhere on here). great food, great professional service, good value.  Not quite  5 stars, but close.

pDQQ5BxhzxeyhOUekYAoCg.review_text: Pretty busy for a Sunday afternoon, this place is hidden behind the busier Fisherman's Wharf street. They have their own valet parking, so you don't have to fuss with looking for street/meter parking.   Food wise: The clam chowder was great! creamy and fresh! with lots of clams to spare. The Broiled Aged New York Steak was ok. The seasoning used was very tasty, but I am pretty sure it was cooked to a medium when I had asked for a medium-rare. My friend ordered the Broiled Mahi Mahi and that was very very good. Very flaky and nicely seasoned. The dessert of the day however fell a little flat. We were given a scoop of spumoni. I was hoping for something maybe a little more extravagant, or even a slice a cake, but... that was it.   Our server was very nice. She was extremely attentive. I should probably give it another try for their crabs since that seemed like what most of the other customers went for.

nl3ywW2cJwLhuNlAPmbBSA.review_text: Always great food great service in the old traditional way that I was used to in the 70s growing up. Never had a bad meal or bad service here in the past 20 years. Will always come here as long as  I live!

9PSrDL6meDoQjee_To_zIQ.review_text: When we lived in Santa Cruz years ago a friend of ours took us to Scoma's.  Over the years we have been back a few times and always enjoyed it.  We finally got our first chance last night to go again since we've moved to San Francisco.  In general the experience was wonderful, although there were some odd quirks.  First when we first entered the restaurant we were told there was an hour wait.  So, we decided to get something to go.  The maitre d' was walking by so we asked him if we could place a to-go order.  He said, "come this way" and then proceeded to seat us at an open table.  A nice surprise but I have no idea why it happened.  On to our drink order.  My wife asked for a glass of the house champagne, and the waiter brought out something that looked like champagne, except in a wine glass.  There were no bubbles so my wife told him it was flat and sent it back.  The next glass was also flat.  It wasn't until I got the bill that I realized our waiter had served her chardonnay, not champagne. His English wasn't great so I can see how that mistake would occur. However why didn't he or someone else bother to figure out why someone was sending the chardonnay back multiple times?  Ultimately my wife just drank it.  I ordered the shrimp & crab louie and my wife had the lazy man's cioppino.  Both were excellent, although also expensive ($32 for the louie, $35 for the cioppino).  The portions were quite large.  Also the sourdough bread served to the table was very fresh.  Another comment on the waiter: he never offered fresh ground pepper.  My wife had to specifically ask for it  When I'm paying more than $30 for an entree I expect to be offered those sorts of amenities.  Still ultimately we were satisfied with the meal.  Scoma's is probably the best choice for dining near Fisherman's Wharf, particularly if you want to impress out-of-town friends with your local knowledge.  Just keep in mind that you may have to wait quite a while for a table on a busy night as they do not accept reservations.

sj0mepLs5DIKbkcWMqzsDg.review_text: My husband and I were on vacation. Every local we talked to suggested that we visited this place to eat. It was AMAZING. We went for our anniversary an I have to say I was not disappointed. I recommend this place to anyone visiting San Francisco.

FHy96zYYf2GVvjIV172jWA.review_text: I've been here a few times (Its a favorite of my father).  Its old and so is every employee of the place -- they've been doing fresh fish right for a long time.   The place allows locals to go to fisherman's warf with out feeling like they've sold their souls.  Their semi-hidden location keeps most (if not all) of the tourists away.  You wont be disappointed with the "house favorites"(see their menu) or the shellfish.  If you haven't, you must try the cioppino -- its excellent. (i'm getting hungry for it just writing this)  It should also be noted that they do not take reservations & you should bring a couple bucks for the required valet parking.

4k43P1zuES57ewaGC4jYjg.review_text: Although this is an "old school" Italian-seafood joint, it was a solid find with great service and tasty food.  The walls are covered with photos of stars nailed on wood paneling, and the feel is 1980's.  We went for a late lunch with two kids, and they sat us a nice window table, overlooking the fishing fleet.  The waiter was professional, but also made us feel right at home, including the kids.  We started with raw oysters - cold and delicious - and the crab cakes, which were warm, tasty, and all crab.  We shared the cioppino, which was fresh and perfectly cooked seafood in a tasty, tomato broth.  They brought us two bowls, making it easy to share.  They even prepared flounder cooked plain for my son, which he said tasted "pretty good.". While I wouldn't run to dine here, I would not hestitate to have some oysters and other seafood when in this area.

Kw4lH6C5wSrYVxaDP68pfA.review_text: Ordered the Lobster Bisque soup, which was absolutely awesome.  The flavor was incredible and i practically licked the bowl clean.  I also ordered the Poor Man's Cioppino based upon the recommendation from our waiter and this dish had to be the best Cioppino I've ever had.  There was a good amount of prawns, shrimp, scallops, clams & fish.  Not to mention it's served with a large piece of their garlic bread and I guarantee you won't leave hungry.    The service was impeccable and they offer valet parking.  Quite simply a great meal at Fisherman's Wharf in SF.

RsIbmSXWRXJLBBlgQsb7tg.review_text: My parents are really into this place.  They go all out and order fancy pastas and dishes and blah blah blahhhh. I only like one thing: The Steak Sandwich. It's not on the menu anymore, but they make it still.  This place is pretty dated, but that's part of its charm. They've also had the same waiters foreverrrrr. It can get crowded/touristy depending on when you go.   Highlights of all of my experiences: -taking a picture of myself next to the picture of Al Scoma and sending it to someone and making them mad because they didn't get to go. -actually texting people pictures of ourselves there and making them upset is something i've done pretty much every time... hmmm -witnessing the most awkward first date/birthday celebration ever -shocking Canadian tourists with my loud conversation -seeing a little girl in a wedding dress but I guess that's like a communion thing lol -pedestrian purposely walking into our car just to be a little jerk -having the valet bring the car over to us and getting in the car while tourists watched and waited and Billie Jean is BLASTING, then driving off as fast as possible

0pnDh5D0yV37fKsvMTKf2w.review_text: Scoma's was on the pricey side, but good food.  Excellent service.

dXPsB-rAoG-VFLCjAzYaPg.review_text: Overpriced, overhyped, tourist trap, the service however was excellent, but the food was mediocre and bland. I have had much better food elsewhere at this price point.

xW_PU6RkiUtezxL0hVWG0A.review_text: This place was really yummy.  The seafood was fresh and the staff was nice.  Plus, we were on our honeymoon and they treated us extra special! :-)

b-jfG4G6LruavTKn1TvWEQ.review_text: Got the halibut. Ok. Sides were veggies and mashed potatoes. Also ok. Could have been at any restaurant anywhere. Did not like the atmosphere. Old carpet and panelling.  Would not go back.

Strb-zv7UKWSSirBQZjeWg.review_text: Perfect meal, off the beaten path we would have missed it if it was not recommended by our hotel! I had the swordfish which was perfectly cooked.y husband had the fish platter which he couldn't even finish- there was so much! Our girls had bowls of chowder which they loved. We had the shrimp cocktail appetizer that was yummy. This place is pricey but worth it. We spent about $160 with tip for lunch!

eZc6ZCAjGlCQDDHYG65iNA.review_text: I love Scoma's!  I always have.  For a traditional seafood dining experience right on the water, Scoma's exudes historic San Francisco, it's been a fixture in the City and if your visiting, it's a must visit!  Their crab salad is off the charts.

_0L4WNYQ6f6y6pMYzJ3b9Q.review_text: Ate here about 14 years ago and back again in the area necessitated a return visit. Over the years, either my palate has matured, I sampled excellent seafood at other places; but it was not the 5 star place I remembered.  I had the lobster bisque: watery Swordfish: Good, but lentils that accompanied the dish where undercooked Service was decent.  Had to wait 20 min for a table and then be squeezed in between other tables.  Overall decent, but I made the drive here from San Carlos based on my desire to revisit; not going to do  that again...

0dnGrJr54WDqByxkj86lkQ.review_text: My boyfriend and I came here on a Sunday for an early dinner.  We made reservations for 4:00 and got seated probably around 4:30 so we enjoyed a cocktail while we waited.    The menu looked delicious and we had a hard time figuring out what to get, but this is what we settled on:  a cup each of the lobster bisque and clam chowder.  The bisque was deliciously creamy and the chowder was very good!  I ordered the grilled salmon on lobster ravioli with saffron sauce and he got the cajun swordfish with mashed potatoes and grilled veggies.  The lobster ravioli is AMAZING!  The saffron rice was creamy and decadent but not over powering.  I almost wish I just ordered the lobster ravioli without the salmon so I could have had more!  The swordfish was good, but the ravioli was definitely the better of the two.  Overall, the meal was very enjoyable and the service was delightful.  We would definitely recommend this place to anyone wanting a nice seafood dinner!

-x2Ulw6ijKqlmlZTcuXWbg.review_text: Ate here 9/27/14. Was assured they would be busy but sat immediately at about 6:00. Service was friendly and attentive.  My lobster bisque was delicious and rich. My wive's salad was fine. A little too much arugula and other greens tasted like dandelion.  Wive's blackened halibut was a little overcooked but good, not great. My dungeness crab risotto was disappointing.  Way too fishy for dungeness, like they added extra fish juice. I also have to ask who the heck puts mushrooms in a shellfish risotto - much less CANNED mushrooms? It was edible but not good. Until I found a hair in it. They comped our desserts so that helped.  But still the only GREAT thing we had was the lobster bisque and nothing else was much over "OKAY".

BLdK_1vIl_EyzWgSH7tywQ.review_text: Their clam chowder is EXCELLENT! It's hearty, meaty, w/ a good flavor. Also, the atmosphere is great, deep in Fisherman's Wharf.

eC3_iAlNzRMh4mY4eut94A.review_text: I brought my wife here on Sunday for lunch. I expected she would really enjoy but, the French waiter was totally overbearing. He kept telling us we should not order so much. He should leave that to the customer so we could have tried many things. The price was never a concern, only great food. He really killed the fun for us!!

5Xmxg3HIx7ZhAGU26jaoPA.review_text: I brought my mother to Scoma's on her first trip to SF. Why Scoma's? Well based on the reviews and the recommendation of our tour guide, I figured we couldn't go wrong. OMG, I have never been sooo completely and utterly disappointed with a meal. And this little dining experience cost us almost $200 for the two of us.  I started with the shrimp cocktail and my mother ordered the salmon cakes. The shrimp were just meh and tasted like they'd been frozen and not yet 100% thawed. The salmon cakes were so heavily deep fried it was hard to tell whether there was actually any salmon in there. And if there was, you certainly couldn't taste it through the oil and batter.   For our main entree I ordered the broiled swordfish, which was completely tasteless and came served with stiff mashed potatoes and soggy vegetables. Mum had the calamari fritti which was also heavily heavily deep fried and seved with mountains of old rice AND penne pasta...REALLY? We sent back the calamari and it was then replaced with an undercooked calamari dish. We reluctantly took our leftovers but discarded them in the first trash can we came across.  If you appreciate good, fresh, and well prepared seafood, I strongly suggest you go elsewhere. The one star is for service, our waiter was very pleasant.

qUIjw3wpXZaFp2klmSx9QA.review_text: I celebrated my 24th wedding anniversary at Scoma's last night.  It was perfect!!!  My husband had called ahead and had flowers delivered there and the staff had arranged them at the table ahead of time.  We were seated immediately.    The food was excellent.  We had roasted crab and received 2 complimentary desserts in celebration of our anniversary.  At Scoma's they treat customers right!    My husband took me to Scoma's on our first date and we always come back, because we've always had wonderful experiences at Scoma's!  Last night was exceptional!

5Y1juYFWdBrK8FP0PHMRgg.review_text: I came in from out of town and came here for lunch. I had the pre-fixe lunch menu with clam chowder, a pasta dish with salmon and muscles(Amazing!- the muscles) and a piece of chocolate mouse cake. The cake was the best part! The view was great, the service was good, the ambiance was not for me, very "old", but all in all a great restaurant.

Tu0xZqGMIbJ_RrV4S5P07w.review_text: I came here for "Dine About Town 2010" which had a set menu for $17.95 a person and included an appetizer and entree.  We went for my friend's birthday and she got to choose a dessert which was complimentary from the restaurant.  I ordered the clam chowder and pasta garibaldi (salmon, mussels, sun dried tomato).  The chowder was creamy and better than the usual canned soups I was used to.  I dipped the sourdough bread the waiter gave to the table into the chowder and it tasted just as good as if I were eating it right out of a bread bowl.  The pasta garibaldi was like a seafood pasta in a marinara sauce, but the best part were the mussels, they were huge and meaty.  Scoma's is located right by the water, so you get a great view of the fishing boats and you can trust that the seafood is fresh.  The restroom was clean and here is my "neat freak favorite," there were hand sanitizer pumps available outside of the restaurant and by the door of the entry way...outstanding!

Wo_ASbM3pzJ4r1Qf6CcNOA.review_text: Ducked in here for lunch one Tuesday afternoon while walking along the Wharf. Thankfully, it wasn't too crowded so we got seated almost right away. The service was top notch and I appreciated the "old school" type atmosphere of the place. I ordered the shellfish saute which was absolutely killer (fresh seafood, generous portion, perfectly seasoned) and my boyfriend ordered (and loved) the lobster bisque.   If anyone has the recipe for that saute, you have to let me know. Otherwise, I'm going to be sitting here in Utah with a mad Scoma's craving.

UMHPiLEba_gDO5efCpUqbQ.review_text: I grew up on the east coast, so I'm a bit of a snob when it comes to seafood. We Marylanders are pretty picky about our crab. In our minds nothing can compare to the Blue Crabs we pull from the Chesapeake Bay. So when a local friend kept telling me that we needed to go to Scoma's for an awesome seafood dinner, I kind of had that, "Yeah, yeah, whatever..." attitude. Then when she said it was on Fisherman's Wharf I was even less impressed with the idea. Tourist trap is what came to mind.   But she was persistent and kept raving about it, so when we had some friends visiting SF and staying in a hotel at Fisherman's Wharf, we decided to give it a try. Their complimentary valet parking makes it so convenient  - so they already had one star in my book. It sits out at the end of a pier/dock so the views are spectacular - the Golden Gate Bridge to one side and Coit Tower and the Transamerica Building to the other. How can you beat that? They don't take reservations, so if you show up at the prime dinner hours expect to wait. But with views like that, who cares? Wander around the pier a bit, take in the breathtaking scenery of one of the most beautiful cities in the world while you wait!   The tables are rather close together, but otherwise everything about our dinner that night was spectacular! The warm baskets of  fresh sourdough kept us happy while we decided what to order. My husband got the Lazy Man's Cioppino, which he loved. I got the Seafood Saute Sec. It's got to be one of the best dishes I've ever had! We've since returned several times and have yet to be disappointed!   It's a bit pricey, but for the view and the food, smack in the middle of a touristy area of a city, what else can you expect?  I am definitely a fan of Scoma's!

-4B1rRNS18CcA7duD2tp9A.review_text: This was the best restaurant that we have been to.  The service was amazing.  Someone always coming by and clearing off dirty plates and refilling drinks.  The food was the best seafood I have ever had.  Everyone was so nice.  We requested a table by the window and that's where we were seated.  The restaurant was totally filled and they still were on top of everything.  They even gave us a piece of complimentary cheesecake for our anniversary.  Would definitely return there.

_GVlCPjKS3eFM9NsFHv1Eg.review_text: My mom recommended this restaurant to us, saying that she and my dad had eaten at Scoma's two nights in a row once, cause it was THAT GOOD. Yeesh (insert picture of me pulling at my shirt collar here).  I guess I just ordered the wrong thing;  my salmon was way overdone and totally dry.  My husband said the same about his fish too; not bad, just overcooked.  I added a star because my butternut squash soup was really tasty.  I couldn't understand what our server was saying to us.  I think maybe he had a few back in the kitchen before he came to our table.  He was nice though!  The girl sitting next to her boyfriend (diagonal from us) who was wearing a giant crab bib and feeding every bit of her dinner to her boyfriend while cooing in a baby voice was pretty entertaining.  I'd probably give Scoma's another shot, but I'll order something other than salmon next time!

bMXigKk6S-e-ApRuMCF7rw.review_text: We decided to go for a great pre-anniversary meal. We were very disappointed. I ordered New York Steak which came with mashed potatoes and MIXED vegetables. The steak was just okay - no flavoring. The supposed mixed vegetables was a large scoop of cauliflower with 3 little round carrots. The cauliflower was deep yellow in color as was the mashed potatoes; neither of which were flavorful. My husband ordered grilled salmon. He started eating it and it smelled like a dirty dish rag. He said it tasted like old fish! Yuk! He ended up with the same scoop of cauliflower!  We were there at 5:30 p.m. for dinner on a Saturday evening so no excuse or reason for the awful tasting food - which by the way was overpriced.   Caesar salad and French bread was good and fresh.   Service was good.

uRzy7KZwZk0Ujhlhsedlhg.review_text: very fresh food. they have lunch special, three course entree for $25. chocolate cake was absolutely sinfully good. clam chowder very creamy and thick...yums. lovely place by the water.

qcmg-jf6ZtaA6HpHhp0A_g.review_text: Ordered off the prix-fixe menu Appetizer: Dungeness Crab Cake on Watercress Salad with Lemon Vinaigrette & Remoulade Sauce Entree: Broiled Colossal Prawns on Linguine Pomodoro with Pesto Garnish Dessert: Tiramisu & Sourdough Bread Pudding Duo  The crab cakes were good. I thought they were a bit small. The bed of salad it was on was quite delicious and refreshing. Also tried my friend's lobster bisque which was quite tastey! Both excellent choices. I thought the linguine was alright. It came with three colossal prawns. They werent THAT colossal but tasted pretty good. I thought they could have thrown in an extra prawn. The linguine was okay. Nothing special really. The tiramisu was really good! I did not particularly like the sourdough bread pudding.  The service was great. The servers were very attentive. Price for prix-fixe was $39.95. I will probably not return to this restaurant. Not because they aren't any good but just because I think that there is better in SF.

cEbzV4xFcjfAVUoP-uyU4w.review_text: Lobster bisque, i have had better 3/5 Service slow and never received drink from bar. Long wait and bang not worth the buck What was i thinking, a seafood restaurant right on the pier. Fried food over cooked looked like what you would get at a fast food chain. Crab cakes were 4/5 Crab loie was 5/5 Vegtables served 5min after entree Food over all good but dining experience not that good Very crowded tables on top of each other

PTSKTcHKZLM3VIzaShYmCA.review_text: A little crowded, but the food was worth it!  We didn't have a reservation, but we were seated within about 30 minutes from arrival.  I can't say enough about the service!  Absolutely the best waiter I think I've ever had.  I had the fresh grilled halibut.  It was amazing.  This is definitely a go to seafood restaurant!

RRi7zRq1Inbw4i7kuBB3yw.review_text: great location! can't beat the view of the pier/harbor.  pros: -good food, such as their clam chowder -quick service -staff was always ready to serve you  cons: -our server was oddly rude (mumbled some comments every now and then) -decor was out dated, but it is an old family restaurant in fisherman's wharf  came for a late lunch after a nice bike ride from the pier to the golden gate bridge.  the restaurant overall was just okay for me.  nothing spectacular as the reviewers expressed.  i don't think i'd come back to this place when i return to s.f.

aSxb9BDlZluFllLgXuqmTg.review_text: Yum yum yum clams and their diplomatica is off the chain. The piña colada was too liquidy although amazing bloody marrys :) and not a wide selection of red wines.

0lLVwzlhWHEvQYYdrgQFyg.review_text: Maybe the only place where I trust everything my waiter says about their food. Great service, (besides the rude hostesses who didn't even say "hi" when I walked in) and great food. The portions are large so be careful when ordering! The calamari appetizer was a full meal!

gIKP4KsBfTbfiQ7yHplxEA.review_text: Second visit here.. love the food... the ambiance is nice and romantic. prefer coming here for dinners

mMhsMvHPagrTJVX-2gMxnA.review_text: This is my favorite place to eat in SF! I had the dungeness crab risotto and a few of my moms lobster pasta. The risotto was cooked perfect, creamy and tons of flavor. The peas in it gives it a fresh taste. My mom's pasta had huge chucks of lobster in it, and was wonderful! Waiter could have had a little more personality to him. But I love to sit there and watch the boats and have a great dinner!

qM860LaOe0n0CpBEPQKycQ.review_text: ROASTED DUNGENESS CRAB with GARLIC, OLIVE OIL, and FRESH LEMON!!!   ...nuff said...   ok well everything we ate was delish!!!  the chowder was perfect (not runny, not to thick, not to chunky)  the calamari was just how i like it (the batter was a perfect texture)  the crab cakes were pretty good  the service was very accommodating, very friendly  ...free parking!!! thats awesome!!! to have free valet parking in the city is just amazing!!!   im definitely coming back again and again and again

IqPxpjgVEcjpdxoR8UCXLQ.review_text: I'm going with 4.5 stars on this.  I was in town for a few days and the Yelp reviews were pretty god. SO, we tried it. Everyone enjoyed their food.  I had the halibut and it was amazing!  Good wine as well.  The only reason they dont get a full 5 stars is because one person asked our server if the chefs could do something different with what he wanted to order.  The server straight up said "no".  Didnt bother to ask the chefs.  Even if the chef had told the staff that they wont do things like that, just pretend to ask and make the customer happy.  The staff was friendly and skilled, though, dont get me wrong.  I would say this place is worth visiting!

HVk2ZvKxBVeXdKTC0yPOeA.review_text: Some of the BEST crab we have ever had in the states! A great place with old school ambiance and good service.

5c9qNzpKvn2-7Mh2Mizi4g.review_text: This spot has great service! Every thing was amazing. We found out about Scoma's from our concierge at the Hilton; Thanks dude!

zWGj3oOA_X8QPho_l5BRKg.review_text: Scoma's is definitely rolling it old school. They are just enough off the main path for the pier that it tends to make the place a little less touristy. It's still touristy, but it's not over-the-top annoying.  The food is great, but a little higher priced than it should be. The dishes should be a solid $7-8 less than they are. But paying the extra amount for the awesome U-shaped booth right by the window was mostly worth it. The shellfish saute was awesome, the swordfish was lightly fried and perfectly cooked. The calamari (asked for spicy) was good, but definitely not spicy. Lobster ravioli was good, but the saute and fish beat it out hands down.  The servers seem like they have been working there for the last 20-30 years - i.e., also rolling it old school. Felix (our bus boy) is so old school that when one of the people in our party asked for honey, he said, "for what?". Now, normally that would be annoying... but it was so ridiculous of an answer from someone that is supposed to be getting you the things that you ask for that it became funny. We basically used that as an excuse to give Felix a hard time, and I think that he appreciated it. Well, maybe he didn't... but we sure had a good time.  Overall really fun experience, and one that could definitely make it hard to pay the bills that month - but something that is classic for a visit to SF.

2NJAGc7KpzQIbKi4aD1Ysg.review_text: My husband's coworker recommended this to us.  We have two toddlers and once I saw the white linen tablecloths, I knew this restaurant was not going to be a good fit for us.  But we were already there and decided to try it out.  The waiter was friendly and gave good recommendations.  I ordered the crab salad.  It was good, but nothing special and was definitely overpriced.

ypT08Su2vSeFZfsVm1sqbA.review_text: I had high hopes for this place. I took my friend from out of town to the Fisherman's Wharf area and checked Yelp for good seafood restaurants. Scoma's was the highest rated place. We stopped in around 1pm on a Saturday and were seated within 20 minutes.   Started with the hot sampler trio for our appetizer. Not impressed. Calamari was a bit soggy and not flavorful. Scampi was worse. Crab cakes were decent but not as good as I expected from such a highly rated place. I had the fried scallops for my main course and was not impressed with that dish either. I left my plate half full.

gBpzv_xVL81_BY8HfKAN-g.review_text: Love this place, great atmosphere and view. Definitely a great place to stop for lunch while in SF. Kind of pricey, but anything with seafood usually is. Clam chowder is obviously amazing, paired with sourdough bread, of course. Crabcakes are really good also.

iTqDx1YEyvwIDXxwcA5Zkw.review_text: When we first moved to Fresno, we made a trip over to San Francisco not long afterwards. When asking friends for suggestions of good seafood, everyone said Scomas. So we have been twice now, and have never been dissappointed.   The portions are enormous and I don't think I ate everything on my plate either trip. The server are very knowledgeable as ar the bartenders. You can tell these people take service seriously and don't hire just anybody to serve their patrons....Always a classic, and reliable choice...

e-Bh0XDCOgYMaC-BmdxkAQ.review_text: I don't like tourist, so therefore I am not very fond of touristy areas (aka, traps).  Almost to the point of when I am a tourist myself, I am very self-conscious on not trying to fit the mold.  I like to ask locals on where to go, and with our access to the interwebz these days, it's easy to stay away from such "traps".  Here in SF, Fisherman's Wharf is such a "trap" that I often find myself trying to avoid at all cost.  So when a good friend suggested we dine here one night, it was like asking me to give up my left nut.  He is in sales, and has eaten many a meals on an expense account, and loves to order Steak n Lobster.  Of all the places he's traveled to, he claims Scoma's to be very legit for that particular plate.  We were kinda celebrating the arrivals of our tax refunds, and I do love a good steak n lobster meal, so off to touristy hell, I went.  First of all, it's kinda tucked away on the back of a dock/alley and is not really visible from the main street, so that was a plus for me.  It is old school in that the food is by no means creative or artistic, but solidly executed fresh seafood.  It is pricey, but there are plenty of service people to monitor your experience and everything is proper, ie perfect SF sourdough bread, "soft" butter to spread, decent drinks, comfortable chairs, etc...  Another friend orders the Swordfish Steak ($32) nice portion with perfect grill marks but served w/ basic rice and steamed veggies.  Although solid, just nothing memorable.  The other 2 of us go for the gold and order the Steak n Lobster for $75 a pop.  He told me not to get an appetizer, a soup, or salad cuz the plate was gonna be hefty.  He even went as far as to tell me to go easy on the bread, but with warm crusty sourdough probably made just blocks down the street, that morning, I told him there was no way, I was going to leave that bread unmolested.  Our plates arrives and it was everything I anticipated.  A meaty, maybe 1/2 pound tail of Pacific Lobster, perfectly steamed with the superfluous sprinkling of paprika with a ramekin of perfectly shimmering clear drawn butter.  A petit filet mignon (6-8 oz) was perfectly cooked with a distinct garlic salt crust and mouth- wateringly tender in the center.  It came w/ both mashed potato and rice, strange to serve double starch, but at that price, I wasn't complaining.  Also came with same mediocre steamed veggies.    We deliberately hiked here from the the Ferry Building as to build our appetites, and as it turned out, we were so stuffed, we decided to hike back, in lieu to taking a cab.  It proved to be a worthy meal, a meal good enough for a king's appetite, but at 75 bucks a plate, it may be a once or twice a year thing for me.  For that much, I can get a 3 course pre-fix meal that won't be as gargantuan a portion but more creative and just as solidly executed.  Just sayin'.    Scoma's, you may be the only reason I ever agree to step foot in this area of cheap t-shirt shops, cheesy street acts and clusters of tourist.  That is sayin' a lot.

Wj0tIFlWz_1Uam1VDWYG5g.review_text: Wow, LOVE this place!  Pricey, but I gotta say their seafood dishes were simply spectacular!  Service was great too!      Smack dab along a main Fisherman's Wharf artery; If you're walking or driving, just trust what google maps says and head down Al Scoma Way!  You'll find this place at the end, with free valet parking waiting for ya.  We arrived at approximately 4:20pm on a Saturday, and it didn't seem to busy.  The hostess greeted us, and we were waited on by Chris.  He had some good descriptions and recommendations from the menu.  Honestly, I was NOT planning on paying more than $15 for a pasta dish. UNTIL one of the servers passed by, and presented another table with a huge plate of seafood pasta!  The little devil on my shoulder said, "Screw it you cheap bastard, you're gettin' that dish!"     I ordered the Diplomatica ($38), and this made for all the reason to write my review.  It had two small lobster tails, fresh shrimp, perfectly cooked soft scallops, and clams.  With linguine noodles drowning in a savory white cream sauce.  Maybe a bit too saucey, but just add some parmesan cheese and you're good!  So glad I tried this, and I had mega-leftovers!    The gf ordered the Mixed Seafood Grill ($39) with penne pasta, rice, veggies, shrimp, scallops, and two small sized lobster tails.  You can tell all of the seafood were fresh because there were just juicy; Not overcooked, and again made perfectly well!  If you cannot decide on what to order, this huge dish will absolutely satisfy.  It's a mix of everything, so you can't really go wrong with this one.  Oh yeah, the appetizers:  The Calamari!  Soft and well breaded!  Another winner!  The sour dough was good, but I was expecting it to be warm.  No biggie!  Our server started out with Chris who was very polite and funny.  His shift ended and we were waited on by CC.  Both were well attentive, and always filled our water glasses.  One minor mistake was serving my Diplomatica to the gf and vice versa.  Also no biggie, but as a compliment we were given some Lady Fingers for free.  Those Lady Fingers were a nice crunchy sweet treat!  I'll absolutely come back, because there's much try like the "Lazy Man's" Cioppino and the King Salmon.  But if I were to recommend anything, it would be to try something that has shrimp or scallops, or both!

2joga52mJyQH6BT0hfvlpA.review_text: Service was on point! Trio appetizer with calamari, shrimp scampi, and crab cakes was delicious. For dinner my mom and I split the King salmon with lobster ravioli And it was amazing! Next time we come to San Francisco from the east coast we will definitely come back!

1VL37A_wk_t67j-WdDecpA.review_text: We decided to celebrate our wedding anniversary with dinner here and were thrilled with our evening. We started at the bar where I had a great Jamison and Ginger courtesy of Phil, the bartender. For dinner, hubby started with some clam chowder and we both agreed it was amazing! I started with a house salad which was simple yet so fresh that it was a perfect way to start the meal. Hubby chose the Cioppino which is something they are known for. It was a huge portion and could easily have been shared, but he thought it was wonderful. I had the grilled salmon with lobster ravioli and thought it was excellent. It was a perfect combination of decadence with light and healthy. Because our waiter knew that we were celebrating our anniversary, he brought us a wonderful chocolate dessert to finish off our evening.

kMdUDZ0bOEECJfPBn6izBw.review_text: Very touristy but the food was fairly good.   Neat collection of photos from people who have visited over the past 100 years.  I'm sad to say I could not try the crab cakes or the lobster bisque as both had bell peppers.

iLDAIBOVTCyX64Kyid5UXg.review_text: this place is an icon and my moms fav. luv the food.

X8niKKANe_S4qjNUQiSvug.review_text: Sighs... Yet another sign things are changing.  Stormy and I visited Fisherman's Wharf this week and all the places of our childhood had gone to pot. Where have the good seafood restaurants gone? They've turned into Scoma. Its tucked away so you have to hunt it down. That's a good thing.  Stormy managed to wolf down a garlic baked Dungeness Crab faster than I've ever seen her eat anything in my life. She almost passed out from the sheer bliss.  I had ok lamb chops (word guys... you must scrap the soot off the grill occasionally. Tasting ash on a chop or a steak is not a good thing!).  Great wine list. Surprisingly good beet, bleu and romaine salad to end the evening.

YnHf1BPFjfj3kK_i1AC4rQ.review_text: What can I say been here many times! Not a bad thing to say and Thomas if you are reading this hire more people like Tony he was awsome! To all you newbies I suggest The "Lazy Man's" Cioppino its the best I have ever tried.

8JC0TnD1YQMTMyAOuDM56Q.review_text: I've been here twice so far and I really like the generous portions. It's nice to get away from the hussle and bussle of the touristy fishermans warf area and drive your car into valet parking, hop out, and get seated. We only waited about five minutes after having a opentable reservation. We were seated next to the waterfront and served with bread and water.  For appetizers, we started off with the crispy calmari. Lightly fried to perfection and so flavorful! The two options of dipping sauce: tartar sauce or cocktail sauce. YUM! Oh boy did it not disappoint!  I ordered The Diplomatica ($38) with linguine and red sauce. They don't mess around with seafood here and I found my plate with 2 lobster tails, a handful of clams, 5-6 scallops, and 2 shrimps. The sauce, the pasta, and the seafood was cooked to heavenly perfection. I could only finish half my plate! Bf ordered Steamed "skookum" Clams ($25) and comes with the biggest bowl topped with clams. The butter, garlic sauce is delicious and i found myself putting down the clams and just drinking the sauce!  If you're looking for a place for a business meal, birthday lunch, celebration, or a simple lunch and dinner, you will not be disappointed! The only thing that I get frustrated with are the stuck up waiters. The first time I came, I felt like the waiter was snobby. This past time, our waiter was even worse. When we inquired about the specials, he sarcastically said, "everything on the menu is a special!" Then proceeded to point out some things and laugh at the prices and said it was a "good deal..sort of" The only reason why we asked was because there were some dishes on yelp but we didn't see on the menu.. Anyway, after the meal when about to eat dessert, they usually take a knife and scrape off the crumbs. Nope, he didn't bother. Didn't felt taken care of at all by him. The other staff was very helpful on clearing our tables and refilling our drinks. I guess they make the most tip on large parties, business people, or "fancier" people drinking wine but he really didn't make us feel like we belonged there.   I give this place two thumbs up but prepared to spend $50+/person for dinner!

5iDzVdP47uWAf8cu56otOQ.review_text: Service was a bit slow granted we may not have been the favorite customers of the night. We came in 15 min before close. The garlic crab was SUPERB. Sadly though it came with no sides. With my half order of crab at $21, you were to pick from sides that were $7-$10. If you're wanting something that's going to fill you to max capacity at a reasonable price don't go here! If you don't mind spending $35 a plate, for good food, just not a lot of it go!! The homemade sourdough was delicious.

eOh8I5t_FqsRWSD_3SwNAA.review_text: If it weren't for Dine About Town (3 courses for $35pp), I don't think I would come here.  $30+ for a plate of mediocre seafood pasta? I'd pass!!! Well, I can't completely blame them since it's in the touristy part of town.    I like that this restaurant has valet parking and it is beyond spacious, but the whole atmosphere (wall decor, customers, employees) made me feel 20 years older than what I really am.  Other than that, the food was good.   We ordered: Dungeness Crab Cakes, Lobster Bisque, Char Broiled Fresh Ahi , Seared Dry Pack Sea Scallops on Linguine Pomodoro, Pumpkin Cheesecake, and Tirimisu  My favorites of the night were the crab cakes, lobster bisque (best I've had so far), and scallops.  I actually had scallops for lunch on the same day and the scallops here were wayyyyy better.  Why? Because the scallops were "dry packed", meaning there were no chemical additives which in effect tasted sweeter, bouncier, more flavorful, and more tender.   Thanks to Scoma's, I am now on a "dry packed" lookout.

a9tEj7VCXGpopznnCqegdQ.review_text: As always, the food and service were top notch last night for our anniversary dinner. The two stars are for cleanliness and management. We sat at the bar while we waited for our table and I couldn't help notice how dirty it was behind the bar. The fronts of the coolers looked disgusting, which are being touched by the bartenders with their bare hands as they're making the drinks. The mirror behind the bar looked like it hadn't been cleaned in six months, with dried splatters and fingerprints all over it. It makes me wonder how clean other areas of the bar and kitchen really are. There's no excuse for that in a place of this caliber. As far as the management, they did nothing to quiet down some unruly people at the table next to us. Loud, drunk, belligerent behavior by a large party of rude, thoughtless guests, ruining the ambiance for all of the other guests in the dining room, is uncalled for. Everyone knew it was going on, including all of the staff, and none of the management said a word to them about it. For the exceptionally high price of dining here, I would expect better.

7FU0F2OuxI_VmzVsZ_DBcQ.review_text: I had dinner on a Sunday night and my experience wasn't good.  I called before and was told a hoodie sweatshirt and jeans were fine but got the impression that the employees judged me for it.  Service wasn't good.  My server seemed to neglect me quite a bit.  When I had questions about the menu, he excused himself to help other customers.  I don't mind waiting but he often walked by without even acknowledging me.  Something about his demeanor gave me the impression of looking down on me.  On the plus side, the bus boy was really quick with picking up plates.  The food was fine but didn't seem worth the price.  The view was a little disappointing because the restaurant sits among boat docks.

fbfPy5ukg2uzNoY1Igd5Mg.review_text: What many newcomers to Scoma's should know is that long before Pier 39's redevelopment to retail, Scoma's was a locals restaurant. It was located on the Wharf because its fishing fleet is there. And, with exception to the hoards of tourists and new people who moved to the Bay Area in the last 10 years, the restaurant has changed very little since the '60's.
