The cioppino broth is still made from scratch using the butter of dungenous crab. I have tried other variations of cioppino from NYC to Venice, Italy. Scoma's cioppino is, by far, the most savory.   Was there for the hundredth time last month. Still excellent.  _____________________________________  former reviews: Forget Allioto's and all of the other tourist traps. Scoma's is the finest family owed restaurant on the Wharf. That is why locals, like my family, have been going there since before the hippies. Yes, it is "old school." If it were anything else, we would stop going.   Scoma's has owned and operated their own fishing fleet for decades and serve up the freshest fish daily in the northern Italian style. If you're looking for a classic San Francisco seafood experience, this is it!   Their signature dish is cioppino. It's a rich and savory seafood stew loaded with the freshest and tastiest seafood northern California has to offer. Their Louis salads are great. Their dungenous crab dishes are the best. Their bar serves up oustanding cocktails. The service is usually outstanding.   The middle of the week is the best time to go.

xy6nD4IOlne5HTaVb2OLtA.review_text: I finally had the opportunity to try Scoma's with some great friends over the weekend and I would definitely recommend this place to someone looking for quality, family-style seafood. Not only do they serve fresh, gourmet seafood, but their portions are huge! I strongly recommend two people to one main entree. Let me give you a breakdown of the food before I get to the ambiance:   CLAM CHOWDER: This had just the right consistency (not too creamy, not too chunky) and lots of flavor! I think I even tasted some crab in it. I saw their bowl of Lobster Bisque and it was large enough to have as a main dish. I strongly recommend their clam chowder.   CALAMARI: The calamari was good but I can't say it was the best I've ever had.   FETTUCCINE WITH SMOKED SALMON & ROCK SHRIMP: This pasta dish was very rich and creamy (and delicious). I love fettuccine and smoked salmon, but I never thought of mixing them together; what a great combo! What I love most about this dish is that it's even better after refrigerating for the next day!   SHELLFISH SAUTÉ SEC: This dish included prawns, scallops, lobster, and crab legs with a side of wild rice. Everything on this plate was very well prepared and flavorful, right down to the buttery rice.   As for service: I'd give them an "A+", shout out our server HAN MIN, for being so accomodating. From holding some dishes for part of our party who were running a bit behind, to being kind enough to split the bill 5 ways, she was great. Seating is a bit tight, but not a problem. The atmosphere is cozy and comfortable and the noise level is just right--meaning you don't get that uncomfortable silence like you have at say, Boboquivari's, and your neighbors aren't too loud that you want to shove a crab leg down their throat. Its a good place for groups, including children.  Scoma's definitely does not disappoint, and you can't go wrong with free valet parking in the city. However, not every place is perfect and they do have their drawbacks such as, of course, the wait. But anything this good is sure to be worth it. It's important to note that you will not be seated unless your entire party is present. It is also important to remember to inform your server that it is someones birthday, therefore entitling the birthday boy/girl to a complimentary slice of dessert! HAPPY BIRTHDAY ALFIE! LOL!

eIqksD_I10Phn9_nzsBmQw.review_text: This is a great place. I feel like it's not as well known as Alioto's or The Franciscan, but this is the best alternate (or first choice) to the others. The food once again is just incredible and it's right on the actual dock, off of the Pier so it's a little out of the hustle and bustle of all the tourist. It's a great little spot I say try it! It's great for families too, I say the best upper end seafood restaurant on the wharf for families.

yZM8bO0dbhffVp6RCTFN5w.review_text: So I tried to be open minded because a friend of mine visiting from D.C. wanted the Fisherman's Wharf seafood experience.  I understood the clientele here would be mainly tourists and the servers would make lame "so where are you from?" small talk.  I expected the prices to be inflated given the location on the water in Fisherman's Wharf and tourist demographic.  However, given such a high Yelp rating, I at least expected tasty food.  I was sorely disappointed.  So please note that all those aforementioned hangups were checked at the door and my Two Star rating is only for the food.  More inland places like Anchor Oyster Bar, Woodhouse Fish Co. and Anchor & Hope have way better San Francisco seafood.  Rock Shrimp Scampi: So I get that "Scampi" has two meanings: (1)  "small lobster" such as prawn or langoustine and (2)  shrimp served in garlic butter and dry white wine.  Since there was no description on the menu, I assumed it was the latter since that is the norm in the U.S. with Italian-American cuisine.  What we got were overcooked shrimp in a bland tomato broth.  Very disappointing.  Calamari Fritti: Pretty standard.  Didn't sense any extraordinary spices, just a lot of fried batter.  Would have appreciated a marina dip option instead of just cocktail sauce.  Crabcakes: These came as part of the $26 Hot Sampler Trio along with the two other items listed above.  Two crabcakes the diameter (and width) of silver dollars arrived.  Seemed unfair that we got so much mediocre calamari and "scampi", but so little crab.  And the crab cake wasn't that great either, seemed pretty doughy.  I ended up drowning the blandness in generous dollops of remoulade.  Lazy Man's Cioppino: This was the whole reason for coming here.  To show my visiting friend a San Francisco specialty at Fisherman's Wharf with a nice view.  Sadly, it disappointed all around.  The fish chunks were way too fishy and overcooked.  I prefer a delicate filet that is lightly poached so not to overpower the rest of the dish.  Though I appreciate being a lazy man and not having to crack a messy crab, I didn't appreciate seeing just crab dust.  Whoever was cracking the crab for me could have been more careful to maintain the integrity of the chunks.  The scallops were a bit overcooked too.  The shellfish (mussels and clams) were ok.  We got huge chunks of garlic bread to dip into the broth, but they were really stingy on the garlic butter so it tasted like bread.

-f3XN9UF7OmjICSDXUaA5Q.review_text: I'm a Midwest girl that headed to the West Coast, to San Francisco to be exact, and demanded an amazing seafood dinner.  Scoma's was everything I wanted it to be and MORE.  We all started out with Lobster Bisque, which was probably one of the best cups of bisque I had ever had, I wanted to lick my bowl clean.  I asked the server for a suggestion of seafood and pasta and chose the Pasta Diplomatico with red tomato sauce, linguine, shrimp, scallops, and lobster tails which was amazing and big enough for a full table to eat!!!  The seafood was perfectly cooked.  All of the other girls in my group loved their meals as well.  Not only was the food incredible, our server was one of the nicest, sweetest people we had ever met, Jose, thanks for all of your incredible suggestions and your extraordinary service.  One thing I would change, I wish the bread was a bit fresher...I wish I could go back, but I'm over 2000 miles away!

9A58ZhWUObzvb-bybheNkQ.review_text: This is one of my wifes' favorite places to dine at while in SF.  Our standard fare is the lazy mans' ciopinno (mispelled) ... and garlic bread + believe it or not spag + meatmballs sometimes.  I need a change of pace sometimes. Parking may seem a chore and the wait - it can threaten to be a deal breaker.  However we always seem to find a way here in spite of the complications!

BiWYDNIf7gBBNRtP6YVwIA.review_text: Likes: Lazy Man's Cioppino with garlic bread, some pasta dish with scallops, and other food I sneaked off of other people's plates  Dislikes: breadsticks were not crunchy but a bit stale, wait is freaking long as usual, parking difficult thank goodness for valet

i9l8TT6Bz63W-PZl8ph53w.review_text: Wow, a 45 minute wait on a Monday? And no reservations, ouch. As the minutes ticked by...past 45 minutes and pushing an hour...my hunger almost overtook me. I stared intently as the hostess from where I stood about 15 feet in front of her for the past hour. I watched as people whom I think arrived after us got seated first (other two person parties like me and my friend). Finally, I went up to her and asked how much longer for us and she waved to the seating hostess and said, she'll seat you right now. Interesting.  Once seated, the service was attentive and the food was quite good! It is a little pricey and quite touristy, hence the big crowds, but I enjoyed my dinner. The lobster bisque was creamy and had a little bit of bitty chunks of lobster in it. I tried their "most popular dish" (as the menu states), which is the shellfish saute sec. This dish entailed crab (already de-shelled), scallops, and baby lobster tails sautéed with onions, mushrooms and garlic in a white wine and butter sauce. At 36 bucks, its a pretty penny, but it was  really enjoyable! The sauce was tasty and it came over a bit of rice. It also came with undressed pasta, but it was good with a little grated parmesan on top and dipped in the saute sauce. It also came with some steamed veggies. Their portions are quite generous so I was stuffed and had some leftovers (and believe me, I am not a dainty girlie eater)!   I think this place is a pretty standard seafood place with fresh, tasty seafood. Being a touristy area, it's a little pricey and busy, so come prepared for $100 for two people and come early!

zCf_XcFK1jvyba1Y8gicaQ.review_text: Apparently, SF locals enjoy Scoma's. I must say, I do too!  I had, hands down, the most savory bowl of clam chowder I've ever had. Plus, the bits of clam meat had only one or two grains of sand (or whatever gives that crunchy sensation while chewing) which is extra brownie points in my book.  Our lunch consisted of a seafood appetizer sampler, green salad, and the aforementioned chowder. The portions were ample, and the food was delicious (in a crisp, they-must've-got-this-seafood-this-morning kind of way). Heartily recommended for even part-time seafood enthusiasts.  As an aside, the ambiance in there was incredible. From the black and white photos of famous people to the cozy seating arrangements, you get the sense that Scoma's has been doing their thing (and doing it well) for a long time.  Expensive, but in my opinion, completely worth it.

YAG90mceVFQLdvl4wndvQg.review_text: + great food. calamari, desserts, pastas well cooked, fresh seafood  + great service + peaceful ambiance + along the water, tucked away from the touristy attractions

9y5NZGmt8fzE7AqEDuNhFg.review_text: my first time here was in 2005.  i was here because my best friend was graduating from UC Davis.  i had a lobster ravioli dish that i remember devouring, because it was really good.  fyi, portions are big here.  5 years later i come back, and decided to try the infamous lazy man's cioppino! excellent! great mix of seafood in really good broth.  will come back again.  remember, sharing is caring! even the pleasant waiter we had, was very happy that my boyfriend and i split the cioppino!

RrwGZpDaGoF_6FHIYvaSfA.review_text: Absolutely yummy! While in San Fran in Sept during Americas Cup with Mom for a getaway, I took her here for pasta. This is my 3rd visit and each time it's perfect. It was packed and we opted to wait for a table in the bar since it was going to be a long wait. Bar waitress had her hands full w customers but quickly came over and made sure we were settled in with bread and drinks before taking our dinner order. Everything on the menu is excellent, pasta or seafood. Aliotos is another of my favorites down on Pier 45 and they are equally as good but a different more formal type of atmosphere. 5 stars for Scomas!

Vr8wJBUdXhK-VvP3CmaYkQ.review_text: Now I'm very skeptical about anything in Fisherman's Wharf. It's THE tourist hot spot that every native avoids like the plague. Unfortunately I had to catch the F line down into the heart of the beast to retrieve a Xmas gift. After discovering the store was closed and I was on the verge of a hissy fit, my boyfriend suggested Scoma's.   This place was so good. Great wine selection. Only thing that keeps it from a 5 star is the fact that we were squeezed in so tightly. Still great food and worth checking out. The attire is between Casual and Dressy in true CA fashion.

mF17wzNM4qUyzoALrN8uwg.review_text: Excellent food, great location, fantastic waiters!

Mkp6wtAA8O5Rx53vNlIp6g.review_text: This is the place to go for fresh seafood in the city. Generous portions that usually require a take home box. The clam chowder and Calmari Fritti are great starters. You can't go wrong with the CALAMONE ALLA ANNA SHELLFISH SAUTÉ SEC as it is their most popular dish. However, I prefer the Petrale Dore or the Halibut. Scoma's is a family run restaurant and it shows with friendly and personal service. It can be pricey but you do get your money's worth, unlike other restaurant's in the city.

jsRjSlPZ67OR4YEgoucbtg.review_text: The first Dine About Town of the year was nearing a close, so a few of us decided to jump on it. Headed here upon a unanimous decision since their menu was the most appealing. Had the 2 course lunch with clam chowder and Pasta Garibaldi. The soup was chock full of clam. Loved it. Had close to high expectations for the 2nd course, but unfortunately had to lower them. The pasta consisted of linguine, mussels, salmon and sun dried tomato. Fantastic combination, however, the more appropriate name for the entree would have been Salmon Garibaldi. The ratio of fish to pasta was way off. I soon found myself playing hide n seek for the noodles after a few bites. My friend had ordered the same thing and she had way more pasta in hers than I did.  Whomp whomp whomp! Probably won't be back unless I'm willing to throw down on a meal here because their regular menu is a bit pricey.

-4KZG53kJd9YWderq_Om7w.review_text: Very good food and the service was performed by true professionals.  I had the crab/shrimp louie salad and it was so heaping I couldn't finish it. Great location and so much better than the chains and micro restaurants on the strip.

fgkJ6KUlrmbKyLDQervxsw.review_text: Scoma's remains my favorite seafood place in San Francisco, but my second visit wasn't as impressionable as my first. There's always a long wait at this place, but we were lucky this weekend and got a table within ten minutes. While waiting outside, we noticed that they now have a dinner prix-fixe menu, which makes a meal quite affordable in this economy. But after we were seated, the waiter actually removed the prix-fixe menu from our table - I'm not sure if that is regular, but isn't that the whole point of having the menu there? I ended up ordering the lazy man's cioppino after having the seafood saute previously.   We started with half a dozen oysters, but they weren't enjoyable because they weren't even shucked properly. I am by no means an oyster connoisseur, but every time I have had them, the meat was severed from the shell. It was a bit unexpected to try to eat them while they were still connected to the shell.  Despite that, they were still fresh and good, albeit a few grains of sand from the shell. As always, the mini crab cakes were great and didn't require any heavy breading. I also had a taste of the lobster bisque that was part of the prix-fixe and it was quite good. There was even bits of lobster, which were not very big, but a good portion for an appetizer from a prix-fixe. As for my cioppino, it was delicious as expected. Best cioppino I've ever  had and loaded with generous portions of fish, shrimp, crab, scallops, and more. What I enjoyed the most was ironically the buttered piece of toast dipped in the soup. It was delicious, but everything in the cioppino was amazing too. The serving size was so large, I couldn't even finish it all. I ended up trying to scoop all the seafood meat out and bypassing the soup.   I also tried the dessert portion and at that point I was too full to eat anything. That may have played a role in my disinterest in neither the cheesecake nor the bread pudding & tiramisu. Good food was had, but I could have had a better experience.

t9OAdJcdL3suwm0jsAzQEw.review_text: Service was awful this time. The food and prices were still good, given that we took advantage of Dine About Town. However, our server was ridiculously slow and inattentive. He only appeared maybe 4 times, and that was just to take our orders and drop off food. He never stopped by to check on our meal and how we were doing. There were many 5-10 minute gaps in the meal during which we sat there with empty plates. I watched many parties who were seated after us finish their meals and new parties take their place. Those parties then finished their meals at the SAME TIME as us, even though some of them were also doing DAT! I think that service at Scoma's is usually really good, but we just got a very lackadaisical server. I'm not sure why he was so slow, considering the fact that he can make more money in tips if he can move us quicker! And we weren't the only party in his section that suffered. There was a nice couple behind us who literally sat with their menus, ready to order, for about 15 minutes. They looked so bored...  We arrived at 6:40, were told 45 minute wait. We were called and seated by 7:25, so the accuracy of their wait time was much appreciated. However, we didn't get our food until 7:50, and we didn't get out the door until 9:30!!!! Talk about a slow, leisurely meal.  I'll probably still return, but I hope not to get seated in this guy's section again!  Oh and about the food:  - Crab cakes on watercress salad: Very tasty! I liked how the crab cakes were mostly crab and very little filler. I was able to share generous tastings with everyone else at the table.   I also sampled the lobster bisque (very rich!) and a bit of clam chowder. The complimentary sourdough bread is a great utensil for scooping up every bit of the soup!  - Scallops and linguine: You get 5 medium sized scallops on a bed of slightly too overcooked linguine topped with a large dollop of pesto. This dish was actually very large in size, which pleased me. It didn't have a ton of flavor though, and the scallops seemed slightly overdone. I had to add some pepper. I didn't finish this so I had enough to bring home for leftovers. It tasted pretty good the next day, but I was kind of appalled at how oily the sauce was. Must have been the pesto.  The lamp was slightly overcooked for medium rare, but I enjoyed the Parmesan polenta, caramelized onions, and sauteed spinach that were under it.   My dad said his halibut had been precooked and then reheated. He was VERY displeased with the texture, as the reheating was obvious from the mushy crust of the fish. He also said it was too salty.  - Tiramisu and sourdough bread pudding: Tiramisu was really good. The portion size of both was very generous. I liked the tiramisu a lot, but by then I was stuffed. The sourness of the bread and the sweetness of the bread pudding was a bit too much for me, so I didn't finish it.   The raspberry cheesecake with chocolate crust was SO. GOOD. I should have ordered that instead.  One thing I'll give to Scoma's is that they don't skimp on portion sizes, even for Dine About Town selections. And all the other plates I saw emerging from the kitchen were massive as well!  Corkage is $20.

oGiqow-Dt9IMepgkswdM4A.review_text: I came here for dinner with my boyfriend and we had my usual fav: the fried calamari - nothing really special about that. However they clam chowder was deliciously creamy! I ordered a grill fish, and you can tell it was fresh...but it was nothing spectacular.  My bf ordered the shellfish saute and we basically ate off his plate for the rest of the night! It had great flavor, perfectly cooked - and best of all - HUGE portions!  Next time I go back, I'm ordering a saute! YUM!

SBgBRz4ONPacMb7VfrWhxw.review_text: Service was slow, but they were still able to accommodate us early. The food was pretty good, but bland and the roast vegetables were soggy and flavorless. Steak was more on the well side than medium. Pricey, but a nice pier experience for the atmosphere.

_apCOddyBZBImQgGu3Hm7A.review_text: Found this place on Yelp when we were walking around. Cute little place tucked behind all of the other larger businesses (which we really liked). We were seated right away, had some deliciously fluffy bread, and had a decent view of the water. Our waiter, Salvatore, was really nice and professional (old school waitstaff).  We ordered a Hot Sampler Trio for Two ($26); it was a mix of Calamari Fritti, Rock Shrimp Scampi, and Crabcakes. BF had a Bloody Mary ($10).   The sampler was really tasty. The calamari fritti was perfectly crispy, the Crabcakes held together but were deliciously moist, and the shrimp scampi was perfectly cooked (and the sauce was great for bread dipping!) BF really liked his Bloody Mary as well!  Overall, great pricey little spot tucked away from the hustle and bustle of the wharf. We'd definitely be back.

asL1d04xS3y8YQtU5ota-g.review_text: Clam chowder with sour dough bread. So good. It's the best I've found in San Francisco. The portions are so large we usually split so my wife and daughter had the seafood cannelloni and they loved it. I had the pasta fisherman style with crab, shrimp, and mushrooms in a white sauce. It was pretty good. The service was really good and the server was nice. I love this place and we always try to go to this place every time I come to San Francisco.

g4R634Rgk_ivLeVJ8byupg.review_text: I was here during Fleet Week and I was in uniform. Therefore, I was treated "above average" during my visit. Beers were on the house as we waited 45 mins for our table. (Get the Liberty Ale.) The restaurant hooked us up with a cup of the chowder and it was definitely one of the best chowders I had. Chunky, thick and cream broth with flavor. The CLAMS were lacking though. I was going to order the Petrale, until I was told it was breaded and fried. The waiter, Andrew (who was awesome), recommended the Halibut. It was bar far the best seafood dish in the Bay Area. BY FAR! Service was great. One big negative: a bit price. $30+ for the halibut.  My boss had the filet mignon. He could've easily cut that steak with a butter knife. Very juicy too. Good job Al Scoma. RIP.

NO36epYec7wWtzrgkPRnzw.review_text: i came here this weekend for my graduation lunch and it was AMAZING! we all had the fixed lunch menu and we were all stuffed!   the pasta garibaldi was the best pasta i've ever had! the clam chowder was also the BEST WE'D ALL EVER HAD, huge chunks of clam in every bite!   the ambiance and our server, Sal,  was fun and had the classic look that made me feel like we were in a gangster movie :)   all in all, a THE BEST LUNCH EVER!

l35uoedk9e740vl9fwYRqg.review_text: I didn't realize that this was a must go to place while visiting San Francisco.  But thanks to Yelp and some friends I found my way there. We got there on the early side for lunch and had to wait for our entire party to be seated even though the place was empty.  It would of been nice to have been seated right away but obviously they don't do things that way here.   Once we were seated the service was good.  We all ordered the Crab Louie Salad and it was a huge salad and they really pile on the dungeness crab.   I would definitely recommend this place for lunch or dinner.

fct5IrXggFcrXFAZXs6coQ.review_text: One of my team members is commuting from Chicago. After a long workday, I asked what he was he'd like for dinner. He eagerly said seafood! This guy's never been to San Francisco, so as a surprise, we took him down to Fisherman's Wharf for dinner.   Driving into SF from the south close to sunset does offer some great views of the city and the bay bridge. Even in the early evening, the wharf was still busy with tourists and folks picking up some food on the way home. We parked on Embarcadero and proceeded to Pier 47.   Having visited to fisherman's wharf many times, I know enough to stay away from the tourist-trap restaurants that dominate FW. Behind the glamour, in a little alley, lies one of the true seafood meccas this fine city.   Scoma's is always buzzing with people. We arrived early evening and waited in the bar for our table. There are very few restaurants left where the bartenders still wore white tuxedos - it just gives this place a sense of class and decorum. The guys ordered beers and I started with a crisp Ferrari-Carano sauvignon blanc.   After about 25 minutes, our party was seated next to the window. We had a view of the day boat fisherman. It reminded me of that scene in Jaws when Roy Scheider looks at the boat he's going to hunt the shark and says "You're going to need a bigger boat."   We started off with the sampler appetizer that came with crab cakes, shrimp scampi and calamari friti. It was delicious and really got our appetites going. My coworkers ordered the fresh snapper and the salmon over crab raviolis. I simply ordered the steamed 1/2 crab it and was so fresh and sweet, it had me thinking I could have finished a whole crab!   The wait staff and servers were gracious, precise and early filled out water glasses and cleared away the dishes after every course. We ended the meal with espressos and the chef's special chocolate torte. It was made with bittersweet chocolate and was sinfully silky smooth. We ate heartily, laughed too loudly, was happily satiated and thoroughly enjoyed our time and dinner at Scomas.

CK-9yOBxEwXcS6efJM8lTg.review_text: A while back I ate at Scoma's and had an inconsistent experience, but since that time I recently returned and our dinner was much better.  I would go back again for the fresh seafood they are known for.

XRE7Np7TswBOrOnokO2nTA.review_text: Seriously people!?!? If you're allergic to any kind of seafood then don't go to a seafood restaurant!! DUH! I think you deserved the anaphylaxis because Scomas is the best seafood EVER. I would wait hours for this delicious meal. The waiters are top notch and treat you like royalty. The Saute Sec is to die for and the Crab salad with both thousand island and blue cheese is out of this world. The bread is probably the best bread you could ever get for free at a restaurant. The cheesecakes are all amazing and beautifully presented with a delicious drizzle of raspberry sauce. :-O

swmrfBnaqU0nyJ3pFBfNgQ.review_text: Playing tourist in my hometown and wanted good clam chowder.  It would have to be at Scoma's.  It wasn't crowded at all which was amazing.  I had a cup of the ocean filled clam chower, $9 and regretted not ordering the bowl and just having that for lunch. Got the fried calamari appetizer which is enough for 3 -4 persons, $14.  Couldn't even finish the entire plate and took it home which was devoured by Jr. Yelper.  Hubby had the open faced flank steak sandwich, $17.  Slices of steak over a garlic toast with a small salad and fries.  The fries were nice and crispy.  I thought the fried calamari was a bit too oily, needed to be drained a bit longer.    The waiter - Jean, was really friend and checked on us continuously. Service is always great here.  Forget the other touristy restaurants right on the main Wharf walkway.  Scoma's is where the food is especially the clam chowder - full of potatoes, clams in a thick, creamy broth.

j7Ew20Kh33lFEaUXW1rGNw.review_text: You can tell this place has been around forever, there are lots of celebrity pictures on the wall but I'm not sure how many of them are still alive! The view is good, you see right into the harbor. As others have said its probably overpriced but you're in SF.   The sourdough bread basket before the meal is excellent. I had the blackened salmon with mashed potatoes and vegetable of the day. The salmon was perfect, had some spice and the perfect balance between overlooked and too juicy for my liking. I will order this again. The mashed potatoes were good too. I wasn't a fan of the veggie, I don't like broccoli or cauliflower and the zucchini was a little overcooked.  If you are looking for a place with history that's on the wharf but not a glorified chain restaurant come check out Scoma's.

dVdXaBCmgT_DhbqQYNiaFw.review_text: Although this a touristy place on the pier, I still recommend it. I've been 2 times now and have had fantastic meals both times. The staff was very helpful in solving for a gluten-free meal and sent the chef out to work with us on it. The food is out of this world although a little pricey.

9nDOWUyYo2Oe5gq3x1DJFQ.review_text: Go here for the dine about town week! Totally worth every penny! Best meal I've had EVER.

GM9N1ImFP-xtpfAFtZ86Gw.review_text: Minus one star right off the bat because they don't take reservations. I mean I understand making the tourists wait, but what about locals that want to experience the place too? The bf and I showed up for dine about town last week on THURSDAY, they told us 35-40 minutes and 1 hour and 15 minutes later we were seated. By then there were tons of empty tables around so I am a little confused what took so long, especially on a weeknight.   Low ceilings, awkward staircases and limited window area do kindof give it the feel of a trailer home inside. I was definitely expecting something more impressive inside given their ideal location at the end of a pier. The bar area was crowded with everyone waiting for their table, and people were pushing by the whole time because it was a pathway. I was excited they had Gordon Biersch hefeweizen and another lighter beer places don't usually have on tap, so props to the bar.   The appetizers were definitely the best part of the meal. The crabcakes were melt in your mouth, and the caesar salad/ clam chowder combo was excellent as well. Long wait for the main course though, and I was pretty frustrated by then so picking apart an entire crab by hand was not exactly what I had in mind. Would have been useful for the menu to spell out what kind of crab was coming on my pasta. Very oily penne, but overall delicious, if someone else had been cracking the crab for me. Just felt like every bite was spit out a piece of shell, wipe butter off my hands, repeat.. The bf's tuna was the best I've ever tasted tuna, since apparently it's super hard to cook exactly right. The raspberry cheesecake for dessert was a little bit of a letdown, definitely dry and cakey and somewhat tasteless.   Our server Sonny apparently didn't speak too much English and got our check wrong twice. Not a fun experience on that end. Overall service was slow and not too attentive. I think maybe we got our water refilled once, by someone else.   Overall a tasty and unique dine about town experience, never to be repeated on a normal night since it's wayyy out of our price range.

G9TiLsiIbc6o_FM4F96_Ig.review_text: I went to Scoma's last night with some friends for the first time on the recommendation of one of the girls in my party.  We arrived at 6:15 and had to wait 30 minutes which I didn't think was too bad for a Saturday night in that area.    The bar and restaurant areas were extremely loud so I don't recommend going if you want an intimate setting (or don't like to yell).  We brought in our own bottle of wine and they were kind enough to open, and decant, it for us while we waited for our table.  Corkage is $20 but we ordered a second bottle during dinner so our waiter waived the fee for us.  We split the cold seafood app for 2 - $25 - which came with 2 oysters, 2 clams, 4 prawns and 4 pieces of crab.  I thought this was pretty reasonable and the prawns were delicious!  For entrees, two of us ordered the swordfish and one ordered the snapper.  All entrees were served with garlic mashed potatoes and sauteed veggies.  I passed on the potatoes and the veggies were your standard carrot/broccoli/cauliflower combo and just so-so.  The swordfish was cooked perfectly and just melted in my mouth.  The entrees seemed a bit high, starting around $30 for pretty much everything but it makes sense when you factor in the location.  We also had 3 desserts, Vanilla Cheesecake, Apple Crisp and Lemon Tart.  All were good but the Lemon Tart was the winner.  Our waiter was very attentive and didn't leave us waiting too long in between visits to check on us.  The decor was a bit 'old-men's club' but maybe that's just because we were in a room with pictures of all sports memorabilia.    Overall it was a good experience...just give a 3 for the noise level, elevated prices and older decor.

jBMtAP37MR9Kk--iiooqjw.review_text: It's on the pier, but views of the bay are limited. The fishing boats and SF hillsides at night are lovely, though. We were seated at a table that received a big draft of cold air every time the doors opened, which wasn't comfortable. On the other hand, the food was delicious, prepared to order, and the wait staff were friendly and observant. Children (at other tables) were made welcome, and that is nice to see. A little overpriced, I think, but bayside property (even on a pier) must be pricey, too. They're forgiven. Go for the fresh seafood! It's wonderful.

F_5_UNX-wrAFCXuAkBZRDw.review_text: Scoma's was pretty much everything I expected out of a seafood restaurant at Fisherman's Wharf.  That is both good and bad in terms of the whole dining experience where you'll know that the seafood is fresh, but because you're in the touristy part of town, service can be mediocre and prices are much higher than other similar restaurants in other parts of the city. I started off with a cup of Clam Chowder and got to try the Crab Cakes shared with the table.  The Chowder was good and loaded with clams.  Likewise, the Crab Cakes from were loaded with crab and were pretty plump and breaded nicely. For my main course I was in the mood for Scallops, so I went with the Shrimp and Scallops alla Gannon --  bit.ly/UeiuOO Well, there's not much to say about this one.  It's simply pan seared scallops and shrimp with steamed veggies and mashed potatoes.  It was good, but it wasn't mind-blowing enough for me.  At least it took care of my craving for Scallops. Our server, while he got the job done, was pretty unenthusiastic.  His tone of voice was pretty ho-hum and sounded like he was just trying to get through the service with  no enthusiasm whatsoever.  It was kind of a shame, but there were no issues with our orders and we were checked on regularly. I don't know what much else there is to say about Scoma's.  The seafood was definitely fresh and the portion sizes were pretty generous, but I thought the food was pretty overpriced for what you get.  Well, the bright side is that they have plenty of tables, so if you have a big group to feed and happen to be around the Fisherman's Wharf area, Scoma's would be good enough to handle that.

-g_eXoAVe3fIUPJlIYvw6w.review_text: Extremely disappointed. Seafood was not fresh. Steamed clams undercooked, crab cakes bland, Lobster Thermidor not browned properly. Coffee burned, not fresh. Would not recommend to anyone. No excuse for an old school restaurant. What has happened? With all the great restaurants in SF, there is no excuse!

bwZn44lANLGt4zI4jRiQcA.review_text: Hands down the freshest seafood I've had in the US.  My family tried the swordfish, the shrimp & scallops, crab risotto, and the lobster ravioli... All were to die for.

3lAWNEEejSRbyh7SqCKBFw.review_text: I've been to Scoma's twice and each time I find something new which I love about the restaurant.  We decided to go yesterday since it was the start of the crab season.   The news reports weren't kidding.  Crabs are small this year but no worries Scoma's did an excellent job of preparing the crab.  We ordered the sampler platter and roasted crab to share.  I ordered the butternut squash & crab soup and the Pasta Alla Scoma.  The Pasta Alla Scoma was DELICIOUS!   Incredibly fresh and not heavy on the butter.  The butternut squash & crab soup was definitely something to pass on.  I could make better butternut squash soup at home.    The staff at Scoma's were very attentive and I have to say, the Valet for the day was awesome.  He saw us heading to the restroom and decided to have the waiting and started for us.  Talk about good customer service.  If you're ever at Fisherman's Warf, Scoma's is the place to stop.

saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q.review_text: San Francisco Treat!  This should be their moniker, not that darn Rice-a-Roni!  There's not many restaurants that draws both locals and tourists alike.  My friends invited me to dinner here on a Friday night.  The valet parking is free, but please remember to tip your valet person as a courtesy.  This is a "no reservations" dining spot, so it pays to show up early, especially on weekends.  We waited about ten minutes, which gave me time to study their menu posted outside the front door.  We were led past the bar area to an upper level dining room and seated at a cozy booth.  I had a clear view of the parked fishing boats that reminded me of childhood PAL salmon fishing trips.  My dilema was to choose between the Cioppino and the three-course prix fixe menu for $39.95.  I chose the latter and opted for the following choices: Appetizer 1) Double Play (1/2 portion of Caesar's salad and 1/2 cup portion of New England Clam Chowder) - Salad was tasty and perfectly seasoned.  The clam chowder was creamy with small clam chunks.  Decent, but not my personal best.(yelp.com/biz_photos/jqEp…) Entree 2) Grilled Giant Freshwater Prawns with Linguini - Two nicely grilled prawns topping a generous linguini portion mixed with tomato chunks, olive oil, and pesto.  Liked that the pesto was spooned to one section so I could mix it to my liking. (yelp.com/biz_photos/jqEp…) Dessert 3) Tiramisu and Bread Pudding - The Tiramisu was rich and creamy and the bread pudding was cleaner tasting and gooey.  Good contrast in flavors here. It was a mixed crowd with after-work co-workers, tourist couple and families, and older couples.  For those who grew up in the City, it's a bit of a Back to the Future experience.  Our waitress was efficient and friendly and the staff made sure our water glasses were full.  The valet was extremely nice and parked my vehicle near the entrance.  Regarding the Cioppino, they also offer a "Poor Man's" version where they remove the shells from the crab (it's pricier which goes against my thrifty conscience).  The cuisine is a nice mix of North Beach and seafood, packaged in a touristy neighborhood.  The business celebrated a recent 45th anniversary last week and gave an additional $5.00 on the above menu.  Darn, didn't make it back in time to catch that discount.

j0aLNLDM0H5CiUbduni-BA.review_text: I've only been to this place once and that was over a year ago on Valentine's Day.  I'm not sure if it was in fact a valet service they provided but they did take my friend's car the minute we pulled up so that was pretty cool. I don't think they take reservations and it was Valentine's Day so I believe we ended up waiting a little over an hour. The wait didn't seem long though, since we were having good conversation but anyway, once we were seated, that's when the real magic happened.  I don't remember exactly what we ordered but I'm almost positive we ordered the Valentine's special which was basically a complete meal for two. I'm sad that I don't even remember what we had but I do know it was delicious. The presentation of our meal was not anything too over the top but it was one of those dishes you didn't wanna touch just yet. The service is what you would expect from a place like Scoma's; our server was very attentive and quick to refill our drinks, which is something I always notice when dining. She also made a clear effort to check on us to make sure everything was fine. The ambiance of this place is nice and the perfect place to take someone special.   I also love how this place is located by Fisherman's Wharf so after dinner, you can take a nice walk and enjoy the view and weather. Scoma's is pretty classy so if you don't feel like spending much, I wouldn't recommend taking a date here but if you know me, I better be worth it to bring here, haha! No but really, this place is dope and I'd love to come back. So.. who's taking me?

e4iL_C8j1MwZE3wFxh-WZA.review_text: Just plain insanely good. Fresh, flavorful, superb. Our server Gus made the evening that much better. Their calamari appetizer was the best. I had the shellfish (lobster, shrimp, crab and scallops) with rice, pasta and vegetables. The amount of shellfish was outstanding. My husband had the scallop special. Worth every penny! Avoid the silly chain restaurants that serve boring same old, and come to this charming establishment that serves true seafood cuisine.

ij1EkydgfT0fopex9SpKLA.review_text: For my anniversary dinner with the SO, we were in SF for the day and wanted to eat somewhere with GOOD seafood. So of course I turn to Yelp and this place pops up as number one. I skimmed through some reviews and they all looked pretty promising.   So we parked at one of the lots by Joe's Crab Shack and decided to go there on foot so we could browse or sightsee on the way over. When we got to the restaurant we saw there was free valet parking, so you can imagine our annoyance with ourselves... Especially since it was quite a cold and windy night. Oh well, next time we'll know.  They had a prix fixe menu that offered a choice of appetizer soup, an entree, and then a dessert. He had the Lobster Bisque, I had the Organic Butternut Squash with Creme Fraiche and Toasted Pumpkin Seeds. I preferred his soup, but mine wasn't bad either. For my entree, I had the Broiled Prawns on Linguine Pomodoro w/  3 Wild Gulf Prawns, Fresh Tomato, Garlic, and Basil. He had the Broiled Swordfish with White Beans, Swiss Chard, and Pancetta. It looked like a small portion for someone with a big appetite like he has, but later he said it was the right size and he was comfortably full instead of stuffed. My pasta was okay, I think I got jipped and should have had 4 prawns according to some others experiences on here, LOL. Anyway. For dessert he had the Tiramisu w/ Sourdough Bread Pudding Duo, and I had the Walnut Brownie and Triple Espresso Ice Cream w/ Caramel Sauce.  Anyway, the service was just meh. I mean, our waiter wasn't rude to us or anything, but he seemed to be chumming it up with every table BUT ours, serenading two Bronx lady tourists with some Sinatra,  joking with some silver-haired group of women having their 40 year school reunion at the restaurant. He would check on us to see how we were doing, if we needed any refills, but that was pretty much it. Because of that I can't really give this place 5 stars just yet.

ZEGyf9O7GyYzJOqbhbSY9g.review_text: A local recommended this restaurant to us and we are glad he did. It is tucked away a bit so unless you were looking for it you probably wouldn't find it. It sits right on the water and has a "rustic" feel to it.   The wait staff was friendly and professional, and the food was quite good. The clam chowder was a little thick for my liking, but the entrees were fresh and perfectly prepared. We had the Atlantic halibut and Washington salmon, both of which were caught fresh that day.

mCPFtnc86xif2DwE80CVOQ.review_text: We come to San Francisco at least once a year and always dine at Scoma's.  Best seafood in Sanfrancisco. Service has always been great, the food as good as it gets, and the experience is always wounderful.

2FcK7DJLcFybpa1lwlrA1g.review_text: Scoma's is really nice experience along the water. My friend had the Lobster Newberg which is creamy and perfect. I had the white fish which was good as well. They run a terrific lunch special here, which includes entree and dessert for $25. The location in Sausilito does not run the lunch special.

KqynXAy4trNllprNCZqA9Q.review_text: I came here for the first time the other day and had a great experience. The lobster bisque and garlic roasted dungeness crab were delicious. However, our favorite part of the meal was dessert - Jack Daniel's bread pudding. It is TO DIE FOR! So amazing that we came back two days later just for dessert because we couldn't stop thinking about it. A little pricey, but worth it. We plan to go back soon and try their prix fixe lunch menu which looked good.

Zwh3xuj4XA8d-1ydC5QV9g.review_text: We were a group of five traveling together and everyone loved this restaurant...the setting, the waiter, and THE FOOD! We were there on a Wednesday evening, off season, so there was no wait, but if necessary we would wait the next time just to eat here again.

Do2_cOmcD75d9yv70lW6TQ.review_text: Whoa! That's what comes to mind whenever I think about Scoma.  I've been fortunate to try out a whole bunch of restaurants and good eats.. but only once in awhile does a restaurant make an everlasting impression in my head.. and Scoma is one of the places that has done so.  I had the Dungeness Crab Risotto... one of the most delicious things I've ever had in my life.  The risotto was so rich in flavors and well balanced.  The amount of Dungeness crab was great too.  A friend of mine got the whole roasted cracked dungeness crab.  It was cooked amazingly with olive oil, garlic, and fresh lemon.  I was impressed with both dishes, and I'm excited to try out other menu items in the future!

3__GPsOrC9FSkxzbV5l6fQ.review_text: Call in before you come for dinner, if you can. This place was packing at 5pm on a Saturday evening. Casual formal dress but jeans ok.  Ordered clam chowder and Hot sampler trio platter for two, and, of course, the cioppino. Hostess was not very hospital but the waitress served with a smile. Han min was her name and she treated us very well. Making sure we were comfortable and our food came on time. First the appetizer and then our meal. So the food was always hot and right on time. Like a meal is supposed to be! Our main course was slow in coming out. But there was a bit of a mix up in the kitchen. Mistake made with my cioppino. Brought me a delicious looking scallop in some cream sauce with penna pasta. Looked good! Just apologies and nothing much for that. Didn't get to keep the pasta. XD Sun was another server who helped us out. Made sure our water glasses were always full. Grated pepper on our pastas and cheese... He was a bit abrupt though. All service, no smile.  This is a great sit down restaurant for sitting and /enjoying/. The food comes in a timely manner and one course after another. A perfect date spot to enjoy each other's company with good food and a good view.   Eat slow and dont order too much. Large servings of perfectly cooked seafood.  A for sure anniversary spot for me and Der Boif.

GupZ7GAIqdiaoRm_PyMdSA.review_text: I had the pasta with salmon and shrimp + creamy sauce. My gf had the baked salmon and lobster on ravioli. My pasta was meh but she was very satisfied with her dish. Considering how classy the restaurant is, the price was okay. The restaurant is conveniently located on the dock so it was surrounded by water and all the boats. Romantic night, if not for an argument we had by the end of the dinner :( but the server was nice enough to joke around and lighten up the mood, so +1 star for that :D

Ieh-Swex83RqQvdmehLStQ.review_text: This place was exceptional. We were VERY LUCKY walking in for a table of 3 about 20 seconds before about 20 people came in. This place does not take reservations so you could be stuck outside on the peer or at the bar for a while waiting for a table.  Luckily we were sat quickly. Ordered mussels, clams, roasted crabs and the seafood saute. All of it was delicious.  Our waitress was very polite and attentive. I would definitely head back here! It is pricey but if you want some good crab...it's worth it!

jF8nR8Iqhq7oHOl1m_yXyg.review_text: ABOVE AND BEYOND THE HYPE!!!!!!  Amazing. So glad this was much better than anticipated. Very cool inside. Old celeb photos on the wall are very cool. Staff is beyond professional. Timing, personality and just impressive. Extra points that they serve their own branded mini tabasco bottles with the meal.  Started off with raw clams on the half shell and some corn and crab chowder. Clams were the best I've ever had. Even the cocktail sauce stands out here. The chowder was a little bland for what I was expecting. I'm from Boston and a snob with chowder, so I'll let it go. Now the cioppino, is best of the best. It was beyond perfect and can't imagine anyone that can ever make it better. When I'm requesting my last meal, it will be Scoma's cioppino.

9GKxUjDShDDTcQjhs3i_fA.review_text: I can't find a reason not to give Scoma's five stars--other than maybe its appearance. It's absolutely amazing. The service is above and beyond, at least every time I've ever gone. I usually end up with a seasoned waiter that's nearly old enough to be my Grandpa, but they sure love what they do and what they recommend is absolutely mouth watering. My favorite was a white sauce pasta with prawns that was paired with the most amazing glass of wine. For what you pay and the quality it is surprising how generous the portions are. If you have the opportunity, you should definitely give Scoma's a try. What makes it even better is not only the atmosphere the views as well.

FDzNNaxpAg9uuGBk2MqtEA.review_text: DELICIOUS AND FILLING!!!   Our first time here, my husband and I...and we absolutely loved it. We were celebrating our 10 years together :)   - Found metered-parking easily. Probably because we arrived after 8p...and it's a Thursday. Note: meter is cheaper after 7pm. Though, I believe the restaurant offers complimentary valet parking.  - Place was packed, but NO WAIT luckily.   OUR FOOD:  * Calamari Fritti $14 Our starter. Squid was fresh. Probably won't be ordering this on our next visit (if just us 2) cause we couldn't finish it and it got us kind of full. I think I'm just sick of calamari, honestly. Feeds 3-4.  * Seafood Salad (Smoked Salmon, Prawns, Dungeness Crabmeat, Bay Shrimp) $33  This is actually an entree, but we ordered to split. This is what you call seafood salad! The prawns were HUGE! Take a look at picture #4; 1st one on the left. Hella crabmeat and the salmon blanketed the salad. The best seafood salad ever! It also had anchovies and olives, btw. People all around us just kept staring at it! Couldn't finish this one either, so our server bagged it up to go. As a side salad, this feeds 4-5, maybe 6!  * Lobster Newburg Alla Scoma $36 HUGE! Loved it! Lobster toppling off the side of the shell and topped with melted Provolone cheese (for you cheese lovers, this is a MUST-HAVE). Very flavorful! Entree included sides of veggies, wild rice, and penne pasta sprinkled with parmesan.   * Lobster Thermidor Alla Scoma $36 Also huge! My husband ordered this and enjoyed it. It's just like my order above, only that it's topped with Hollondaise sauce instead of cheese.   * Tiramisu $9  Loved it! It had the cutest presentation! Served as if it were a large mug of cappuccino...with an all-chocolate spoon in the middle. Oh, there was cookie stick on the side, too. Feeds 2-3.   * Coffee $3 (with unlimited refills) Fresh!   Oh, I almost forgot - we also each had a glass of wine :)   DISLIKE: Our seating. We were in the middle of a section where the tables were TOO close together. It felt like we were seated with a party of 12. There was however, an entertaining moment; a 40+ year old man at the table next to us singing Flo Rida's, Low. :D  BILL: Pricey! But we were celebrating :) Total + tip came out to $192. but as you can see, we ordered everything...AND we have leftovers for breakfast! By the way, we couldn't finish our lobster either. Tim (our server) was EXCELLENT and each dish was served when WE were ready. Water and coffee were refilled without being asked.   We love this place and will definitely be back!

1P9BpFZ_d3PGCdytDTYJCw.review_text: My friends and I went to Scoma's for a nice seafood restaurant out on the wharves, and we had a great experience.  The atmosphere is nice and trendy, the service is solid and friendly, and the restaurant is efficient.  Scoma's offers everything you want from a popular restaurant, except solid seafood.  The prices are extremely steep, and Scoma's counters that with ridiculous portion sizes.  They like to support the "sustainable" fish movement.  Unfortunately, with the simple preparations and single levels of flavors, I would like a bit smaller portions with more depth of flavor.  My cioppino stew was definitely a hearty dish.  Even at $32, it provided an enormous amount of seafood and an overly buttered slice of bread.   There was probably about 2 fish fillets, 20 baby shrimp, 4 large shrimp, 8 scallops, and 5 clams.  Oh, and there was definitely a half crab in there, which I picked myself in order to save $3!  If I was a starving fisherman, it would no doubt have satisfied, but the flavors were very one-dimensional.  It was basically marinara over seafood.  Way too tomatoey.  I had a few bites of my friends' scallop dishes, and they definitely gave generous portions.  The scallop risotto was not bad, but it lacked a certain freshness.  The sauteed scallops were somewhat ordinary and merely served over rice.  Scoma's is a great restaurant for a night out on the pier, but if you are truly looking for seafood, go into some of the more refined seafood joints.  This one is more about packing customers in than the food, and it is very pricey.

5X-oZmluK1w6dc57b2JSxA.review_text: Saturday night, date night with my man.. a lovely cool, foggy evening.. we headed to Scoma's for a grown up evening out.   Scoma's is the type of place that takes you back in time. I walk in and expect to find my grandma wearing a lovely dress and gloves.. the way she looked and dressed in the late 1960's.   Scoma's is old school. The decor is right out of the 70's. The servers almost could wear their uniforms for Halloween. However, old school is GOOD. The service is excellent! Servers are friendly, attentive, appear at regular intervals without being intrusive. They don't rush you. They know EVERYTHING about the vast menu. This is an old fashioned restaurant with old fashion customer service. I LOVE IT!   We arrived to a find a crowded pier and crowded restaurant. It's Saturday evening, who cares! We put our name in and head to the bar after being told it would be only be a 10-15 minute wait. We stood at the bar for less than a minute, didn't even have time to order our drinks, and they called our name. What? The place is packed and they're calling us already? Yippey!   The food is soo good. All the fish is fresh, fresh, fresh and also wild caught (no farmed fish here). The chefs have the knack of cooking everything to perfection so even the super meaty fish arrives tender and moist. Food arrives HOT and portions are generous.   Mr. started out with a prawn cocktail. He couldn't decide between the prawns or the baby shrimp. When our server brought him his prawn cocktail, she included a small portion of the baby shrimp so he could taste the difference. Very nice touch!   I started out with a mixed green salad with a side of their delish anchovies. Mmmm.. Fresh and cold and tasty! Their Blue Cheese is heavenly.   Mr. had the Cajun salmon which was cooked perfectly and very moist and flavorful. I went for broke and got the lazy man's chippino. So good! I loved the garlic bread that came with it. I could have easily just gone for the bread dipped in the chippino sauce. MMM...   Do you want to know a secret? Shh.. come closer and I'll whisper it.. they have FREE valet parking! Yes, that's right, the best deal in town. You pull up to the door, hop out of the car and hand the keys to the attendant. Be nice, give him $5 or $10 when you come back to get your car. It's the best deal in town and easy to do (if you don't get caught in a traffic jam coming down Al Scoma Way).   This was our third time having dinner at Scoma's. We'll be back for a fourth, and a fifth, and a ...

D2epirooWNjvwTI6MFhNGw.review_text: I have a confession. I was born and raised in San Francisco. Still live in San Francisco. I've never been to Alcatraz.  You know what else?  I didn't eat at Scoma's until this year.  SHAME ON ME.   First thing to note: great service. Waiters are super cool and chill yet professional.  Great view of the water and the docks.   They have a pre fix lunch for I think it was $25 but oh lord somebody really should have warned me that it is a MASSIVE amount of food that you get! My friend ordered an appetizer sampler from the regular menu. i tried not to eat too much since we both had the pre fix.  For my pre fix meal I had  clam chowder - heaping amounts of clams in it, definitely fresh. tasty.   pasta - I forgot what exactly it was called but it was linguini with fresh mussels and salmon. Boy they do not skimp on the amount of seafood they give you! Really really tasty but I was barely able to finish half.   chocolate cake - too rich for me and I just don't like chocolate (I know, I know. What girl DOESN'T like chocolate!?!? Yea yea, well THIS ONE does not like chocolate so live with it)  My friend had the salad that had a mountain of crab meat and shrimp on it. That seems to be one of the most popular items ordered there because I kept seeing plate after plate of that being served up.   I'd definitely come back for some crab.

pJEOLjW9O99SLISSFRueHg.review_text: We were very very disappointed in our recent meal at Scoma. We have eaten there before and it was average, but this time is was just poor. The crab risotto was very very tasteless, full of chewy slimy mushrooms and slight on the crab. My wife got the fish of the day and very underwhelming overall for the cost.   We have eaten at much better places for much less and there are certainly options in San Fran that I would suggest you consider.  This unfortunately was just an awful meal and the chatter from the table next to us was similar. Look elsewhere.

RQj4Lf2yfWyUaOgn8FhuDQ.review_text: alwyz LUVD scomas. used to come here all the time when i lived in sf. came back on a visit to sf over the weekend and ordered their famous cioppino to go (thats all i ever order frm here). before, when id order it to go, theyd make it the same way as if id ordered it when dining in. but this time? SOOO DISAPPOINTED! totally gypped me! there wuz nth in there except for a lil bit of seafood and tomato paste! and the portion? wayyy smaller! had to come home and add my own vegetables and more seafood and recooked it. SUGGESTION: DONT ORDER TO GO! total rip-off! trust me. paid $40 for a lousy cioppino that i had to re-make myself anywyz!

me3msnteOfLhtroz02Zfbw.review_text: A friend recommended this for happy hour: great deals in bar and lounge with $5 appetizers 4:30-6:00 Monday-Friday. The crab cakes were wonderful, capped off with a bit of a delectable Caesar garnishment. We also had the fried oysters and torpedo shrimp. Definitely worth a return visit.

a0e_V4wvBCa2yTnrfavcCA.review_text: I loved this place and will definitely go back!  I saw it on TV and it looked really good.   A couple of my cousins ordered the lamb that was in the Prix Fixe menu and it was delicious!!  My brother got the smoked salmon and shrimp Alfredo and that was pretty good too.  I had the dungeness crab risotto and that too was also pretty good.  It's hard to describe in words how good I thought the food was here.  I think you should just go try it out for yourself!  Oh, and there is free Valet parking!!

a4r7b9qJI_1HwfVul-ns5A.review_text: This place is a cute little gem tucked away from Fisherman's Wharf. You can't see it from the main street, so you have to know it's there.  At about 5pm on Memorial Day, there was already a good crowd in the dining room. We only had to wait about 10 minutes for a table for 4. My mom and I split the seafood sauté, my sister got the prawn risotto, and my dad got the fettuccini with smoked salmon and shrimp. We all got some of their famous clam chowder, also. Their portions are quite large, so I'm glad I split my place with my mom. Even so, I didn't even finish all the pasta, and was still full!  The chowder was creamy, but not too rich. It did have potatoes (not a big fan), but also a hearty helping of clams. My seafood was cooked to perfection with a mini lobster tail, shrimp, scallops, and crab leg meat. The sauce was also quite good and light, without being overbearing in flavor. I also liked that the rice (pilaf?) soaked up all the juices.  Our waitress was also very personable and nice!   Fresh seafood and great service! Their prices are a bit on the high side, but it is Fisherman's Wharf, so it's to be expected.

JgzsbQFK07qkCMM9yvribQ.review_text: We loved this cozy restaurant. We were seated quickly but our waiter was able to get us a table by the window. The scallops were excellent and the menu had too many choices based on all of the wonderful entrées we saw around us. Can't wait to give it a try next time we are on the wharf.

rtxK0K7zOtMxLx6nKbNsCA.review_text: I love this restaurant, very old school San Francisco. The seafood is some of the best in the city and beware, the portions are huge. We also end up with extra to take home. I've had their pastas, soups, salads, and sautees and they are all worth the trek and the price. When I want good seafood in San Francisco this is where I go.

tmWzlxp-l8Zbo8zN011AZQ.review_text: I lived in the city many years ago and Scoma was my favorite restaurant. It hasn't changed nThe cioppino was great. The bread was delicious.I couldn't ask for a better meal. If you are anywhere near fisherman's wharf for lunch or dinner this is the place to go.

a0t6NAiwBK6yic02Hu8PHw.review_text: Went in around 5 pm with a party of 12 (6 of them kids) and after a short 10 minute wait we were seated.  Our server, Jean Marc, was very knowledgable, friendly and attentive.  The food was excellent with generous portion sizes.  I highly recommend this place and will definitely come here again the next time I'm in SF.

1BPcBErfYKyNoY5OHaptyg.review_text: I thought they loss their way in regard to the food prep when I dined there a few years, ago.  They're back!  Great food, attentive service and an overall pleasant experience.

Py4uSNauadyXKMxMm2Ty-w.review_text: Boyfriend treated me to a romantic dinner here and omg what an amazing chef they have! Worth every cent and more! Not only was the ambiance nice but looking out into the water from our table was beautiful! Had the lobster ravioli and omg, each ravioli was like heaven. The taste was so rich that I still remember it perfectly. It might be pricey but so worth it! The food in volume was not filling but in taste filled me for a while. I thoroughly enjoyed our meal and bottle of wine, my boyfriend who tends to be very stoic about everything was actually very impressed. I'm hella picky and really don't like spending tons of money on mediocre food. So this place definitely came through and more.

zldraWSIjkbDFFdDezGluA.review_text: I've been eating at Scomas for about 20 years and can always depend on a wonderful dinner and great service.  Always a winner.  My wife and I eat there regularly and were never let down.

ZH2BsTXtOrzgNLFGDFsogA.review_text: I have been to Scoma's multiple times, with a large group, with a small group, and alone.  I really like this place.  To me, it best captures the spirit of good seafood in San Francisco.  The restaurant is situated on the end of a pier on Fisherman's Wharf.  You can drive out to the end, and they will valet park your car.  The motif is classic, nostalgic, withe celebrity photos.  The menus contains a great selection of fresh seafood items.  There are great appetizers, salads and entrees.  I literally have never had anything bad here.  Service is great.  I can hear Tony Bennett singing "I Left My Heart in San Francisco" in the background.  I recommend this place to all my friends who are visiting San Francisco.

17e5W0HaRJ2kgQApt_5wHw.review_text: The steamed clams were amazing, and the clam chowder was delicious. There is balance in their dishes. The ingredients are simple and straightforward (garlic, onions, clams), but the execution and taste in your mouth is to die for. Better seafood here than anywhere else in the city, including Crustaceans.

h0jCr72NLkdGTNQmPuWp0A.review_text: TLDR: - Vibe over food. - Wait is long, likely because of novelty factor. It's on a dock by the sea with cool decor. - Service is good. Hectic crowd. - Cioppino yummy, but typical. - Halibut dish was filling and satisfying, but fish was erring on tough and overcooked. Muddy sides. - Price-unworthy and tad overhyped. Would rather spend money elsewhere for better.

mD8T6tegVU9v06osh8W2sA.review_text: I wouldn't say the views are all that rad since the break wall is right in front of the location but they aren't too shabby.  We popped in for a beer which was priced cheaper than expected and the bartenders were very nice and hospitable.   We checked out the menu and the pricing is about the average rate for higher end seafood restaurants.   I'd like to come back in for some grub.  And if you are interested they do valet parking in the back.

42eVIq32kZAnGndSUSLOng.review_text: Terrible service, long waits, way overpriced.  We were here for the week, we read the reviews on yelp and excitedly walked from our hotel to visit this highly rated location.  We came in and had a seat at the bar waiting for our name to be called. The bartender and waitress proceeded to fight with not a care in the world that we were there. They continued to bicker over the next 30 minutes or so. We would have left to find another place but as grouchy as that bartender was he did make a good margarita. We are from San Antonio so that is saying a lot.  Finally seated my girlfriend and I ordered an appetizer and another round of drinks. Things were going great and this review would likely have been three stars had we stopped there but when it came time for the main course everything fell apart.   Our waitress was very difficult to find. Only the guy that refills the water was ever seen. The risotto was 33 dollars and terrible. It was watery, bland, and did I mention $33....  If you absolutely want to eat here get a margarita, and lobster bisque. Eat somewhere else for your entree. It was our only bad experience in our entire gorgeous vacation to San Francisco.

YRDq2RwMO6VMIoXDIN5l8A.review_text: Best Seafood place- service was great and the food was awsome! It was packed when we went but that was to be expected- the food was BOMB!

pzyKIwEUp8axXqlRCUUfqg.review_text: We were wandering the wharf and trying to find something not completely overpriced and lousy. Seriously, who goes to Joe's Crab Shack in a city like San Francisco??   After much Yelp checking and rejection (by myself - I was fussy for some reason) we landed at Scoma, a totally old school restaurant that reminded me of the restaurants that used to exist in Trenton back in the day. Waiters that have been working there for 40 years, wood decor and pictures of celebrities who have graced their presence over the years.  Service was ... good. We felt ignored at times and our waiter never told us the specials which every other table around us were told. I ordered the broiled salmon with mashed potatoes and vegetables. The salmon was HUGE and very good. The mashed potatoes were lumpy and bland and the vegetable was broccoli which I don't like. My three star review is based on my meal only. T got the lazy man's cioppino and I think it was one of his favorite meals while we were there. I'm pretty sure this is a case where I ordered wrong which is disappointing. But there you go. Oh, and it was ex-pensive. At least no one left hungry ...

8TQ4QWrbS6nKvQAjvQMbug.review_text: Don't be taken in by the other places at Fisherman's Wharf, and for heaven's sake don't go to Joe's Crab Shack.  This place was pricey but delicious.  I arrived for lunch alone and in very casual clothing, but was treated kindly and given the same excellent service as the people who were dressed up.   It seems to be a place where employees  come and stay for a long time. I had great conversations with both the Valet Manager and the server (Sean).  I didn't want the lobster bisque to end...and I did find some lobster in there (sorry, other Yelper).  The prawn cocktail was fresh and it was a generous portion (although it was 17 bucks).  The garlic dungeness crab was delicious as well. Sean tied my bib on for me and gave me a quick refresher tutorial on how to use the crab tools.  After I was through, I was given lemon wedges and a hot towel (eating that crab was a little messy).     I do not believe they take reservations, although the full menu is served all day.  The Valet Manager advised me that it gets VERY busy during the dinner rush.  Have a big lunch or an early dinner and make this place your splurge meal in SF

Eva274V0UhvqY4owmBEu9w.review_text: Okay, if a friend or relative comes into town and says they want to spend the day in San Francisco as a tourist, the next thing out of their mouths is usually Fisherman's Wharf.  Being a native California girl, I grew up with my Dad taking us to FW every time anyone new would come to town.  We'd wander the streets in search of that perfect bowl of chowder and some fresh crab.  Now it's my turn to play host and secretly I'm excited anytime I get this opportunity.  It brings back all of those childhood memories and let's me eat some really terrific food.  But now that the pocketbook is a bit bigger, instead of just browsing the chowder vendors, we make a special lunch trip to Scomas for some truly fantastic food and great service.  They have lunch specials that are under $20 that Hubby and Sis tried.  Sis had the Crab and Shrimp Louie and said she had never seen a Louie with so much seafood on it.  Piles of fresh shellfish that was stunningly delicious.  Hubby had the Fish & Chips, but wasn't crazy about them.  I had the Salmon and Shrimp Alfredo which had a light and lovely sauce that wasn't too heavy and really hit the spot.  Delicious!  The wine list is packed full of fabulous wine to go along with everyone's meal and we enjoyed a fine bottle of red.  So the next time a friend comes to town and asks to play tourist at Fisherman's Wharf, don't cringe - indulge!!  Scoma's is the way to recharge your energy before wandering the streets of San Francisco.

PvqoIJmoM65QrVqE2K8eMQ.review_text: The food was good, BUT you ate wedged into a very tight area and you better like your neighbors. The service was nothing special. The bad review comes from the added 4% surcharge . When our bill came besides the tax there was a 4 percent surcharge and when we asked what it was for our server could not explain it. The charge is for there medical, the restraunt charges this to help cover the cost of the medical! I've felt this is out of line, they should tell us in advance! We will not be going back! Stay away from the Cioppino, my brother in law got a bad clam!

pUV7yun5ZEM9DCA_P2lj5Q.review_text: DISAPPOINTING.  After having Scoma's a couple of years ago I HAD to come back here as soon as I was financially capable of doing so. lol. I came here expecting a delicious meal and unfortunately didn't get that. I had a pretty inadequate waiter.   Me & my boyfriend Ordered: Oyster Rockefeller Calamari 2 Filet Mignons  Our water took our order, didn't ask how we wanted our meat cooked, and left before we could catch him. By the time we caught him he said the order had already been put in, so we just had to stick with it.  Our filet mignons came out and they were completely flavorless, dry, and overcooked. I was beyond sad that the place that I've been looking forward to eating at was such a huge let down..

Xd-r6-BiYigA0y_tGuQlEw.review_text: Went here based on the positive Yelp reviews, but didn't have a great experience.   We got there and put our name down for a table and went to the bar for a drink.   My glass of wine had not one, not two, but three pieces of cork in it, so I had to ask the waiter for a new one, which he obliged and apologized.     About 5-10 minutes later, a party was called because their table was ready, and a few seconds later, our name was also called.   We went up to the hostess stand and said our name, and the confused hostess started walking us to another side of the restaurant that we said we didn't want to sit on, so we inquired, and she went back to check, and realized that the other name that was called should have been going over there, not us.   No biggie, it was corrected.  My wife ordered the $29 dungness crab ravioli after hearing good things about it on yelp.   I ordered pasta pomorodo with prawns ($31).   Our food came out and we started eating, and my wife discovered a HUGE black hair inside of her crab ravioli.   Completely disgusting!    I also noticed a smaller hair on the bottom of her plate.   We informed the waiter, who was very kind, and asked if she wanted to replace it, but she was turned off, so she just ordered the same as me.   The waiter brought out her replacement meal and apologized again, and said the meal would be free, which was very nice.

GS71FOuRgohr3IjzJYc42g.review_text: 18 years later, I finally returned to one of the most famous places on the Wharf for classy, power broking type seafood. We departed the Hyatt Regency on a rainy, cold Saturday afternoon-wow, rain, after years of Colorado living we forgot how cold and bone chilling the Harbor experience can be for near desert dwellers. We were seated although we looked like soggy tourists with a wonderful view of the bays. We ordered two california chards-somona family which were impressive, but my lobster bisque was amazing-chunky, creamy, a dash of cayenne was world class. Pamela enjoyed a magnificent new england chowder with tons of fish, crab, and the bread was hot, fresh, crisp.  A perfect quick lunch, very crowded with the former city judges party in the back room

jvIbrfeXHz7tGpONEr3mcA.review_text: I have been going to Scomas for approximately 20 years now at the rate of two or three times a year......   I can't say that I've tried alot of dishes there as I am (or was) a lover of their Lazyman Chiapiono.    We went last Friday and I ordered the same thing....   This fish stew in the past has been wonderful...   What I got on Friday for $40 was tomato sauce with COD.....  I had two small pcs of Crab, Two Shrimp and two clams.....  The rest was tastless cod....   I was very disappointed and will now return to this establishment....

E-Mq9XSHtu4n85SXlV-AAA.review_text: The reason I give this place 5 stars even though my lunch was more of a 4 star quality is because of the amazing service that we got at this place. After a morning of playing tourist, my fiance and I wanted to stop to get some lunch. We were at the Wharf so we were obviously craving clam chowder but wanted an actual sit down place.  Upon walking in, I noticed the servers with the white jackets and immediately thought that this would be hoighty toighty place that would judge me for just ordering a beer and bowl of chowder. However, this did not happen. Our waiter was super friendly and made some small talk with us. The busboys made sure we had plenty of water and we generally felt very welcome here.   As far as the m... my Stella was ice cold and my chowder was delicious so I was a happy girl. I really liked that my chowder was heavy on the clams and lighter on the potatoes. We also got half of a giant roll of sourdough bread in our bread basket so that was perfect for dipping... no breadbowl needed here. I was also intrigued by some of their other seafood chowders which I will have to try if I make my way to Scoma's again. eal

r06pGG9oIKONcl6pNNftiw.review_text: This is probably one of the best restaurants in SF! Mind you, we were visiting for the first time, so we're by no means experts in SF restaurants, but the quality of the food, service and ambiance of the place is top notch.   It's in Fisherman's Wharf, which may lead some people to think it's touristy, but totally not! This place has great views of the harbor and the food is outstanding!! This is probably the best quality seafood I have ever had.   We also had a great waiter, who had the most awesome French accent. But don't get the wrong idea, this place is not snobby in the slightest. The waiter was very friendly and helpful.

K7W2UaUGJvpbqiqObRhQQQ.review_text: Outstanding!  Wonderful service and tremendous food.  I had the oysters to start, then the garlic roasted crab with a side of spinach - everything was tremendous.  The freshest crab and that spinach!  Who knew?  My husband had fisherman's pasta and was nice enough to let me try it - I could see why he was hesitant - it was too good to share!  All around great place.

TnoOjz13X3H1n95CxBMFUg.review_text: Before you bother reading this, FYI: my rating for this joint is purely based on the crab and nothing else.  Ok.  In my very humble opinon, this is the best fresh seafood in San Francisco.  This is old school SF at its best.  No glitz no glamour, no fuss no muss: give me my gigantic crab with melted butter and lemon and leave me in peace.  Plain and simple.  There are no reservations (you are soooo unoriginal Bourdain), the place is right on the water and slightly tacky by design.  But the prices reflect what you are getting: fresh-outta-the-water-an-hour-ago huge fish.  I suppose people order other things...but really what is the point?

RAkCCF014NM1Ls_MD0FA-g.review_text: Like the thousands of other reviewers.... Excellent food and the seafood is very fresh. A little pricey, but worth it. We went on a Sunday night and the wait was about 30 minutes which is pretty decent. Usually it is a much longer wait.

vLg4MRDT3k5WgHsaDrRtaw.review_text: I grew up all over the bay area and now that I live far away in a land locked state there is nothing I miss more than the food culture and my favorite restaurants. Of all the restaurants, taco stands, cafes and dive bars I sometimes reminisce over I feel the strongest about Scoma's.    Unfortunately I never lived close enough for it to become a regular haunt but whenever I got to choose a restaurant (hopefully on my parents dime) I chose Scoma's. Which meant a lot of special dinners with my family were here. I think almost every time we had the same waiter and what I would say is the best service I've ever had.   It's kind of an old school look inside with lots of wood and some nautical hints. The food is old school delicious. I recommend swordfish because that's what I love but I would not steer someone away from anything I've had on the menu. Sometimes you just want fresh fish with the least tampering possible and you can get it done beautifully here along with just about any other seafood craving you have.   I obviously have some emotional attachment to this restaurant but I've also grown to have high expectations (unrealistically?) of the establishments I go to and most of that can be traced back to great experiences here.

UL0ypgePQ3WQDjTpFJmSTQ.review_text: I wish I could give this place a higher rating, but the food and service just didn't merit it for the price. I ordered off the prix-fixe menu, while my friend ordered the cioppino. Her dish was chock-full of seafood and had a flavorful, spicy broth.  I started with the lobster bisque and lobster salad.
