The bisque was completely smooth with no actual chunks of lobster meat. The fresh lobster meat on the side was only about the size of a quarter, but at least it tasted great. I was a little annoyed that my cup of soup was about 2/3 full.  My entree was linguine with diver scallops. They definitely didn't skimp on the fresh scallops, but the sauce wasn't memorable.  For dessert, I opted for the tiramisu. It came in an espresso cup, and while it was delicious, it was only about two bites. Tasty, but nothing special.  I'm glad we weren't rushed, but the service was incredibly slow and the atmosphere was too stuffy for me. Maybe it would have been better if we'd sat by a window to better enjoy the views.  I would give Scoma's another shot, but for $60 per person without drinks, I think we could have done better elsewhere.

SHMyjUQ71_Dq_Sro6p5pQg.review_text: It was one of those weekends where me and the lady just picked up and rolled out on a road trip - no plans. Just me, her and San Francisco. It ended up being one of the best weekends of my life.   Searching for "Seafood" and not caring from where - we ended up at Scooma's on pre-fixed menu. Roasted Crab.....OMG!  The place is beautiful, you look out the window and there are real fishing boats netting in the catch of the day on the Bay...amazing. It ended up being one of the most romantic dinners in history as well as one of the tastiest for under $80 for 2. PERFECT.   Great for Special Occasion Dinners - CHECK IT OUT!!

2df2el0XrwUmSHdz9iEF7Q.review_text: We had the BEST waiter I have ever had.  I think his name was John B. The food was delicious and I loved eating with a view of the water.

p-w-1gh3aGEMPAL6-RwC4g.review_text: We tried the lazy man's cioppino and oysters, which were very good. The view is nice and atmosphere of the restaurant is pleasant.  It did get really busy around 6-7pm but there are quite a few tables, and second room with a view is especially nice.

V3alMhjWa3x0v8DlDp49Sw.review_text: Spectacular food. Salvatore. Chris. Tim. Are wonderful. Ask for them. The food is beyond good. The sauté sec. The lazy mans cioppinnio. The crab Louis. Are amazing. This is what San Francisco is all about. The potions are amazing and the service is friendly and helpful. . We have been coming for over 25 years and we feel at home, even if we come from New Orleans.

mcunSSneTRDcv5pU_QbCLA.review_text: The filet mignon was just incredible.  I eat the filet without any topping on it and the savory flavors are just awesome.  The steak is tendor even when cooked butterflied well-done!  Serivce is always great!

FUFIzjgUpGZP6UYJJ10MEw.review_text: So we walked around for 20 minutes looking at different reviews around the area of fisherman's wharf. After a diligent search we found this place. Very rare I give 5 stars but this deserves it.   First- ask for David to serve you. He'll take good care of you!  1- get the oyster platter.  2- Jordan 2003 is still a great wine and I've paid twice the amount at other places  3- the green salad is awesome! 4- get the lobster

h_2NGTYvjOc38cjx90rM5Q.review_text: While most locals might think that Scoma's is a tourist trap, it's not.. Even locals come here. It's delicious and the selection of seafood is fantastic! First off, the sourdough bread is amazing! I'm not a huge bread person, but I couldn't help myself.. Crab cakes are a must.. I had the lobster ravioli, hearty portion, creamy, chunks of lobster. Lobster bisque, a must! The seafood is ALL fresh, you can't go wrong with anything on the menu..   Thank you to my tourist fam for visiting and re-introducing me to this SF gem..

DUCVhBH9quiMZo5phvNzIw.review_text: Great food as well as service. The inability to make a reservation, outdated interior and located in a hyper touristy areas all detract me from wanting to come back again.

EVNgQmC9v4wq04nWbYhmzg.review_text: I've only had the pleasure of eating at Scomas once, and I can honestly say, that my only experience there was enough to bring me back for years to come. The atmoshpere was quite pleasant, it's a quaint little place and my water cup was always filled in a non evasive manner. Portions are more than enough to leave you stuffed or perfect for sharing. Steamed muscles were delicious and their Cioppino was fantastic!

kTtpHgsr588EcZLqgkEIAQ.review_text: We went to lunch on Sunday afternoon for the Dine about Town meal. I had the clam chowder which is consistently delicious an the pan seared scallops. While I expect good, quality seafood in a traditional preparation, I was really surprised by both the flavor and the size of the dish, which came with a medley of vegetables and mashed potatoes. My wife had the crab louie, which is one of Scoma's usual top dishes. Again I was really, and pleasantly, surprised by the portions, particularly considering it was half the price of the menu crab louie.  Overall, I highly recommend the Dine About Town meals at Scoma's if your in the mood for a quality, traditional seafood lunch.

t3Jh69CBeMjjjXB6NyxQXA.review_text: I think I've gone to this place 100 or so times. Every time it's been delicious! The service is friendly, the seafood is fresh and the VIEW IS AMAZING!   Love this place.

HEPfqAH6ObF36Fp1B9Fi1Q.review_text: I had friends in town last week, and naturally they wanted to have dinner in Fisherman's Wharf one of the nights. Reluctantly, I logged onto Yelp to find some semblance of a decent place in the Wharf, and I had remembered a client once recommending Scoma's.   To my surprise, it was actually a decent venue. A fairly relaxed restaurant (especially for the Wharf area), with a pleasant ambiance, and good seafood. I ordered the fixed price menu of the day - the butternut squash soup, the Petrale Sole (the fish special), and the warm brownie a la mode with a warm caramel sauce. Everything ordered was delicious.  There are but two complaints I have about Scoma's - one, the wait staff seemed a bit patronizing and had that Disneyland-esque feel about them (I was so tempted to just blurt out, "I live here, I'm not a tourist," but refrained from doing so). And second - when we went to split the bill on 2 cards, the waiter accidentally put the entire bill on my one card. Unfortunately, it was my debit card, and the entire bill had to sit on my card for the next 4 or 5 days, until the correct amount posted to my account. It was an easy mistake, but it sucked, and I wished they'd had a better POS system to simply void the mistake.   Anyhow, all in all, I think I prefer Scoma's to the Pier Market - the only other restaurant I've eaten at for dinner in the Wharf. Though, I do wonder what it's like up top at Boudin for dinner?

ASa6W02VHfkVxKhsT3GL7w.review_text: As a native from the bay area I thought why not treat my new husband to a night on the town so he can take in some of what SF has to offer. I thought Scoma's was a great start. The food was magnificient, the wine choice by the bartender was on point AND more importantly, I was able to have a nice corner in the restaurant so I can talk sweet nothings to my beautiful husband! We ordered to cioppino...and the seafood saute!!!! YUMMY! Had a great time and as always the food was MAGNIFICIENT.

1y-hH-WZTOzM9UalO8l98Q.review_text: You can't go wrong at Scoma's. Get the cioppino, OMG it's worth it.

cFSn7gzXbs5NoIBYXPqswA.review_text: Ehh... I really wanted to like this place.  Pro's: Great location on pier Quality fresh fish  Cons: $$$$ Slow service? (Place was packed though so maybe 50/50 here) Food was a bit bland, I expected more for my money Calamari was oily and heavy.  My opinion as always- if you do decide to go I hope you have a better meal!

sMWHjqOe3nJxHRl7C8QX5A.review_text: For the price point, the food was good but not exceptional. The service was decent, but not great. I had the fresh grilled halibut with a butter sauce, which was mistakenly served without the sauce. The dish was bland and the halibut was a little dry. The restaurant is on a pier but views are mainly blocked by adjoining buildings. No one asked how the food was until well into the meal when I was able to ask for the sauce.  A solid 3-stars, but certainly no more.

-WZH08M_-jsc5a40x2XLcw.review_text: This place is a gem on Fisherman's Wharf, assuming you're willing to pay a bit extra for the location and (IMO) quality of food and friendly service.  My family had a late dinner here which was absolutely delicious across the board. The server was friendly, old school, and didn't rush us at all.  - Oysters: Awesome - Mussells: Awesome - Pasta dishes with crab, lobster, scallops: Amazing, the amount of seafood/shellfish they toss into their pasta dishes is mindblowing.  Wine: Affordable list of bottles.   Even the bread's good.   Totally recommend, especially for out-of-towners who  don't mind a high-quality old school seafood restaurant right in the middle of Tourist Central.

CDtbuyJBYyDT21lJMod6OA.review_text: Don't come here without at least one person who looks over 35!  I came here once with a small birthday party my boss was throwing.  We had bottle service, appetizers and entres... so we got treated VERY well.    I came here again with a friend visiting from the midwest.  We both had eaten about an hour before and weren't too hungry, and were busy trying to squeeze in the sights before it rained, and my friend wanted oysters.  The moment we walked in, that receptionist guy peered down at us from the very tall desk he sits at.  Narrowed eyes, no smile or anything.  Weirdo.  We get seated, and we order what we want.  The waitress came and checked on us mid-meal, and asked how it was.  My voice doesn't carry much, and I said "everything's okay, thank you" as in meaning it was alright!  My friend said something too.  I guess she didn't hear me right and she was like "It's more than just okay!"    My friend and I were both kind of just o_O....  Yeah it was a weird experience.  I guess they judge you here if you order a "low roller" meal.  I should've gone with my gut and gone with my first choice for my friend, Swan Oyster Depot.

KjnxhW5CSjjKVzytq_OM6A.review_text: Let me start by saying that I have been coming to Scoma's for years. Unfortunately after my visit tonight, I don't think I'll be back. San Francisco is full of too many great places for me to keep visiting simply for the nostalgia of what this place used to be.   First, I'd agree with other reviewers that this isn't a modern fine-dining establishment. The décor is definitely a throwback to old-school seafood restaurants, but that isn't necessarily a bad thing in my opinion. Lots of wood paneling and memorabilia on the walls. Tourists used to look in, see the prices and fancy clothes and turn around to head back to Bubba Gump Shrimp Co., but those days are long gone. There were plenty of people in camouflage cargo shorts waltzing in. That might be more a statement about society than the restaurant, but there it is. Sorry if you like camouflage pants or Bubba Gump.   The service has always been a high point at Scoma's. Tonight was no exception. The wait staff was very attentive and helpful. The only minor blemish for gluten-free diners: tonight was our first visit after my wife had to adopt a gluten-free diet regimen. We looked ahead to ensure there were good options on the menu (there were) but our waiter wasn't very knowledgeable about the different options. Some of the menu items that would normally be gluten-free (even simple grilled fish) didn't carry that designation, which was confusing. Just something to consider for those with a dietary restriction.   The food was ultimately the reason for the low score in my book. We started with the highly vaunted lobster bisque. It barely even tasted like lobster, much less contained any - it was more tomato bisque than anything. I've had better store-bought.   With entrées, I went with cioppino while my wife chose crab risotto. The seafood part of my cioppino was pretty good - a little squid-heavy for my taste and with decidedly non-traditional lump crab (is that why it's "lazy" cioppino?), but overall it's good and there's plenty of it. The problem was the tomato sauce. It tasted like a cross of canned spaghetti sauce and tomato soup poured over the seafood - bland and weirdly thick, not the spicy, wine and tomato-y broth that usually comes with the dish. Just plain weird.   The risotto was even worse. First, they used long-grain rice, not Arborio or another short-grain rice. I'm no food snob but it looked like they dumped Minute rice onto the plate. It didn't look edible, much less appetizing. Second, there were random peas, mushrooms and tomatoes throughout (none of which was mentioned on the menu). Risotto should be rich, creamy and flavorful. This was none of those.

OpFr1MdG2MjChr1ucdp1nQ.review_text: Our meal was well worth the 45 minute wait. Making reservations is definitely recommended. I had the Mixed Fresh Seafood Grill with swordfish, salmon and shrimp. It was served with grilled vegetables; peppers, zucchini and egg plant. The spices were well flavored but not overpowering.   The service was good, but not intrusive; and the atmosphere was casual yet elegant at the same time. I strongly recommend Scomas to anyone in the San Francisco area.

nmrxTK4y3JDoJ7di6wpS1w.review_text: I took my first vacation in a long time to San Francisco, and my girlfriend and I ate here for our first night in town. After the meal, I had to actively check to make sure that my plane had not fallen out of the sky, crashed into a hillside, and killed everyone on board; after eating here, I thought I had died and gone to food heaven.  We arrived around 7:00 pm on a Saturday night, and the place was packed to the rafters. However, in spite of that, we were seated promptly (inside of 5 minutes). Our waitress was attentive and came to the table frequently, but not so often that it became creepy. Refills on drinks came quickly; we never ran dry at the table.  For our appetizers, my girlfriend ordered a Caesar salad, while I ordered the "world's-best" clam chowder. The salad was prepared and dressed perfectly, with the lemon in the dressing giving the salad that one last missing element. To me, this is one sign of a stellar restaurant - take the classics, maybe put a small spin on them, and execute them flawlessly. As for my chowder, I am always skeptical when something is advertised as the "world's best," but this particular dish did not disappoint. This chowder was as good or better than any I'd ever had on the East Coast, and was delicious from the first spoonful to the last.  Our entrees came out shortly thereafter, and they did not disappoint either. My girlfriend got the salmon, while I ordered the Yellowfin Tuna. First of all, both fish were cooked perfectly, but what blew me away were the portion sizes. Both my girlfriend and myself received huge portions of fish, to the point where we both stuffed ourselves stupid in order to eat them. Sadly, we saved no room for dessert.  The only drawback of this meal would be the price; it was rather expensive ($60 per person, including tip). However, I didn't have a problem with that price, as the food my girlfriend and I received was worth every penny.  My meal at Scoma's was one of the best meals I have ever had. The food was fantastic, the service was excellent, and while the price was high, I didn't mind paying extra for such quality. If you are a fan of seafood, this place should be on your list of must-visits when you visit Fisherman's Wharf.

tEe-2SWAxD1DyYnzuRv6ug.review_text: Food: delicious Service: delicious View: beautiful

6a8XHypxGwNTRWqtqQsylQ.review_text: Try the Dungeness crab sandwich (open face) and clam chowder - it's the perfect lunch at Fisherman's Wharf with friends who are visiting from out of town. When my roommate's brother saw my crab sandwich, he asked "...if they have a special machine that takes all the meat out of a crab. I want one." I wondered the same as I disposed of the fresh crab meat into my hungry stomach.  Our waitress, Han, was very attentive and it was pretty impressive that she memorized all of our orders (we had a table for six). Since Scoma's right by the bay, you'll get a nice view of the water and the city buildings like Coit Tower.

bW2USanomtJ7WHbpdbpX9w.review_text: I'm going to start out by saying how excited my wife and I were to eat here after hearing good things. Soon as we met our waitress "CC" we felt discriminated against.  She takes our drinks order with is water since neither of us drink. After that it was just insulting.  As she walks back with a plate of food to serve the people behind us she stops and says "this is our crab sandwich and it's only 23.99". I was like ok.  She comes back to take our order and without us saying anything to provoke her she only goes over the appetizers, so that's all we order and not once does she ask if we want anything besides appetizers.  Everyone else she serves around us she goes over the entire menu and gives them more options and is very informative.  After our food she only offers us coffee and others dessert.  Our words with her were very limited and we basically let her treat us like peasants not good enough to eat at her restaurant.  Now I must add we were dressed casual the same as everyone else and have absolutely no idea why she would treat us this way.  We by far are not sensitive people and I come from a background of a food service family and am hardly ever critical but CC was very insulting and classless. Wouldn't recommend this establishment to anyone.

mDHWcDvan7_7D9Xdd02bcQ.review_text: Very good/fresh Seafood, Sat by the bar by myself, ate like a pig/drank like a fish...Was not thrilled that they didn't serve a full menu at the bar but being I was too embarrassed to sit at a table for 1, I just ordered a giant deep fried Seafood sampler which was perfect anyway...

BwTPj8XS_iqdSTLPBVMs1w.review_text: I hardly ever venture out to have seafood at Fisherman's wharf. I should, seeing as I live in San Francisco. But it is rare that I will check out restaurants there. A friend suggested that we try out Scomas for dinner. They do not take reservations and from what I've read, the wait can be daunting. I called them around 7pm on Wednesday to see how long the wait was going to be to grab a table around 8pm. The lady on the phone said that it was about a 40 minute wait. When we arrived, we grabbed a drink at the bar and waited for our name to be called. There were a handful of parties waiting around for their tables. Note: They only seat parties where everyone is present. To my surprise, names were being called quite frequently and one right after the other. The restaurant didn't see large but they have a good number of tables available. We were seated right around 8:10pm. By then, a lot of tables were open and the restaurant seemed less busy. We decided to try their "Triple Play" which was basically a choice of appetizer, entrée and dessert. For about $40, they offered at least 4 dishes to choose from, which was great. I choice the lobster bisque, the scallop linguine and the three of us shared all 3 desserts. Everything was fantastic. The food came out in a timely manner. The food wasn't as hot as I would have liked but it tasted just fine. I'll have to come back and try other seafood entrees.   Great deal if you choose the Triple Play menu, validated/free valet parking in the back, relatively fast seating for a weeknight and great seafood dishes. I would love to check this place out for lunch and take in the views of the water.

_kN-YGPzrh94XT_PvQPE4A.review_text: My family and I really enjoyed scomas. They have great seafood and the cioppino was delicious! Every plate was a hefty size plate and we will definitely return again. Only downside was that its not really a kid friendly place but definitely great for a night out with friends or date night.

QfgI7R2VU_50oChVdrsJ0Q.review_text: We have been coming to San Francisco for years and never tried Scomas and am I sorry we didn't find this place sooner. I had the Seafood Diplomatica which was wonderful and my husband had the mixed grill, which he loved. The waiter we had was very good and the food was outstanding. I also had the clam chowder which was great but my husband had the lobster bisque and said it was the best he ever had. It is pricey but the food is worth it. For any special occasion I would highly recommend this restaurant.

GeVbqCZ-zOyLNTDOTzphGw.review_text: Best bloody Mary cocktail ever, calimari best eaten hot was amazing, fresh oyster assortment was so good, and the clam chowder is possibly the best I've ever had.   The bread on the table was definately house made or very local.   Great view, wonderful staff, romantic and off the beaten fisherman's wharf path.

lDs5thze5vNWoXGUc3lcAQ.review_text: The food was soooo bad... One of the entrees we ordered after more than 2 hours of wait was crab risotto and I couldn't eat more than one spoon of it. It was too sweet and weird. Most of the ingredients were green beans rather than crab meat or rice. The appetizers weren't good either.   I've lived in the area for more than four years so I know the kinds of good fancy seafood that I like, but the food here was nowhere near the standards.   Also, I asked for the bill after making it CLEAR that we weren't getting dessert, but the waiter nevertheless brought the dessert menu INSTEAD OF the bill. Then he asks us if we were getting coffee. Thinking that what he brought us was the bill, it totally looked as if the coffee was complimentary and as if he was apologizing for the 2 hour wait we had to go through after being told that the wait would be only 45 minutes -- so we asked for coffee. Seconds later we realized to our dismay that we didn't get the bill from him yet, and the coffee was going to be charged on the bill, so I actually had to walk up to our waiter to cancel the order for coffee. How not classy...... We all felt like we were tricked into paying more.. it may have been his small mistake of the day but there's only so much you can tolerate after being ripped off in terms of time and money.  In sum, if I ask for the bill and say no to the dessert menu then I want the bill, not the dessert menu. Give me what I ask for and don't give me what I clearly and loudly refused.

UvRUygcyvpJuHh1BiZrrbQ.review_text: Fabulous! Things to get.... lobster bisque is amazing!!! Wish there were a few extra chunks inside but that's ok :)  We ordered the cioppino. This thing is HUGE. It could feed four people. We also order a whole garlic roasted crab. It was all delicious and steamy.  It was funny because when the crab came out the older waiter take out this huge bib an starts to tie it around my boyfriend and doing it for him. I put mine on myself but it was priceless to watch.  Great place for seafood.   The location is in Fisherman Wharf which is tourist town but I'll come down here since I'm a local for this place!

fF0bQM6YHyPHcdxJkMKtFw.review_text: This restaurant is completely overrated and over priced! Besides for the mediocre food, the waitress, Lori, seemed only interested in getting us through our meal quickly to turn the table.   Certainly the location is beautiful, and the environment inviting, but the food and service were far from warranting the high stars or cost, ($120 w/out alcohol) that we reviewed on Yelp.   With so many great options to choose from on the Wharf, we'd recommended a food cart vendor for $30 rather then return to Scoma's with disappointment.

jnxgeymWjNw0uXe_4qQy4g.review_text: I love San Francisco!  Some of the best food in the country is there.  Scoma's has got to be one one of my all time favorites.  The wait staff are professionals and always do a great job.  The menu is fabulous.  They've got a cold CALAMARI VINAIGRETTE salad that'll blow you away; a meal in itself.  All the pasta dishes are outstanding and the Seafood Cioppino is full of flavor and the freshest of seafood.  I've dined there many times and have never been disappointed.

SFBfsySKt-Rb5aBovef78w.review_text: Scoma's doesn't mess around with seafood.  You pay for what you get and that's huge portions, quality food, and excellent service.  Here's my recommendations if you come to Scoma's for dinner:  * Valet it. Complimentary service but give a nice tip.  They work hard for tha monay!  * Come for dinner between 5:30 and 6 p.m.  I know, I know...It's dinnertime for seniors but if you come later than that, you'll have a 45 to 1 hr. wait on a Sat. night.  We waited for about 10 min and got seated promptly. Plus, they don't take reservations so it's first come, first serve.  * It's all about the Ahi Tuna, cooked medium rare with a glass of Pinot Grigio!  * The Tiramisu is delicious!  * Look at the menu before you go so you know what to expect in regards to prices.  Forgot to add:  Many of yelpers commented on their reviews to dress nice, no jeans, but all I got to say is that as long as you look presentable and smell presentable, you're good.  Some people had on the weirdest clothes - a guy with cut off jean shorts up to his bootay, a lady wearing a nice black skirt with a Nike Sports bra.  Eegads!

Ylp5jwQYatmorHDI_qO8Pg.review_text: Great seafood! Everything really is fresh!

CmYy4CG1yH15qHamF_RAfA.review_text: Being from MN, visiting SF means having seafood.  Really, really good seafood.  I came here in October for a work trip with my fiancé, and we loved it.  I came back again in May on the tail end of our honeymoon (same girl, if you can believe it), because we just had to.  Amazing pasta and seafood - had 4 different dishes and tough to come up with a favorite.  It's all good.  And the service is awesome.

RTCUwgU6XzAXcTrQTbZpwg.review_text: Great seafood restaurant tucked away near the fisherman's wharf.  I would recommend trying the SCOMA'S SHELLFISH SAUTÉ SEC which is the following:  Scallops, Baby Lobster, Shrimp, Dungeness Leg Meat sautéed with Mushroom, Lemon, Garlic, Tomato-Cream

4FE8md9fMr_jZFNbcOmHsQ.review_text: Cioppino. Seafood. Nice, cozy restaurant. Scenic location, near Fisherman's Wharf.

SGnqMkPh2OmOXJV59tzKZg.review_text: As a native San Franciscan, Scoma's has been a family favorite for years.  A special occasion type of place, usually come here with large parties.  The mother in law is in town and loves this place, so we came here for her birthday dinner with a party of 9.  They don't take reservations, so with a large party you need to get here early.  We got there at 5:30, was seated at 6:10 on a Thursday.  As typical, ordered a variety of dishes.  3 ordered the pasta diplomatica, a couple of crab cakes, a cippiono, and I had the lamb.  They have "Dine about town" special for $35 that includes an appetizer, entree and dessert.  Considering most entrees are $30-$35, that's a great value.  The food, especially the seafood was good.  Portions are large and the service outstanding.  Water glasses are always full.  Waitress cut and served our birthday cake for us.  Its expensive, but you expect that.  Still, a solid choice for a special occasion dinner after all the years.

Ud4pIxzG44xNlSIwWkOoaA.review_text: My boyfriend and I came to Scoma's for lunch on a rainy San Francisco afternoon with high hopes for a delicious meal and I would have to say, I was a little disappointed.  We arrived and were seated right away, our waiter was attentive yet patient while we scanned the menu, he took our drink orders and delivered them in a timely manner...he answered all our questions and arrived with our food "lickety-split" so you get the gist...services was excellent.  The food on the other hand was unremarkable.  Here's what we had...the dungeness crab cakes where okay, flavorful but bread-to-crab ratio was leaning more towards bread.  I guess I just got my hopes up a little too much, maybe we should've went to Pacific Cafe instead.  My boyfriend ordered the shellfish saute which seems to be a big hit at the restaurant and for good reason 'cause it was yummy!  Small lobster tales, scallops, and prawns all sauteed in a garlic-white wine sauce...it was pretty good and I think this dish saved the rating from a 2 star.  I think I know why Scoma's is one of the highest grossing restaurants in the nation...their prices!  I don't think I've ever spent over $70 on lunch until I ate here.  Just a warning...be prepared to pay the big bucks dinning at Scoma's.  So the question is...will I come back?  Maybe to give it another shot, cause I want to like it, I really do.

T8OuKyHjm5TlpASOP8wY4w.review_text: Lazy is great. Essence of soup made me warm. Be prepared. It is s big bowl.

Re0D5snuHFN9ycAfC-aglA.review_text: If not for the recommendation from a native and the packed waiting area, I would not have expected that this restaurant would deliver like it did. We were four thirty something guys coming from Muir Woods, so we were naturally placed at the worst table in the place. We asked to be moved and were accomodated nicely. I had the Petrale Dore which, for a seafood novice, was both safe and tasty. Sure, this place looked like the background for either an episode of Mad Men or a bad Sinatra movie, but its classic and memorable.

Snn3AGqWvV08kjLnDei0fQ.review_text: Made reservations for 6:15 for 5 pax. Went in at 6:05pm and I asked the hostess how long is the wait, she confidently replied, "...at 6:15pm" And I thought to myself, wow, seriously? OK..then, I stepped aside and waited. 5, 6, 10, 15, 20, 30, 35, 47 minutes later, I got my table. Then, I asked her, "what happened to my 6:15 on the dot table ready comment? And she said, "it happens..." So much for a great impression.  Sat down at the table and waited by a server promptly and he said something about the specials which I didn't hear very well. Anyways, ordered the food, waited for about 10 minutes, food came. The only thing that's worth mentioning is their famous Lazy Man's Cioppino..not because it's so fabulous, IT WAS HORRIBLE !!! They got their name right, so damn LAZY ! They don't even bother cooking the tomato sauce properly. To me, it was just a bottle of Prego dumped into the pot, stirred a little (please note that the sauce was not even hot, it was....luke warm), then, throw in the seafood.  Unless you're up for some "..a-little-better-than-microwave-tv-dinner.." type of food with HIGH price. GO TO SCOMA'S ! The rest of the food, cod, seafood platter, clam chowder and fried oysters, go to Red Lobster or Sizzler instead...  The only reason why I give 1 star is because of the view.  Good luck

zk8VjDmlZL8_J18lhZrwIQ.review_text: The chowder is outstanding as is the shellfish sauté. Really delicious. Plenty for my lovely wife and I to share. Made our time in San Francisco a real treat. I would definitely suggest this as a spot to enjoy a special dinner.    Yelp comes through in the clutch once again.

mcwzPxr4JwAUKXVV7eDQFw.review_text: A San Francisco institution. Yes, a bit tourist and overpriced ($36 for my cioppino) but there is just something about this place that keeps me coming back for special occasions.  Oh yeah, it's the Lazy Man's Cioppino - Yummy!

-vHFlSgl-3S3pKBr5zpv6Q.review_text: I'm always told that great food can be found in San Francisco. Mouth watering. The food is excellent. Large portions, tasty sauces and yummy seafood, too bad I had to share my plate with others.  We also had a friendly waiter, even valet was nice. This is a great spot for tourists.

qpd7G_CzpGfHrTxvdX0TFg.review_text: -The Oyster Alla Scoma is the best dish there.  -The mix shellfish is okay.  -The sea food(shrimp,  oyster, and scallop) is fine, not super fresh but not bad.  -The service is really good.  -And the desert - - tiramisu and brownie with vanilla ice cream is good.  -There's one thing I'm really confused about - - we need to pay 4% surcharge for the employee's healthy and welfare. I've never been charged for that kind of fee before, and this is the first time and I don't know why.   Two words for this restaurant - - not special.

q_59ARjoIUkyfzdtnE2ciw.review_text: This is an interesting restaurant.  It is not on the main drag, and you have to walk down a short alley like street.  The restaurant itself is rather small.  There is valet parking.  The patrons are a dedicated bunch of seemingly regulars.  I say that as everyone from the parking attendents to the wait staff met would call these people by name, and come over and hug them.  Kathleen was our waitress and she was great.  The wait staff were all quite professionally dressed with white coats and tuxedoes.  If any of them were younger than age 50, I'd be surprised.  I got the feeling that Friday lunch was when San Francisco "old money" all came to Scomas to eat lunch. For a sit down, classy, main stay restaurant of San Francisco, I did not think the prices were out of line at all.

iahyDjVaVCU6O6Lsnmollg.review_text: Super romantic and the food is fresh and good!!! We ate here while touring fishrmans Warf!! Who doesn't like eating on a boat! A boat with good food! It's s very charming restaurant!! Old skool style ;)

3sU6jd4MIpcgETygfyVUzA.review_text: This is our favorite spot to eat in Fisherman's Wharf.  We started coming here is 2010 and loved our waiter Sergio.  He was genuinely friendly and very helpful.  I even sent my sister here and she loved him too!  The lobster bisque is AMAZING!  We usually get the catch of the day which has never let us down.  Also I like that the restaurant is a little off the path so it doesn't seem as touristy and crazy as the other places on the Wharf. Overall an awesome restaurant with a historic feel and excellent service.

A26hAdAoVCYeq-Jl8UThKg.review_text: Blackened Halibut is the best tasting fish that've have ever had.  Fantastic service and great food.  Waiter was very knowledgable and recommended the perfect dish for me.

EOuNkbCZo43i3RkdsPOitQ.review_text: Arrived by taxi so parking wasn't an issue but I can see how it could be if not organised ahead of time. Concierge was excellent as I was quickly seated. I opted for a clam chowder and the the signature scallop and prawn dish. Both were excellent and everthing I could have hoped for. Price was very reasonable given the food and service quality. Of the three places I ate over three night I would rate this a 2nd for food and first for service.

V2TCCue6lWUR3NQwKsJ87w.review_text: OMG! this place is heaven!  their lazy man's cioppino was hugeeee and full of yummynessss.. fish, shrimp, scallops, clams.. yummmss...  i first tried their cioppino at the location in sausalito but it does not come closeeee to this location.. it is much bigger! and who doesnt like more of the best cioppino ever!  They have a pre fix menu with 3 course.. I would not recommend as the portions were smaller than regular entrees but if your partner is ordering a lazy cioppino then there is nothing to worry about because it will feed the both of you and have left overs...  I asked for an extra bowl so I could share my cioppino and they even gave us an extra piece of butter bread to dip in the cioppino... :))))  I am in love with this place and will look forward to making a trip back to SF to go thereeeee...

6O8NjN3o3K9UcMdVntT-7Q.review_text: *** For all of you seafood lovers out there ***  Scoma's is a hidden gem within Fisherman's Wharf. Nestled in a little back lot off of Al Scoma Way, this place can be tricky to spot if you're not paying attention. If you do drive there, the parking is strictly valet unless you park on the street.   The decor gives off almost a boathouse type of vibe. Depending on where you're sitting you can catch small glimpses of the city or the bay. The service here is excellent, they are friendly, knowledgeable of the menu, and very attentive.  I highly recommend the Spice Crusted Salmon and Shrimp Cake as a starter. Cooked to perfection with just the right amount of crisp, you catch both the salmon and shrimp flavors with each bite. For an entree I recommend the Scoma's Shellfish Saute which is an assortment of shellfish (2 Lobster Tails, Jumbo Prawns, Large Scallops,  and Dungeness Crab meat) served over penne pasta, rice pilaf and a vegetable medley in a buttery wine sauce. This is the epitome of perfection. Each savory bite is filled with sweet decadent flavors of the shellfish. Whenever we dine here I can never bring myself to order anything else. The Saute is a winner and worth every penny.  Whether you consider this a touristy spot or not, it's definitely a must if you're craving fresh, delicious seafood. It's a bit on the pricier side so I wouldn't say this is a go to every time you're in the area but it's definitely a great spot for a nice intimate dinner or special occasions.

_9TKddYP4YX7G0vDa7yAMw.review_text: Okay seafood place. I expected more since it's oh-so-famous or well-known.

kXXrzVUFZJvPaj5cEcixpg.review_text: All I can say is Its the best!!!!!!!!!!! My favorite place by the water!!! Awesome service and the fish is very fresh. A must go to!!

hZo9zjadQWsbZkY1Sr0iPg.review_text: This is a great seafood place. Like pretty much every seafood place across this great nation, the decor is outdated (wood paneling ) the silverware started out formal but has been run through the dishwasher one to any times. And the food options are more originals and old fashion as opposed to more modern cuisine.  With that being said some things don't go out of style and fresh seafood cooked well never does.   I had the scallops in saffron cream sauce. These little puppies were delightful. Nice crispy on the outside with a perfectly grilled crust, moist and juicy on the inside. Some of the best I have ever had.   My wife had the local caught salmon. Man oh man could I have eaten this everyday. The salmon is so stinking good I would call you crazy to order something else.   Ordered the fresh  caught salmon.   Order the fresh caught calamari. Boom best app  Clam chowder...enough said.  Thank me later

S7y4b02kZHy3SzIhSEbG0w.review_text: I food was okay, not worth the price. Though more importantly, it came with a bout of food poisoning. Don't order the swordfish.

-Ih4ezfe150bS0B9tPqxgw.review_text: Incredibly fresh seafood! I had the combo crab and shrimp salad.  The flavor is fresh and tasty. The service... Impeccable.  While the decor is dated, it serves to the overall experience of an established icon of the neighborhood.  Well recommended.

BYgwqKrgcmXwE1kCsdCzTA.review_text: Yum.  Great old SF feel.  Good wines and drinks, really good fresh seafood. This place is a must every time I am back in San Francisco!

7nJrkjSd9DqBkVgCyXzoMA.review_text: A driver cab suggested this restaurant to us, he said the food is great so we decided to go and give it a try This restaurant is really pricey and the food is not as good as I expected,  I ordered bake cod fish in a butter lemon sauce and I got and oily tasteless fish, we paid $160 for soft drinks, appetizer and entrees.... Was not worth it  I wouldn't go back

M01neU-mU5UFTyVRwJpVXw.review_text: Delicious cioppino! Served spicy or nonspicy your choice. Huge serving size it could feed two or three.   Lobster bisque is really rich and creamy. Absolutely delicious!   Oyster trio was great! Tasted really fresh! Served half dozed and had three pairs of different types.   Service was excellent! Out waiter was enthusiastic, had suggestions, and demonstrated exemplary knowledge of the menu and how everything was prepared and cooked!

-ki-qIZHP4zZ2D49-b8ZzA.review_text: OK, I admit went here with friends based on the hype. Went in for lunch with a rather large group of 11.  For me it went bad as soon as our two servers started openly arguing over who serves who while trying to take our order. The appetizers we ordered, Wasabi Oysters were great. I also ordered the Clam Chowder, great. I then tried the Seafood Grill again very good. Over all, great food, just poor service and openly hostile servers...at least to each other. Kind of ruined it.

F1uCFF8QqK0P5xx-nIZDhg.review_text: Classy, upscale place.  A bit pricy, but it is a nice convivial atmosphere.  I enjoyed the lobster bisque.  It came with fresh Boudin bread and breadsticks.  Nice.  I also had a caesar salad that wasn't good.  When I noticed there were no anchovies, though, a waiter brought them over to me - exactly three anchovies!  Bartenders are friendly when you're drinking a lot, and quick.  This place does a killer business that caters mainly to tourists, but it can be good for a special occasion.  Evidently the views are good as well.  Maybe from upstairs; not from the bar.  The bar can be loud, but everyone I talked to in the whole place was having a great time, so I liked that.

SQblJmxo_tuMs_G1jS85SQ.review_text: This restaurant was recommended to my travel buddy and I, and so we ate here. We both ordered crab for our entrée and lobster bisque preceding it. Oh, also a pina colada and a rum and cake.   The entire meal was delicious. My favorite part was the lobster bisque. It was the first time I had eve eaten any but it was so good. I wished my bowl was never ending.   I didn't expect the crab to be seasoned so well. I put a leg I my mouth and even the shell was seasoned in in lemon and garlic if I remember correctly. Superb! I finished my pina colada with ease and it usually takes a pretty long time for me to finish alcoholic beverages.

cPCjyKxlzrIC8bhyVNYJew.review_text: I have been here twice with my family and every time the experience was great.  My mom is a huge fan of their crab salad, which tastes really fresh (highly highly recommend). The serving size is huge also. I honestly don't think this place is much more expensive than the crab stalls outside. Let's face it; a crab doesn't have that much meat. Given the ambience and the service, I would much rather eat at scoma's.  We usually come here for lunch to do the prix fixe. They have valet parking also which saved me so much headache for parking in fisherman's wharf.   Their dessert is awesome too. I had their raspberry/blueberry sorbet once and it was the best sorbet that I ever had.

m91rWRWBkMS9vQ5jhW-_Bg.review_text: Came here with my family for lunch and was very impressed and also lucky because the weather was perfect. The view of the bay is spectacular and the food is delicious as well. I ordered a glass of the Pinot Grigio to start and followed with the shrimp cocktail. I would love to come here again and sit outside if I got lucky enough to come when the weather is warm

pwRM_dUm4q1hL5NMCoy_1g.review_text: Good crab, took forever to get a seat even with a reservation :-(... And on my birthday.  So so, won't be back.

oKrct4Hc8hZNMYXecitLCw.review_text: I had a very nice business lunch  here with my company. I was here in the middle of the week, in the middle of the day and it was very busy.   I ordered the lobster ravioli and salmon and it was excellent.  There was a lobster tail also with the dish. I had garlic bread and you sure can't beat sourdough bread with seafood and Italian food.  I was salivating over the dishes my co-workers ordered. Crab piled high on salads. I love crab.  I am making plans to go back.  We all shared some tiramisu and cheesecake.  I don't think the Scoma's parking validation for two free hours in the Triangle Lot is enforced. I had to pay $15.00 but I will expense it.

YQoY_ygdtOaYgmdj3cNi1Q.review_text: It was ok.  The food was ok for the price and the service was ok in the sense that they gave everything we asked for but it all seemed like a favor at times.  Free valet parking and a place right on the waterfront are positives but this is really for the occasional visitor in town that wants San Francisco seafood and to see Fisherman's Wharf versus someone who lives here.

dYHZbU-QWN_V2QL-FzVc0A.review_text: My husband and I love to eat, and when we traveled to San Francisco for a vacation, Scoma's was on our list of places to try out based on the recommendation of a family member who had been there.  I ordered from the prix fixe lunch menu (not a bad deal), and my husband got the seared tuna sandwich.  The food was well-prepared, but we thought it was too predictable and overpriced.  Nothing notable about the food at all.  Also, the atmosphere in the restaurant was really dated, and is overdue for a face lift.  We walked away feeling like we could have saved some money AND easily had a better experience somewhere else.

AS-6FLwDQK6IMW0_dQoJHw.review_text: I've been coming to Fisherman's Wharf for years and have always had my eyes caught by all the tourist traps (I mean, really, who goes to Joe's Crab Shack when you're at Fisherman's Frikkin Wharf?). But I finally found this place and took the wife for her first cioppino. What a great one they had. They do it "lazy" style which means they take the crab meat out of the shell. Since my wife is pregnant, our waitress Sze Sze accommodated us by giving us more salmon instead of swordfish (most places usually just give you cod). The place is expensive but better than all the overpriced tourist traps around here.

BOETp4Xhi8apbdCyWG8O_w.review_text: Unreal food ciopinno was the very best I ate in San Fran grilled sand dabs and the petrale sole then get a pillow

BzuKRfaUpbr8gaWb2Dom8g.review_text: Our family "go to" for special events. Again We loved everything this last visit, raw oysters, calamari, bisque and scallops are a must. Complimentary Valet parking is key.

cXwzAeXKuWXe9y-3SHayOw.review_text: Me and my fiancee were there today. As we're Italian, we were little afraid about the so called italian cuisine. But we had to change our mind. The salmon and the halibut were tender and really well cooked. Delicious! Definitely recommended... And the italian-speaking staff is a huge plus! :)

ongkMyvWO2rZmk8DPd2Fiw.review_text: Everyone has their own definition of what makes a great cioppino. That being said, Scoma's has the best I've ever encountered. Their broth is slightly more robust than the standard with really bold flavor. Seafood was outstanding and fresh.   Don't buy into the snooty "Fisherman's Warf Tourist" crap, this place is great.

JTB_5P3Ua92FXW1Ob6FU-Q.review_text: Best seafood in town.  Must try for tourists and locals.

kSCi9zYkeB9dTYtcz-jzNQ.review_text: Seared Ahi and Calamari appetizer, Filet and Lobster for me, Salmon and Lobster Ravioli for her. Everything arrived perfectly cooked and at a perfect temperature for eating. The calamari was fresh tender and crisp and we had the Calabrese sauce on the side. Exceptional with the right amount of heat. The seared Ahi was terrific, but I expected wassabi on the plate. The fish was so tasty, we quickly forgot how to spell wassabi. The main course came together and was delicious. The filet mignon was cooked exactly med rare and the lobster was huge!. We shared the plates and both exclaimed how perfect this dinner was. A very nice Birthday for my girl and an exceptional SF restaurant.

iKdUwPGZvrrW6TMAcPFQMg.review_text: O-M-G! Is it possible to have a platter that's part orgasmic? Whoa. First time here and I had the $36 Shellfish Saute Sac...or something like that and enjoyed every last juicy drop of that pasta/lobster/rice/veggie/shrimp platter.   The waiter Juan was amazing and was super helpful in making my selection. The wait was not that bad for a 730pm Saturday night and who can beat FREE (tip of course) valet by the wharf!  So today I enjoyed my last night's leftovers and they were just as good as last night. Perfectly cooked, marinated, and served. HUGE portions so come hungry or ask for a takeout box from the jump.  It has a "Love Boat" feel on the inside of the restaurant, but if you get a good seat, a cool view of the Bay.   I am already planning my next trip here. Btw- did I mention I am not a seafood lover? Scoma's changed my mind.  Oh yah, for 4, including a bottle of vino and yummy Tiramisu = $300, plus tip.

DFs_Zh2jGbAMNszgiF5tyg.review_text: Touristy. The location is top-notch, the food is okay. I think there are better fish places in the city. Worth trying once or twice. Also reservations are tough to get from what I understand.

VHdY6oG2JPVNjihWhOooAQ.review_text: Scoma's is a nice departure from the hustle and chaos of Fisherman's Wharf. Right on the water - it's a timeless example of classic San Francisco. With a slightly dated but altogether charming interior, lined with pictures of celebrities who have once enjoyed the Scoma menu - it's bursting with character. We were seated quickly and were able to peer out at the docked boats gently lolling on the mellow water ripples. Seals even swam by with relaxed elegance as we dined.  Our waiter was suited in up in a formal white shirt and black pants. It was evident by the way he discussed the menu that he's been a fixture at Scoma's for awhile. We ended up getting a plate of the prawns and scallops - which came nestled beside creamy garlic mashed potatoes, seasoned rice, and steamed vegetables, the Petrale Dore, and the Broiled Wild Salmon. The salmon was incredible. Moist and paired nicely with the mashed potatoes and simple vegetables. The scallops and prawns were huge and exploding with flavor. The Petrale Dore was tasty - but it is served fish and chips style - so it was a tad heavy and greasy.  We all thoroughly enjoyed our meal, but moreover we enjoyed that we could hear each other talk and welcomed the quietness apart from the busy main wharf.  Highly recommend this fresh fish restaurant and would definitely love a return visit to enjoy their other acclaimed dishes such as Scoma's  "Lazy's Man's" Cioppino.  Trust.

UFrMtW4z6Bauap6PHY9wnw.review_text: Great Service, ok view if you like run down buildings. Food was ok, defiantly was expecting much more.   Bread was the highlight of the dinner.

rQa9B8sNudevbhXnaLm9jw.review_text: The best clam chowder ever! Delicious soups, seafood and pasta.

kUdZrk983lUDZSCkuiffDg.review_text: Maybe it was because it is just the start of crab season, but the crab we had at Scoma's tonight was the most delicious thing I have eaten in a long time and I am a regular at some pretty nice restaurants.  We had a group of 6 people and they gave us a quiet area off the main dining room with fantastic views of the harbor.  It was a peaceful evening in the normally touristy fisherman's wharf area.  The lemon tart was also just something that was out of this world delicious.  I did not think I could stuff another morsel of food in my mouth, but I had to take one more bite of the lemon tart it was THAT GOOD.  I highly recommend it, and will definitely go back.  Everyone in my group agreed that they had been to all the other seafood restaurants on the wharf and this was by far their favorite dining experience.  I can not say enough good things about it.  From the attentive staff, to the views, the ambiance, the wine, the food, wow.....

UhrtCI2WBxsubN8vGDSHuQ.review_text: Really grateful that my aunt treated me to this place, otherwise my broke ass would not even think about coming here. This place is tucked away behind the rest of the restaurants you see on Jefferson St, but finding it is like a kopi luwak farmer finding coffee beans in civet crap, IT'S GREAT.  Wait time on a Saturday night around 9pm was 30 minutes, but well worth it. Really good clam chowder, really rich and flavorful. Lobster bisque pretty good too, but personally preferred the former. Got sauteed mixed seafood with linguini, where the seafood was amazingly tender and fresh. Portions not bad, while those for the cioppino are very generous; however it has a heavy tomato-based flavor, so if you're not a fan of tomatoes I would not recommend. Not sure if it's just me, but the complementary breads I've had in SF (including this restaurant) have been relatively hard, but I guess that's what sauce is for.   Best seafood I've had ever.

GrktSJ7Bv9t37gwDLIlAwg.review_text: I've only just recently visited this fine establishment. Not only has it withstood the test of time, but the food is killer as well. The portions here are giant. I got the lazy man's cioppino and the bowl the size of a helmet. It was flavorful, but not fishy. The scallops and shrimp used were large. It was full of crab meat. The chefs did not skimp out and that bowl was loaded. The clam chowder was the same, lots of celery. I loved it and it was not thin at all. The Alaskan halibut steak was great too, but the person who came to clear our dishes away threw away a big piece that we were gonna take home as leftovers. It was a sad moment, but I wasn't too sad at the time because I was drinking a well made maitai. The beer selection here is pretty standard. You should also know that there is no drink menu! You'll just get what you want. There is also a prix fixe menu every night and it's a pretty good deal considering most entrees are within the 26-35 range.

Ust0z0l6J3t5e-nIgToxPA.review_text: While walking along the wharf with my cousin, two elderly British men followed us (one wearing a bowler).  They approached us and asked where we were dining for supper and we were not sure.  They raved and raved about Scoma's abalone and were insistent that is where we should go.  My cousin and I looked at each other, and I said, "It sounds like it might be a great restaurant".  Ok, well we walked with a more rapid pace to get ahead of them.  We got to this crowded restaurant and were told it would be a 45 minute wait.  We decided to get a glass of wine at the bar while waiting.  Suddenly, the British men approach us at the bar and said, "The wait for the table may be 20 minutes".  We responded, "We were told it would be 45 minutes".  The man with the bowler said, "I cancelled your table, so you will be dining with us".  In horror, my cousin and I looked at each other and didn't want to create a scene.  We didn't know what to say.  Just minutes after this conversation, the hostess called us.  As we passed the other patrons and then the front door, my cousin darted out and I was just behind her.  We never got to eat there, because of the British gentlemen, but we felt hijacked, and laughed about what their faces must have looked like when we pulled a sly one on them.    I can only speak from my experience here, and the hostess should have never changed our reservation without our consent.

Ud8tcgnxp0w0qBtXt_DKOg.review_text: My friends from so cal raved and raved about this restaurant.  Funny thing is, I'm from the yay area and have never heard of Scoma's...and no one else from home had heard of it either.  Well, I'm glad they introduced me to this place because it was delicious!  It was an upscale dinner on the water.  Upscale actually might be the reason why I've never been to or heard of Scoma's.  Food was amazing!  We started with calamari and I got the pasta "Fisherman style"-  seafood linguini in red sauce.  Delish!  The cioppino was also amazing.  The portions are huge and definitely sharable!  The highlight of our meal was our waiter: Andre.  Without a doubt, we were the youngest (also darkest) people at this restaurant and Andre seemed to be really refreshed by the change in clientele.   He was hillarious, polite, quick, and a little loopy.  In other words:  awesome!  Scoma's?...S'co!!

jaKOnWN9eEfLvYhjLfYTbA.review_text: Disappointing. The food was excellent (as always), but the service was not up to the standard I am used to and the changes to the menu are equally disappointing.  Their prices have increased but the portions are smaller, the side selections have narrowed and are not up to the standard of their traditional rice pilaf and garlic mashed potatoes. The main dishes are still the highest quality and in the 15+ years I have been going there, I have never had a bad meal, but the 25 minutes between ordering my salad and getting it and the additional 15 waiting for the entree (while waiting the whole time to get a refill on my coffee), was unacceptable. The explanation of why they replaced the traditional rice and potatoes was to offer more"healthy" choices. Clearly, they mistake the purpose of a fine restaurant. If I want someone to watch my calories for me, I'll get married.  When I go out to dine, I am looking for quality food and service.  I felt this was not what I received. The service was slow, the selection of sides to my meal less than satisfactory, and while the entree ( prawns and scallops) was outstanding, the overall experience was less than I have come to expect from Scoma's.

u9KhzES5reUljwccEyFdJw.review_text: It t'was a roomie dinner kind of night. I kept getting rave reviews about this place so naturally I had super high expectations. But my high expectations fell short and was not super impressed. Everything was just ok here. The server was hilarious though!! Wayman was his name and he was too funny, but not the kind where he was trying to be funny at all. Hard to explain but needless to say he made our night.

IIlSJgf_KNPbbw5Vr9hvbw.review_text: This place is so elegant. The food.I'd great the drinks.are the bomb. Of I could I would eat everyday. Seafood sec is on Dec

Bv9hxkLqarmTj63cyNj70g.review_text: Great location, great view, and a cool old school feel. Service was patchy- but I've had worse. Food was also decent.  We had: - Crab cakes- amazing. Get them. Now. - Lobster ravioli with broiled salmon- also decent, but the ravioli was better than the salmon (a bit dry). Bonus point for the saffrom cream sauce being an amazing dip for the pound of sourdough bread we consumed. - Seafood platter- scallops, shrimps, crab, and lobster. I dont care either way for scallops or shrimp (my friend left most of the scallops behind, and he loves scallops)- but the crab and lobster were delish. This comes with rice AND pasta- strange! - Apple crisp a la mode- sugary apple sauce was good and I ate this with the ice cream, after finding the apples were far too hard and spongy.   Overall worth checking out- but next time I will probably come just for the heavenly crab cakes and wine.

b1eSLK5ChHf48_yDQq-6pQ.review_text: Old school SF waterfront dining.  Much go at least once in your life. Clam chowder was the bomb!  Go there and ask to sit in Heros section, he is an Armenian waiter that has been there for 25 years and is very fun.  Get him talking and interact with him.  Salads are to die for.  Prices are steep but what a great meal and fun time.

2nfGdDq4cYOMuRgeGJGYrw.review_text: We enjoyed a great vacation in both Sonoma and San Francisco.  Ended our stay at Scoma's for dinner the night before we left.  We first had drinks at the bar while we waited for our table and the bartender recommended the cioppino.  Thank God I listened to him!!! Food was fantastic and it was the first dinner in a VERY VERY long time that I could NOT finish.  The bowl that the cioppino came in was filled to the brim with seafood.  The appetizers were unbelievable as well.  I had the ahi tuna and my wife had the crabcakes.  I recommend either of them.  Service was good.  Why 4 stars you ask?  The service may have been slightly pushy...the minute you finished there was someone on top of you taking your dish away.  I guess we felt a little rushed...All'n'all a great dinner and I would definitely be back when I'm on the west coast again.

_rCTsmoYmWmM-F33PBGN2w.review_text: Wow - what a difference 30 years makes.   I came here on my first visit to SF in 1978 and it was totally awesome and classy.  I was wearing a shirt and tie back then in 1978 and I didn't meet their dress code since I didn't have a jacket.   They went and got me a totally oversized jacket so I could eat dinner.  Fast forward to 2011.   We stopped in this weekend and there were people there in shorts, worn out jeans and flannel shirts, with the topper being a dude who looked like he'd just changed the spark plugs in his tractor - his shirt was totally covered in oil stains.  Come on people - I wouldn't dress like that for a trip to Red Lobster, if I would actually go to a Red Lobster!  Maybe it would be ok to look like that at Long John Silvers - for lunch.  So about the food.   It was just 'ok'.    We had crab cakes, clam chowder and lobster bisque to start.   The crab cakes were the best of the three.   For entrees we had scallops with pasta and salmon entrees.   Scallops were good, but salmon was almost tasteless.  The brownie dessert with Jack Daniels caramel sauce was nice.    Good wine list - we had the Hess Su'Skol Chardonnay.  Our server was an older woman who was great.   I wonder if she has been forced to suffer through the changing patronage of the last 30 years?   I know the economy is not great Scoma's, but bring back some level of dress code.  Maybe no oil-stained work shirts would be a good start???  Not an offensive meal, but we're in no hurry to go back.

UDVZDR7uabI1blSiXQE4aQ.review_text: This restaurant was definitely not worth the money. Its small, out dated, my fiancee and I were sat at a table in the corner of the dining room where part of the wall jutted out and I had use of about 1/3rd of the table. How this place gets 4/5 stars is beyond me since there are many other restaurants in the area serving better food (looks like all the meals come with mashed potatoes and vegetables). I wish we had gone to one of the other restaurants. If you are wanting  average service with 1970s paneling environment, this place is for you.

Ng8FR41UoOL64zT7NrcdqQ.review_text: My wife and I got 2 whole garlic crabs.  They were fantastic!

7MRgjyhnAtcnoAnv7T0bCw.review_text: The best smelling urinals I've ever had the pleasure of using. (Sorry ladies - you'll never know.) The seafood was exceptionally good as well.  Try the calamari.

wpK6Ac4SO4GcI5JNNgnHXg.review_text: Great little place tucked away on the wharf!  This place was recommended to me by a friendly employee at the Embassy Suites in Burlingame. First off, it is super easy to get to, you pull your car up and they whisk it away for you for no charge (well, except a nice tip for the valet). This is definitely a plus for a "tourist" at the wharf to not have to worry about finding a place to park in a foreign city.  Now to the dining! My group had drinks at the bar as we waited (we were walk-ins and were accommodated with no problems, took maybe 10 minutes). Nothing special, waitstaff was helpful and informative regarding the local brews on tap.  Seated (party of 4) at a smallish table, albeit most tables at Scoma's are on the small side. The waitress was very energetic and was quite knowledgeable about any dish we asked about. I went with one of the specials, a seared, caught-that-morning Ahi tuna steak, served with a ginger reduction (complete with soy and wasabi), fantastically cooked (i mean perfect!) fresh veg, and smashed garlic potatoes. The tuna was skillfully seared and was very tasty; the accouterments creating an Asian flare. The sides were great, with the mash done with gusto and the normally forgettable vegetable side being an absolute stand-out.  My comrades also decided on one of the pescetarian specials. Two of them having the blackened halibut, again wit the fresh veg and garlic mash. The halibut was magnificent, envelope white and wonderfully flaky, with a meaty and fulfilling mouth feel.   All in all, my experience at Scoma's was a great one. My only regret is that I would have chosen a dish with a fish that has more inherent flavor. Don't get me wrong, tuna is good, but its flavor is not overt and I'm afraid the flavor of the fish itself was maksed by the heavier flavors of the meal's other players.  Needless to say, I'll be going there again!

8O5ZFkqiR8MMkPeSJrnZjA.review_text: Be prepared for a wait because they do not take reservations, but that is okay because the food is worth it. Every time a visit SF I'm sure to have dinner at Scoma's. I love ahi and the prepare it perfectly. Their clam chowder is to die for as well.

B5p1dfNdGtIzZxZd5qcOoA.review_text: I felt this place was more of a tourist trap.  Cioppino we had was not very good.  Everything was dry and bland.  I guess you don't order steak in a seafood restaurant, but that's what my wife did.   She really learned her lesson with this one.  Hah!  RIbeye was over cooked and way too thin of a cut to be in a  higher end restaurant.  Our dinner was around 6:30 so we only had to wait 15 min.  There were about 8 in our party so we were also able to try each others plate.  No one was really impressed.  View was nothing to rave about.  You get to see some boats go in and out of the slip.  Nice touch is the free valet!  Can't say I'll be back, but I can now say I've tried the famous Scoma's at fisherman's wharf!

4gs3sWfbQ5j0wv73-lZLhw.review_text: I love sea food. But like another sea food restaurants it is not better but simply the good. I visited here last month for only one time and took their smelish hospitality. i was so disappointed since ever other experience I've had here was so much better. Its ok, But their Salmon was awesome and so pretty. If I come back, just for it's delish Salmon not for others.

WY36nLwpx5vml_HYCxKG1Q.review_text: My wife and I have been going here for 40 years. The freshest seafood, tastiest sourdough bread anywhere.  And the location on a pier called "Scoma's Way" adds to the total genuine San Francisco experience.  A good place to bring special family visitors or guests for a drink first, then lunch or dinner.

J9HamWsxKorlPGUAXy-M9Q.review_text: Scoma's can be easily missed even with Google Maps navigating on your iPhone.  Be prepared ahead of time to avoid circling around an already busy tourist area.  Parking is somewhat limited so valeting it would be your best bet.  When you enter, you'll want to have that nice view of the bay since the large glass windows won't block the nice view.  Onto the food!  For starters, you'll want to grab the infamous hearty man's cioppino.  It's stewy and hearty so be careful you don't tap out only on the first course.  With the complimentary bread, it's easy to fill up since the bread goes so well with that tomato soup base.  If you want to play it safe, split the cioppino with your date.  The other thing to try is the lobster bisque.  It's a love or hate thing so if you're not a fan of bisque, then don't get it.  I'm a fan of both bisque and lobster so it was a great starter for dinner.  It tastes like I'm sucking out the lobster entrails from it's body/shell/carapace!  The crab cakes were pretty good but small.  I wished they were just a tad bit bigger to be satisfying.  I won't go into detail for the main entrees since the appetizers were pretty good and talking further would ruin the good vibe already built up.  Only thing I can say is that the entrees are mediocre compared to the appetizers/soup.  Summary of items ordered: * Cioppino * Lobster bisque * Crab cakes * Lamb t-bone * Yellowfin tuna * Tiramisu * Chocolate brownie with vanilla bean ice cream

cEfuagqIryfE3Q804DNn7w.review_text: Excellent place for a date. Kind of a classy joint tucked away on Fisherman's Wharf. Well worth the price. A must try is the crab cakes!! Excellent service!

8B4LYEZHc6Vw2BsqDHgnvg.review_text: My fiancée  family has been going to this restaurant for over 30 years to enjoy different dishes, but mainly for the Lazy Ciopinno. We went here as usual this last Saturday, and found out that the old. traditional recipe for Ciopinno was recently changed. Unfortunately, not for the best ... My fiancée who was so loyal to this place for so many years said that there is no really reason to come back:(

9SoO6g3AT7UHSaIRtwr_-g.review_text: 4.5 Stars  First let me say that there was many things that were not going in our favor in regards to eating here.  Like I do in many cities I visit I like to ask the locals the best place to eat.  Many times I get "tourist" places, but sometimes I get some good unique places.  This is definitely the former but the location and the building was pretty cool and made it look like a place that I may have never been before.   First, I don't think we (and my wife for sure) were looking for a "fine dining" place to eat.  More of just a good seafood joint.  When my wife saw the menu and the prices next to them she nearly fell off her chair.  She was so upset with how expensive it was she literally started crying.  I; however, was just looking for what I wanted to eat from what looked like a pretty righteous seafood place.    This is where I look like a bad husband (but I partially redeem myself later I promise). I ordered the cioppino and the lobster bisque...she was so pissed off she ordered nothing.  I had little remorse...but I digress...  The whole time while the food was being prepared I was consoling her and assuring her that we were on vacation and we can go out to a nice meal.  When the food came I split everything I ordered with her (GO ME) and she had nothing to say but positive things about the food (However, when she looks back at this place she still doesn't think it was worth it).   I guess this is the part where I actually review the food (c'mon I had to set the mood). The cioppino was the best I have ever had.  The broth was very flavorful, but didn't take away from the freshness of the seafood.  It felt like there was literally pounds of seafood in this dish too.  The size of each piece of seafood was very impressive - and you can almost justify the price because of that.  The lobster bisque was great as well.  So yeah, its quite pricey (and crowded), but I would go back there to get the cioppino no questions asked, but I may need to sign the deed of my car over to get it.

zk_mInlLMmLLqMk6IvXm9g.review_text: Ciopinno! (medium please) adjectives: large serving (can be shared), Hearty, rich, tasty. The 2 pieces of garlic bread goes so well with savory broth. The Crab stuffed Portabello Mushroom was a good appetizer.

l9qCVCOFcdtoBqp88WYHmA.review_text: This is a delicious place to get your seafood . We live in the bay area and was just told by another local that this is the place to go for seafood by the worf. And that is so true.

boKoupSPbFkqB-tkXbEkPw.review_text: Had lunch two weeks ago. Overpriced. Mediocre service. Clam chowder was served cold and with very little flavor. $35 risotto was tasteless. Tuna was good.  $50 per person for a mediocre lunch? Bill oakland

GBfOPFlKzRXRAkQUJ1K_6A.review_text: Scoma's is a classic restaurant that everybody who visits SF should go to. Great views and great food but unfortunately the service is on the disappointing side (and prices are high). Waiter was audibly indignant at a low tip (not mine but from a different table), seemed inconvenienced by our requests, didn't refill our waters, etc. is not what I would expect from a place like Scoma's.  The squash and crab bisque was wonderfully rich and flavorful. The special of crab claws has generous amount of crab claws, had and okay flavor but was on the soupy side (broccoli was nicely cooked) and had to much onions.  Overall I would have expected more and hope that the next time I go it will be much better on both fronts.

gWXH61bWjPIOJC9rzAxKoA.review_text: Amazing atmosphere...service was excellent and the food was perfect. My companion had the seared scallops and I had the halibut. So flavorful ... Delicious!!!

7KFWWjzHOSBl9HDVXkyusQ.review_text: Its really cramped in there but the food is wonderful. They have valet parking (its a little pricey) so its convenient. You get an awesome view of the Warf from where ever you sit. I have been coming to this place for almost 30 years, and I will always make a trip to Scoma's when I am in San Francisco!

5Qx5gSh8bBpxJ6GkzWJ3Zw.review_text: Yelp is not always right. I learned this the hard way this evening. This place is not good. I really cannot figure out why it is rated so highly on yelp. Girlfriend had the ciopinno. Every recipe we have seen of ciopinno has a fish stock or chicken stock as the base of the broth. Scoma's has a marinara sauce. It's fish, shrimp, mussels, and scallops drowned in marinara sauce. I had a cup of clam chowder and broiled halibut. The clam chowder was actually pretty good. The halibut could have been served by Red Lobster and no one could tell the difference.  As some previous reviews have said, it is an old place with wood paneling on the walls and framed pictures of old sports stars on said walls. It looks like a trailer home on the ocean. And you think "This place has to be good to look like this and still be open." Don't think that. Just eat somewhere else

GCKeeBPoVFFboelHsRhMpA.review_text: I went to Scoma's recently and was so disappointed. I've been going there for years because I loved their pan seared scallops. Right away, I noticed the change in the menu and the higher prices!  My friend ordered the seafood platter and it was overcooked and very average. My scallops were fresh enough, but swimming in a pinkish colored sauce. Not a fan.  I really wish the menu had not changed and I was able to get my resonably priced pan seared scallops, like I always got in the past...

m_dpeYKcVRdCoQIVJ6DoOA.review_text: San Francisco ledge.   Sort of underground, off the beaten path of the touristy crab traps, which is why I love it! Great crab, oysters, wine and fun old school atmosphere... on the ocean!   Go here!

dsBY5eS8qMdzLcc2EGWRig.review_text: I went here on a Sunday afternoon with my family who introduced me to this place. I highly suggest getting a reservation when coming here because it gets packed pretty early. We ordered some oysters, seafood pasta, lobster ravioli, clams, calamari, and a mixed seafood grill. Everyone also had their own little bowl of clam chowder. I can honestly say that everything was delicious!!! Seafood was very fresh and portions are pretty big. I was stuffed after sharing all of that with 5 other people. On top of that, the service is also amazing. Just thinking about this place makes me want to go back! This is a must visit especially if your a tourist!

n-ek8dBSyqrN0hw85uEcbA.review_text: Excellent service. Minimal wait time. Food was outstanding. Lobster bisque and clam chowder outstanding.  Cioppino best ever.  Would definitely come back again. Big portions. Cioppino enough for two. Fish and chips yummy for kids.

zDXsPnVKieNwjfHhexNR_Q.review_text: One of my favorite all time meals.  From the outside this place looks kind of odd, but its right on the water, parking has never been a problem and its off the beaten path.    I have been here 2 times during my trips to San Francisco and both times the staff was amazing, great at explaining and recommending different dishes.  Its a little higher priced but so worth it.  The bisque is amazing.  Everything I have ordered or my friends have ordered here has been amazing really.

UlVDOMIYfTwxWeRVtVI4eA.review_text: OK friends prepared to be shocked. Many consider me a food connoisseur and if they want to find a good place to eat will ask my opinion. Here it comes... I have lived in the Bay area 35 of my 36 years and I finally went to the World Famous Scoma's in Fishermen's Warf for the first time. I had two items, a cup of clam chowder and the Shellfish Sauté.   Let's start with the clam chowder. Overall it was very good, but not my favorite. I am however not going to knock them because I can see why so many think it's one of the best. it was very flavorful and very dense. I personally prefer clam chowder that has less potatoes and veggies and is more about the clams. Probably the best chowder I've had yet was on the pier in Monterey, sorry the name escapes me. The waitress did bring me a little sample of the Lobster Bisque at Scoma's and my recommendation (unless you can't get chowder off the brain) is go for the bisque.  The Sauté was absolutely amazing. Prawns, Scallops, Lobster, and Crab Legs Sautéed with Onions, Mushrooms and Garlic in a White Wine and Butter Sauce served over a bed of rice with a small helping of pasta noodles and zucchini. This was one of the best seafood dishes I've ever had, what's better is I could not finish it and had the rest for breakfast the next day.  I will not be passing by Scoma's without having them ever again. I fell in love!

QsMLT06-s4vltVIz8DgpMw.review_text: Their seafood is ridiculously good, I can't believe this was the first time I've ever been here. We came for dinner on a Saturday (we made reservations ahead of time), and were seated right away.   We ordered the Ciopinno (drool...) and the Mixed Seafood Grill (consisting of grilled shrimp, scallops, and salmon). We also ordered fried oysters and lobster bisque as starters. I'll begin with the fried oysters, which were fried perfectly. Breading was crispy like a panko breading, and the oyster was fried just enough to give it that crispy edge, but without drying the oyster itself out. The lobster bisque was on point, savory but not too salty.   Now, the Ciopinno was great; the tomato broth was a bit on the rich side, but not enough to cover the taste of the seafood. Mussels were cooked just right, soft and not rubbery. Scallops were amazing, and the fish was fantastic. The mixed seafood plate was amazing; their grilled shrimp was probably the best shrimp I've ever had. The seasoning was SO good, and the shrimp itself had that snap/crunch which all grilled shrimp should have. Salmon was perfectly cooked through; moist but not raw, and was seasoned well. Scallops were great too, as expected.   I'd recommend coming here for any special occasion. The staff is well trained, courteous and very accommodating should you have any special needs.

auPmZp0fAi0kxlYppfg1XA.review_text: We had several dishes, including the Seared Tuna, which I get everywhere, so lots to compare it to. Hubby had Crab Louis salad, which was way overpriced. Everything was okay, but nothing was great, and the prices were high for what you get. Older decor (and not in a good way). Very good service, though. I'd say 2.5 stars would be more a more accurate rating, but I couldn't give 3 stars based on the prices..

CHg5ikv6HjCcSLAc8vo1Kw.review_text: Can you say sea food heaven?!  I have a love/hate relationship with it's reservation policy.  It's great that you could get a table there any day of the week and all you have to do is show up.  But this place is ridiculously popular for locals.  An average wait time is an hour or more for a table.  It is worth the wait though.    My favorite menu items: Oysters Rockefeller - a must have for oyster lovers. Shell Fish Saute - it's a treasure chest of the sea. Lobster Ravioli - What's bad about ravioli stuffed with lobster in a saffron sauce?  You'll never know who you'll see here. So be prepared to look your best!

AR5UkND2s1kj4JBGWmX2MQ.review_text: Its good food, I was happy with my meal. I also sampled off the other plates in our party, those were equally as good.

Io1ILaKfXwA0XUratbsKhQ.review_text: Here's what you need to know...  It's a tourist trap but a decent one.  Their fish and shellfish are very high quality and fresh.  If you have a view of the water you scored; I usually am seated with a view of the parking lot and pier.  They have a surcharge of 4% for the "health and welfare" of their staff; thanks Obamacare!  Their soups, both clam chowder and lobster bisque are delicious.  Entrees are fairly expensive, don't let the cheesy atmosphere here fool you, the owners think they have quite the classy establishment  Vince Scoma was in my 6th grade class at Moraga Junior High. :-)

88qLfMt45wIB1in74KrDMA.review_text: The lack of fourth and fifth star is due to the rude hostess tonight. Upon arrival at 5:30pm on a Sunday evening we were to be seated immediately but I had overheard our same hostess offer  the arrivals behind us the option of window seating.  Of course I'd wait for this option as well, I thought to myself, and quickly requested that we have window seating as well.
