Oddly enough the couple (who arrived AFTER my mother and I) were seated first. Why?  The less than pleasant hostess shortly answered, "because they asked for a window first". Failing to admit that you hadn't offered us the window AND stating such ill logic so rudely is a terrible first impression in my book.  5 more tables continued to be seated before us. Ridiculous.   The dinner we enjoyed was A-OK.   Lobster Bisque: after noting this suggestion in multiple Yelp reviews, I had anticipated this bisque to be a life altering experience.  It was fair.  Dungeness Crab Cake on Watercress Salad with Lemon Vinaigrette & Remoulade Sauce:  The BEST plate of the night. The crab cakes were delicious, the watercress was fresh and tasty and all of the flavors went very well together.   Broiled Wild Pacific Swordfish with Tuscan White Beans, Pancetta, Tomatoes & Organic Rainbow Chard: One bite into this dish and I immediately wished I had went for the scallops instead. This entrée was fair but nothing to write home about.   Pumpkin Cheesecake with Pumpkin Seed Brittle: Delightful! I was so surprised to have such a tasty and beautiful dessert at a seafood restaurant.

fTEyXnoDabxUi4v5aaF01w.review_text: I was very disappointed with Scoma after going in with high expectations.  The location was great, but in my opinion the food was below average. My fiancé and I both had the crab risotto after having other great risottos elsewhere in SF, and it was pretty bad.  It wasn't a traditional risotto, but rather looked like some rice mixed in a light tomato sauce.    It didn't help matters that this place was way overpriced...or that I felt sick right after my meal.

7mFixJ9TS6UCvNMPaikI7Q.review_text: Went here a few weeks ago during fleet week with my fiance, mom & her husband & I must say that the valet parking was much greatly appreciated. So this was my 2nd time coming here, the 1st was several years ago for our families annual Cousin's Lunch. I didn't get it then & I still don't get it now... what exactly do they all love about this place? I know, I know... they've been around for a long time, the same people who worked there 20 years ago are still there, blah blah blah, but come on already, can they spring for a few updates? I don't know, something about it just doesn't mesh. The small wobbly tables that are so close I might elbow you in the back of the head if I turn in the wrong direction, the waiters with their pressed white coats & black bow ties, it just doesn't feel right.   The food? It's over-priced & just OK. When my mom suggested this place a few weeks ago I cringed because all I could remember was the last visit when I ordered crab & it came out already shelled. Yeah, I know for some that sounds super convenient, for me, the meal was ruined... I LIKE CRACKING MY OWN CRAB. Anyway, this time was okay. My grouper was fine, my fiance wasn't overly impressed because he thinks anyplace that serves seafood should offer whole fish (head, tail, everything).

onXW3feeMlULCH5z-ebyEA.review_text: I enjoyed dining at Scomas! Many reviews mentioned that the resturant needed updating, but a Detroit girl like me can appreciate a resturant with history, good service and an ole school feel :-)  The food was amazing!! We ordered crab cakes for an appetizer. The cakes were soooooo FRESH, served with a delicious sauce and atop a small bed of lettuce.   I ordered shrimp annuzzi. Let me tell you...this dish was bursting with flavor. The shrimp were cooked to perfection (lightly pan fried in an egg batter) along with rice and veggies. Btw, the dish had eight large prawns, for thirty bucks. Really??? Why are people complaining about prices??? Very satisfied!! I have no issues with paying for good food.   My boo ordered shrimp/Dungeness crab risotto. I had a spoonful of it. It tasted amazing.   Too stuffed for dessert. This is a MUST STOP if you're in San Francisco. The waiters were cute, with their formal outfits.

T2gH3azj_24N4DiyoPPZQQ.review_text: We were there in oct 2014. Enjoyed and very good food. Highly recommended for fresh seafood.

2jC4uzM_rUMYS2kDrJJ3UA.review_text: I have eaten at Scoma's in the past with mixed feelings.  So being in The City again I thought I'd take a friend and try it again.  Was close to our hotel and was raining so a close place was definitely in the cards.  No problem getting a booth overlooking the fishing fleet (which is really a bunch of charter boats that likely never leave the dock but, hey, it's Fisherman's Wharf so there had to be boats, right.?).  White table cloth Italian. I will say the service was very good.  Not hovering, knew when to leave one alone.  White jacketed waitstaff in a white table cloth restaurant.  Cool.!  As for the food..  Well, it's crab season so I go with the Dungeness Crab Cocktail.  $18..  One can do better at the walk up in front of Alioto's or Pompei's Grotto.  Crab was mostly flakes, was watery and the cocktail sauce so overpowering with horseradish that using it drowned what little taste of crab existed.  Friend had Caesar Salad.  She ate maybe 5 bites and pushed the rest around the plate.  Said it was mostly watery lettuce and tasteless.  On to dinner.!!!  Neither of us wanted fish so she has a Pasta Pomodoro.  Simple thin spaghetti, tomatoes, olive oil and garlic.  Looked terrible..  Skins on the tomatoes and watery.  More small bites and food pushing.!!  I had a Penne Bolognese.  Waiter said it was made with "really good cuts of meat."  OK, so I didn't know hacked up Italian sausage was considered "really good cuts of meat."   The sauce was thick enough and somewhat spicy where positives..  However the penne was over cooked to the point of being pasty and bland.  I also thought it amazing that both mains arrived very quickly after ordering.  Hum, can you say "pre-cooked/hot boxed/pre-fab.?"  Price..  When all was said and done with 1 drink each we ended up owing some $150.  Way over priced for the quality.  Look, I get the Wharf.  I get the tourists, shops full of junk, tee-shirts, etc. so I guess with the tackiness comes mediocre restaurant options under the disguise of "high end SF dining."  So be warned..   Scoma's isn't great and not worth the price.  And please don't think it is representative of the quality of SF dining.  I tell my friends that it's hard to find a bad meal in The City unless, that is, you go to Scoma.!

Ml2i2mGdUyrRswXZZlbKNw.review_text: Overdue review... but better late than never?  Known for their seafood at Fisherman's Wharf. Thank goodness they offer valet parking! Definitely saves time and it's FREE! :)  Food-  Dungeness Crab Cakes on Watercress Salad - Crabcakes were crispy with small chunks of crab. Watercress salad was refreshing and complemented well.  Lantern Scallops and Fettuccine - Scallops were pretty small... Pasta was rich in flavor, but nothing to be amazed or wowed by.   Chocolate Brownie and Vanilla Bean Ice Cream - Can't really mess up with this dessert.... but tasted delicious especially mixing the brownie with the ice cream!  Service was just OK.... but prices are definitely higher since you're at Fisherman's wharf. (This restaurant is definitely a tourist trap!) The restaurant was really packed that Saturday night. In my opinion, I don't think I'll be back just because I have had better seafood meals elsewhere.

xCZoEjVXr6rvmEIlSpSm9w.review_text: My favorite place to get Dungeness crab that's excellent every time! Service is always great even when the place is super crowded

lXYJQ5UyogEig_6rXoaTRA.review_text: Why bother writing a review after all the hype?  I will tell you why,,,,,,,,,, BITE ME,,,,,,,,,, this place is great!  I would never never never never never never never never never never never never never never  (you get the idea) consider going to Fisherman''s Wharf to eat anything!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  I have been humbled.    One of the best clam chowders I have ever tasted.  Ordered a small dinner salad and added crab,,,,,,,,,, there must have been 1/2 a dungeness crab on the friggin thing,,,,,,, for 8 clams!  Great Louis dressing!  Wifeypie ordered a Shellfish Saute and I had the Broiled Colossal Prawns and Dry Pack Sea Scallops Alla Gannon.  No need to say anything except that these dishes were beyond generous, cooked perfectly and totally some of the best prepared seafood anywhere.  If I could subtract 1/2 a star it would be for ambiance or being tucked into your neighbors lap unless you luck out or complain. Get past that,,,,,,, this place is now one our faves in SF, hands down!  Yelp,,,,,,,,,,,,,, THANK YOU!  Moi

-z4PYdA2F5O-r3nf34LiCw.review_text: Super happy with this friends reccomondation!  Pasta alla scoma was fantastic. Yelp came really handy with a photo. The Wild Alaskan Halibut was so fresh it tasted more like chicken then fish. Absolutely no fishy taste what so ever. Also had the calimari Calabrese fritti.....  So GOOD! A must have. Older atmosphere but with traditional pier flair. Out waiter was off the boat from Greece and served us well. Must recommend and or return.

Xj0O2l0bp633ebmG468aZw.review_text: Good touristy. I had the pre fix. My scallops rocked. Big portions. Old fashioned. Free valet. Fresh wild fish and crab galore.  Crunchy breadsticks complimentary. All good!

MY4pJRclxETmrBIyTyyQYg.review_text: We were traveling to S.F. and had a recommendation from someone local to go here.  It was absolutely fantastic and some of the best seafood I have ever had.  I ordered something off the 'local favorite' section that was the dungeness crab spoon bread - it was out of this world.  I would highly recommend this to anyone.

k9nUcZwsgRL3MdWBgd-28w.review_text: Touristy yes but still some of the best seafood in SF.  I'd recommend it to anyone looking for good, fresh seafood next to the water.

zQfszAWNRDjoo2RA_AD34Q.review_text: This is a nice classy old timer place with very nice ambience. You will know many people have been customers for years. The price matches the quality. We had to wait about half an hour to get seated but we sat at the bar and sipped more Pinot Noir while we were waiting. When seated I ordered the combo sea food, calamari and oysters to start and more Pinot Noir, We then noticed the portions were very good for this type of restaurant. It's not Majiano's Italian Restaurant but it can be very filling. You can share the food if you are not a big eater which places you in an outstanding position. I am glad I found this place. This will be my great refuge from frugality of my earlier years when I can enjoy some good seafood and feel I deserve a treat once in a while. It's. Sometimes enjoying life is what we are after without regard to saving money.

H8a-W9858Q9tbwEADFKcKQ.review_text: God this place is good. If you are going to do the wharf in SF, do it here.  After my dad begged for years, we finally brought him on Father's Day. We made a rezo online day of- no problem getting in! No wait! Valet is strange here... Very tight but cheaper than any parking garage in the area!!!  Large wine list. 4 different kinds were selected at our table and all were delicious.  Calamari for appetizer made the spicy way... Perfection!!!  Highlight of this meal... My dads CIOPPINO!!!! Omg!!!! Please. You must get this. This is the end all to be all.  My half baked crab was exquisite and garlicky, but if you are not willing to get cracking and stink like a shellfish the next 24 hours... I don't suggest it:) crab takes work!  A standout in this meal was my sisters lobster ravioli. Wow. Fresh lobster stuffed in pasta with a huge piece of salmon laid on top. Need I say more?  They have the best sourdough with EVOO for dipping..... Pair this with the huge bucket of cioppino  (it's seriously a huge portion) and you are set my friend.  Ps- if you watch the horse races on tv you know how legendary this place is! Ha!!! (Except hostess did not get this reference. Sigh-what a newb).

PWaLh-C6KzdYZEzXm79rzw.review_text: can't get any fresher than the oyster bar. although right in the middle of manhattan, you'll feel like you're in a cape cod diner (that's a good thing!).

NzXl-gSkj_c3kaZvRh1ymA.review_text: Probably the most delicious lobster bisque I've ever had.  If you go and have a waiter who is a lovely older gentleman named Heros, take his suggestions and ask no questions. He'll get you the best of the market for the most reasonable price, and you'll love everything he brings out.  We had the petrale sole and a seafood medly of lobster, crab, scallops, and shrimp. The two meals were more than enough for the three of us, and the pasta, mashed potatoes, rice, and steamed veggies that the meals came with were each phenomenal.

KN_lRZ-bZUK7K7-fI9n_zg.review_text: I think this is my few 5star reviews.  You can run up an expensive tab here but you won't have a better experience. The Dungeness Crabcakes were served with delicious Remoulade, a delight to the pallet.  My main course was Shrimp Scampi, it was perfect, I only wish I could make it at home.  The place also has a rich tradition and is SF landmark.  I would love to eat every single dish they serve. I have told half a dozen friends and they all agree, it's a fantastic choice.

_DjHX8PiDjiCZMltk1xmIA.review_text: Delicious food and great ambiance. We ate in the lounge and had our food in no time. Great service.

IgyUHX7lsh1zPAdaW4zikg.review_text: Sublime.  This was a tremendous experience for all six of us.  I had the cioppino and it was every bit as good as any I've ever had.  If you are looking for a good seafood restaurant in SanFran, this should be at the top of the list.

n8hU8AQpa4Jn_mLSK69Xew.review_text: Meh. For the price, the food quality was so-so. The lobster bisque and clam chowder were great. For the main I got the fried calamari dinner. The calamari was fantastic, but it was served on a bed of bland penne and rice. My girlfriend got the cioppino, which was still a bit on the bland side and the subtle flavors of the seafood were overpowered by the tomato sauce. We both had water and the total came out to $83. A decent experience, but won't be returning the next time I'm in the city.

uytxtD4uSb51OI090Ibb1A.review_text: We were at Fisherman's wharf and wanted crab for dinner.  We decided that Scoma's would be worth a try, and we weren't disappointed.  It's a nice restaurant just a couple hundred feet off of Jefferson St.  It's a great place to take a date, but my wife and I weren't interested in the romantic atmosphere as much as devouring some crab.  She even brought along a bottle of Thai seafood sauce (green chili sauce).  We shared a whole dungeness crab, I had a bowl of the lobster bisque, and she had a salad.  To start the lobster bisque as great!  Even my wife's salad was very good.  They make all their own dressings in house, and the thousand island was excellent.  I actually found myself regretting not ordering a salad with bleu cheese dressing.  The steamed crab was delicious.  I alternated between dipping it in butter and the Thai seafood sauce.  It's a good thing the waitress gave us bibs for eating the crab because I am still working on honing my skill of removing crab meat from it's shell.  If I want to master that skill, it's going to take some practice, and I'll be happy to do it!

iDDcCo38zq_2DtuIwIbr-A.review_text: Visited San Francisco for the first time and a friend recommended Scoma's.  He said we had to try #74 on the menu.  We went on his recommendation and sure enough, the menu items were not numbered!  We asked the waiter who was quite nice and also happened to be from Chicago about the numbering.  He was very helpful and knew exactly what #74 was, we ordered and it was great.  Loads of fresh delicious seafood.  Everything was super fresh and well prepared.  The atmosphere was nice.  The location is right on the water and the walls are lined with pictures of celebrities.  It is very comfortable.  The service was good and attentive.  The food was excellent.  Amazing seafood.  The prices were a bit steep, but this is a nice restaurant in Fisherman's Wharf, so that is to be expected.

yO0QyTuu5z-8wzcwtopwKw.review_text: I have been going to Scoma's for about twenty years, and it has been very good every time. It's my go-to seafood/Italian place at Fisherman's Wharf. There are other similar places equally or even better than Scoma's (ie. Café Sport)  in the city, but for the fisherman's wharf experience, Scoma's  is hard to beat. I always get the clams and pasta or the Ciopino, and they're consistently excellent. My daughter and wife ordered the battered Cod fish with vegetables, and they liked it. They have Valet parking, which is a plus. The view is gorgeous, and you can see boats along the wharf. This place has been consistently good, and it's hard to beat along the Wharf.

iLUkEj-XMTYIr45ukkaMXg.review_text: Ok, maybe my love of being a tourist and childhood memories of this place taints my opinion but we had a wonderful dinner here.  The waiter was fun (and from Fresno) and the food was outstanding (Clams, Halibut, and Filet Mignon). Great SF wharf spot to eat.

Lccmw9Tyx5EKqWXKEOHvPQ.review_text: Chowder is just okay. Don't pay this much for a sub par meal.  Best choice is to stay away from the wharf.

N7x9AKSXgLOCMDbtpd50-A.review_text: if you want fancy, fresh seafood, come to Scoma`s. If you don't want to spend a lot of money, then order from the tasting menu if it is available. Smaller portions and smaller prices! Even with smaller portions, you will fill up! I love the woody décor and romantic candle-lit atmosphere Although, it may be a bit crowded depending on which part of the restaurant you are sitting in. Because Scoma`s offers the freshest, finest seafood dishes, they truly are the best seafood restaurant on Fisherman`s Warf!

9U30DANobkrn3Zlu6T9p6Q.review_text: Came back in here last week and have to admit the atmosphere is still great. However, the service this time around was weak. The oyster shucking was sub par. The mussels were solid, but I found the Cioppino to be just good instead the amazing experience I had last time. This is probably still one of the few places in Fisherman's Wharf you should check out regardless of this of my latest outing.

ts1nVs6KScKxCRqbPwer0Q.review_text: Great food, nice atmosphere. Had the grilled rock cod and Wife had the halibut, both where very good. Nice view of the boats at the piers.

-nhBPP8dhKM1I_9_J8wmPQ.review_text: 2 Words. Fresh Seafood!!  I found this place using my trusty Yelp App while looking for a place to eat near Fisherman's Wharf and found this place. Its kind of hidden and you have to walk off the main street to get here. Anyway, I got the Fresh Salmon and my gf got the Clams. I have to say, everything was so fresh and tasty!! The clams were so delicious and the sauce was to die for! My Salmon was very flavorful and tasty as well. We also got the appetizer sampler, and I will say this, the crab cakes were so good they practically melted in my mouth!! MMMM  Service was top notch and service was prompt. If you are ever in the SF area and want fresh seafood, then give this place a try!!

TLiv7pKzS1ruZ4rD1ZzhJw.review_text: Quintessential SF tourist restaurant, we finally had a chance to visit Scoma's when my brother in law came into town.  A party of 5 us waited for approximately 35 minutes (no reservations taken) by the bar before we were seated.  We ordered the crab (very difficult, messy to eat), fried calamari, fish, bruschetta, crab cake so I would say we got a myriad of items. They have several pre-fixe options.  The diners run the gamut from dates to business men to single diners.  Personally I thought the Franciscan Crab House on Pier 39 had a more fun atmosphere but Scomas is a little bit more upscale.  I'm glad I tried Scoma's finally but I didn't find the food memorable.

ZwkqKwSASAVHCFsz3-oZmQ.review_text: I came here during the Sunday of Fleet Week and waited the expected 30-40 minutes for our table.  Located behind the hustle and bustle of Fisherman's Wharf, it provides a good escape from all the tourists and street performers that may be too overwhelming when looking for a relaxed dining experience.  Aside from the slightly awkward wait staff, the food is definitely good here.  I don't find a lot of places that serve lobster ravioli and can never deny them when I dine there.  Scoma's is no exception.  With generous chunks of lobster swimming in my saffron cream sauce, mixed with large pillows of ravioli, I enjoyed every single bite, albeit having to salt it up a little bit more.    My lovely dinner date had the garlic dungeness crab which was bathed in garlic butter and olive oil.  I was impressed with the taste, as a side of butter wasn't needed as if the crab meat had plenty of flavor.

WmQpVokWmWMVja7sTDNm6Q.review_text: We came here today to celebrate my fiancé 30th bday lunch. Our waiter was Gus.  This gentleman has been there 17 years and was very exact with his recommendation s. The crab sandwich was delicious but the highlight of the meal was the clam chowder.  Normally I don't feel there is a difference between most restaurant clam chowders however this one absolutely stands apart from others as amazing.  I would strongly recommend it.  Also ask for Gus he was pretty kickass!

te_3sFwC4hdNJN-HtqCXQQ.review_text: We were a little worried that it was a bit pricey, but decided we had to go and give it a try. Boy are we glad we did. We had an amazing experience. The service was great, both at the bar and at our table.   My wife had the Alaskan King Salmon on a bed of Crab Pasta that was amazing.   I had the Lazy Mans Ciopinno which I had seen on the Food Network (not Scoma's ciopinno, but a show on ciopinno) a few months back and had never heard of it prior. I am afraid to try it anywhere else, because I am not sure it can be any better. WOW.  The decor is a little out of style, but I am willing to overlook that for the great service and food we received. All I can say is Thanks!

CSodofoRKkM93p1nAsK8IQ.review_text: I have been here many times before.  I always thought the food was good, but it has really gone down hill.  I had a special meal which was crab claw meat in a bisque with onions.  There were too many onions.  I couldn't taste the crab meat through all of the onions.  I was sorely disappointed in my meal.

t1OMCEJ2SssQOa61-0gtoA.review_text: Scomas was an excellent choice to get dinner at in the wharf. I was walking around the wharf and saw Scomas kind of hidden around the corner and gave it a shot. A little pricey, but well worth it!

OiBmu84gTMZhWqDi2PXhCQ.review_text: Looking for some great seafood on the wharf and went to try Scoma's.  I really liked the vibe in the restaurant.  Good food and drink, staff was very nice and friendly.  No need to dress up for this place even though I as coming from a business meeting.  I had the "Lazy Man's" Cioppino and it was outstanding.  Plenty of seafood and fresh as you would expect.  The shrimp and scallops we're nice and tender, definitely not overcooked.  Nice toasted garlic bread for dipping.  I had a Malbec to help wash the meal down.  I'll be coming back again to try something else on the menu.  The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is I want to try some more and give it the 5th star.

y3VYs63lDS2AD9TNLQSirw.review_text: The cioppino was delicious and lots of seafood. I think my husband's order of Filet mignon was messed up because I am gluten free. Good thing he filled up on garlic bread and didn't care he didn't get mashed potatoes. He said the Filet was very good. The service was good.

7dnh9OrD8LekBwvachGH5Q.review_text: Thanks to Yelp, I found this place.  But also, because of Yelp, it's really popular and the wait is long.  They have no clue how to estimate time since it took almost 3 times longer than they estimated.  I already made up my mind to give this place a bad rating.  However, when the meal came, I quickly forgave.  The best Cioppina and Clam Chowder I ever had!  Wow, it was that great.  The restaurant is hidden in Fisherman's Wharf since you have to walk in an alley where you can find this on its own pier.  But, again, thanks to social media, it is no secret  The waitress was among the best in service and advice.  The meal is 5 stars alone.  I knocked it down for one star for making us wait much longer than they estimated.  Be prepared for the wait and I guarantee that you will find the meal a great experience.  There are tons of places, much cheaper than this place, but you won't regret it.

LhFzr2vZDEc2KNHxuiHtIw.review_text: If I was a tourist I probably woudnt go to Scomas. You have to know about this place to look for it because it's hidden behind the touristy spots.   My friend told me about Scomas clam chowder so I had to stop by for some on my trip to s.f. It was restaurant week so I got clam chowder with a crab salad. Clam chowder was the best I ever had!!! there were tons of clams in there! and the crab salad was a favorite of san francisco, told by my waiter. I didnt believe him till I tried it! there were tons of crabs and it was so goood!!! Dressing was like a thousand island dressing. I love this place! and I would recommend this restaurant to anybody!!! get the clam chowder!!!! you wont be disappointed!

LwqC94izxiTnbL1z4rhwvQ.review_text: I love it when i find a place worthy of a full five stars and this is definetly one! I love the free parking (they will even watch your segway for you). The hostess was friendly and made us feel welcome, the wait staff was just perfect. Our waiter Kevin was warm, genuine and he made me feel wealthy and important. The food was nothing but top shelf and all that i hoped it would be. I had the crab cocktail (worth it)and  the clam chowder (clam were soo tender you could just slurp um down except for good manners. The special fresh pick of the day fell on the saute' scallops, which came.with a medally of mushrooms rice pasta an veggies. Mmmmm mmmm! Just cant go wrong here. It is pricey but the portions and quality are worth it!

NPRyDEG1D2taLdbdXhrNlA.review_text: It must be me because the recent reviews are fabulous and mention that the food is always great but I did not feel that way.  I had the snapper and it was excellent but the broccoli was bland and the pasta was significantly undercooked. On the positive side, I enjoyed the view, the service was above average and I will go back because of the complimentary valet parking. In the coming months I will return, have a seat at the bar, and have a side dish because, in fairness, a restaurant with such a rich history deserves a second look. On the other hand, perhaps it was just me.

jkLXur4Z2aXV1e7atBMHTA.review_text: Too expensive for the quality of the food. My order consisted of scallops (the best part), shrimp (BURNED??!?!?!?!?!?! WTF), rice, mashed potatoes, and some under boiled veggies.  Seriously though, what the hell at the burned jumbo shrimp? I felt like I was going to get cancer from eating this and the flavor was gone and replaced with the taste of charcoal.  Go to Scoma's in Sausalito. The food there is SO DELICIOUS and this plate comes with scalloped potatoes, not powder form mashed potatoes. San Francisco Scoma's was just a terrible disappointment.

gyvBwQPhZiJkND2tpjYz1A.review_text: Love, Love, love Scoma's! The Dungeness Crab Cocktail is to die for - you have to get it everytime you go. You can't go wrong with a seafood pasta dish or ordering shellfish a la carte. I don't eat red meat but my friends have never complained. :)   The waiters are lifers so don't expect them to be too nice but know they know the menu. Give em hell - ask lots of questions, I always do.

6s-bRtWG9eIkD9aOaDrqIA.review_text: Cute little place, but the food was not all that great.  I expected more with the number of high reviews.  Had the Lazy Man's cioppino and while there was a lot of food, the sauce was too thick for my taste.  The crab cakes were really good for appetizers and so was the bread.

OvR19daYCBiL4FnZOQzQsA.review_text: The pearl of the wharf.   Within seconds of being seated, I hit the waiter with:   1 bottle of Kendall Jackson 2011 Limited Reserve 2 Lobster Bisque 1 order of Oysters Rockefeller 1 Cioppino 1 Pasta Diplomatica  This is how its done people. This is the perfect dinner. I really don't have much more to say. Try this.   You're welcome.

RATviC9wz4NZOuMI9_9Bug.review_text: I know this is a tourist area but for the prices and reputation, I expect better service. I was told it would be a 45 minute wait, but I could order food at the bar so I found a seat, asked for a menu but then couldn't get either of the bartenders to even look my way to take my order. And then, when they did, it was wrong. We're talking about a cup of bisque and an appetizer, not a complicated meal with lots of modification. I guess if I had been 20 with a short skirt or a businessman, it might have been different, but my wallet talks and it's telling me not to come back.

J0KQrPC9oe5BsC56YmgRQA.review_text: This is a great place to eat in SF. Service, food , and setting. I walked by the entrance Sign many times. I tried it after checking Yelp reviews .Wow this was just what I was looking for . A hearty fresh fish meal after my swim in Aquatic Park on New Years Day

Z3vY6CM1aSJcyDMrFfhPIw.review_text: So I just made the move to San Francisco, and when Scoma's was recommended to me multiple times the first day I was here I was a little afraid this would be a straight-up tourist spot, but I was pleasantly surprised. There actually seemed to be more locals/regulars than tourists and the place was still packed.  The location is very cool, and it sets the tone for Scoma's atmosphere. It's pretty much a seafood only restaurant, but they do have some meat entrees, but lets be realistic, you order fish at Scoma's. All of the food is very, very fresh and I think it would be hard to go wrong with any seafood selection. Even still, the oysters rockefeller are outstanding and I recommend trying them. The portions are very generous, so be sure not to fill up on the sourdough bread... like I did.   Scoma's is a very good seafood restaurant, but be sure to get there early or expect to wait (no reservations). Anyone looking for a good seafood dinner, tourist or SF Resident, will not leave disappointed.

ycfmNK1zMwu6Km6-bM3CFA.review_text: This was my first time at Scoma's and my expectations were high and disappointingly not met.  We had a party of two and the wait was an hour, on a Tuesday night. I thought the food was so bomb, it got me super excited.  After we settled into our tables, I ordered the pasta diplomatica, my companion ordered the lazy man's paciollio, and we ordered lobster bisque, clam chowder, and also some oysters.  Their seafood is fresh, I'll give that to them. The oysters were delicious. However, our soup took 40 minutes to arrive and were definitely not up to par.  The pasta diplomatica was so bland. It definitely looked way better than it actually was. Every bite was a disappointment. Although all the seafood were top notch fresh off the boat, I couldn't taste anything in the sauce.  The lazy man's was decent. Earthy, savory, except it was nothing spectacular.  Friendly, welcoming service and friendly servers results in the one star, but the food is undeserving and underwhelming to say the least.

o6npRJ9RO5ybYnovGO3tEA.review_text: Seafood was amazingly delicious. We had clam chowder, Chioppino, alaskan salmon and garlic danginess crab. Every single dish was very flavorful, fresh, perfect. Especially Chioppino was incredibly good. MUST HAVE menu.  We went there as a party of 5 for the lunch time. Since the restaurant doesn't take reservations, we had to wait more than 1 hour to get the table. Still, totally worth it. Free valet parking is a HUGE plus, too.  Dessert was nothing special. But hey, you can find hundreds of nice cafe for dessert and coffee in San Francisco. I rather eat more sea food here than keep space for the desert.

93OnUKuKb69Up0FUETU-eQ.review_text: The lobster bisque is divine!  A SF landmark!  A trip to SF should always include Scoma's.

fj654yv6kkCtQfygTSWQYA.review_text: Good old fashion wharf restaurant in a great location with a spectacular view and fresh seafood.  They were very busy so expect a wait.  Locals and tourist share the Scoma's experience, which is nice.  We paid $220 for 4 people, so a bit on the pricey side, but we had a lovely dining experience.

bsNPOZzmhJJQ8U4V4QDYIQ.review_text: chilled oysters on the half shell....lazy mans cioppino...and a few pints of anchor steam.  it just don't get much better than that on a beautiful afternoon in san fran.  thanks to all at scoma's, i really enjoyed the visit.  see you next time.

2aLW8ItlscUSyOxTi-j0MA.review_text: Maybe this is five stars for another city, but not for San Francisco.

58GDRxQ7TdZCNNliSLJ9Pg.review_text: I had the grilled combo which was excellent and my husband had the rock cod which he says is the best fish he has ever had. Service was great. We didn't know about the valet parking so next time we'll use it.

84YggI8CgE9x2szUYV_76g.review_text: I love seafood, so I have tried many places (Santa Barbara, Newport Beach, Monterey Bay, San Diego, other Fisherman's wharf restaurants).  I had never found a place that served a clam chowder that came close to Fish Company's (Los Alamitos in southern cali) New England Clam Chowder, and yes, moving up to the bay area...i was disappointed in the "SF clam chowder" until I came to Scoma's.    The clam chowder is just as good as my favorite clam chowder, but I think it's better because it has pieces of crab in it as well. Not too many potatoes, plenty of clams and celery and the soup isn't too creamy like most in SF. My girlfriend even said that it was better than Splash Cafe's clam chowder (in San Luis Obispo).  Main Courses Ordered: CIOPPINO ALA PESCATORE ($32) A San Francisco Fisherman's Wharf Original. Prawns, Shrimp, Clams, Sea Scallops, Fresh Fish, and a 1/2 Dungeness Crab cracked in the Shell in a rich tomato broth.  and my gf got the SCALLOPS SAUTE SEC ($30). She originally wanted the "GRILLED SEA SCALLOPS RISOTTO - 30 Peas, Red Bell Peppers, Zucchini, & Pancetta", but the waitor told us that  only 3 scallops come with that and 12 come with the the saute, so she got the saute.  If you want the freshest seafood and the original SF landmark, this is the place to go! Scoma's owns its own fishing fleet and brings in fresh seafood daily.  Seeing how crowded it was on a sunday night with a full 420 capacity restaurant and STILL having to wait 20 minutes is amazing. It isn't even located in a great spot, yet you could tell...it is the place to be if you want the best seafood. Other reviewers say it is pricey, but for what you're ordering....and what you get, it is worth the money.   DONT LISTEN TO THE REVIEWS THAT GIVE IT ANYTHING LOWER THAN A 5......THEY DONT KNOW WHAT THEY ARE TALKING ABOUT!  P.S. - TripAdvisor has Scoma's as one of the top Seafood restaurants in SF.

TGLkiBIRgVUzTxsxhAOIpw.review_text: Scomas is my favorite seafood restaurant in SF.  I've been coming here for years and it has never changed.  I highly recommend the clam chowder, crab cocktail, fried calamari, and pasta diplomatica in cream suace. These are my favorite dshes, the portians are very large and I always have left overs to eat the next day.  My husband loves the crab sandwiches, filet mignon lobster dish, and the seafood saute.  The food is so fresh and cooked perfectly every time. The service is excellent the waiters are old school and they know the menu like the back of their hand. They have valet parking so you don't have to worry about parking.  You won't be dissapointed in Scomas, as far as I'm concerned it the best seafood in SF.

EfYNsqr9S2qZaWRvbpZGXw.review_text: Had lunch here on a Saturday and they were packed.  Service was great as was the food. Only thing that makes it a 4 star instead of 5 is the price.

LueFP5wqHjyCrsIF9VWkiQ.review_text: Whenever we are in San Francisco since I was little we always went to scomas. The food is fantastic! The portions are large and sea food is very fresh! I love the Saute Sec, crab louis salad, and roasted butter and garlic whole cracked crab. yummmmm... Free Valet parking too.

w-UUD__OCINqlqED7iysCA.review_text: Coippino is great. Beautiful views. I have visited them for lunch and had their mahi mahi which was fantastic.

RQXWuiQTKxxdOLn_7Wc0Uw.review_text: This gets 3 stars since I can't give it 2.5.  "Meh I have had better" is probably a good description, but I feel like 2 stars is too low.  The first time we ate here it struck me as a place that was probably popular at one time, but was now a little down on its luck or coasting on past success.  The food was all right & the service was all right as well.  My wife accidentally made a reservation there again & we showed up with 6 people.  Once we go there, she realized that she hadn't meant to go there again, but since we were already there, we went on in.  This time around we had almost the same experience.  The food was all right.  I actually liked the crab I had, but my daughter & I who also had the crab were the only ones pleased with their meal.  The seafood is very fresh & that is great.  They just seem to use much imagination when they prepare it.  I'm probably just not the the target market here.  I feel like the pace is overpriced for the closeness of the tables & the caliber of the food.  It seems to be an institution though, so they won't miss me.

CfV_axQI2rK0eHB9FfG_GQ.review_text: Come here if: - you're a tourist - you're over 40 years old - you don't mind waiting over 1 1/2-2 hours to be seated - you want seafood that you can find anywhere at the wharf - you want to eat somewhere with dated decor and sky-high prices  I hated this place. There is maybe 2-3 things for vegetarians, I ordered the pesto and it was flavorless. FLAVORLESS PESTO! It's some sort of oxymoron. Obviously this isn't the place to be for a veg but damn it get a pasta dish right for $20. I can thank my family for coming from out of town and dragging me to this miserable, touristy, expensive place.

kd1JJduGAnNqoGnviu5qHg.review_text: Amazing Seafood! the Dungeness crab cocktail - awesome. Definately the Seafood restaurant on the wharf.

XmEywucVDyUP9VJ4SXGjzw.review_text: I've been in San Francisco going on eight years yet until today had yet to visit or eat at Fisherman's Wharf.  So I walked the area and then ate at Scoma's.  Why people would visit Fisherman's Wharf is a mystery.  All that I saw was crowds of people looking to throw their money at who knows what.  And then there is Scoma's, another easy way to part with money fast, as the place is expensive.  Not necessarily horrible.  But expensive.  The venue had the feel of an airport lounge.  The hostess was continuously calling waiting patrons for their tables over a microphone.   Once seated I felt a bit like a sardine or to keep my metaphor straight someone in an airplane.  Everyone was lined up and regimented for fast service.  Get them in.  Get them out.  I started with a crab cocktail.  This was quite good.  The crab was obviously fresh.  And for nineteen dollars there was a substantial serving of crab, as well there should be.  Next, grilled sand dabs.  The four fish had been breaded and then cooked with some considerable oil that was taken up by the breading which became leaden.  The fish however were fresh.  The pasta that came with the sand dabs was undistinguished, but the vegetables still had some snap and taste.  At twenty nine dollars this plate of food was an expensive mediocrity.  Their sourdough bread is not the best I have had in San Francisco by a long shot.    Given that this was Fisherman's Wharf, an immense tourist trap, I could have done worse than Scoma's.  Given that Fisherman's Wharf is in San Francisco, I could have done better.

qUGMYSGV24KD8QFCdGGIlQ.review_text: I came here this past weekend because my favorite restaurant (House of Prime) was all booked up.. This place doesn't take reservations but luckily we have a connection with one of the waiters and were able to score a table within 30 minutes.. Scoma's was packed from the time that we got there, 7, until the time that we left, 10, with a bunch of people still waiting for tables! From what I've been told it's normally like that but I'm guessing that the NFL Playoff game being in town didn't help the crowd control either :P.. So there were a bunch of rowdy New Yorkers present as well as the usual San Francisco/Bay Area crowd.. The waiting area of this restaurant is pretty narrow so expect to stand in a cramped area while you wait for your party to be called by a hostess who looks unhappy and gives you a fake smile when you enter or speak.. The bar is right by the entrance so that's a good way to dish out $10-12 per drink while you wait.. Probably the most annoying part of our wait was listening to a group of drunk New Yorkers (I do not dislike NYers just this particular group!) yell to each other across the bar.. This isn't Applebee's it's a fine dining restaurant so let's get it together guys!  Being that our family friend is a waiter at Scoma's he would naturally know what the best things to order are so we left this in his hands and offered a few suggestions for what our party of 7 likes.. For our first course we had 2 plates of clams and oysters on a bed of ice, calamari (mmm baby tentacles!!), garlic bread, shrimp cocktail, steamed clams, and a cup of clam chowder (packed with goodies!).. I didn't try the hard shellfish because I'm not really a fan of it raw or cooked except for in a few dishes.. The only time I tried the clam was when it was steamed and even then I just couldn't take to the taste or texture of it.. The shrimp cocktail came with jumbo prawns and was absolutely amazing, as well as the calamari and clam chowder.. The garlic bread was probably some of the best I've ever had and was flavorful, well textured, and warm.. My guests thoroughly enjoyed the shellfish platter and the steamed clams so I'm guessing that was good too! For our second course we had a platter with an assortment of seafood including sole, seared ahi tuna, scallops, and crab cakes.. Everything on this platter was delicious except I'm not very partial to scallops, especially raw, and these were only partially cooked (75% maybe).. The seared ahi tuna was the most impressive item that they brought out and I could've eaten it all night if my stomach allowed for it.. We also had spinach, garlic mashed potatoes, and steamed veges as sides with some seafood pasta.. I didn't get a chance to try the mashed potatoes but the veges and spinach were okay.. I don't generally like my veges steamed since the flavor can be quite bland.. By the time the pasta got to our table I was already quite full so I only tried some of the lobster tail that was in it.. Surprisingly this was my first time trying lobster, ever! And with my under developed palate for seafood, naturally, I wasn't that big of a fan, haha! I still enjoy crab now and then though [: For all of the above mentioned our bill came to ~$340 +18% gratuity and we didn't order and drinks once we were seated..

1o8I1s6kSfLkJlHeKPc5ZA.review_text: Wow, beautiful view, great ambience, can't wait to go. Back. $80 for steak & lobster.  The steak was good, not great, but good. The lobster on the other hand was HUGE & tasty. Plan on going back & bringing the wife with me this time.

vL6IDWIvMauR6snzXnKvzA.review_text: SCOMA's in the seafood HEART of San Francisco!!! It's conveniently located next to the wharf and the ambience is just lovely!   BF ordered the Lazy Man's Cioppino with garlic bread... maybe after eating a whole bowl of that seafood stew, you may become lazy to start walking again!!! LOL!  I ordered the Lobster Ravioli (as pictured), which was heavenly!!! We're actually flying back to San Fran next week and we're definately coming back here... I am sooo tempted to order the Lobster Ravioli again, but I guess I should try something else different. Everything looks great anyways! Portions are generous and prices are reasonable!

nTKjqX4YAYXc4PqWS6Qipg.review_text: I highly recommend Scoma's to any SF local or vacationer!  I took my fiancée here for dinner after proposing last Friday night.  Nick (the manager) was VERY accommodating and gave us complimentary glasses of champagne/free dessert.  Our server was attentive and friendly.  Our seafood appetizer sampler/dinner was fresh and both of us were very pleased.  We will be back every year for our anniversary!  Thanks for making our day so special!

o39ALmdV8bHAsVvhFn6WHg.review_text: The food was good, but the service was poor.    First, my GF and I were seated in this horrible little 2 seat table wedged near a window.  The table next to us consisted of 2 drunk couples who would not move their chairs to let us in.  Obviously this part was beyond the restaurants control but why they chose to cram that extra two-top in that small area makes no sense to me.  Literally 2 feet between tables in 2 directions.    Second, our server, Gus, stereotyped us and another table in typical restaurant fashion... We were young and dressed casually therefore we wouldn't tip.  The other table he barely helped was another young couple.  Luckily, I'm not a complete jerk and left him 18%.  However earlier today, at Cafe GoLo, I left John about a 65% tip.  Just think of how well I could have tipped on a $100 meal?!  The only reason I'm giving two stars is for the crab cakes... Delicious.  The clam chowder is better at Boudin's by a landslide.

UObFv4Cc6AzhkxwONFcNXQ.review_text: Dinner was great!  We got there around 5ish so the wait was only about 5 minutes...basically to get the table ready.  We sat down and received our delicious bread (fresh from Boudin's on the Wharf).  Our appetizers arrived pretty fast but the entrees took a while to arrive.  The Cioppino was GREAT!  Everyone loved their food including the crab ravioli and filet mignon (she didn't eat seafood).  All in all, would definitely go there again.

WDyILww9HxfTwq5zKOGymw.review_text: Mediocre, overpriced seafood at astronomical prices!!    This place is old-school, in the sense that it's a flashback to the restaurants of yester-year:  white table cloth, aging male servers who are politely brusque, middle-aged tourists and older diners who have had too many cocktails and have gotten a bit too loud for the comfort of their neighboring tables, uninventive "classic" recipes that all too often remind us of just how far this country has come recently in terms of culinary creativity...and therefore how much of a dinosaur this restaurant really is.  My biggest objection:  The prices.  $15 for shrimp cocktail???  $7 for garlic bread????  $16 for a spinach and goat cheese salad?????   And most offensively, $26 for penne bolognese???????  It would be one thing if the food really were exquisite, an explosion of new, creative flavors in your mouth, the sensation of "oh my GAWD this is SO GOOD, I can't eat enough of it!!!"  But that's not what I felt here.  Instead, as I dined on a fairly by-the-book Lobster Newburg ($36), I couldn't help but wonder why I was feeling so "meh" about lobster, ie, my FAVORITE FOOD IN THE WORLD!!!  It was just sort of...bland.  And why the steep prices?  The portions weren't large.  The boring ol' steamed veggies on the plate didn't lend me any clues.  And my friend's flacid pasta didn't give me any answers, either.  The food wasn't bad, it just wasn't exciting.  And since we weren't sitting near a window, and it was also nighttime, it's not like we were enjoying any exquisite view.    And then I remembered:  I'm on Fisherman's Wharf.  I never go here, because it's famous for one thing, and one thing only:  tourism.  Aha.  So when someone comes to San Francisco and opens a guide book, they see Scoma's listed as being located in a tony location on the wharf in what all their not-from-San-Francisco friends tell them is the area of the city they simply MUST go see (because certainly there is NOTHING to do in SF unless you see Pier 39 and Fisherman's Wharf!!!  Ooo, don't forget to buy an Alcatraz t-shirt!!!!  Otherwise, how will people know you've been to SF?!).  And they suddenly rationalize paying $26 for an average bowl of pasta and meat sauce.  Because after all, there WAS a white table cloth, so certainly this MUST be a classy joint, a San Francisco landmark!  Listen, people:  if you want to experience really good Italian food and/or seafood, there are a ZILLION better restaurants in San Francisco to go to.  A little research will reward you with a dinner at a far more delicious (and reasonably priced!) restaurant in town!  Sure, you may not be able to buy an "Alcatraz Triathalon" t-shirt on your walk back to the hotel, but you'll have a far more genuine and exciting culinary journey if you venture outside of the Fisherman's Wharf bubble.  Scoma's might've been what spelled class to your grandparents back in the day, but nowadays we've come so far from over-priced entrees made up of protein, pasta, and a heap of limp, favorless steamed veggies....

Wlk6JwG7rGmL-kP0dHgUHQ.review_text: To start off, this is a white table cloth type of place. And I know being on the wharf (super tourist area), you might have reservations. I think the rating with the amount of reviews is evidence that this place is a gem.  Service: excellent and swift Atmosphere: nice (a place you take a date or an out of town guest) Food: CIOPPINO! Delicious and huge. The seafood is succulent and tender. It's definitely a dish to share with another person or family style.

oel5UAI1J6MACnoLO9VRGQ.review_text: Went here for my wifes birthday while traveling.  We started with the calimari appetizer which was very tasty and a great portion.  I had the scallops special and my wife had the mixed grill.  Everything was perfect!  Our server was Gus and he also was outstanding.  Great experience!!

9OszQMQICXKZEljm2twuzw.review_text: Delicious.  A little old school, but tons of character.  We stumbled onto Scoma's trying to find a place to eat around Fisherman's Wharf that wasn't a chain.  Found this little gem.  Best freaking crabcake I have ever had.  Seriously.  Get the crabcake.  Also, their special lobster bread/potpie dish (forgot what it was called) was really really good as well.  The service was excellent.  Our waiter looked like Harry from the old show "Empty Nest" and he was awesome.  Very responsive and very helpful.  Even took time to give us a rundown of things to do in the area.  Docking one star for a bad bloody mary and it was a bit pricey for what it was.  But overall, a great experience and i would highly recommend it.

p6RurvWCPEqR8PP4siwiVA.review_text: Travelers have always welcomed and been welcomed at inns and restaurants generations over; at a certain threshold of exhaustion any place will do.  So imagine a hungry and footsore family who has stumbled into paradise.  That paradise was Scoma's. I still dream about their clam chowder.  Other memorable dishes included the pasta alla Scoma's and the Dungeness crab. The table side views were of the bay right outside; a seal swam by while we were sitting there. General decor was on the classy side but not overly so.  Service was great.   Wonderful wonderful memories of dining here, would highly recommend it.

b5-4HlYC_cou6AfZEY72cw.review_text: Scomas is a staple within the beautiful waterfront that graces our remarkable city. I had the pleasure of working with Nick and Laura in planning a large group dinner event. The wait staff, management, food, ambiance, were all 5 stars, absolutely incredible.   We will definitely go back once a year as a large group to enjoy everything Scoma's has to offer.   Thank you again to Nick, Laura and everyone at Scomas! A+ experience.

QqJrMBOjWJeaDjUC7K2X_Q.review_text: Seafood platter for two is a perfect starter. Good selection of wines. And view of the water. Great date place. Cioppino is a MUST!

oC-7VXIy5aBwDZ6-rBPYIw.review_text: Wow. Just wow. The sea life jumps out of the ocean and into your mouth. Everything is so fresh and delicious. It was among the best seafood meals I've ever had.   The decor is kind of tired but if you're spending a day down by the Pier this is the place you must come for food.

P27aSCwfgpQKcaqNuwUn9w.review_text: Good, but dated and utterly boring.  This place is in the tourist part of town. The good news is the food tastes good. Excellent crab cakes and the lobster ravioli was fine. My colleague had a badly overcooked steak that came with steamed veggies and mashers. As far as I'm concerned, if you order fillet medium well, though, who cares?  The decor was straight out of the 70s -- not in a retro cool kind of way, but in a never changed kind of way. The walls are festooned with faded color photos of older people having good lives who are probably long dead.   I suspect the menu hasn't changed much in decades. Same old staff. Same old uniforms (service was fine though). A bit rain down, but not dirty.  For me this doesn't cut it when there is a city full of places making awesome, imaginative and mind blowing food for the same price.   However, some people like boring, and at least it wasn't expensive, boring and terrible.

ep5jHAg6xL8XztpzpHEVKw.review_text: Fun place. Great food with large portions. Spicy cioppino was a nice heat with lots of seafood.  Went at 7 pm on a Thursday. Was a consistent 30 min wait for 2-4 with the place packed with the front area by hostess a waiting area. Two bars with quick service allowed for waiting with drink in hand. A number of very large gt 12 parties were being accommodated.

8I1NKQlmjai_R-Ne2UkVaw.review_text: A very interesting location on the water, but the recipes at our table of six were average.  We were crammed in next to another table even though there was room in the restaurant.  For the money, there is better seafood in San Francisco.

OSIm_uKf8FUtcPXiQw4MwA.review_text: Scoma is an all-time favorite of mine. I've been coming here since dirt was new.  GREAT seafood and GREAT Italian food. Used to love their abalone, until that was no longer on the menu. Then I got hooked on sand dabs, and they got taken off the menu. Good thing the Petrale Sole Almondine is still available! Lightly breaded and cooked in a very light butter sauce, this is still one of my favorites. I usually get a side of pasta covered in a bolognese on the side - I can't resist their Italian fare, either.  Excellent bread and Italian wine list. VERY romantic for a first or second date...just don't order the spaghetti! ;)

tQs0aM0Cj6G7fCyVpeEiyA.review_text: The best crab legs that we experienced in San Francisco! Awesome view and great service!

WwF6Ug5mYksdJbznmJ2eZg.review_text: It kills me to give this Staple of American Restaurants anything lower than 5 stars, but after 30+ years of coming here, I was really disappointed this last visit.  I come to SF once or twice a year and always try to make it to Scoma's.  I know its a tourist place, but for the last several decade, it has been extremely consistent.   With this visit I had a very boring meal, and iit may have been PREVENTABLE!!  I ordered my usual, Patrale Dore.  When the meal arrived, it a was the usual nice piece of fish, but it was on a bed of rice.   Historically, it is served with Penne pasta.. When I questioned my server Catherine, she said that is how it comes now.  Later she told me I could've gotten it with Penne pasta, but management wanted her to push rice instead.  WTH?  I should have been informed up front.  I will probably visit again...but I will make sure up front, that I get pasta.  mmmm, Patrale Dore on Penne pasta with butter and garlic, and fresh parmesan cheese...come on!  That is how it is supposed to be served!

duoCB7tgRgE8EtggkECpog.review_text: My entire family has been eating at Scomas since I was a young child.  I use to love it and they would be my number one choice when visiting San Francisco.  After my last experience with my husband I will NEVER go there again. Our waiter was extremely rude.  He ruined the entire experience.  We had other things to do in the City and when he came back to take our order I ordered the appetizer and then proceeded to order my main course.  He arrogantly cut me off and said that I couldn't order the main course at that time. I feel that the customer is always right and if we CHOOSE to place the entire order...we should be able to.  He then took it upon himself to put pepper on my salad....without asking!   When we were finally allowed to order our main courses and they came out I have to say I was not impressed.  The crab was rubbery and tasteless.  We ended up coming back to fishermans wharf later on that evening after seeing a Giants game and the crab at one of the little crab stands was WAY better. I have told numerous people about my experience and will definitely never dine there again.

B6zk5FhreyKBXhi83HlOQg.review_text: Simply the best on all fronts.

tFeGSYSSSo3UdWIRSi40SA.review_text: Solid four stars. Hate the seating and the auditorium feel, but that's the charm of this place. Last night they had some roughness at the bar (49ers game) and that would not have been cool for a family. It was handled with grace at the front desk.  I started with chowder (great) and friends had lobster bisque and a crab cocktail which looked fantastic. I has swordfish with capers (ok, not perfectly cooked) and friends had salmon... that looked better.   Service was gruff and as you would expect at this place. Fun though.  I'd go back and have a few times just for the history lesson.

EO47ao8qAykoK1PGstY4JQ.review_text: I literally fell in love with crab cakes and I hated crab cakes before my first one here! Apparently my mother kept it a secret from the rest of us but now the secret's out! Other items to try calm chowder, chippino and whatever their daily special is for the day. Minus one star because the bldg. could use a face lift.

NJqmAzerpbAIC0-VBclwgA.review_text: Gonna make this a quick one... Being in San Fran, I thought this place would have been better!  I was kinda dissapointed.  Shoulda gone to a more hipster place...  First impression- thought it was dark and lacked character. It is on the water front so it naturally attracts diners.    I had the lobster bisque, which was good & creamy.  The bread was good, as was the variety.  I actually love when restaurants provide carb variety!   I also had the crab risotto, which was my main meal.  It was really just ok.  Not much more I can say about. Shared the polenta with my friend, which would have been a better entree than the polenta. \ Just ok.

mI0_hOKm7g-iN7A3wSwXxQ.review_text: Are you kidding me?  A great spot in San Francisco in the harbor. Great fish, great service and overall just an amazing place. Love it.

w9bZmMN6Bjy252t7gjX_Xg.review_text: Traditional western-style seafood. There were good and bad points. There's lots of butter and lots of cream, but weirdly under salted. Salad was drowned in dressing, I couldn't finish it. Seafood was fresh and lobster bisque was absolutely BOMB. Came on a Wednesday night and it was packed; we waited nearly an hour. I guess they're doing something right. I'd come back again if someone else is paying, and get the lobster bisque.

rUnA4AJnSZWLRVsvWmoypg.review_text: I had the cioppino here again the other night.  I must say it doesn't get any better than this - a heaping bowl of sea morsels in finger licking delicious broth, accompanied with some crusty toasted sourdough bread.  The cioppino is loaded with crab, fish, scallops, squid, clams, and mussels.  Besides the quantity, the quality is excellent, fresh and cooked to perfection.    According to our waiter, they use same day fresh catch used for other dishes unlike other places where they use less fresh ingredients for this stew.  Also, the person that makes the cioppino has been making it for nearly 30 years . . all at Scoma's.    At $36, it's not cheap.  I suggest splitting this and another dish with your dining companion.  Also, reservation is highly recommended.  Even on a Monday night, it was packed.   And yes, it's in Fisherman's Wharf and it is touristy.  But if you like cioppino as I do, you just have to try it.

ohsL6aKdwcRjc7Wc6Wloog.review_text: I don't know if it was cause I wasn't in the mood for seafood when we went, but this place just didn't do it for me. The wait was an hour+, but at least it's near the wharf and you could walk around to kill some time. The service was excellent, but the food was just a-ok. The cioppino was the best by far. Nothing else was really notable. I'll probably try a different restaurant the next time I'm in the area.

85MihShAd5WGI7vq24Q8mA.review_text: Hands down to one of the best clam chowder! Before trying Scoma's, I tried the clam chowder from another vendor at Fisherman's Wharf. It is not comparable to Scoma's whatsoever.   I placed a to go order which was about $10 but big portion. Brought this out to the Cristal Park nearby on a chilly day. Perfect food with a nice view of the Golden Gate Bridge.

SNURSQilbXoezzcg1m9zVA.review_text: Scoma's has it all: great atmosphere, excellent food, super service and an excellent menu.  As a tourist in San Francisco from New York, my expectations were pretty high, but Scoma's left me asking for nothing more.  First the atmosphere.  This is in a very touristy area and I wanted to avoid that.  The prices on the menu scare off the typical tourist, which is good.  The food was up there with the best restaurants in NYC.  My wife and I had different seafood and both were amazing.  A-M-A-Z-I-N-G.  The service was excellent.  Our waiter had a thick French accent which made it all the better.    After we finished eating, we were ready to do it all over again.

AIXFzsxjQTTxZ0AUxvXpxQ.review_text: My in-laws have been coming to Scoma's for years. They were so excited to share their love for Scoma's with us when we all traveled to San Fransico for the holiday.  When we arrived at Scoma's we did not have a reservation because we were travelling in from Concord, and did not know how long the drive would take. We waited at the bar for about fifteen minutes and then were seated in the renovated section of the restaurant overlooking the marina. It was a gorgeous view!  Our server was so knowledgeable about the menu and shared that he had worked here for many years. My in-laws and husband all ordered the same thing. It was a seafood medley, so they could try a little bit of everything. I decided on the Dungeness crab and a side of French fries.   When they brought out our food, my crab was steamed in a garlic seasoning (which I did not order) but it smelled so good that I ate it anyways. While the garlic seasoning was incredibly messy, I loved the flavor it gave the crab. The French fries came in a massive order. My hubby and I split them, and even then we couldn't finish!     Everything is fresh. You see them cleaning the seafood and fish in the building over when you walk by. Seeing that made me love Scoma's even more.   I would come back here in a heartbeat. Be prepared to wait if you don't have a reservation. But, the food and atmosphere is worth it.

YdNML-H8HVZMxR4LwF3v2Q.review_text: 2nd time here, 2nd time ordering the infamous cioppino. It is really good.  Rich, hearty, and they use bay shrimp as fillers.  But they don't have calamari in it and put in a lot of fish, which was good, but would prefer more of the other sea goodies. My husband ordered sauté scallops, and that was what I really remembered.  It was fresh, melt in your mouth, buttery goodness of the sea.  Came with some veggies that were also super fresh.  It was fantastic.  Besides their no reservations policy and the fact we waited for more than an hour for a table, the restaurant has really good, fresh seafood.

XJgRdHOsgypEba4oKwAh1w.review_text: Scoma's is terrific--head and shoulders above other seafood restaurants in the wharf area. It's off the beaten track--down an alley--but worth seeking out.  We started dinner with a salad with crumbled blue cheese, and the salad was fresh and the blue cheese plentiful.  My dad said his lobster bisque was terrific.  For dinner, dad had mussels and said they were among the best he's ever had.  My wife and I enjoyed two different swordfish dishes; both were great--many times better than the one I had the week before at a restaurant on Pier 39.    Service was friendly and attentive.

G-QM2_56Fi-iDyUIfhN5ng.review_text: Not good.  Scallops just okay.  Prawns were tough.  Wouldn't go back.

KFaUuuvfw-6rAbTzuYwU0g.review_text: 4.25 (3.75 for food and +0.5 for top notch service) DAT (dine about town)  shellfish combo $38 The waitress recommended this and it was a good one. Came with 2 lobster tails, 3 shrimp, 5 scallops, 5 pieces of de-shelled crab meat, pasta, veggies on top of a bed of risotto. The seafood was slightly above average with the juices flavoring and enhancing the risotto and pasta. 4.25/5  1)DAT $35 lobster bisque bits of lobster on the side with a small cup soup. Nice presentation with slightly above average taste 3.5/5  ahi Not over cooked and served with veggies. The portions were kinda small but its DAT.  The fish its self is similar to roy's in quality and taste. 3.25/5  brownie with butterscotch and coffee ice cream The brownie was very rich, the caramel and butter mix was also very rich. The ice cream was also very rich. My only complaint is that it kept me up until 4am until I could sleep. The whip cream that came with it tasted like air. 4/5  2) DAT crabcakes 2 pieces of super yummy crab cakes with some greens. 5/5  halibut not overally impressed by this dish. The spinach? with ham that came with it was pretty good though. 3/5  tiramisu baked in a small tea cup. It also came with a very rich rum cake on the side along with extra light whipped cream. One of the better ones I have had. 4.25/5  bread stale. Went well with the bisque. 2/5  Overall. A very nice place to bring a date as its pretty fancy and the food was above average. The service was 5/5. I would not hesitate to recommend this place for the right occasion.

eSlDbkIXnPhJB1NH553zUg.review_text: The San Francisco landmark is good for lunch. We had a nice lunch on Father's Day. The lunch menu is a decent value. We enjoyed the French bread, clam chowder, seafood pasta and the catch of the day. The dinner menu looks too expensive for the ambiance and quality of food !  The service was nothing special. The steamed vegetables are average.

asC9kSYVy6_QIsZSt3n-Xw.review_text: Hands down, my favorite place on the planet.  A trip to SF is not complete without a stop there.  When in town I stay at the Wharf just so I can go a couple of times.    There is nothing on the menu that is short of brilliant!  The Cioppino is the house specialty and is one of the best I've ever had.  The seafood is fresh, the pastas are wonderful, but for the treat of a lifetime you have to try the Sand Dabs (when you can get them).  Buttery, delicate and melt in your mouth!  Probably the only dish in the state of Cali that I would sell my soul for.    Be prepared to wait during peak times, but please do wait.  I promise it will be worth every minute and you can get sloshed at their bar.    My only complaint (and its a small one) is that they won't do takeout at all.  When I'm in town on business alone I'd rather take a meal back to the hotel, but that has never stopped me from eating there!

zEAmT3BX-o-l6WA5OC0kZg.review_text: Best chowder I've ever had. On a boat tour the guide mentioned something about them possibly using seawater for extra flavor. Mmmmmmmmmm.

4hfETiyxeV_6O1zNIO8FhQ.review_text: Great location on the wharf although the location in Sausoiito is far better than five stars. Even with the normal wait if 45 minutes for a table it is well worth it. Best clam chowder and the sourdough bread comes fresh hourly from the bakery around the corner. Best advice I can give is before ordering the special ask the price. I failed to do this when they had a lobster special and it was $150. Anything with scallops is incredible. If you like it spicy, request the scallops be blackened.

GodFH0SvRPNHrq5c3VCESw.review_text: One of my top 10 best meals ever.  You know what I am talking about - when the food, drink, company, and conversation is perfect.  I had the Cioppino seafood stew.  I am not a soup fan because I want a lot of food.  I took a chance on this dish after seeing someone else's go by.  Unbelievable!  The red marinara sauce was a dipping sauce for the perfect bread.  And the chunks of seafood were divine.  Even for a heavy guy like me, there was way enough food.  I even had enough to share with my wife.  We both agreed that this is a San Francisco must.

rijTi0IGn8u9rgLe9pvPgw.review_text: Sadly, I was kinda disappointed by my Scoma's experience last night.  I went with 2 co-workers since we were in town for a business trip over the weekend, and my one co-worker had heard that it's one of the "must see" restaurants in San Francisco.  Happily, we managed to get a table within about 20 minutes on a Friday night during the dinner rush, and we spent the 20-minute wait having a cocktail in the crowded bar while everyone watched the game on TV.  I can appreciate the sort of kitsch factor of the place -- you can tell that in the 60s or 70s, this was *the* place to go...  but with the original wood paneling and fixtures and everything, plus the servers' boxy white waiter jackets, it all comes across like you're stuck in a time warp.  But again, I can totally appreciate it.  What I didn't appreciate, though, was the rotten service once we were seated at our table.  Someone brought us the bread basket, and then it was almost 20 minutes before our server came over to even greet us.  When he did, it was just a very short "sorry 'bout the wait, what can I get you".  All of our interactions with him were this way -- pretty much he'd just drop off the next course without saying a word and walk away.  When our desserts came (we did the 3-course prix fixe where dessert was included and ordered at the beginning), he didn't even ask if we wanted coffee.  It was obvious he just wanted to get us eating and get us out...  which was confirmed when we were outside waiting for the valet to bring our car, and we saw him put his coat on and head home.  Now, I totally get that people have lives and everything...  but it doesn't add extra time to your shift to smile, ask how our meal is, etc.  Goodness.  I've had service 10x better at a TGI Friday's, for half the price.  The food itself was pretty decent -- my arancini appetizer (3 risotto balls rolled in bread crums and quick-fried) was piping hot, the risotto was cheesy and gooey...  the entree of giant grilled prawns over pasta was a little bland but the prawns were grilled perfectly.  and the dessert of a small brownie served with a scoop of ice cream and caramel sauce was good to satisfy a need for something sweet, but the brownie was rather dry.  My co-workers got the swordfish entree and cheesecake dessert and enjoyed them.  In a nutshell, it's worth going to for the old-school seafood restaurant experience...  just hope you get a different server than we had.

zFQnGH2aXZkP3gK7OIgcig.review_text: Our first attempt to dine here was completely unsuccessful. There was a 3 hour wait for a table, and we only had 2 hours before our play at the Herbst Theatre was to start. On our way out, a man offered unsolicited advice and told us it was, "worth the wait." We thought, alright, we'll definitely be back!   Fast forward one month and there's practically no one else in line. Our waiter, though strange, seemed to really know what he was talking about. I REALLY wish I would've done research beforehand, because I was at a loss when it came time to order. Both our dishes were good, but we didn't consume anything life-changing.   Though a bit pricey, I'll definitely be back to try something else on their menu. After hearing raves and praise about this place, I can't convince myself on being content at 4 stars. C'mon, a 3 hour wait? I had to have ordered the wrong dish. I want to taste a 5 so badly.

XW4TSu9LodFF4Lc5NkKh_g.review_text: A wonderful experience. The fish was very fresh, flaky and delicious. I started with the portobello mushroom stuffed with crab. The combination of savory and sweet was heavenly.  I then had the grill platter which included 2oz each of salmon, swordfish and haddock, plus 3 prawns. Creamed spinach and a mix of sweet & regular fries were included. A superfluous dipping sauce was also on the side for those who might want it. I recommend Scoma's to anyone who loves fresh seafood!

XDobuOFvYDwcOIbr66Y1RQ.review_text: so my boss recommended this place based solely on their famous cioppino. Being italian i was intrigued, i'm from Boston and love seafood. I'm also italian and love italian food. Combining both was bound to be good. I was not disappointed!  First, this place is expensive. The bill for the soup alone came to around $50. But high cost does not diminish the experience. Scoma's is a CLASSIC place, the kind of place you want to take your wife on special occasions. Places like that are worth it.  Second, the ambiance is old town San Francisco from the North Beach of the 1960's. This is a place that the wise guys used to come for the best food around. I was most definitely in my element.   Third, the food... WOW. As soon as I ordered the cioppino Salvatore advised me that I didn't need to order anything else. Now I can eat but I got a little nervous about the breadstick i had eaten. When the food arrived I realized Salvatore was right, this was a huge bowl of seafood with a big slice of garlic bread. But having walked to the restaurant through the cold and wind i was ready. In fact that made it better, warm soup on a cold day. The broth was heavenly, i sipped most of the broth before I started on the fish. Now most fish in soups gets a little tough as it cooks. Somehow this fish was incredibly tender, the cod, the scallops, the clams and shrimp, it was all delicious.  Lastly, the people. Everyone was awesome! Salvatore was a true professional. Salvatore was hard working, knowledgeable, friendly. I was very lucky to have him as a server. Then the chef, Donnie Grey, came out and talked to me about the cioppino. Donnie was a great guy, very down to earth and friendly. He treated me like I was a celebrity!  Scoma's is a four star restaurant and a San Francisco landmark! I would highly recommend it if you're visiting with someone special and you want a romantic night out or you want to celebrate a special occasion....or if you just want GREAT food and service. i know I will be back whenever I am in San Francisco again.

cXOKF_ySM9ps2vBhMOkcvw.review_text: Scoma's has been in the Bay Area for nearly five decades. It's age certainly shows, both in its kitschy (not intentional) dated usage of all things wood, and its experience in articulating great dungeness crab. The serving staff are attentive and garbed like they were out of the Rat Pack era, very cool. Its somewhat hidden location on the Wharf, just makes it more rewarding when you partake in its various renditions of crab; it also provides a great view of the dock community it is ensconced in. Scoma's, for well over 40 years, is a find.

Et0qEP5K0oTCpAZ0aULmpw.review_text: Shellfish saute - add baby lobster, split it, get a glass of wine, go to heaven. Bartender was a hilarious matter-of-fact older woman. Waiter was like a maffia goon - frank and helpful. Ate until my gut exploded.

5XDgaMQeXLIHpR1e3d-HUQ.review_text: We met some out-of-town friends here because Scoma's had been highly recommended to them. I had a lovely glass of merlot, split a tasty spinach salad with one of my dining companions, then had the best blackened swordfish I think I've ever eaten. I've been avoiding swordfish because of its previous avoid status on the Seafood Watch list, but our very competent waiter assured me this swordfish was handline caught, and I succumbed. One of my non-fish-loving dining companions was sorry that she'd ordered the mediocre steak instead of the swordfish. The other orders at my table included a decent pasta dish and a crab risotto, and both diners were quite happy with their orders. The bread slices were huge and really good. Next time I'll avoid the bread basket, lol, because half of my swordfish came home with me for lunch. :-) If you don't like seafood this is probably not the best place to eat. For seafood lovers, you could eat here every night for weeks before you'd make your way through all of the seafood entrees. I'm looking forward to going back.

9MNumsdViMbqwH3LjGRCSw.review_text: Lovely atmosphere. Valet parking. We were being romantic and this place definitely kept what we were doing alive. Sat by the window with the view of Aliotos. Love that wine list. My waiter was Hella cool and Hella chatty. But it's good. We had the lobster bisque and clam chowder for starters. I ordered the Dungeness crab risotto. He ordered the whole crab garlic roasted. The crab portions were good for my risotto. However, I don't care too much for the actual risotto. The crab came and the presentation was boring. The roasted garlic on the crab was very light. But edible..of course. I will say that the crab was the cleanest crab I've ever seen from any of the restaurants in the area. Overall, the experience was nice and that's what I really wanted

q-zcBRObGdiAMScvBIy2tQ.review_text: Scoma is so cute. For out of towners visiting I strongly recommend riding a bike on Fishermann's wharf across the Golden Gate Bridge and stopping for lunch here at Scoma. Ask to sit in the back, there is the a beautiful view of the water. I ordered clam chowder in a sourdough bowl which was the best I ever had. My friends got shrimp tacos and crab which were wonderful as well.

V27hh0C2KItIxFwV7EIbSg.review_text: One night, one meal: Scoma's  After reading restaurant review's of Scoma's I was hard pressed to make a menu selection once in person.  The selection was very good and my expectations were high.  In the end, based on the recommendation of my server, I chose the Lazy Man's Cioppino.  My mouth still waters when thinking of it.  It is no less than a bowl of perfection.

T_TvlfXcSUbXm2-ZFoe73A.review_text: Of the countless fine places in San Francisco, California and about everywhere else, Scoma's is the among the very best...if not the best.  I hate to be repetitive, but yes, the Lazy Man's Cioppino is as good as it gets.  With a side of delicious sourdough and rich butter, the Cioppino is sheer culinary bliss.  The fresh fish selections...all simply prepared are exquisite as well.

DBzGwIxUsIvlhZIVTfoisw.review_text: Seriously the best restaurant at the Wharf! It's well hidden so not a lot of tourists no about it, but it is not something to miss. My family comes here everytime we go to the city, about 4-5 times a year. SOO GOOD! I have never had a bad experience here or a bad meal. Some of my favorites: -Cioppino (fish stew in thick tomato sauce--if you have never had it, its a must!) -Swordfish -Seared ahi -Salmon -Crab stuffed mushrooms -Sweet spoon bread  So delicious. Great service. Beautiful views. Lovely memories.  PS. If you don't like their desserts take the five minute walk to Ghiradelli square :)

7jzmHn6u0u2tVJPvH9wz9g.review_text: Not impressed. Way over priced for the amount of food given.

npMj3QhyOP0GbCvvv0xOkQ.review_text: Ciopinno over here was not good as it was pretty large and I almost could not finish with all the other appetizers I ate.  Great place to visit while visiting the warf.
