ddX-WlnqPRny43OrtSKoCw.review_text: having been here several times, i believe it is fair to finally to write a review with a rating of three solid stars. after the first couple of visits, i thought it strange that so many have given glowing reviews of the food here, but subsequent visits have assured me that it wasn't just me unluckily picking out the mediocre dishes on a few separate occasions. not a bad place, just not memorable.  dishes i still remember:  mixed shellfish platter for two - fresh and delicious. flavors shone cleanly. no complaints here.  hearts of romaine salad - mehhhh. just because it's not a seafoody dish does not make it okay to slack on it, given the kind of place this is/presents itself to be.  prawns and scallops alla gannon - mediocre, at best. flavors were...boring. missing, even. sadface. i had expectations for this dish.  risotto - "i paid this much for....this? o_________O"   king salmon - if you need to get a robust salmon fix, then this will definitely meet your requirement. but plainly put, nothing special at all. i understand the concept of minimal masking when the fish is assuredly fresh, but this just made me go 'meh'. very filling though, lovely portion.   lobster - yummy lobster is yummy, but not in a crazy mind-blowing way. but then again....lobster is lobster, i may have unfortunately had one that's just not naturally as sweet-tasting as the better ones i've had elsewhere.  garlic mashed potatoes - OH MY. i would gladly fill up on this carbful of tasty.  tiramisu - quite delightful. wonderfully rich and boozy enough to cut through the cloying aftertaste that creeps up halfway into the dessert.   the servers are always great. professional, non-intrusive and very efficient, quick and attentive. no reservations, so chill at the bar or mingle with the tourists while checking out touristy knick-knacks in the souvenir shops to while away the wait time. free valet parking, which is amazing given the stupendous fee that the parking lot here/street parking charges.

RFXcKWIaGsqFWK6WJbkl4g.review_text: Outstanding clam chowder!  The fried sea food platter was very good, but was disappointed in the Bloody Mary, it was weak. That wouldn't stop me from going back. Great place to eat if you're in the area.

ZWGZDAqYOKoxUC9hmITe6Q.review_text: We had good food, great service, but compared to other good restaurants in town, OVERPRICED.  Have not dined here for a few years, but our out of town friends wanted the experience.  These days most diners here are tourists.  Some with guide book in hand.  Any SF dweller that gets out at all knows other good places at much better prices.  Arriving around 6pm Sat., we were a group of 5.  As they do not take reservations we had to wait 45 minutes for a table.  I had a deliciously dark draft beer to make the time fly faster.  When we finally started I had some perfectly prepared Crab Cakes.  Followed by a stellar Shell Fish Saute.  It included shrimp, scallops, small lobster tails, crab, steamed Cauliflower, manicotti, and risotto.   Finally the Tiramisu was served with the Marscapone, some Lady Fingers, Coffee/Choc. mousse in a cup and a solid Chocolate Spoon on top.  Whipped cream and extra lady fingers where served on the side...delicioso!  It was good but for $60 per person with tip, not worth the price, so only 3 stars.

_viYKotRiCsrUU34EglRXg.review_text: My husband and I have been going to this restaurant for over 30 years. This is one of the best in San Francisco and has some of the freshest seafood . This is a must for any first time visitor. This is a S.F treasure.

jFZ7xAhnT5tteHgqL-zw2g.review_text: Made a reservation here for NYE and was extremely disappointed considering all the great reviews on here. This is definitely more of a touristy place than a restaurant that actually serves great food. My biggest pet peeve is when "nice" restaurants serve cold almost stale looking bread with cold butter. As a first impression it's well not impressive. The food isn't well presented for a place that's $$$. The mushroom/dungeness crab appetizer looked like it was overcooked and the vegetables in my lobster risotto seemed like they could have come out of a frozen bag from the grocery store. Not a place I would recommend.

xoZvMJPDW6Q9pDAXI0e_Ww.review_text: This is a fantastic seafood restaurant in the heart of Fisherman's Wharf.  Based on location it should be a tourist trap, but it's not!   The atmosphere is very nice, but the food is what makes Scoma's worthy of a return visit.  I have been going off and on for about 10 years, and can tell you that I have always been very pleased with the food and service.  The Cioppino is what everybody talks about, but I have also enjoyed a number of entrees ranging from the catch of the day to steak.  The oysters are fresh, the prawn cocktail is huge, and the lobster ravioli is really good.  As a tourist, this should be the place you visit on the wharf for dinner.  As a local, this is a place that is perfect for guests or the occasional dinner in a part of town you wouldn't normally venture into.

0eGVtn7yM-eHYB8hHSR5Jw.review_text: We loved this restaurant.    The food was excellent.  The service was even better.   I felt like I was on a cruise ship.

1T0aVUBJl6HSN4FAMtz6hg.review_text: Delicious lunch special of clam chowder, crab Louie salad and chocolate mousse pie. Nice restaurant to kick off a girls weekend in SF!

C4dqGS0ld9yWsTNKatyqGw.review_text: The lobster bisque was amazing!  The bread was soft and yummy. Scallops and prawns with lemon and butter was good... The scallops were grilled to perfection, the prawns were kind of tasteless ... All I could taste was the charred skewer flavor. Service was excellent! Very friendly and knowledgable.

PHfmvyVcxoccNyyMBUD3sw.review_text: Great service. Yummy food. We went here for lunch on a Friday, and it was a more mature crowd.  OYSTERS ON THE HALF SHELL- Half Dozen (A Selection of Three Types of Oysters) - DELICIOUS & fresh! My boyfriend usually doesn't eat oysters, and he enjoyed them. Was kind of sad...wanted them all to myself. LOL!  ROASTED WHOLE CRACKED DUNGENESS CRAB (Olive Oil, Garlic, and Fresh Lemon) - This was excellent! But I kind of felt weird peeling the crab in a nice restaurat.   LOBSTER RAVIOLI - yummy! Was topped with chunks of lobster.

cpg93yMQpYKTk2pwoB_1aQ.review_text: At 6:30 it was already an hour wait for Saturday night dinner! This place must be written up in every guide there is. When I posted to Facebook that I was here, friends immediately started to reply that they love Scoma's. Well, so did I!  This place is old school, white jacket service for tourists and foodies alike. JN and I shared several dishes. We started with lobster bisque (awesome) and clams bordelaise (pretty tasty, soak up that broth with some bread). Then came the dungeoness crab (superb) and grilled sand dabs (a fish I had never tried and really enjoyed - tho I'd prefer it without the requisite pasta side).  Next time I see you check in on Facebook or foursquare, I'll comment on how much I love Scoma's!

RhUQ1Vz3-bDMLbIGlcyzfA.review_text: An old school San Francisco seafood restaurant, Al Scoma's place on the wharf continues to shine even after 50 years.  While the worn red carpet and wood paneled walls hung with faded photographs of famous visitors seemingly haven't been updated from since the 1970s, the décor is just what one would expect from a longstanding San Francisco landmark.  The location right not he water cannot be beat.  The expansive menu has something for everyone, even those that shy away from seafood.  That being said, the dishes that feature the bounty of the ocean really shine at Scoma's.    With a light vinaigrette, the organic baby spinach salad ($16) with bacon, hard boiled egg, and tomatoes was a great way to start the meal.  Sweet and creamy, the butternut squash soup ($13) topped with chunks of local Dungeness crab was delicious.  Hearty and chock full of scallops, shrimp, crab, and fish, Scoma's "lazy man's" cippino ($39) is large enough for two and still leaves some to take home.  Fresh from the boat, the whole steamed Dungeness crab ($MP) is sweet and succulent.  The meal is accompanied by a seemingly endless supply of warm, freshly baked sourdough bread, butter, and olive oil.  Friendly and attentive, service is excellent.  Dressed in cropped white jackets, white shirts, and black ties, the waiters (nearly all are men) are classic.  Be sure to consult your server before ordering, as they are supremely knowledgeable of the menu and can direct you to selections that are sure to please.  Scoma's has a full bar as well as a nice, reasonably priced selections of wine by the glass and by the bottle.  With tasty seafood fresh from the boat, there is a reason why Scoma's has been a San Francisco seafood go-to for 50 years.

Be8gtmKER07-GSblnX56TQ.review_text: Don't waste your time here!!!  Maybe it was the hot spot in 1980, but it's not now!!!  It's tourist trap!!  Service is good, but the food is mediocre quality at best!!

DU9kqCNO1_OH2MBndiMUfw.review_text: Seated right away. Long wait once seated to be greeted. Drink order wrong. Told no sole. Ordered cod. Out of that too! 2 drinks .. One wrong ... $26.00. Won't be back!!

4tJndq_LK-kfYaxLNYfEKg.review_text: I have been a San Francisco resident since 1986 and was first taken to Scoma's back in 1989. My first impression of the local restuarant tucked back in Al Scoma's Way was one of wonder. How cool it was to find a piece of "old San Francisco" hidden among the touristy confines of the Wharf. After my first meal at Scoma's I was hooked. I came back often and nine times out of ten I would order the blackened salmon. It became one of my favorite restuarants in SF and even had many of my  birthday dinners at my "favorite" spot.   But things have changed.....  A couple of years ago I knew the end was near when Scoma's replaced its bound menus to a one page laminate. The menu had been replaced and was scaled back. But the food was still excellent and I saw no reason to complain.  Until now......  Took a date my to old "favorite" restuarant last night. I talked it up all the way to our seated table. But once the food arrived I was sorerly disappointed. Gone was one of my favorite places to dine. Chalk it up to another place in disappearing San Francisco. My date and I shared the trio appetizer for two......it was disappointing but still looked forward to the main dishes. I couldn't wait to get my blackened salmon! My date ordered the once famous shellfish sauté. When it arrived It looked nothing like it did back when Scoma's cared about presenting quality dishes. My blackened salmon was an even bigger bummer. The size of my fish was a third the size it used to be. And it wasn't even blackened......the waiter offered to have it blackened but after I saw what was to come I thought to myself why even bother.   It just sucks forking over $150.00 (including a couple of cocktails) on mediocre food at best. What was once one of my favorite places to take my out of town friends and myself is no more. I have spoken to many other of my local friends and they all agree. Scoma's is no longer the restuarant that it used to be. And I will miss it. Giving it two stars solely on the great memories I had there.

BLmRIoETvx6ZiegiIWh0tw.review_text: Scomas is a bit of a conflict in my mind. The portions are enormous, the crab linguine is phenomenal and I have never seen seafood pasta that looked that appetizing. The clam chowder is, of course, brilliant seeing as it is near the wharf. What more could you possibly want?  Oh yeah, that's right. You might want a fucking table!  It doesn't matter what time of day you go. The place has so many damn tourists that it's impossible to get a table if you go anywhere near a normal meal time. There will be about half-hour waits on off hours (like 3pm) and usually an hour and a half to two hour wait at dinner and on weekends. More than that, the place is horrible for odd numbered tables. They will try to shove 3 people at an obviously two person table instead on conceding the extra seat at a 4 person table.  Yes, the food is great, but I don't want to spend more time waiting for a table than I spend eating my meal. No matter who you're with (and I was with my best friend for this dinner) the wait just isn't worth it. I would come back over and over again if only they took reservations.

98DslWquC6ypAJZyZcKcZg.review_text: We came to Scoma's after a very touristy sightseeing day.  It is close but is a little bit tucked away from the chaos.  We were able to make a late lunch reservation and were seated quickly. It has a sort of old-school vibe to the decor.   Service was just okay.  Our waiter said they had a full bar and asked if we wanted a drink.  After walking through the crowds, that is exactly what we wanted!  I wasn't into the drink list and tried to order a Dark'n'Stormy which their bartender had never heard of it.  I found rather odd if they have a full bar but was good sticking to the menu. Our waiter really pushed the pre-fixed lunch menu saying it was a good value.  I was a bit hesitant but he said it had Scoma's best items.  We went for it, but in the end I am not sure if it was the right call. Also, at the end of our meal, we felt rushed as it appeared to be shift ending time.  The food was good and fresh.  Their clam chowder was very good and probably my favorite item.  I ordered the Combo Crab & Shrimp Louis salad and my husband ordered the fish of the day (halibut).  The Crab & Shrimp Louis was very fresh and I can see why it is a popular item. My biggest complaint is that I had shell pieces and quite frankly expect better from a restaurant of this quality. My husband's halibut was fresh, perfectly cooked and perfectly seasoned.  However, the cheddar polenta that was served with the fish was a bit heavy and didn't seem to fit with the dish. The raspberry desert cake was excellent and not too sweet.   With the service and pre-fixed menu choice, I am not sure we had the chance to really get the best taste of Scoma's.

VAEUcVCiNwsjr_LN8rj51A.review_text: Scoma's was amazing. My friend and I came here for lunch. We both had the pre-fixe lunch and got clam chowder and a mixed louie salad (shrimp and crab louie mixed together).The lunch also came with a chocolate mousse cake. Delicious. Loved this place and I will for sure be coming back in the future.

OY61OeL_-Hc2BucJx4IQsg.review_text: To be frank...Scoma's just isn't what it used to be. It was the one place on the wharf that maintained a high quality standard and didn't go the way of Alioto's or The Grotto, sub par seafood for the tourist crowd. It is clear from my last few visits to Scoma's including my dinner last night, that they have joined the rest of the Fisherman's Warf bunch. Sure they are still packed, but with their prices, subpar service and now average food that won't last long. Too bad too...another icon gone.

dw2vrp4tYOACJW-WriVoJQ.review_text: Last night I decided with some of my friends to go here instead of another restaurant in North Beach for my birthday. Just becuase I couldn't find parking. So me and my girlfriends got there and parked outside without the valet just becuase we didn't know they even had it. big mistake. I admit we should had researched the place before going becuase it would had saved us time and pain from our heels walking to that place that seemed secluded.  It took a 20 minute wait without reservation, which is good but all in all it was good. I'm a fan :)

ulBTTSoQy5_PxAIhf5A7VQ.review_text: Wow, this was a local place that's tucked away in the fisherman's wharf.  Huge portions, great wait staff and an interesting ambiance.  I'd go back, but I will certainly not eat for a day before I go.

X7DFMjhqMOQ3KQaKFLk4sg.review_text: Excellent, excellent food and service on the Wharf. Their dishes are huge and worth the wait. Probably could split and entree if you eat appetizers. Waitstaff was attentive and helpful. Would recommend to anyone wanting a great selection of seafood and steaks on the Wharf.

z09OGtJho3W8ZFx7emLctA.review_text: The food is very hit and miss. The appetizers were acceptable. Three out of the four meals were not. Service is good. There are many better seafood restaurants at a cheaper price. Worst for us was that they placed a large party of irritating and drunk tourists that literally surrounded us.  If you were going to the Wharf area. I would actually, suggest Joe's Crab Shack before Scoma's, which is sad I really wanted to like it.

PezOw_38vSaZEFJhFvSCKg.review_text: I had a waitress recommended meal and it was the best meal at the table.  I had one of the specials for the night with sauteed crab.  It was seriously amazing.  I did not enjoy how long it took for our orders to be taken.  But everything else was really good.

GFUA6QtkOAleazw0TBoGUw.review_text: The best lobster bisque in the world and the crab is great.  The potatoes were different. They taste more like a dessert. However, the service was great and I'll be back soon.

luzIKywwBqpNE8Rr0efXxQ.review_text: Had dinner there early on a Sunday evening.  Didn't get to sit on the scenic side and were seated at a pretty cramped table that was too close to the next table.  The food was okay, nothing great.  My halibut was a bit overcooked.  Service was just okay.  One person mistakenly poured water into an glass containing an alcoholic drink, and another person when clearing the table dropped some food off the plate that just missed hitting my friend and later tried to take my plate away while I was still eating.  Price/performance-wise I wouldn't be inclined to return.

DOjR-B_JMCxh10MxVGnozw.review_text: Get here early.  We were there on Saturday night, about 5:30pm.  Walked right in.  But about 6pm it started filling up.  By the time we left, people were waiting outside.  I had not been here in about 15 years, still had the same high quality food that I remembered.   My Finance and I ordered the Filet and Lobster and it was devine.  Served with mixed veggies and awesome mashed potatoes.  The Filet was thick, juicy, moist and tender.  Cooked to perfection, and not a single piece of fat on it.    The Lobster was absolutely amazing.  Big 12oz tail, very tender and with the melted butter to dip it in, it was mouth-waterting.  We shrared this meal, along with a cup of the best clam chowder ever.    The service was great, fast but still enough time to enjoy the meal and the scenery (old crusty boats at the dock).  That was funny.  The meal was priced at $80, which I cringed at.  But when we got into the meal, I felt it was worth it.  We don't get to San Fran very often.  I highly recommend Scoma's to anyone that loves seafood.  For some people it's a little hard to find, just look for the big orange sign down the alley way.  You won't be disappointed.

rhM01fl3iU0xHr3TIpCMhQ.review_text: Why didn't I just eat at Fisherman's Wharf the entire time I was in San Francisco?!  You live and you learn.  My last night in San Francisco was spent here and am I happy with the way the trip ended.  After biking the bridge, we were all very hungry.  Our wait was about 20 minutes which I think was all we were even going to wait.  We ordered drinks at the bar while we waited.  Trust me, after biking, we needed it.  We sat down at a table next to the window and got to look at the boats that were docked at the pier.  Great table.  I loved the way the restaurant felt.  One of those places that had been around since 1950s and hasn't changed.  The servers were in bow ties and jackets and just seemed old fashioned.  Loved the ambiance.  I don't remember what my other dinner companions ordered but I got the roasted whole crack dungeness crab with olive oil and garlic.  To die for!  It was messy but I didn't care.  Bring on the crab meat!  It was so succulent that I didn't want it to end.  The roasted garlic just enhanced the meat.  Garlic makes everything better anyway.  I was too busy enjoying my meal that I don't know if everyone enjoyed theirs as well.  I'm sure they did but I was too busy stuffing my face.  When I come back to San Francisco, I am definitely going back to Scoma's and every other restaurant on the Wharf.

G4sv-tyShHFbleUFODS__w.review_text: A family ritual. No trip to the city is complete without a trip to Scomas. They have valet for customers-only. Delicious food, pasta, two bars, elegant service. Worth the prices!!!

DDrwHxw2XGdtjYj9ISAbAA.review_text: This place is fantastic.  I ordered the Lazy Man's Cioppino for lunch.  Honestly, this was my second lunch of the day...but I heard so many great things about Scoma's Cioppino that I had to try it.  Even though I hardly finished (it's a lot of food), it was excellent.  The restaurant was packed and we had a short 10 minute wait for a table of two.  I highly recommend getting the Cioppino here over some clam chowder at another restaurant.

WFGLQTWfEChPy-PpRplqKg.review_text: One of the best old fashions you will ever drink. I love drinking an old fashion at an old San Francisco place with classy old people all before noon. Old school is definitely cool.   Order the pasta diplomatico.

ngDBUZLXxlwHmajgUT4LUw.review_text: I was very skeptical about this place because it's definitely touristy, but I'm so glad I decided to give it a chance. SF has so many great trendy restaurants as well as authentic ethnic food...and Scoma's is where you go when you're not in the mood for either of those things. It's just a very classic restaurant with good service and good food. The give you endless sourdough bread with butter (that's actually room temp, which is a nice touch!) and the menu has an abundance of seafood standbys. I had the lobster bisque (so so good!) and the crab cakes (also excellent) and my husband had a whole crab. We really enjoyed our food, although we both left absolutely stuffed! Don't let the touristy exterior/repuation/location fool you, this is a great place to go if you just want normal, classic seafood done right!

FRxcVEYqm7-jpWPTapPhbQ.review_text: Outstanding.  In what can be an otherwise touristy area, this slightly off the beaten path restaurant deserves every single one of these 5 stars.  Fresh, fresh, fresh!  The server informed us of the fish that had been caught THAT DAY (some from their own boat), that would be available on the menu.  We started with delicious west coast oysters, that were some of the best I've had.  Then, I got the rock cod (caught that day) and the person I was dining with got the scallops.  I will also say, that the scallops were some of the best scallops I have had.  My rock cod was great too!  I almost forgot the dungeness crab cocktail - not to be missed.  Wine was reasonable, white coat service - overall, a highlight of the trip.

vT3e-GICbTP_eEGBWykZeg.review_text: I came here because of a recommendation from my online friend Ahnah (see couple entries below.)   This place is reaaaaly packed! We were so sure we had to wait but...how lucky! Our wait time was about a minute!  The 4 of us tried (see pictures too:)  Sampler Plate : Mini Crabcakes, Calamari Fritti, and Firecracker Popcorn Shrimp - $25.00  Clam Chowder $4.50   Seared Ahi Tuna (Huge!) $29.00   Shellfish Saute Sec (Most popular dish) $36.00   Pasta with Salmon and Rock Shrimp $26.00   Pasta Alla Scoma $24.00   They were all good. My Shellfish Saute Sec was huge! So huge I had to take it home. It comes with pasta AND rice AND veggies. I had a nice snack in the hotel room!  Definitely recommended!

6foXESDaUTxXLmp0V1T-JQ.review_text: 2.5 STARS. I gotta say, the view is beautiful, but the food was just alright. This place is very outdated, a little bit too old school for my liking. If this place got a revamp, it would be so much better!  Ordered the lobster bisque, forgettable. Okay, honestly I don't even remember the name of the entree I got which is really sad considering I remember almost everything I eat. This is how forgettable the food was. I just remember it being overcooked fish with different sauces and broth that were all mixed together with some vegetables plopped around it. The dessert was not good - got the brownie.  Would never come back here, but the reason for 3 stars instead of 2 was for the service. The waiter we had was incredibly sweet. Although he didn't really pay attention to us, he was really nice when he did. It was a very casual and comfortable dining experience that I can see regulars coming in and ordering their favorites. The view is pretty nice, and the location is great if your'e a tourist and want to go walk around the pier aftewards. Okay, just to give you an idea about the unsatisfaction of this 3 course meal, I bought a whole steamed crab from the pier after and ate it all.

vsfG95vDU20d7upU1Zs6uA.review_text: I honestly can't think of anywhere else in San Francisco to get fresh seafood cooked to perfection! Perhaps Tadich Grill on California St. puts up a good fight with Scoma's but other than that, I don't know where else to go. Suggestions?   FRIED CALAMARI (appetizer) I love how the calamari comes out tangy, with a crispy fried crust. The calamari itself is soft, and the two dipping sauces (tartar and cocktail) go so well with the fried calamari. I usually mix the tartar and the cocktail sauces together to get a better consistency since I think the tartar sauce resembles mayo TOO much and the cocktail sauce can be on the watery side.   PASTA ALLA SCOMA (linguini and clams) I'm sorry, Scoma's. But I had so much better linguini and clams in Venice! Something about that dish hasn't been topped yet. I'm still on a search for a good linguini and clams dish but the one I had here was decent. I had about 30 clams on my plate. I definitely had more clams than pasta, which is a good because I'm getting what I paid for, but I was also craving pasta. I would recommend this dish for someone who isn't a big seafood fan, but would like to try something new.   CIOPPINO We didn't get the lazy man style where the crab was out of it's shell and we should have paid $3 more for it. They give you 2 crab legs plus that big part of the crab and it's still all in the shell. I think it would have been easier to eat had it been shelled for us. Oops. Oh well, now we know. The sauce to this cioppino was good -- not too tangy and not too sweet. I love the bread that comes with this because it's nicely grilled and it's way oily. It's definitely goes well dipped in the cioppino soup, YUM!   There are two complaints I do have about this place: 1. No reservations for SUCH a classy restaurant. Sure we wore jeans and a tank top to dine here but you would think such a fine establishment would take reservations. They tell you to stay at the bar until your name is called. I'm guessing that's a good tactic to reel in more profits but that's at such a disadvantage to your customers since they have to WAIT for a table. Sigh! I do have to add that Eddy (Asian man with a comb-over makes an excellent Fruit Punch -- no alc) -- GET IT! 2. As the server was refilling my water cup, he accidentally poured a bit of water on my camera, realized it, then swiftly walked away. He didn't even acknowledge that he did something wrong. I was half fuming, but stayed calm because of the good food I was devouring. Plus, the water only hit the shell of my camera, not the lens (THANK GOD).   I'm definitely returning to Scoma's but if a server pours water on my camera again, I will be livid (that might be an understatement).

CGoC5-mTfkAU4pJj3WT6FA.review_text: You can never go wrong when eating at Scoma's.  I love this place.

_FTBtYe8sTjbSUkm22e_mg.review_text: This restaurant did not live up to the reputation or location.  The server was OK, but the food was poor.  I had fish, of course, and it was mushy and bland.  I can say I've been there, but won't go back.

x5wPZc6EwodnRZptPoPjWA.review_text: Stumbled upon this place through yelp reviews. Arrived and waited 45 minutes for 5. The hostess was really nice and friendly. Got seated, water was poured quick and bread and butter came quick. We finished the bread and butter and still no waiter to take our order. After about 15 minutes, after we finished our bread, then a waiter finally came to take our order, not impressed with that. We should have been acknowledge not long after receiving our water and bread.   We ordered the Lazy Mans Cioppino. Plenty of seafood, good flavor, but we have had better. The soup was light.  21 Oz. Bone-in Cowboy Steak. This was good and even though this place is known for seafood, this steak was good, no A1 needed. Just the Gratin potatoes and bacon-bourbon butter with every bite of steak was enough.   I guess this would be the best restaurant on the wharf so far, but overall it's average.

K76dmjxtfvrbui_jeMAivQ.review_text: As I was dragged to this what appeared to be a rat hole amongst many dirty fishing boats I started to get real disappointed. I walked inside the restaurant and my disappointment quickly went away. I felt like I went through a time warp. It was kinda neat because all the waiters looked like they were from the 40s with their white coat and black slacks. The bar looked extra vintage. The bartenders had on black vest with white long sleeve button downs. The interior is very nice! We ordered our food. Tasted pretty good. If I could i'd give this place 3.5 stars simply because I feel the food was a bit over priced. Don't get  me wrong the food was good but i just don't feel it was worth the money paid.....but i did enjoy myself.

GGSfLyM88SbFGhnm46ykXQ.review_text: I don't get it.....   Maybe because we went for Dine About Town, but the quality shouldn't suffer because of it  DAT lunch:  Clam Chowder - nothing wow and not a lot of clams  Salmon, Mussels, Sun Dried Tomato pasta - first bite it taste good, toward the end, I can't finish it because I was afraid all the oil will clog my arteries.  The bottom of the plate was soak in 5-6 table spoons of oil    Mussels were good, and the salmon was a little over cooked  Grilled cod - not a lot of taste and nothing wow.  Cod was a little over cooked too  Service was below par too, I asked for hot water and  the waiter didn't note it down so had to ask for it.

64D9Ax7fQ5tbweQKXLOcUQ.review_text: Met some long time buds at Scoma's for dinner after a recent conference.  While I generally avoid the touristy Fisherman's Wharf area, Scoma's is tucked away off the beaten path, so you really have to know where are you going.  I walked in had flashbacks to my time spent on in coastal NC.I would have sworn I had just been transported  3000 miles to the NC coastal and dock areas!  Scoma's has an "old soul" complete with a wonderful bar.   The wait staff, all formally dressed in black and white, when's the last time you saw that... was quite helpful in guiding our selections and uber attentive throughout our meal. Several guys had the awesome looking  "Lazy Man's" Cioppino which others have commented - you best be VERY hungry or consider splitting this dish.  They are not kidding.  No one was able to finish this dish!  I opted for a cup of Bisque and then the mixed grilled seafood.  The Bisque was great but the mixed grilled seafood was just OK. I was disappointed with the inclusion of french fies with a grill dish of this caliber (guess I'll read the menu closer next time).    My second choices were the Seared Tuna or the awesome sounding Seafood Salad which I'd get next time.  Overall, Scoma's is a nice place to visit to have some really really fresh seafood while avoiding most of the touristy side of the Wharf.   They also have nice parking arrangements for those daring to drive.  Overall good, but be prepared, their pricing is on the upper side of the seafood scale but the experience and service is well executed. Cheers.

25nqzvPO_s0E8s0JCcnRZA.review_text: I know it's a tourist trap, but goddamn this place is rad. Food is great here. The servers all know they prey on non-natives. Our wait wasn't bad for a Saturday, only about 20 minutes. Food was amazingly delicious after a day of drinking. Definitely touristy, however. If that's not your scene, then stay away. It's just one of those "everyone local" doesn't go here kind of places. Fuck em. It's good eats. Reasonably priced. Fun to go to with friends. Sure, might not be the BEST, but it's decent. Great atmosphere too.

NRRPUnrCEIjDSt4uGV-rSw.review_text: A Wonderful Dinner!  We were smart and went for a 5:00p.m. dinner on Friday. It was very quite there so that was good because I have heard how crowed they can get.  Service very sweet and friendly.   What We Ordered:  Sampler Plate (crab cakes, firecracker popcorn shrimp and calamari fritti) Best crab cakes eaten. Not any added fillers, just great crab meat. Pasta Diplomatica Scallop Saute Blackened Swordfish Calamari Alla Anna  All were delicious and were very fresh. Although the Pasta Diplomatica was the hit of the evening. Which was a: Petit Lobster Tails, Prawns, Clams, and Sea Scallops in a Cream Sauce.  I will be back but because they DO NOT take reservations, I am very happy we went EARLY because upon our leaving, there were MOBS of people waiting and I overhead a 2 hour wait.

gwakmAy1XKzQPl87jXRLVQ.review_text: BEST DAMN AHI EVER.  Let me take a step back.  I am a seafood gal.  My other half is a seafood guy.  Scoma's hit the spot.  I had the seared ahi which was melt-in-your-mouth make you wanna slap  your mama good.  Seriously, I cannot stop talking about it.  The other half had garlic linguini with scallops, shrimp and other assorted fish.  His dish was awesome (slightly less awesome than mine, but I am probably biased).  Our server Lori was awesome.  She was extremely personable and friendly.  I was also impressed with the wine list.  My other half was head over heels for the bread basket.  Warm sourdough? Yes please!  Finally, I liked the vibe.  Even though the decor is a little dated, I liked the white table cloth feel of Scoma.  The location, right next to the water, was also great.  All in all I had a wonderful time here.  Great seafood, always on point with great service.  Check it ou!

16L58WcB-RmvtxDmUHwi6g.review_text: Ambiance: inside decor is simple and a bit dated, but your right on the waterfront and have beautiful views of the bay  Food: delicious! While this place is a bit on the pricier side ($25-30/person) the entrees are phenomenal! Try the calamari as an appetizer and the pistachio crusted salmon with balsamic butter sauce. Portions are generous.  Service: the waiters were very nice, however we waited for our food for over 40 minutes after waiting 20 minutes to be seated.   Bon apetit!

cwqYWgrPD4aLF4HB9ArtGw.review_text: Acceptable, though expensive, seafood at a shack on the Bay.  We hit Scoma's to find cioppino on a recent business trip to SF, after hitting the web to find a decent place that had one.   I like cioppino, and get it anywhere I can.  This one was pretty good, though it's a "Lazy man's cioppino", so there's nothing to crack, and only the clams are in shells, no mussels at all.   Good scallops, good shrimp, large pieces of fish, no chunks of crab (just threads), not much squid, sauce was tasty, but not very thick.   I'd put Brenneke's and even South Point's Oyster Bar over this one, and at $40 it's no bargain.  Others at the table had other things (there's a lot of pasta on the menu, which seems odd for a place on the Bay).  The best prepared dish was the seared Ahi, which wasn't very interesting palate-wise, but was cooked exactly to order.  The interior is acceptable, with lots of "Look who ate here!" shots on the wall.  The exterior is awful... looks like you're eating in a shack.   Oh, and it's a bit of a pain to get to if you're walking the wharf.  3rd star is really just for having an edible cioppino.  2 1/2 otherwise.

ZzHHfnVZn7nWAOzhRlBX3g.review_text: Of course 5 Stars!!!  The food is excellent, if you love seafood, Scoma's Restaurant is for you.  The service is amazing, they really deserve my 5 stars, even more. This place is an example how the service should be, they do know how to treat customers.  Can't wait to visit you again!

8pjrrLQwGw0wlp_k9E0vwA.review_text: By far the best restaurant in the fisherman's wharf. Its a traditional restaurant that i go eat at whenever my parents are in town. MMM! Their louis salad is off the charts!  sateed collosal prawns and scallops is my favorite!   For desert i recomend the white ghirradeli chocolate with rasberry purree!

oZK2DjCiA-8Xq6utMi4AYA.review_text: 824 reviews already, not much for me to add I suppose.    The food was delicious, the service was fantastic, the prices matched the quality.  I'd definitely go back if I were in San Francisco again.

P2vlvVy9u7PofeGEOjPJmA.review_text: AMAZING PLACE!!! I have never had a bad experience here.  Their food and service are the best in the area!  If this is your first time here, I would definitely try their crab cakes and Lazy man's Cioppino!!

7A9USrvW_ziStOB2W7bjaA.review_text: I've never had clam chowder so great before.  You can tell its fresh from the bay.  New England watch out, the San Francisco Chowders win this game!    Oh, do try their crab ravioli.  It's amazing, especially the sauce.  I want to try the lobster ravioli next time.  Shrimp linguini was pretty damn big and good too, but I think the overwhelming flavors of my ravioli shocked my palette for me to fully absorb the well seasoned complexities of this dish.  Service was okay.  Felt rather rushed.  He must be from New England because I saw his blitz coming.  Yay!  I'm a fan.  End.

RMMK0ukrzf7z7Pf8IY4URg.review_text: Classic Cioppino served Lazy Man Style enables you to kick up your feet and be served. Sometimes the service is a bit lazy too, but you'll be too busying enjoying the fruits of the ocean to care.

xXHLN98SH_wpREdQ76_IQQ.review_text: As a vegetarian, I was pleasantly surprised by Scoma.  I went there for lunch and had a delicious eggplant parmasean.  The restaurant is tucked down a lane on the wharf, and the space was like stepping back into the 1960s -- bow-tied staff and all.  Our table had a view of the Transamerica Pyramid and skyline.  Our server was excellent, particularly in recommending vegetarian options for me.

v7tuX0m6ajhxjlXX_LeKyA.review_text: Freshest Sea Food in The City !

xMYdgaWjAvVFej72f4qHxw.review_text: Every time I go here I'm amazed at the quality, taste and amount of food I'm being served. Have had many different dishes here and have never been disappointed. The food here and the service here are second to none.. I love this place and will always come here when in the city.

JQTmEjST0R_qgpev-879fA.review_text: Being new to San Francisco, this was one of the first restaurants I visited, and I was not disappointed.  The service was excellent. I tried fried calamari, grilled swordfish and fresh crab legs. I have to say that the crab legs were definitely the best part for me.

1CLFB9Zos3kGz1Xuj2eyww.review_text: I absolutely love love love this restaurant. The food is always delicious & the service is always 100% perfect. We've been coming here for easily 8+ years -- birthdays, anniversaries, random family dinners, date nights...  You can't go wrong with the Manila Clams, Garlic Bread, Fried Calamari & of course the absolute best Clam Chowder as your starters.   We always go with a steak, fish & pasta as our main entrees. Always yummy too!   By dessert, we are way too stuffed.   Note: make reservations, otherwise you're waiting.

6DZ8RlrHIzvmiSK7wRkGzw.review_text: Calamari fritti is a great starter! Lobster ravioli is a favorite of mine and love the half or whole cracked crab! Very good service, most waiters remember me from past visits and seem to take extra good care of me! Parking is easy and i'd have to say the best seafood I have had on the warf! If you don't like this place you are wrong.........correct yourself!

TVRZY8f7ygulBocq8nYIFA.review_text: Scoma's is my families go-to restaurant when we are getting together up in the city. We have been coming here since I was a baby and it has never failed us. I also look forward to their fresh sourdough bread and butter and a cup of some of the freshest clam chowder I've ever had to start off the meal. I've gotten multiple fish dishes here but love the Scoma's pasta. My dad is a sucker for the cioppino and has ordered it for as long as I can remember. When my grandmother passed away we rented out a room at Scoma's and had a wonderful memorial dinner here for about 40 people.   All in all this is a great seafood restaurant on the water and we will be coming back time and time again for many years to come.

PzzcjpzzanDDhxsR9OlmLg.review_text: We came here after multiple people said to check it out (cab driver, another couple at a bar, yelp) and it was alright. We made reservations which is a must as the place attracts a large crowd. Has a good location right on the pier so if you are lucky to get a table near a window, its fun to gaze at the docked boats. Wait staff was definitely old school which matched the decor in the restaurant but friendly and informative.   Our meals were good and a hefty. We definitely were not blown away as all the hype made it seem, but overall a good place and worth checking out for a good seafood plate.

a6QBpmU6kkt8cqH02B6Deg.review_text: My family and I have been going here for many years.  It is a great place to spend some time with family and friends.  The food, the ambiance and staff are great.  My favorite dish is the Shellfish Saute Sec.

lv3_Ua42m9h-77SxZ0ntlA.user_location: Griffith Park/Los Feliz, Los Angeles, CA
lv3_Ua42m9h-77SxZ0ntlA.review_text: Amazing! You must come here if you're in town. The seafood was the most amazing I've ever had. All fish is prepared the way you'd like. I got the scallops and couldn't believe how well they were prepared. Cooked to perfection. I came with 3 other people who all raved about their meals as well. Everyone ordered something different too! I'd definitely suggest making a reservation though, as the wait was about an hour and 15 during their dinner hour without one.

XfdQwvMC-sXkBxGTn4Snow.review_text: I checked this place out because of the overwhelmingly positive reviews on Yelp. I came on a weeknight in the summer, and after a short wait, my party was seated. For my entrée, I went with the Acqua Pazza, which consisted of mussels, clams, calamari, shrimp, fish, and tomatoes in a light, aromatic broth. It was a really nice, refreshing dish that's perfect for the summer time. One of my dining companions ordered the cioppino, which came loaded with seafood in a thicker tomato-based broth. When she failed to finish off the cioppino, I gladly volunteered to finish off the rest of it. There was a ton of seafood, and I made sure to get some extra bread to sop up as much of the sauce as I could fit in my stomach.  Great seafood, good service, and reasonable prices - there's not much not to like about Scoma's.

suB5Ari7u3w9d4kyCM940A.review_text: I cannot praise this place enough. I hadn't tried crab before Scoma's, so I will always treasure it as the place where I fell in love with Dungeness crab. All I have to say about the experience is OH. DEAR. GOD. There are no words to express the surge of joy that coursed through my body when I took that first bite of tender, sweet crab meat dipped in drawn butter. It was perfectly cooked and the freshness was unparalleled. Conveniently, they give you a bib imprinted with the Scoma's logo to protect yourself against the spray of crab juice, as well as a warm cloth with lemon to clean your hands when you're finished. Others in my party also raved about the lazy man's cioppino, and being Italian, I trust their opinion about cioppino.  The first time I was here I had a steak and didn't think it was anything to write home about. They say you shouldn't go to a steak house and order seafood, and unsurprisingly the reverse is also true. Their beef is obviously not as fresh as their fish, which I believe is caught daily. It's not often you'll get to eat seafood that fresh.  Yes, it's pricey, but not prohibitively so. It's worth it for the quality and quantity of food you get. The portions are decent, neither too much nor too little, and $26 for a whole crab is definitely reasonable. The service is average in speed, but they make up for it in friendliness and professionalism. They always have a knack for suggesting the best thing when you ask what they recommend. They're almost always busy because they don't accept reservations, so be prepared to kill some time at the bar. The ambiance is fantastic, and being on the pier, the view is even better. I don't know what it is, but there's something about the decor that makes you feel swanky. Don't come here in jeans if you can help it.  "Died and gone to heaven" is an understatement. If you don't visit this place before you die, you will regret it, I promise.

12RBGrVS7yNhRfDzlnFahA.review_text: I have never written a review before but I feel the need to after my experience at Scomas this past weekend.   My family and I have been going to Scomas for over a decade.  We make the long drive from San Jose and Gilroy just to enjoy their delicious food.  Service has always been excellent and the food was always amazing. Unfortunately our experience this past weekend was terrible.  While prices remain the same the portion sizes have been cut in half if not more.  We always order the lazy man's cioppino which used to come in a large bowl with tons of seafood.  Now it is served in a small soup bowl and the sauce, which used to be AMAZING, tastes terrible.  My mom had the crab louis and it was half the size it used to be (she pulled up pictures on her iPad of what it looked like the last two times we dined there).  The crab sandwich didn't even have lump crab meat on it....it had a pile of stringy crab.   Service was excellent as it always is, which is why I am giving it one star.  We normally leave the restaurant full and feeling like we got a great value for our meal.  This time when we left we were all starving!  I don't understand why management wanted to change something that was so wonderful.  It looks like other reviewers are noticing the same changes and are deciding not to dine here anymore.  Sadly, management probably doesn't care about customers like us because they know that tourists will continue to dine here because they don't know any better.  We will surely miss Scomas and all the wonderful servers who work there.

P0tcGzp-3RIT0t2fAry3vQ.review_text: Having been introduced to Scoma's in 1998 by a SF colleague of mine on my 1st trip to the city, I've made it a point to visit each of the next two times I travelled there.  On this, my 4th trip to SF I tried several times to get in by using the Open Table link on their Yelp site, but the times were either too late or too early, so I resigned to the fact we wouldn't be going to Scoma's. I found our last full day, a Monday, we had availability so I found a 4:00 time and worked our schedule for the day around it.  Glad I did. We started at the bar 1st for an early cocktail (it's 6:30 back east where we live!), my wife having a blue cheese stuffed olive martini, and I opted for a glass of Zin.  My wife raved about the martini and my wine was quite tasty. When we were ready, we were seated at a table with a view of the back dock. Nothing overly scenic, but better than looking at a wall.  We order a bottle of wine, and while uncorking it the server went over the menu, offering  her opinions and suggestions.  We usually share dishes so we can experience more tastes, so we ordered the Lobster Bisque and the Oyster Rockefeller alla Scoma to start.   We decided on the Mixed Seafood Grill and the Alaskan Halibut Siciliana for our entrée's.  The Bisque was good (I'm not a big bisque fan anyway, so 'good' is a compliment) but the Oysters were out of this world.  Made me wish I didn't have to share them. Yummy. Then came the entrée's;  Both were delicious.  The Mixed Grill was plentiful, so much so that my wife couldn't finish it all, but did manage to leave no shrimp or lobster behind.  My Halibut Siciliana was so flavorful I didn't leave anything behind. Our server (change of shift, seamless) tried to temp us with desert, and he was successful.  I judge places based on their Tiramisu against my favorite back home (I won't give away the name of that place) and considered whether I wanted to risk souring my overwhelmingly favorable opinion of  the early evening's dining experience, but decided to go for it.  He also told us of a Chocolate Torte that wasn't on the menu, so we order that too.  The Tiramisu exceeded my expectations and the Torte just made it hard to declare a winner, so we called it a tie. What a wonderful dining experience. The food and the service are top notch. So glad we decided to fit this into our schedule. We had some great food during our week in SF, but I think we saved our best experience for last!

JUeI2eM3d2sfKrodpj7A6g.review_text: Very Good food and ok prices I had the garlic half crab with the salad with beets and blue cheese

9rHSwmHoqihbaxm3pKKw9Q.review_text: I think my favorite line was from our waitress that day, "....and those are our specials. And of course, there's our famous clam chowder." Nice try, but I'm an SF native who actually worked at Fisherman's Wharf & Pier 39 as a teenager and EVERYBODY says that about their clam chowder when in fact, most of it comes frozen and then re-cooked in a large pot. For a real bowl of clam chowder, try Hog Islands.   When a friend a mine told me she wanted to her birthday luncheon at Scoma's at Fisherman's wharf, I was a little skeptical because of the fact that it's on Fisherman's Wharf. Everything on that strip is a tourist trap. And Scoma's is just that, a tourist trap. Equipped with okay food, high prices and the ambiance similar to an old Elk's Lodge. The wait staff was pleasant, but I expected something with more personality. Yea, I get tradition but I think Joe's Crab Shack might have more ambiance than Scoma's.   Ambiance: Old, maybe somewhere I'd go with my grams and gramps. Conservative. You can argue its on a dock but Fisherman's Grotto in Monterrey is also on a dock and they serve flavorful food and it had a livelihood about them that Scoma's didn't.   Food: Bland. I have to give them credit for their scallops. They were tasty and did have flavor. Went well with the mash. But the veggies on the side were so uninspired and had no flavor. I mean they were really sorry looking to the point I'd compare them to hospital food. The clam chowder was good for my tummy but at the end of the day, its not the best and it wasn't too different from what you would get else where.   Service: They were polite.   Conclusion: At the end, the bill came out to be $30ish for Dine About Town. If I had to pay their regular prices for their "meh" dishes, I'd probably be pissed. Sorry Scoma's, you didn't do it for me.

kAf3fe3Z4T43DYys8j1jaA.review_text: Had a really nice lunch there in a party of six, and almost all the food was DELICIOUS, except one of the salads were way too lemony (too sour) to eat.   But - the clam chowder and seared ahi tuna sandwich were to-die-for. Service was great. Prices are reasonable for the quality of food.

NWK2-Yzx8qRQzxV5WZLS7g.review_text: Good fish, sometimes great fish.  I find it too crowded and too much rushing around, and the tables are pretty tightly packed together. Service was very friendly and attentive but rushed. Basically it seems like you order the fish, and you get whatever basic veggies or other sides they have determined. Pretty expensive for what you get but if you are jonesing for a fish fix you could do a lot worse than Scoma's.

kFhZsW6A8zQaKJJjJkCpUQ.review_text: OLD SCHOOL. Dark, themed rooms.  Very good staff. Very good food.  I wanted a more creative menu, but again, very old school.  I would go again if there were not so many other options in San Fran.

A8cPchGG9CppHpr8sTVQyQ.review_text: Rule #5, If your grandpa liked it 30 years ago, he was probably on to something!  Scoma's has been around for 50 years for a reason! I used to see the ads for it when I went to Golden Gate Fields with my Papa 20 something years ago and he'd always rave about the freshness of the fish there. It has that "old SF" vibe that has been dying bit by bit in The City. If you like wood paneling, sweet heart Filipino waitresses, and a great piece of fresh sea steak!  Because people like lists: 1) Fish so fresh, it blinks at you before you dig in. 2) Rule #1, Never eat at an empty restaurant, and this place is hardly ever empty. 3) All are welcome, look around, it's damn near the UN 4) Bring your water jug full o' pennies, you're gonna need them cause this place is pricey. 5) Don't go pasta, just go with the special/catch of the day, best bang for your buck. 6) Get yourself a souvenir glass, to remember these good times when you're at home eating Ramen. 7) This place looks like your grandmother's old house... before you sold it, and put her in a home... you know, you should call your grandmother more often.

yX6miszwwodkYGLBg7UEmQ.review_text: Classic San Francisco restaurant in a touristy area.  The drinks and food are pretty good, but not epic or great, but was worth the visit.  One of the great bonuses here is the parking as they have free valet parking in a part of town that can be very difficult to find a parking spot, so this is a great choice for visitors with a car.

lZHn-ZDHbwaxXCz7FqP2pw.review_text: Yeah it's in a tourist trap section of town but the food is great  I've been coming to Scoma's on Fisherman's Wharf for more that twenty five years. Al  Scoma passed a few years ago, but the staff carry on his legacy.   They make a wide variety of seafood and Italian dishes, but I prefer the Petrale Dore, a Sole fish sauted in a light batter.  Some of the staff, like Joey, my waiter on my most recent visit have been there for decades, so the service is spot on. On of my dining companions didn't know what dish she wanted so described in general that she wanted to eat crab but didn't want a messy, time consuming whole crab. Joey brought her a Dungeness Crab Risotto that she really enjoyed.   On the down side, the wait can be long on weekends and they don't take reservations. They do offer valet parking.   Have a drink, look at the view and enjoy your meal.

E73hatBdAXT2Pk3rkeJPxA.review_text: We returned to San Francisco recently with friends and raved about Scoma's.  They agreed that we should go.  The crab cakes were excellent as usual, but everything else was mediocre. The side dishes, in my opinion, were terrible!  The polenta was sent back (an $8 side) and the vegs and rice were, in my opinion, inedible.  The bartender was surly and covered me, my coat and purse with beer when the keg emptied and did not apologize or show any concern; in fact, she admonished me for having my purse on the bar.  A lot of money and and embarrassment for having taken our friends there.

zaF2tOkKtw_EMr5K7mgGDQ.review_text: Went with the "wild " salmon.  Veggies and garlic mash potatoes.  Visiting San Fran from Dallas and I had better Salmon at Red Lobster and much better priced.  Bland fish.  Undercooked veggies.  Over seasoned potatoes.  Disgusting.

cCTUFH4DKPuSuFhbIIcbzw.review_text: I've been coming here for years and I love this place. Its much more casual than you'd expect.   I always used to get the lobster (never fails. :) cioppino is really good tiramisu is sooo good all their appetizers are really good too  i had the salmon recently. it was really bland. i was so disappointed since ever other experience I've had here was so much better. Its ok, guess you cant win everyday.. I'll be back to try something else next time...

gfnPfaedHcM5lFntUnFAxg.review_text: Yes, it's pricey but it's also on the wharf. The wharf is teeming with tourists, but Scomas has been an SF classic so you'll find a mix of both locals and tourists here. I recently came here for the "SF Dine About Town" event.   Clam chowder (4/5): good, not too salty, fresh Pasta Girabaldi (4/5): very fresh seafood; pasta sauce could have used more salt   Overall, I had a pleasant dining experience. I'll be back again.

ttauTXuRemnMf1SDhMgQZQ.review_text: Overrated.  Long wait.   Food is not worth it. I had the prixie fixie. I felt like my lobster bisque was a tomato basil soup. As for my main entree, I had the pasta with scallops. I love scallops but this reminds me of a pasta dish that olive garden can make. I wasn't impressed, it was very bland.   As for my dessert, I didn't care for it.  Everyone gets served bread with butter.   I felt like I waited long for mediocre food. Everything on yelp loves this place but the seafood didn't blow me away. It reminds me of a food from a chain restaurant. Parking can be difficult here. There's valet parking as an option though.

2IsqsEtOffZl9N0v0RknGw.review_text: For some oddball reason, I didn't realize that this restaurant was pretty much inside the tourist trap of fisherman's wharf. It must have been the lack of coffee when I was looking at the map. Hence, this misadventure was not prevented like it should have.  Came here for dine-about-town with the bf.  Overall impressions: Service, very good. Food, pretty typical for a restaurant on tourist land and nothing special. Didn't get crowded until 7ish on a Friday. People at the bar seemed really happy though (and red).  ---Mini Details--  Bread: Cold. Not good at all. Butter, so chilled that I had to wait 15+ minutes to spread it on the bread.  "Famous" house chowder: Typical wharf chowder. Nothing special about it.  Dungeness crab cakes: Pretty good, with chunks of crab meat, but I've had better.  Swordfish: Uh...how many ways can you say 'average'?  Seared Ahi: Okay, this one was pretty good. A solid 4 stars.  Pumpkin cheesecake -- which they ran out of, so got the raspberry cheesecake instead: No striking thoughts.  Sourdough bread pudding & tiramisu: The former was a nice relief from the majority of the meal -- finally, something that had FLAVOR and good texture. The latter...was more...interpretive at best, and I mean it the way in which your father tries to show you his dance moves.

TaymD7MKm8OH1VI77kMWMw.review_text: An old but still solid establishment on the wharf. My dad still reminisces about this place when he is back in SF so naturally we came here during father's day weekend for dinner. First just know that if you decide to come here, be prepared to wait. There's no way around it. They don't take reservations, so just get your name on the list and grab a few drinks at the bar or walk around while you wait. They overestimated our wait time, lucky for us, but it was still about an hour around 8 or 9pm on a Friday.   Our waiter, Sal, was great. He must also be an old-timer because we noticed more regular customers chatting him up, and he was great in pacing our meal really well, providing helpful recommendations for food, and all around just making sure we were having a good time.   Food... Yeah seafood is the way to go. I have no comments on the red meat here because frankly I don't see why you'd want that at a seafood place on the pier. The chowder is pretty tasty, and it's more creamy than it is full of large seafood bits. The warm appetizer trio had good calamari and crab cakes. The shrimp was fine too but not super amazing. The swordfish fagioli is a solid dish - also has some pancetta and leafy greens. I loved my seafood mix sauté plate, which was not only HUGE but very tasty, tons of large crabmeat pieces, 2 1/2 lobster tails, about 4 large scallops and at least 2 or 3 shrimp on top of a bed of rice + pasta (not sure why there was both) plus lots of veggies. I could only finish about 1/2. Seared tuna is also a good choice.   Overall, a great dining experience. The wait was long, but worth a good time had by all.

PVyMWt-NpDJF41NAkdIPiQ.review_text: Just OK.   Went here on my first trip to SF and expected the best.seafood.ever. considering the whole Fisherman's Wharf thing. Oysters were good (they were raw - not much to say to the chef there), clam chowder was in desperate need of salt and pepper, and lobster tail was also good (again, that kind of speaks for itself).  The restaurant was crazy busy, tables too close together, and atmosphere was just meh.   Very upsetting, yelpers. First time you've disappointed me.

qolJVR7HE5vbvzQppINCCQ.review_text: It is what it is... Touristy?  Yes.  Old school?  Yes.  Crowded with long waits?  Yes.  Big prices?  Yes.  It's all on Yelp, and it's all true.  But you're on Fisherman's wharf, and this is a good representation of fresh seafood in an exceptional location.  Is it 5 stars?  No.  But it's good, especially if you know what to get.  Get the Cioppino.  It's great by any standard.  Lots of seafood in a tasty tomato-based broth.  Add two pieces of garlicky toast dipped in the broth, and you have heaven on earth - $38.  Yeah, it could have more clams or more mussels or whatever someone else has critiqued here.  Forget all that.  It is what it is.  A very memorable Cioppino with enough left over for another two or three meals.  Mmmmmm.  Don't be a hater.  Quit qvetching and enjoy a world-class Cioppino and the view!

VEgMc0Jat_HMTrnQ3ZWnEw.review_text: On a trip to San Fran we asked our hotel a good place to get seafood and they recommended Scoma's.  I was really excited when we got to the location and let down soon after.  I ordered the lobster ravioli $30.  The ravioli was overcooked and I could barely taste the lobster.  Between the prices and the taste I was disappointed.  Definitely to much $$ for the quality.

EkQFC89AuK3PX-S-DCCQZQ.review_text: LONG wait and a lot of hype.  They definitely have FRESH seafood. But I had hoped to have better service (it was friendly, but always a long wait just to get drinks and make sure everything is OK after getting food).   the cioppino was stocked FULL of fresh seafood and the scallops, in particular, were fresh, HUGE, and tasty. The problem with the cioppino was the think, tomato 'sauce'.  I had hoped to have cioppino like Tadich Grill - where the broth doesn't overpower the fresh seafood.  More of a water-based broth.  But their cioppino is think like a sauce.  It took away from the wonderful seafood and made the dish much heavier than it should have been.  All in all, probably one of the better places to eat along the wharf, but I prefer Tadich Grill for cioppino.

P4b9u28jXzigsPGrT-W0xw.review_text: This place is off the beaten path, but worth it.  Unfortunately, many has found this place and there is about an hour wait.  Cioppino and Clam Chowder was delicious!  I would definitely recommend.

pC0DiTh7y91Tr4Ih3c45kg.review_text: I came here with my family and was told to wait about 30 minutes, which we expected. I had the crabcakes and the pasta diplomatica, and the rest of the family had the risotto and the lamb with clam chowders. Overall, the food was great. My pasta was light and delicious. The seafood in the pasta was a lot for me to handle, but for the rest of the family the food was adequately portioned.   The quality of food is okay, not super great or amazing. My family thought that compared to price, the food could have been better. But it's a tourist attraction and I don't blame the restaurant for this. But I do have to compliment their chowder and crab cakes. They were very good and after trying out a lot of the chowders in the area, i can say that this was one of the better ones. same goes for the latter.  The service was also very friendly. He was very attentive, kept good conversation, and was very genuine throughout the meal.   However, the one star I took off was due to something that happened towards the end of the meal. It was not directly related to us, but it was a bit distracting in a bad way. Apparently one of the other waiters could not find the tip that was on a table next to us. The guests had already left and the table was already cleaned. He kept looking for it, and asked one of the "busboys" if he had taken it. I dont really know what happened but the waiter got pretty angry and kept flipping through the tablecloths. Then he said to the "busboy" " youre not getting paid tonight." Maybe I didn't comprehend the full situation, but for him to say that in the middle of where all the guests are that loudly made me frown. He kept saying "where is my money?" And the repetition bothered me and the guests around us.   For a restaurant that is supposed to be renowned for its class and service, it was surprising to hear such things.   But our waiter fortunately was very nice til the end and we were generally satisfied. Would not come back because of the price which we just considered a bit overkill, but I would still recommend it to others. Nice restaurant!!

UGGpN4-q_4cf3SZ3mBJdbg.review_text: I dined on the prix fixe dinner menu which was a great value at $44. My starter was the lobster bisque which was creamy with just the right amount of spice to make it pop with flavor. It was served with a small tasting of lobster salad. The seared tuna for my entree was perfectly prepared with a side of vegetables. Dessert was a perfect ending with a chocolate brownie which arrived with whipped cream, ice cream and caramel topping. The service was efficient and friendly, and my overall experience was very good.

P2xv-jXk22flUgLBtfGMSQ.review_text: Great place to eat if you have a large budget. Very fancy with lots of stars photos on the wall. We only had appetizers and they were excellent. Not really kid friendly. Make a reservation or you'll be waiting.

h1BV6ILuNK7vfatxhbm8aQ.review_text: The salad and dessert were great as was the service. However, the lobster was over cooked and thus a bit tough and lacked flavor.

8ZZDvBgeJCnNUPLS0FAyfg.review_text: Breathtaking! What an incredible dining experience!!  My Fiance and I came stumbled upon this restaurant during a recent trip into San Francisco. I had previously heard about Scoma's through various blogs, news articles, etc but had never ventured on to try it. As we docked from our bay cruise, our stomachs started to talk and we went searching for dinner. After speaking with a few locals on the street, they each RAVED about Scoma's! We took the bait . . .  Tucked behind every other restaurant on Fisherman's Wharf lays Scoma's, which is actually on a receiving dock. We didn't let looks fool us, the reviews we heard we too incredible to miss. Any place with raves of this magnitude is bound to have a wait, and our experience was no exception. We sat in one of their three bars, where we were served a couple of the best drinks of our lives! A perfectly created Mojito and an excellent Old Fashioned.   The time (30 minutes) passed quickly as the crowds began to swarm. We discovered this is a very popular destination with locals! We moved upstairs into a comfy booth with, as you could expect, glorious views of the SF Bay. I couldn't begin to tell you how many people worked at this restaurant! Each person had a specific duty, whether just pouring water, setting the table, bringing bread, serving drinks, busing, etc. The service at Scoma's is EXCELLENT! You will have a difficult time finding better service anywhere.  Our waiter, and any of the waiters we saw, was extremely professional and knowledge about the dishes, preparation, and ingredients served. Scoma's only uses local produce and wild-caught seafood. This dedication to quality is reflected in their prices, which are extremely high. Several dishes pushed $50 but most seemed to fit the $30 - $40 range. We were warned about this by folks we chatted with but I was on a date with my Fiance, celebrating seven years together, and had saved up for months for the day - she deserved the best and she certainly received it!  We each opted for Scoma's "Triple Play" menu. A daily menu featuring chef creations with the best of their available ingredients. For only $39.99, you received an appetizer, entree, and dessert. Here is what we enjoyed: (My Fiance) Roasted Butternut Squash and Dungeness Crab Soup with Toasted Pumpkin Seeds & Creme Fraiche Garnish, Broiled Colossal Prawns on Linguine Pomodoro with Pesto, and a Walnut Brownie & Triple Espresso Ice Cream with Caramel Sauce. (Me) Lobster Bisque with Lobster Salad and Chive Aioli, Broiled Wild Swordfish with Sicilian White Beans, Pancetta, Tomatoes & Organic Rainbow Chard, and a Tiramisu & Sourdough Bread Pudding Duo.    I could go on and on about each dish but you'd be here for the next 20 minutes reading when you could be in the car on your way to Scoma's to try it yourself! I will tell you each dish was beautifully presented, with the perfect marriage of flavors and seasonings. The chefs at Scoma's have a magic touch - this food simply melts in your mouth!   If you are looking for the perfect culinary experience, complete with friendly, professional, and knowledgeable service and savory sensations you'll be raving about for weeks, Scoma's is where you want to be . . .

XxTf-dF1lfOBgLGV-mbyfg.review_text: Gonna throw two stars (2.5) with the hope that its noted.  Forever & a day our crew has been coming to Scoma's.  The typical order? Cioppino "lazy."  Apparently, (but, I don't know,) Chef Scarbosio has left the building, and that may be the reason.  The presentation, flavor, and entire dish was just off, Way off.  #disappointed.

gxHCanBs5pDYXSGw0aEfpA.review_text: I had a great meal here.  It was classy, but being on the pier it felt a bit touristy.  The views were great and we were seated fairly quickly.  My tuna was cooked perfectly.  I would recommend this place.

o70in88o7YdoixD9plDVPQ.review_text: its been years since i've visited here.  The first time was back in 2003 on a whim before the likes of facebook and Yelp.   We started out our meal with the  hot sampler for 2.  Really great,  it was a mix of their hot items. Enjoyed the crab cakes as you could actually taste chunks of crab meat and not that filler stuff(if you know what i mean.) For dinner I ordered the same item on the menu as i did years ago.  The Lazy Mans Cioppino.   I remember complaining about this dish years ago as it was filled with so many items especially lobster and that i could not finish the meal.  On this visit, i think they forgot the lobster or had taken it out of the recipe. i was somewhat taken aback by that. I asked our waiter about the lobster(s) and he said that they never put them in there. Leads me to believe that he has not been there long enough to even give me a better answer. I started complaining again, this time, there was no lobster. I was a bit disappointed. However the dismay, this place is classic, the food is great, the service is wonderful and ambiance is oh so old school style.  The food is tasty with variety in the menu they prepare.   The dining area a bit tight as they try to cram as much people in such a little space (but this is San Francisco). I would have given them 5 stars, however, stirring for lobsters in your meal to find them not even on the bottom of the bowl is a bit disturbing.

J2fBAeXP0rKDDPWdTscMhw.review_text: I grew up in the bay area and have made hundreds of trips to fishermans warf. IMO this is probably the best place to eat there. Very good "Seafood Saute" and "Crab Louie". It is very pricy, but no more expensive than the other restaurants on the warf.

2J4SwmI7UczrgZTmm-mpvA.review_text: After a disappointing Forty Niners lost, we had an amazing birthday dinner at Scoma's. The bartenders and wait staff are always first right and the food as wonderful. Scoma's is a San Francisco institution for a reason. For me, they are top of my list, second only to The House of Prime Rib. The food was cooked to perfection and the wait staff, not only responded to our requests, they anticipated them. A meal at Scoma's is a must anytime you visit the City by the Bay.

alEd1mZ_l-DVtS3Ar5bMLA.review_text: Party of 3, approximately 2 hours before we saw our first appetizer.  3.5 hours later, the table of 8 we were waiting next to/chatting with were gone before us!  It was a rare night for us...we made the decision to eat out at a nice place on a Saturday night.  The valet serviceman were very efficient, almost too efficient, almost taking our car before we could grab our baby out of the car.  We get into a packed house at 7 pm, as they do not take reservations.  The verdict: an hour wait for 3.  OK well it must be good...We wait and chat witha  party of 8, wait time for them 2 hours.  They were plenty happy though with all their cocktails and they were fun to talk with.    Mrs. Scoma herself was walking around and shook our hands.  She asked our names and the names of the rep from party 8.  In my mind, I was thinking, SWEET, maybe we could shave some wait time off since she said she would check on our wait time/names.  She returned to confirm that we had an hour wait........She was very friendly though.    We wait.......and wait.....and wait.....1 hour 25 minutes pass.  Why are we still waiting again?  After my baby's one diaper change, a bottle of milk, and her falling asleep, we finally get called.  We know what we want to order, as we've had time to think about it.  In my low-blood-sugary state, I ordered the cold clams (which was my fault).  For some reason, I thought they were boiled.  So as not to waste them, we take them down, sliminess and all.  The silver lining was washing them down with lobster bisque and clam chowder.  The clam chowder was the highlight of the meal.  We wait some more, and get our cheeseburger and baked crab with bread.  The actual hamburger is actually quite tasty with a hint of saltiness throughout.  This is weird to me that this burger is better than the seafood, as the latter is their specialty.  The baked crab with bread tasted like a low-grade lobster pizza.  My salad was drizzled in sour vinagrette and I ended up ditching it for my hubby's thousand island drenched salad.  I picked out the crab to put on the salad.  It was clear this wasn't the best meal we've had.  The waiter came by once the whole time we were there to ask how things were going.    We had to flag him down to ask for the dessert menu and then again for the check.  Tip: If you order the apple crisp, you will be waiting at least 15-20 minutes for it to bake.  Even after that, the apples are still hard.  By the time we walked out of the door, it was 11:00. $140 later, and a stomach ache this morning, I am still disappointed.

LYL_65Q9chiv_7p5d67dCQ.review_text: My last review of this place was removed by Yelp because I used some harsh words.  I will restate my case "tastefully."  The food was pretty good and our waitress was outstanding.  I ordered the blackened swordfish and my group had the crabcakes.  Both were good and the waitress came around just the right number of times.  So why the horrible score?  I was hit in the head by some careless busboy's katana-like elbows... get this... 3 times.  He was not looking around at all as he was walking around, and mine was not the only innocent noggin' knocked around.  I can't think of any other time I was hit in the head while enjoying swordfish.  Or anything else.  Horrible experience.

CpQYT3SuNP295OppVlW-Lg.review_text: Good view, they tried to seat me in the worst possible table. Thefood was actually good, if not spectacular. Portions were quite large. They we tasty and made of good fresh ingredients. Waiter was irritated because I asked to be moved. Later was helpful though. Overall a good experience. I may go back.

TZelLnaGbHgaG7LBI6rfgg.review_text: This place is tucked away behind the main strip and a classic seafood spot in the area. Very old school and the decor matches. Do not expect a modern seafood take. It's meant for the tourists and the elder sf crowd.  If you want to take the grandparents out, then this place might be the right pace but don't expect any innovative or flashy items. Overall, not the vibe and style of food I enjoy. The price point is high and an update would be helpful both in decor and on the menu.

THXdIY73jWmzYNrYPp-dIw.review_text: I know this is a broken record but I just gotta let everyone know how delicious the shellfish saute sec is!   I could eat it everyday of my life and never get bored! It is just so simple and spectacular! Yes I broke out the 10.00 word of the day. I have never heard of an unhappy customer at Scoma's. They are always busy, but wait times are never to bad. The service is prompt and efficient. The decor is a circa 1970ish leather dark you know. It has that old world Italian vibe working.   Other dishes I have tried to my delight. CALAMARI CAESAR , CRAB-STUFFED PORTOBELLO MUSHROOM, DUNGENESS CRAB CAKE DINNER , LAZY MAN'S CIOPPINO , ""BLACK'N BLUE" AHI , ROASTED WHOLE CRACKED DUNGENESS CRAB.   I have loved everything I have ever tried here, every now and then they get fresh abalone an it is amazing! Last time I had it it ran me about 85.00. It is so worth it though.  SCOMAS YOU ROCKS MY SOCKS OFF! I WANNA GIVE YA 10 STARSSSS!

Dd1u-UMqFtIiIDix9fHxwg.review_text: Drove up to Scoma's shortly after Christmas, and we were very disappointed that Scoma's doesn't serve what we considered to be one of their signature dishes - Calamoni ala Anna. The waiter said that they haven't served this calamari steak dish for six months. He was vague about the reason they have stopped serving it. Six or seven of our party of nine would have ordered the dish if it was available.

WGVRnbgyxQL4FLZpXf7uXw.review_text: As a visitor to SF, or to any out-of-town destination, you take what you take and you get what you get.   I visited San Francisco last week and decided that Scoma should be an evening adventure. BUT, I had not been to Scoma in over 10 years. Indeed, what I expected I got: upon arrival, a nice and cordial greeting. I asked the hostest (at/about 8 pm) for a table for two. As she checked availability, we stepped immediately to the bar for libations. Pleasant and courteous bartender - we got our drinks and immediately were escorted to a window-front table looking into the immediate harbor.   All we wanted was a waterfront sanctuary for a simply, seafood dinner. We got just that! The waiter (Sal) was most attentive. He made menu recommendations to support our selections. We decided, further, we would ask for wine from the wine list. We got just want we wanted: a pleasant Napa Valley Pinot.   For those that enjoy a family dinner, birthday celebration or a simple dinner for two - Scoma - per my observations on our particular evening - rendered up just that!   Costly? NO.  Ambiance? YES Good food/good prices? YES  I will go back! A simple walk from any Fisherman's Wharf property or via Street or Cable car. Car parking is limited but they have valet.  Be my guest......go.

jq8zJR-Ew8QKjGudPmL8IQ.review_text: The hubs, our 11 month old, and I went here for our anniversary dinner. Best fish I've ever had! Cooked to perfection! I ordered the fish trio. My husband had a seafood pasta and we shared the stuffed portobello mushroom. I was a little nervous coming to a nice restaurant with a baby, but the waiter was so good with her. The restaurant was very family friendly. We will definitely be back next time we are in San Fran!!
