cKci42jLfslgS2ptCpm-bw.review_text: Not like it used to be....we used to love coming here when I lived in the city.  The food was fresh, tasty, and the atmosphere was buzzing.  Now, the wait was just as long, food bland, and the service was suffering.  After waiting an hour for a table "by a window" so our daughter could see the water during dinner, we were seated away from the windows completely.  Our server mentioned that it took her 15-20 min to take our order because she told us 6 tables were seated in her section at the same time, she didn't apologize for the wait, and continued to do the blame game until there was an awkward silence.  (I wanted to leave then but we were already an hour and a half into this)   We were literally not even acknowledged and thank God another employee noticed our wait and brought us bread while we were waiting.  (strike 2) and then the worst...we waited so long to be seated, waited on, and then our food...and the food was blah!!! I ordered the organic chicken and pasta, and the chicken was so difficult to eat because it was over cooked the skin could break a window.  The calamari had no flavor, and our salad had so much dressing on it that it made the lettuce soggy.  I am sad because this had always been my go to restaurant a while back, but it looks like things have changed a lot.  There are so many options.  I would venture and try another place for the wait, quality of food, and the kind of service you will get.

12v8ca2BUo-dEtUXOHqYRw.review_text: Very nice waiters and top of the line sea food!   I had grilled salmon and it was delish!  The mashed potatoes were also good.  For dessert I had yummy French vanilla cheesecake!  The chocolate marquise also tasted good!

gzU54aTUyrBmHAseiCfuKA.review_text: For the money I was very unimpressed.  I was expecting warm bread not cold, SOME kind of seasoning for the Alfredo pasta with scallops, and a delicious $12 Cesar salad not lettuce & croutons with a side of oil.  Won't go back unfortunately :(

JYw4OmQhq33CijEojhK72A.review_text: I don't know if it's me or what, but I think it's overrated. Whatever we had, most of which didn't leave an impression on me AT ALL other than not returning for, did not impress. Three of us from the four choose from the prixe fixe dinner choices available for a limited time (I think it's over). We all got something different so we would be able to experience as much as possible. Of the 3 appetizer, I only remember the clam chowder as good. Of the entrees, all failed!   However, the dessert is where they shone like no other. It was glory. They were all so very wonderful! I could live on their desserts for the rest of my life! The bread pudding, tiramisu, not so much the raspberry cheesecake (not that it wasn't good but it wasn't AS good), a la mode something. YUM!  I'd come back just for dessert and that's it! Oh yeah, the table behind us were a bunch of ...older gentlemen talking of "firm" females they've encountered. Male cougars. Ew.

MF7q-2IBUnqfMmixmcP6dg.review_text: Excellent food I highly recommend  The crab cakes are delicious and the service is spectacular. Our waiter Kevin was pleasant and knowledgeable and made our meal complete. We will be back

6Dk2bOwUQBz3aNcEOM1p_g.review_text: How can you go wrong with this place? This place attracts an older crowd but it is a great place to have a good meal. The seafood is top notch and the service is great. I would recommend calling ahead of your visit. Can't go wrong with the crab, and the calamari was fantastic!

ilesK4CRarjiblkxUDL_tQ.review_text: Was there last night for dinner, we did not make any reservation and got seated right away. I ordered the whole crab garlic it was delicious but I would say that it totally falls on the greasy side (especially with the cup of melted butter they gave me to dip the crab meat in). I also had the lobster bisque- it was the best lobster bisque i've ever had.  Personally, I would totally go back for more of that famous lobster bisque :)  My husband got the crab salad- It was huge! He wanted something light but ended up with gigantic salad topped with crab (a lot of crab)!!!!  The service was not amazing- the waiter keeps refilling our water ever 5 minutes for some reason (we were really annoyed that he came to our table every 5 minutes).   Overall, Scoma's was ok. It was kind of noisy and touristy but the experience was fun!

ZuExuTpG8PMhwi7mH6vbTg.review_text: If you want seafood while you're in SF, this place is pretty much off the hook.  You an dress up and valet park or you can wander in wearing jeans, not matter what you'll eat amazing food.  Oysters Rockefeller, Shrimp AND Crab Louie....or pasta and steak.   The service is amazing as well as the view.  Give it a shot!

WmfvEE9bXozI8slUtJkCNA.review_text: The menu has so many choices it is hard to know where to start.  Everything I ate was good, and maybe I could have made better choices but I have had better.  Appetizers: Dungeness Crab Cakes were good, but not great.  Obviously homemade however they were lacking flavor and the consistency was a little mushy. Clam Chowder could have been creamier. The Black 'n Blu Ahi  was the highlight of my appetizer built dinner.  Perfectly rare, seasoned and flavorful.  The sauce it was served with was the perfect complement.  One of my friends had the Shellfish Saute and it was amazing! They de-shelled the shrimp, lobster and crab legs... not to mention the scallops were HUGE. If I could do it again I would order this, hence the 4 stars.  Our server Gus was such a trooper, putting up with some loud and crazy women.  We were very lucky to have him and the beautiful view of the bay.

xeepEFKfXdo50TNOt-43xw.review_text: Delicious! Bartender was friendly and the food was amazing!  Crab melts in your mouth. Definitely give it a try.

1kMsw9gF2SnPH9egAx2Uqg.review_text: What happened?  New menu, higher prices, food not great.

EAVrB9nvw1WE0guMHH34EA.review_text: Definitely high end touristy typical for the Wharf in the city but the service is very professional and personable. Excellent actually. Partner had the tuna steak which was medium rare, but he told me it was delicious. I had the fried oysters with a Japanese paste for flavor and they were tasty. It was my first time having them this way. You get a lot for what you pay for which surprised me, but definitely worth every single bite.

0tddAiCypf-J3Rph5cTRDA.review_text: Scoma's has the freshest fish in the wharf. The swordfish is grilled to perfection.  My wife had the seared tuna and it was delicious. Although it can be pricey, the freshness of the fish is worth it.

itfQekl0lnYNh1-tXbouUA.review_text: Great seafood. I brought my out-of-town guests and they were very impressed.  Everything was expertly prepared and delicious. The service was top notch.  Highly recommended!

IZ4zmvOP4zv3ajsBkD9w8Q.review_text: Cioppino.  Not very good.  Clams, prawns, crab, fish, scallop.  Crab was shredded. Fish was extra fishy.   Tomato soup based was very tomatoey. Nothing complex or subtle about the soup flavor.   I guess this is a landmark restaurant with a long history. They claim scenic views. You can see a few docked boats on the pier, but I didn't see any views of the bay.

pknnVqGB8rLvv512pTPyIg.review_text: Perfect restaurant for a nice seaside dinner! After some research, we couldn't have been happier with our discovery of this place. Though it looks like a dive from the outside, this place has class inside, not to mention the incredible location off the beaten path of Fisherman's wharf. We sat right next to the window and watched the sunset on the dock as we had our meal.  Make sure to make a reservation, try the California wine, and order the Caesar salad and garlic crab.

02tYMxGnwAwr_i2j5vh9XA.review_text: OMG. delicious. everything on the menu sounded so good I couldn't decide... I went with the famous cioppino... *see photo* YUMMMMMMYYYYYYY... free valet parking... loved it cant wait to go back...  the only thing I think they could do is fix it up a little clean deeply window areas ect... its tiny, and older and has a lot of history but doesn't mean you have to scrimp on the elbow grease...

K5s226IQ6DQ4HNmy-9lang.review_text: It was an amaaaaazing experience yesterday ! We came back from our visit to Alcatraz so we went to the pier. My husband had the idea to have a food lunch at Scoma. Our waitress was VERY friendly. We had a cocktail (mmmm) and the main course gets 11/10 :) Fish is so fresh, you can still taste the sea ! The coffees were well made and left the resto with a big smile... Certainly a place to keep in mind.

90wNq7vSkBOpCX0IaDs5fA.review_text: First off if your going to eat on the wharf this is about the ONLY place I'd recommend.Have never had a bad meal hear,EVER!!My favorite is Swordfish  spiced with just a pinch of blackened seasoning.MELTS in your mouth.Garlic mashed potatoes are a favorite side dish along with a pasta side.I truly believe they have "The Best" clam chowder on the wharf!!Thick,creamy and VERY tasty(Gezz,sounding like a commercial).Have also had the jumbo shrimp with steak(VERY VERY GOOD)!!Service has always been top of the line!!Going to spend some money here but  well worth it!!

ERjkjlCFjpN27V3nvn83xg.review_text: Had delicious food on a Sunday nite with great service. They accommodated very well to our 2yr old (stroller was folded and left by the hostess).  I would recommend reservations if going prime time b/c as we were leaving, it was very packed & people were waiting for a table. We were there right around 5:30 pm and they were opening their other dinner room, which got filled in 15 mins., if not less. All around, fantastic. Btw, I recommend the lobster bisque over the clam chowder. Amazing!!

u_gBXr3zspHR5nwaTU2d2A.review_text: Always a favorite. Make your reservations and make sure no one is late. they wont sit you until you are all there. they have parking under control with valets. they offer great service and food is served hot and you will not go away hungry. this is one of my favorite places. Young or old it is a great place. I have been here for business, for an aunts 88th birthday, and with my wife.  it does not get much better than this.

20NjQx3rC2FKdmua5sYcHA.review_text: The BEST restaurant on the Wharf.  The food is amazing.  If you want fresh seafood Scoma's is the place.  The Lobster Bisque is to die for.  Oysters were great.

sT5rA-ELaGdf65KXWjPKLQ.review_text: Nice place on the wharf. Good food & nice atmosphere. Little pricey but its a tourist area, so we expected that. Wish all restaurants would season food though.

UxtmR9TXujlR7x-kESyxDw.review_text: Went here for my boyfriends birthday! He requested a seafood dinner. So researched all around and found Scoma's! Although I thought it could be a tourist trap, it actually wasn't.   My boyfriend ordered the Pasta Diplomatica and loved it. Plenty of different kinds of fish in a creamy sauce over linguine. He ate the whole thing which was a pretty large portion.   I ordered the Salmon and shrimp pasta with dill cream sauce. I will say mine wasn't as good as the Diplomatica. Next time I'm going to just order a fish meal.   We will be coming back and will make this our seafood dinner stop every time we visit San a Francisco. You must go here but don't get side tracked by all the tourist buzz.

QdQWkr7T-SCkklEQPCS9jA.review_text: Went here during VMworld in August of 2013. Sat at the bar for a bit while waiting for other friends to arrive. The bartender was super attentive and gave us a couple of samples of things he has made or over poured. Ordered some oysters and they were perfect. After a few drinks we went to the table and ordered. I had the BEST swordfish ever. It was swordfish piccata, and it was simply amazing. 10 out of 10. Had some wine with the meal, fresh bread and excellent service. The place is right on the water in the wharf and has a very cool feel to it. If you are in the area make a point to visit Scoma's.

mwpqciBkHxE2MBw4bjKqpA.review_text: It's Friday night, in San Francisco, so what culinary delights can we enjoy? Tagging along with a pair of friends, we came out to Scoma's to try out their cio-cio-cio-CIOPPINO! (Sorry, one too many ciapet commercials!)  We walked up to the hostess desk and put our names on the list. It's a 45 minute wait. But hey, it's Friday night, so no surprise, right? There's a bar to kick it at and occupy our time, while we wait. Our friendly bartender joked with us, as we ordered our drinks. For me, it was the Malbec from Argentina, later to be followed by the Prosecco di Congliano. Both lovely choices.  Conveniently enough, after we finished our 2nd drink, it was time for dinner. The seating area is tight and intimate. Our server was exceptionally on his A-game. My girlfriend and I split the Caesar salad and the cioppino. Our other friend ordered the pasta diplomatica.  Let me tell you something. I was pretty apprehensive about having the cioppino because it was a tomato base soup. Me and tomato anything, at night, is definitely going to lead to some kind of tummy rebellion. But, since my girlfriend strongly suggested it and we were splitting a plate, why not give it a whirl?  The cioppino all pescatore was absolutely, wonderfully DELICIOUS! A light tomato base soup with clams, scallops, prawns, fish and crabmeat. Every bit of it was a tender morsel to savor and cooked to perfection. Served with a chunky piece of garlic toast, I used it to soak up every last drop at the bottom of my bowl, after my 2nd serving. Yes, I said 2nd serving.  I highly recommend this place to anyone who wants to enjoy an awesome seafood experience. All our dishes were delicious, extra thumbs up for the cioppino. Definitely worth the splurge.  And, even though my stomach battled it out with the tomato-y goodness, I would definitely have cioppino, again, in a heartbeat. Or, should I say in a heartburn?  ;o)

Nh8yiMS4C6GmBEuFc-G2NQ.review_text: From the first greeting by John, our waiter, we suspected the meal would be special. All 6 of us agreed that this was an understatement.  The food was devine, service impecable, friendly, efficient. A perfect evening with friends! Thanks to all from the wait-staff to the chefs...job well done!

paNtPIcJtA_7TqwC8q27-g.review_text: Fav! I've been going to Scoma's since I was a baby. The bread is amazing and the food is great. The atmosphere is old school and great. The waiters, most of them, have worked there forever. Great views.

31FB4niOjwyZdMqFdHNfJA.review_text: Love the freshness of the seafood but hate the attitude from the waiters. I wish I could rate this more- get rid of the sh**ty waiters and I would.  I took my family there for a special dinner and within seconds of arriving the waiter asked us for drinks. My wife opted for a soda and the waiter seemed insulted that she didnt order an alcoholic drink- she was pregnant...went downhill from there. the waiter changed shifts and things got better- wish I could enjoy this place better

Rdt-JiAN7Qlw3dJ7UVdNtw.review_text: While we were at Fisherman's Grotto Yelping places, Scoma's came up and we decided on this spot.  We walked down here and had about a fifteen minute wait to be seated. We waited outside near the water and took pictures and enjoyed the weather.. There is an intercom outside so you can hear when they call your name which is nice so you don't have to just sit around inside doing NOTHING.  We were seated in the back of the restaurant next to the window with a nice outside view. We get a round of drinks and then start with a half dozen oysters on the half shell. These were very good! Personally I can't really taste the difference between different oysters but I know when they are BAD. And these weren't.  Next we move onto the whole Dungeness Crab! We get it steamed plain (you can get garlic steamed or something too) and it is served with warm drawn butter. I usually don't use butter with my crab but I did this time and it was QUITE delicious!! Half of the crab was cracked so it made it VERY easy to eat and the other half wasn't for some reason... I would have given FIVE stars if it had been.  At the end of the meal they gave us warm towels to wipe our hands with and lemons to clean off the crabbiness!

tZKF63NSI4tC_FYZVCS13w.review_text: I think it's funny when people rate this restaurant and downgrade it because of the ambiance. Guys--c'mon. Note the nautical decor. Now note the ol' friendly host. Also note where the god damn restaurant is. It's in a narrow alley behind a bunch of tourist shops for godsakes. It's not supposed to be super uppity. It might as well be a gathering place for old fishermen who enjoy the finer things in life, so if you're super trendy be wary!   However, diners should also note that it has nice white table cloths and equally shiny and white plates. It's somewhere in between fine and casual but definitely San Franciscan. But hey, I'm not stupid enough to go on a weekend night.  Now down to business. My first experience and best experience was with the cioppino. Good Lord, it had so much seafood, they really don't skimp. I've had a lot of cioppino and this one takes the cake. Fish in every bite. And incredibly fresh (except maybe for the baby Alaskan shrimp, but hey shrimp in every bite) The individual pieces of  petrale, mussels, clams, and prawns weren't overcooked at all. Which means the cooks know when to put the fish in.  It's not just tossed into the broth. Heavenly, broth I might add. And it's all served with a delicious and I mean delicious buttery piece of toast.  But the best thing is Scoma's doesn't pretend to be something it's not. It's behind the tourist shops. Down a smelly little alley. It's San Francisco and it's how they cook there seafood. And if you want your fish served in fusion cuisine contorted into a roll slathered with mayo in a more "hip" environment--well there's those kinds of places in the 7mile by 7 mile city too. Just not here.   So yes, the service might be a little slow. But your server more likely than has been there for 20+ years. Have mercy and just enjoy your fish.

oGHKVJERILGJAi17LbC9aA.review_text: This is the family's go-to restaurant when in San Francisco for seafood, but this is only my second visit here. The location is great and the staff will tell you exactly what fish has come off their personal boats that day. I will say this place caters to a more, ahem, mature crowd. While there we were seated in a corner wedged between 2 tables with wheelchairs. This is really my only complaint for the whole evening because it felt cramped. The service was good, but not spectacular. I went with the crab risotto because it's crab season and I didn't feel like wrestling with the Dungeness crab legs and I wasn't disappointed. It was creamy with good flavor and generously sprinkled with crab throughout. The others in my party had dishes with prawns and they both raved about their dishes. It is an upscale seafood restaurant located in a touristy area that manages to deliver the freshest seafood available and not feel overly touristy. We will definitely be back.

cVVCy1JTIZsOGHWbB6LMuQ.review_text: A group of ladies celebrated here after finishing the Nike Women's marathon.  This place came highly recommended by one member as she previously lived in SF.  Love the fact you walk right past the boats that bring in the fresh catches each day on your way to the front door.  The lobster bisque was enjoyed by two girls and all entrees were equally delicious, especially the garlic mashed potatoes.  The servers must truly love their work as most have been around for 20+ years.  Friendly atmosphere where neighboring tables can engage in a chat over apps or dessert.  Minus one star solely due to the hostess.  We were seated in the bar area while we waited for our table, even with reservations.  Several other parties were called and about 20 mins later we asked where we were on the list.  She gave a look and said she had called us at least 3-4 times.  There were four of us carb depleted girls , with only one drinking, who couldn't wait to dive into a plate of anything.  Trust me, we were listening and weren't called.  The rest of the night made up for her snub.

Wjl73qDBmUlbuTWcJ-gpCA.review_text: Since I'm a SF native and of Italian-American ancestry, I've been having dinner at Scoma's for years. I was raised in the North Beach part of the city and so Fishermen's Wharf was in the neighborhood. Scoma's has been around for many years and has a certain reputation. I think it lives up to that.   I've learned that this is one of the restaurants where it's great fun to eat off the appetizer and pasta parts of the menu.   I'll just list the items I've tried and enjoyed in the past.  Dungeness crabcakes with Remoulade suace is excellent, as well as the calamari fritti, which to me is the best in the city. Grilled sea scallops risotto is memorable too. They usually have them fresh so make sure of that. Even though caesar salad is a restaurant staple, Scoma's is unique. As far as pastas go, try the lobster ravioli which is quite rich but great. Also the pasta pesto. Most of the other pastas are good too. As I said, I don't usually eat off the entree part of the menu, but their Cioppino Alla Pescatore is the best thing on the whole menu. Talk about Italian comfort food. On return trips to Scoma's you could also try the grilled local sand dabs with Amandine sauce or grilled Alaskan King salmon on crab ravioli.   I realize that Scoma's is expensive but if you want to have the best fish in the city, then this is the place, served perfectly with a great choice of wines. Of course the restaurant has a lot of charm and warmth as well.

bK83JqfkLOOayKXjoaR62A.review_text: Incredible food and service was simply outstanding.  I recommend the clam chowder and I had the seafood mixed grill which was incredible.  I don't know if you can go wrong on this menu.  They also make service important and despite being in a group of over 20, the service was flawless and I didn't see any gaps in the delivery of appetizers, soup, and entrees.  Wine list was robust; however I recommend bringing your own wine and paying the rather modest $20 corkage fee.

eli3CSeV02vphttQijU8nA.review_text: Local Tiburon resident.  Went for Crab Louie, not on menu.  Asked waiter, where were the crab Louie on the menu.  He said, sure we can get you a crab Louie.  We said great lets get one for each of us.  Crab Louie was good, price should have been mentioned, even without us asking, $38.00 each is never the price for a Louie.  Let us decide if we want to spend that much, don't just sneak it in!  Problem is the waiter probably thought we were tourist, one and done customers.  Not a good way to treat even rich people.  Just thought the restaurant should know.  Larry

eis4M28wDXmyguVJ9A2lDA.review_text: The venue is a bit old and it needs some remodeling. Servers are okay but nothing special. However seafood is fresh and is bought directly from local fishermen. Scoma's lobster bisque and clam chowder are delicious.

cqf8dqO5_QUxjfo6WiM7yg.review_text: If you're ever sitting around pondering a never-ending seafood salad, Scoma's has got the perfect salad for you. The $34 seafood salad with smoked salmon, prawns, dungeness crabmeat, and bay shrimp atop leaves and leaves of green and quartered artichoke hearts, it's served with tartar sauce, cocktail sauce, and a balsamic vinaigrette. (yelp.com/biz_photos/scom…). Is it tasty? Ehhh. Is it fresh? ...I guess? How about the service? Good! It was good! (At least something was.) I think I managed to put a tiny dent in the salad before I noticed that the table next to us loudly complained of the mediocre food and refused to pay for their meal (on which they'd put a sizable dent). Clever, but I'll pay for my mediocre salad, thankyouverymuch.

bMMRPKHC1LdASDbRHl7RnA.review_text: Came here for the Jan 2014 Dine About Town Dinner option but was very disappointed with the overall quality of the meal.   Starter - Dungeness crab cake - pretty good Main - Blackened shrimp with brown penne vodka tomato sauce. This was a pretty horrible dish; no flavor whatsoever. I asked the server for more sauce and they basically just brought a bowl of canned mashed tomatoes. Ragu sauce would have been a huge upgrade.  Dessert - lemon panna cotta - Okay, tasted more like cheesecake because it was so dense.   My boyfriend had: Starter - Lobster Bisque - Warm and satisfying Dinner - Seared Yellowtail Tuna Medium Rare - Bland Dessert - Chocolate brownie with caramel sauce and vanilla bean ice cream - Cold brownie saved by globs of caramel.   I definitely wouldn't go back to try out the regular menu.

bcXUat3O2NyYUQNThcliNg.review_text: I've visited this restaurant twice and had different experiences each time.  My first visit was at least 5 years ago - Food was fresh and the chef personally came to our table to serve us our dinner. The chefs random visit, made our dining experience unique and special. I had a salmon dish which was great. My friend loved her meal also.   The second visit was in January earlier this year.  I wasn't impressed with the food nor was anyone else in our party. It wasn't bad, but the quality seems to have down graded and the flavour & freshness were average. I dont expect average from an upscale restaurant.  The menu items are typical of a seafood restaurant. Expect good/decent seafood, but don't expect gourmet and creative.    The restaurant has an older, outdated feel - it needs updating. On the other hand, the waitress went the extra mile to check all the ingredients in my mother in laws meal and make sure there wasn't chili in her meal. When she found that there may be chili in the cocktail sauce, she quickly created an alternative solution. Good service and nice location on the water.

pgQurApfbrV-rPKZKYo-Tw.review_text: Wandering around fisherman's wharf, doing the tourist thing, I stopped to ask some charter fishing boatsmen for a good place to eat, where there would be quality food, and not jsut the same old tourist thing I saw everywhere. They pointed me down an alley, out on a pier to a restaurant with its own dock on the water.  The place reminded me a good deal of the old New Orleans classic, Brunnings (R.I.P.). It has water on 3 sides and wood paneling on the walls. The waiters wear black bow ties and white jackets. The restaurant has its own dock, whichput the freshest seafood on my plate. I read reviews here on yelp while waiting at the bar about 20 minutes for a table. By the way, a 45 minute wait isn't really that bad. If I am going to get good food and good service I am willing to wait. Maybe that is just the NOLA in me though (see Galatoire's line for Friday lunch). I had their house Pale Ale, made by Red Hook. It was  good bitter beer, great as a compliment to the fish I was going to soon have.  I started with the clam chowder, as the reviews here on yelp indicated a should. It was very good (though I ahve no bassis for comparison, as it was the first time I had ever had clam chowder.) and it was full of large chunks of clam and potatoe, and lots of veggies.  After inquiring of the waitress (who was nice, but seemed like she had better things to do than wait on a table of 1; but don't blame the restaurant as a whole for her crimes) what was local and fresh. After she showed me what was, I decided on the red snapper in lemon butter sauce. The fish was delish, and it made quite a dish. The lemon butter sauce being practically the mueniere sauce I am used to at home, it reminded me more of dinner in New Orleans. The portions were GIGANTIC. The pasta that came with the fish was bland, but lets face it I wasn't there to eat the pasta anyway.  I appologize for all my comparison's to my home town, but as I see it, New Orleans is the unatainable standard of perfection as far as aseafood goes. If you are looking for good food on fisherman's wharf and want to avoid the tourist traps,I highly reccomend you stop here.

h4oOQdnfjpEHbygEJDsFbg.review_text: The last thing this place needs is another 5-star review, but I feel obligated to give them something after they gave us such a wonderful meal. We arrived on a Saturday evening with two other couples and no reservation; so we had to wait to be seated. The place was packed and I was not very hopeful of getting seated very quickly (even though the hostess did say 20minutes); so we made our way to the bar. We got some drinks; chatted it up; and before I was half-way done with my beer we were called to a table and seated.   We started the meal off with the crab cakes and fried calamari appetizers and they were good, but not great. I ordered the "Lazy Man's" Cioppino (LMC) and my wife got the Smoked Salmon Linguini. The LMC had a hefty price tag of $40 but it was worth every penny. The bowl came loaded with shrimp, fish, clams and scallops! It must've been a 80-20 ratio of seafood to sauce and I was afraid it was going to be the other way around. I did partake of my wife's Smoked Salmon Linguini and it, too, was terrific. The other two gentleman in our party got steaks- which I thought was going to be a mistake since I'd personally never order beef at a seafood joint, but if you want a steak you want a steak. They both said they were great and would order it again given the chance.   Our server, John, was great at making recommendations; answered all our questions and was very attentive (but not too attentive; you know what I'm saying).   The price tag was a little hefty, but well worth it. I can't wait to visit Pier 39 again so I can dine here again.

I7TQJq7cn8TmQgoDZNS4Ug.review_text: We came here after a wine cruise out in the bay.  After properly boozed and cruised, Matt B. suggested that we come to Scoma because it has really good cioppino.   Indeed!  The cioppino was delicious.  The broth was flavorful and the tomato wasn't overpowering, masking the freshness (and saltiness) of the seafood.  I enjoyed the cioppino here because it's "lazy man's" cioppino, meaning that there was absolutely no hands on work.  No cracking open crab shells, no pulling shrimps out by the tails.   The service was friendly and the water glasses were constantly refilled.  The wait was definitely long for a Sunday night, but we wouldn't expect anything less from this touristy place!   We also had their rich and creamy lobster bisque - very tasty as well.  Actually, I prefer the lobster bisque over the cioppino simply because I enjoy creamier soups!

h5iQ7WfXFq7IRlGDNooxPQ.review_text: So, this place was our second dinner, but it should have been a choice for a regular dinner. We were in Fisherman's wharf and we wouldn't be back before our vacation ended, so we decided to stop off here for one specific dish.   We really wanted Cioppino. It is really freaking GOOD. omg. Maybe a little pricey, but worth every penny. I don't really have a comparison though, but it was just that AMAZING.   DO IT. It is filled with all kinds of delicious seafood. Scallops, shrimp, crab, mussels... I could go on, but I won't.  The restaurant had a wait, so we decided to dine at the bar. The bartender was great! He accidentally threw away my friends invisalign, but was very apologetic.

OvfWYdkqE_4dv26TIQ9wtw.review_text: Hands down, my favorite of all time.  I am biased, but just because every time I've been here, the Ciopino  is the best thing I've ever eaten.  Not cheap, but sooooooooo worth it.  Go there.  Eat with a bib, and enjoy one of the best seafood meals you will ever have. :)

UqONGs7JFFvA3TzxzNVnFQ.review_text: Very pricey.  Food very good.  Go early due to high demand.

zpiyQRFRXoYxk-zT2dLdMw.review_text: Feeling a bit bad to give a well liked establishment a poor review. I just didnt get the experience everyone talks about. The restaurant is classic but dated and slightly stuffy. Maybe I didn't order the right food but it was subpar. If I am remembering correctly, it was a platter that our server recommended. I love seafood and was not impressed here.

zp-VvZl661XVEeKnFpv5FA.review_text: Delicious lobster ravioli and lobster bisque! So good we ordered it twice before leaving!! Wait wasn't too long--about 15 minutes around 5:30pm dinner time. Would definitely come back if I'm ever in the area.

4vMTHch8h-kTy91Fo9syaA.review_text: As I only hit the bar to check the place out I can only write on my bar experience! The bar was small but nice and the second bar was not open yet! Drinks were a little more than normal for this area but where stiff and the glasses where clean!  Service was a little to be desired, on several occasions we witnessed waiters coming up to bar with bad attitudes!   The food looked awesome an smelt even better! Must stop by, I hear this is the best place in town for seafood dishes!

_BHTC7nyCBoZcfiiD5cOXg.review_text: In business since 1965, this family-owned-and-operated restaurant is still one of the best and most popular on Fisherman's Wharf. Not much - if anything -  has been done to the decor in the past twenty years, but you come here for the food, not the ambiance. Think seafood with an Italian flair. For starters, share an order of calamari Calabrese-style, fried in a spicy tomato and red pepper sauce with mushrooms, and Dungeness crab cakes, prepared with a minimal amount of breading and served with a zesty remoulade. Pasta orders are huge and best shared, unless you intend one as your main course. Among my favorites is smoked salmon, rock shrimp, and red onion in a dill-cream sauce on a bed of fettucine. If they're in season, order the sand dabs, lightly grilled and served with lemon butter. The cioppino is sensational. Most entrees include fresh vegetables. Sauteed dishes are served with rice, while broiled or grilled dishes are served with pasta. Prices are very high, but portions are so overwhelmingly large that you'll be toting home enough for a second meal. As much as I'd like to award it a full five stars, their aggravating no-reservation policy means a very long wait to be seated, no matter the time of day, and the place is always so crowded, service can be brusque, out of necessity more than intention. Still, this is the best reason to come to the area, and the one place I always take out-of-town guests. (Note: there's a calmer atmosphere at the Sausalito location - yelp.com/biz_details/c/P… - where reservations are accepted.)

SgqocLuiOoIP5jB46KKQIA.review_text: There are so many crappy tourist restaurants around the wharf and I am happy to say this is NOT one of them. I have been going here for years with my motorcycle buds. This was the first trip where I had my wife, her brother and his wife.   I just sat back and enjoyed them all taking in the atmosphere at Scoma's. It was cold and raining when we arrived. Like always, there is a short wait for a table.We found a bar room table and enjoyed their no nonsense drinks.  Our food server was Chinese with a great sense of humor. He was an old fashioned, professional server. I memorized all of our orders, made sure our drink were in order and then brought us a perfect meal.  I have always left Scoma's with the feeling that I got wonderful value for my money. But, more than that, we always have a wonderful restaurant experience. They know how to do it right!

H8g0BBhsXiupdwwz6FIcXg.review_text: Boring place but good overpriced food. Today our waiter Jean Marc excellent but the hostess that seated my husband and I, a total BITCH:(  The location in Sausalito is a wonderful place. Also, did not enjoy sitting at our table and watching dust and lent from the bus person setting up the next table really awful and the flies flying around the restaurant. No need for us the ever return here again!

paviduDaSV3uZK6MeHR9Mg.review_text: Went to Scomas on the advice of friends while we visited the city.   It was the real deal. Good seafood and right on the water. Can't go wrong with dinner here!!

KxrKVxdXGkfMJ9XwJZzoLQ.review_text: The first time I went here, I was rather suspicious because we left the main street and started walking behind a building along a pier at night, only to discover that there was indeed a legitimate restaurant located back there.  Everytime that I've gone, there has been a wait for a table, so be prepared for a wait if your hungry.  What I don't like about the setup is that most of the tables are pretty close to each other so it's easy for your neighbor to eavesdrop.  The food is amazing and it's more on the pricey size, but the portions are generous.

PTrfkLyyhjmoDq5xUtC_ow.review_text: I love food. I have no problem paying a high price for good food. This place was not good food for a ridiculous price. I will start with the positive. The clam chowder my mom ordered was really good borderline great. By far the best thing I had tonight. The other good dish was the cioppino. Tasty but I have had just as good elsewhere for less money.  This is where the good news ends for the food. I started with the lobster bisque myself and it was bland. Edible but for 10$ a cup I had higher expectations. The entree I ordered, which the waiter assured me was very good, was the prawns and scallop alla Gannon. I absolutely hated this dish. In fact I found it insulting. It came out looking like someone just threw it together. There is zero creativity in this dish and the only flavor is garlic. The vegetables looked and tasted like they were reheated frozen from a bag. The mashed potatoes, garlic of course, were like glue and there was a pile of rice under the whole mess. The "stars" of the dish should have been the scallops and the shrimp. While the scallops were cooked decently they had been overpowered with garlic and butter. The shrimp were overcooked and tough. For this I paid 38$?!?!  I expect this quality from a cheap chain restaurant and know for a fact I could cook better than this at home which is where I should have stayed. As for the place itself The location is fine but the decor is outdated and crowded the waiter was friendly enough but rather inattentive. I do not think I have had a more disappointing restaurant experience in my  whole life. My suggestion is try the chowder and hit the road or skip it altogether and spend your hard earned money on one of the other myriads of dining establishments that have not fallen asleep at the wheel.

YLmAV9o5D4JmeCUBKtgnMA.review_text: My boyfriend's parents went to Scoma's 15 years ago and said that it was one of the best meals they have ever had so when we came to SF, we had to try to out - and it did live up to its expectations.   First off - it is right on the water and you can see where the fisherman dock and bring their catch in for Scoma's each day!   The food was so fresh and delicious!   My boyfriend had the garlic roasted dungeness crab - AMAZING!!!   The lobster ravioli was extremely tasty and succulent.   The crab cocktail was the freshest thing I've tasted in a long time.   When traveling to San Francisco, Scoma's is a must see!

1u3fWu8mwoYngz1sevTeTg.review_text: Mediocre food . Casual atmosphere. Went there for anniversary. Not as romantic as I thought it would be. Wait staff seemed like a bunch of untrained rookies and were not very knowledgable about the way a high end restaurant should operate. Tourist trap that will be avoided in the future. Food quality and experience definitely does not match the prices.

s3kRi7b8t2sdtYcsMbqlJA.review_text: I came here with 7 others for a late Monday lunch.    SERVICE - Commendable and attentive  FOOD - I got the Lazy Man CIOPPINO ($30) stew.  It had clams, scallops, shrimp, crab meat.  The tomato stew was a little too watery for me.   APPETIZERS - The crab cakes, calamari were good. We got the sampler as well.  DRINKS - I was disappointed with the mojito but I got a glass of the dry white house wine instead and that was so crisp. I loved it!  PARKING - Valet only.   Overall, a good place but I don't think I'll be back because I think any restaurants by the pier is overpriced for tourists.   Our bill came to about $500 for 7 people so you do the math! SEE MY PHOTOS

TZ9mfycN7WU4MtYJQtQxfg.review_text: The King Salmon was melt in your mouth AMAZING!! Definitely glad I took the waiter's recommendation! The garlic mashed potatoes weren't too garlicky and the vegetables were so fresh!

omyHIX0dVsoBAFfYfBlsiQ.review_text: Classy and delicious! Got a humorous side show looking outside at the fisherman guys going up and down the ladder to their boat. Finished our excellent meal with coffee. Perfect. Expect to spend some money and wait a bit for a table.  Four stars instead of five because the white jackets on the waiters looked stained and dirty. I'm pretty sure after what we paid for dinner that you can afford to have it cleaned properly or replaced.

bkUbCTcfOmI491O3dnuRVQ.review_text: Okay, okay.  So, I took an out of town friend here.  She wanted nice seafood, esp crab, so I figured, what the hell.    It was nice.  I liked the bartenders. I did not like the wait, but what do you expect on the fourth of July?  I drank two wonderful beers outside by the water and then we were seated.    Our server was nice and everything was lovely inside.  I was a bit disappointed when they brought me my red wine and it was not served in anything even close to an appropriate glass, but it was decent vino, so I wasn't too phased.  I ordered the crab risotto. The crab was abundant, but the risotto sucked.  I was really bummed, especially considering how much I was about to shell out.  Risotto is supposed to be a bit al dente...this was not.  It was mushy to high heaven.  It also had green peas in it.  It was a fine addition of color, but it did nothing for the texture in mouth or taste.  I felt like someone had thrown a handful of frozen peas into the dish.  It was in one word: yuck.    It's too bad, because my friend had the crab ravoli and they were freakin' amazing!    So, skip the risotto.  But, don't skip scoma's.

iOZeiIY1ere91HqrsiU-MA.review_text: love this place, will come back again when in town, food are fresh and delicious, great services as well, small but expected, wait time wasn't too bad, got a cocktail at the bar and ordered appetizer while waiting, wait time for us was about 20 min, but the time we had our appetizer it was time to be seated. :)

YvW04plmz8QZrF7l6EdDwA.review_text: My wife and I had the halibut chops and they were excellent. And the pumpkin cheesecake was great. Highly recommend.

NMaHUBl_u5iVCC5MYUdqXw.review_text: Stumbled upon this place while walking around Fisherman's Wharf. Our waiter, John B., was AMAZING. I wanted to take him home with me! We started off with an excellent oyster trio & app platter. The oysters were good but I've had better. I had the swordfish piccata for dinner & would definitely get it again. The swordfish was a huge piece of fish & the flavor was delicious.  Overall, we had a great experience & I would definitely go back. Not sure if they take reservations but I would recommend going early if you don't as the place was packed by 6pm.

XFGqNlqKAaaNFxrpkyMN5g.review_text: Scomas - 4 Stars: a nice old find in San Francisco - on Pier 47 at Fisherman's Wharf. Opened in 1965, we first had dinner there in 1974, long before the internet arrived; returned for the fourth time, on June 20, 2012. While the restaurant is a bit dated and the wait staff shows their age, this is still the place to go if you want fresh seafood...emphasis on fresh. The food is still the draw and well worth the visit. We'll be back again. Recommended.

p_keWnqhWHSuic1qqS-J-w.review_text: Went based on reviews, looking for a good seafood place since it's SF after all. It was mid-week at about 6/7PM. Got in without a wait.   My co-worker and I had the butternut squash soup, crab cakes and cioppino. The butternut squash soup was mostly just pureed butternut squash. My coworker buried it in pepper and still didn't enjoy eating it. The crab cakes were good though pretty standard - no wow factor - and came with plain pasta and steamed veggies. Snooze! The cioppino was tasty - plenty of tasty broth and fresh seafood. I would have traded some of the white fish and thousands of tiny shrimp for just a few good pieces of scallop or something else.   The atmosphere was very old school, as well - old people, tourists, two Japanese business men, waiters from European countries. My co-worker and I (mid-20's) felt a bit out of place.   Overall - I'm sure this place is for someone with this many positive reviews, but it wasn't us.

US7Ol4LW5-lCg8qwXmEEOQ.review_text: Great little spot. Nice to go after a bike ride accross the GG bridge, a bit expensive however. bring a jacket if you want to sit outside.

KlCmZnQE0RQT6BSpmJh48A.review_text: Food was great but the service is excruciatingly slow. First there was a 45 minute wait before we were seated, then our waiter was very hot and cold with us. He was nice when we first came in then he disappeared for another 45 minutes before taking our order, no drinks, nothing. When he showed again he looked mad, eventually warmed back up but remained very, very slow. Crab was fantastic. I had the prix fixe dinner: crab cakes and seared Ahi entree, pumpkin cheesecake which I couldn't finish. All very tasty.

_jg7sgGBRKiW3PZoep0-oQ.review_text: I went here for a friend's Birthday lunch celebration. Most of us got the lunch prefixed menu. Which was Clam Chowder Soup or Salad, an Entree (either NY Aged Steak, Scallops, Crab Salad, and another dish).  $24.95. Mimosas were $8 and mojitos were $11 (typical restaurant price)  The clam chowder soup was delicious. It was in a small cup, but just enough. It had a lot of clams. I was really impressed & satisfied.  I requested my steak to be Medium Rare - and it came out just as I wanted. It was although a bit dry at the ends, and tasteless. We asked for A1 sauce to save the day ! (:   Then there was the chocolate dessert. It was pretty yummy with an oreo crust.  The menu was really expensive - but it is off the pier. I like how it felt as if we were in a boat inside. We were in a private room, away from the entrance - which was nice.

qcqjzBi2pzWzCnc5crDiyQ.review_text: Great place to try! Came here for an anniversary dinner and had the prawn cocktail, spinach salad, and filet mignon with lobster tail. Soooo good. Although the food would probably only get a 3.5 or so, the view and ambiance bumps it up to 4 stars. Although I have definitely had better and cheaper variations of the above, the old-school SF feel and view of the bay is worth the trip.

EM9qQxKzCbPONjOXbCCQBw.review_text: While I did enjoy the food and the (unintentionally kitschy) atmosphere, I must say that this place is overpriced and overrated.  First of all, the interior of this restaurant is truly comical.  It reminds me of somewhere my parents would take my sister and I in our small hometown for a "fancy dinner" in the early 80s (or late seventies had I been alive).  I think the walls are dark stained wood grain with bronze tinted mirrored sections and brass light fixtures.  Even more hilarious is the staff uniform of white tuxedo jackets and bow ties.  I wish I had been able to take a picture of all of this.  It was obvious that they were under the impression that they were providing a super classy dining atmosphere and experience, which could not be further from the truth.  What I found perhaps the most strange, aside from the fact that there was nary a meal under $30, was that they did not serve Coke or Pepsi.  When I asked for a Diet Coke, I was informed that they only had Diet RC Cola.  Um, isn't that a discount brand?  I had to look at the menu for almost half an hour to find something I would even consider eating, let alone spend $30+ on, and came up with Lobster Ravioli.  Gee, I've never had that before.  In their defense, it was pretty good and I had a bite of my friend's Lobster Bisque, which was lso good, but this is one of the few times that I've not been interested in trying anyone else's food.  I looked around the table and thought, nah.  Honestly, if you are a senior citizen with poor taste that likes cheesy traditional family restaurants but willing to pay top dollar the same experience you could have in a crappy diner somewhere, eat here.  Anyone else, get in a cab and get the hell out of this area.  I pretty much knew the experience would suck going into it, but I wanted to give it a chance since it was so highly regarded by the local who recommended it.  Fail.

aHEaxb8_vJbEWb5Do06Ixw.review_text: We were really lucky and got seated within ten minutes for brunch. I saw people lined up after us.  Bread was good and food was good. Service, not so much. I had to look for our server twice.  Overall, I enjoyed it.

WLurjvs4U9HjwmwiHIHQeA.review_text: Unfortunately, I did not enjoy my meal here. I had read reviews and thought that it was going to be great. I found that it was extremely overpriced for the quality received. The soups were good (we had corn and crab chowder and lobster bisque) however our main meals were not good. I also felt that the staff members were rushing us. The soup came out right after ordering and the main meal immediately followed. I didn't feel that the dining experience was relaxed or worth the money.

MrHOzab16pg4EGFHyoROPA.review_text: Excellent! I ordered the mixed shellfish entree. It was a very large portion of shrimp, scallops, crab, and lobster. The seafood is right off the boat fresh, and their prices are very reasonable considering the quality and amount of food they give you. Also, they have free valet so you don't have to worry about finding parking. Overall, great experience!

7fi2YhGwDZOcOB3S9X86cw.review_text: On paper I didn't think I would like this place but I did. Here is why: Fisherman's Wharf Tourist nightmare area -- check. No reservations accepted -- check. Insanely overcrowded -- check. Old school, unrefined 1960's interior -- check. I could go on.....  But this is my girlfriend's favorite place and it was Valentine's Day so...  I liked it. Very obvious seafood menu but also very good. The servers dress the part in their black and white and were helpful and with no attitude. I remember the crab cakes the best and they were big and tasty. Definitely an out-of-towners special occasion kind of place. I would also like to go to the Sausalito one sometime.-

Jtj_c2qMRDMgno8tLSlCuQ.review_text: I relied on a non-Yelper recommendation that Scoma's was THE must have splurge seafood meal to eat during our vacation. Yeah, I skimmed the reviews, but we knew we were going. We went for lunch, hoping to save a few clams (groan, sorry. but I needed the $ for more Irish Coffees at Buena Vista). Anywho- yup, it was delicious. We had the crab appetizer, which was just enough for both of us to get really into seafood mode. Fresh and cold and plain, with dips on the side. Perfect. I had the Lazy Cioppino. Huge. And completely stuffed with stuff. Not bits of this and that swimming in broth, stuffed (you're waiting for me to say 'to the gills', but I can't do it to you twice in one review) . And not all white fish and a few bits of crab and some clams and mussels. This was worth every penny ingredient and quality-wise. And they will package up the leftovers very securely, since there is no way a normal human could finish it. Hubby had the seafood cannoli with scallops and crab. Super rich, he could only get through about half. If you want to eat again in the next 12 hours after Scoma's I suggest sharing a dish. I loved the restaurant and service. Definitely didn't have a touristy vibe, and was elegant yet casual. Sort of jeans and a tshirt are ok, but you remember to use the right fork and keep your elbows off the table. Since our friend said it was a 'splurge' meal, I really expected to pay a lot more. But I found the prices pretty much on par with the many other places we went. And so totally worth it.

hexu8fEA9SdNr_NDLyaYcQ.review_text: I was looking for Cioppino in San Francisco, and found it here.   I will base all future Cioppino experiences on this magical bowl. Not only was it the largest bowl of soup I've ever consumed, it was the most flavorful combination of brothy tomatoey perfection with a treasure trove of lovely shelled sea creatures to enjoy.   My only complaint... I ordered it "lazy man's style" with all shellfish cracked for me, but it left me wondering where the crab was? I could only find two small chunks in my soup. What the heck? I was really counting on some sweet salty crab bits in that bowl. It left me wondering if I had not been so lazy and had cracked it myself, would I have found more crab? When I told the waitress about this, she took it upon herself to bring my bowl back to the kitchen and added an insanely MASSIVE amount of crab meat to it. I was completely full by that point, but a local friend went home happy with crab soup dinner for the next night. Wrong, righted.   Wishing I could give this 4.5 stars...5 stars if the crab hadn't been MIA to begin with.

oP217-ZV7zgtTQF2O0jd6Q.review_text: A San Francisco Landmark not to be missed! We had a wonderful Mother's Day lunch at one of the oldest establishments in San Francisco. The restaurant is very accomodating when it comes to large parties and children. Our waiter was wonderful, and we never felt rushed. It was as if they wanted us to stay all day...and we did! Thank you for always making our dining experience so wonderful.

azlNapykyOvdl7cEI2wFEw.review_text: Scomas is the best.  There is a reason that they have been here for 50 years in SF.   The best seafood.  Boom.   The lobster bisque is to die for.  I have never had a bad dish.  Do not come Here thinking you will get right in.   There is always a wait.  That's because this is the most popular place on the wharf or anywhere    It's worth the wait and then some.  Anyone who has anything bad to say about this place is a big whiner spoiled baby

ggVZLUj4WIRdE9L3Mgdb3g.review_text: The waiter was very nice and helpful. It was my first time here so I wasn't sure what to order. He asked me what I liked and he basically created a dish off the menu.   I got a fettuccini Alfredo plate with prawns, crab legs and scallops. The seafood was scrumptious. The sauce was lacking. I was very watery and lacked flavor.  I should have taken it back considering how pricey this restaurant is.   The sourdough bread is good but think it could have been warmed given the style of restaurant.

oKpKp6pb_-O9DZaHLPMJyQ.review_text: For an appetizer we had a dungeness crab cocktail.  The crab was fresh and delicious.  Definitely a must get right now during crab season, it's an especially great pick for those of you too lazy to break through the shell for the crab. For the main dish I chose lazy man's cioppino.  Great selection of seafood in a rich, bit spicy  tomato broth.  Very yummy eaten with bread dipped in it. My friend got shellfish saute sec which he said was unbelievably delicious.  We had very helpful service.  When asked about certain dishes they were very knowledgable and pretty good with their wine pairings.

eMUvk1q9uk1Ni_RQdMtNIA.review_text: We've been coming here for years, and it never disappoints.  Fabulous food, service, and view of the old buildings. Best seafood on the wharf.

fQrHILDadvRrSTTP2DenDg.review_text: The only reason this place doesn't get five stars is because it's a little pricey.....but that said the food is outstanding and never disappoints

4UjS4PxlfrUOATK4eqP3gg.review_text: Clam Chowder is a must...but lobster bisque was great too.  Food was amazing, hands down just amazing.  The price was pretty steep but the service was great and we had a great time!

xf_vN-BJHNccH8iUhPu4yg.review_text: Does your employee handbook say, "Don't get trashed in front of executives?"    Mine doesn't.  But it should.  A 90-minute wait at Scoma's last week enabled me to impress my co-workers, boss, and really big boss with an impressive demonstration of how to get plastered on a Wednesday night.  Since Scoma's doesn't take reservations, our party of 7 had a long wait ahead of us, so we made ourselves comfortable in the spacious bar area.    In a misguided attempt to regulate my blood sugar, I threw back beers like a frat boy during hazing week.  By the time we were seated, I was playing the "they'll think you're paying attention if you stare between the eyes" game.    I ordered wine during dinner.  Or, I believe I did.  You see, when we were actually allowed to order food, I was already in a self-induced Coronacoma.    I remember the tomato sauce being tasty, I remember the linguine noodles being difficult to eat, I remember choking on a breadstick, and recall a green vegetable falling down the front of my shirt.    Including the wait to be seated, the wait for our food, and the wait for our check, we were here for hours.  Drinking and eating... and drinking.   The next day, I stumbled into the office wearing dark sunglasses and a look of shame.    Not bad.

lDKbTlZqjIn2gn490gU2HQ.review_text: For starters, we ordered:  Trio of oysters (1/2 dozen): The oyster meat was smooth and yummy! (5/5)  Scoma's famous clam chowder: Creamy and delicious! (5/5)  Lobster bisque: Probably the *best* I've ever had. I've tried lobster bisque at other nice restaurants and I am not a fan of the bitter aftertaste. However, when I tried the lobster bisque here, it didn't have that strong taste of bitterness. I'm a fan! (4/5)  As for our entrees, we ordered:  Swordfish: Everything about the fish was perfect. The meat was moist, soft, and fresh! The penne pasta that came with it was great too. Only thing we didn't like was the capers. You can request to have them taken off. (5/5)  Lobster Ravioli: A TOTAL MUST! It's served with saffron sauce! The ravioli itself is large and pretty filling. The lobster meat was fresh and delicious. Yum! (5/5)  This place is a little bit hidden near the piers, but it's a seafood gem! We made reservations ahead of time and were seated promptly with a wonderful view of the waters. If you ever want a nice place to dine-in at Fisherman's Wharf, definitely swing by here for a visit! It's quite romantic to have dinner by the waters. :)

HbzCOJ-RClX9mXfEnlCCoA.review_text: Strike 1: Had a reservation and waited just as long as folks off the street to be seated (35 minutes).  Strike 2: Family had called and arranged for our check to be covered as a surprise but the staff dropped the ball and did not do it...greatly disappointing the gift givers (who wondered why we did not call to thanks them...).  Strike 3: Food was good but not great.  I had been here many times over the years and think it has really gone downhill from the quaint family atmosphere of the past.  Won't go on my next visit to SF.

EaeekNRTHToAAVmp-PymtQ.review_text: Yum! If you're in sanfran, this place is not to be missed. Apparently, they've been around forever, as you'll see from the decor but don't be discouraged. They sit tucked back on the wharf, and a little pricey but well worth it. I got the lobster bisque and petrale sore and had a bite of my family's calamari fritti and risotto...all of which were excellent. I don't think it's possible to order a bad meal here!

0lDl1Jg1Qz2KhvkfJKk6fw.review_text: Scoma's on a Sunday is not for the faint of heart but yay valet parking. We had a wonderful time. At Fisherman's Warf. On a Sunday. Let that sink in a moment. On a whim, we decided to go to Scoma's and it was a madhouse. We had an hour wait in the cocktail lounge but everyone was so nice. Employees. Other waiting diners. We were then summoned to our table which was perfect and on the water. Our server, CC, was friendly, knowledgeable and spot on in her recommendations. I can't say enough good things about her. We started with Oysters Rockefeller and moved on to Lobster bisque. We split a whole crab and finished up with Bread Pudding and a lemon dessert. The Joel Gott Sauv Blanc ($8 a glass and wonderful) was a perfect pairing. The valet guys were friendly on the way out. It really could not have gone better. We'll be back but maybe not on a Sunday.

I5PaiOdOl0lQKhDJbpc8pA.review_text: We don't visit San Francisco often, but if we have a chance, we go to a new place as much as possible. Scoma's Restaurant was suggested by Yelp when we searched for seafood and soup after the AIDS walk this year. This place has a funny, attentive, and friendly server named Salvatore. He made our experience great. My husband and I both ordered Fresh Half-Shell Oysters and Lazy Man's Cioppino. Their Cioppino was so good. Lots of seafood meat in it, and the broth was thick, creamy and flavorful. Their bread went well with it. It was one of the best Cioppinos I've tasted. Now that I'm recalling it, I'm craving for some. LOL

Wnxhk0AdpyFwubxESl6Rcg.review_text: Very disappointed. Atmosphere was very old fashion, touristy. Food was just ok.

K6t_6uutCnz-1wnHb9cgvA.review_text: The best shrimp I have ever eaten. Came here as a tourist in April and I still day dream about the shrimp here.

RjkL9KkS6aX_s-_9alYFcg.review_text: I am often long winded, so I will try to keep this in cliff notes version.   Food was ok, I had the pork tenderloin with sautéed veggies and Parmesan polenta. The pork was served very dry and overcooked for my liking. The veggies were good; however, the polenta was fantastic.   Overall, this restaurant is overpriced and outdated inside. I imagine many of the dishes are very good, but you are really paying for prime real estate, not the food in front of you. Also, the view isn't that great, it has a parking lot view with a bit of wharf water and a warehouse across the waterway.   The valet was very rude to our party on several occasions. We were taking a group shot and he asked our uncle holding the camera to move so he could park a car. My uncle said he was almost done and would move, but it wasn't the immediate jump that the valet has expected. So he rolled his eyes and made several hand gestures showing his displeasure. It took another 10 seconds, and we moved our party inside to spend our couple thousand dollars on lunch.   I understand the valet is busy and has a job to do. However, there are ways to act, especially when we are your patrons who just tipped you, and are about to spend a bunch of money at your establishment.   We had a similar rude incident when leaving with this particular valet - I'm sorry I tipped him.   We also saw him park another patrons car too close to the edge of the dock, opened their car door into a wooden pier (somewhat hard), and then moved the car and walked away. Didn't check for damage, and I have a sneaking suspicion didn't tell the owners of the vehicle.   Needless to say, this valet left a poor taste in our mouths. Overall food was ok, prices much higher than the quality of the food was. Polenta was amazing though!  Also, sorry for getting long winded. My attempt to keep it short was obviously a fail.

zLaGvDtBPupMOjpc-2xHag.review_text: So far at the beginning of dinner I am super impressed.  I think my Yelp status ( humble though it may be) plus my Open Table points merited me quick seating.  I had 8:45 pm reservations but we were seated and had placed our order by 7 pm!  I'm having dinner with the best friend in the world and feel like this is going to be a memorable meal.  We gad a great seat with a view looking out on several fishing boats.  For an appetizer we chose OYSTER ROCKEFELLER ALLA SCOMA for $18 which consists of six tender oysters lightly breaded in a delicious sauce.   The meal was also excellent! I had the MIXED SEAFOOD GRILL which will consist of 3 types of fish and 3 shrimps with grilled veggies and garlicky mashed potatoes for$39.  Tonight's selection included 3 small (just enough though) pieces of salmon, tuna and swordfish all very moist and tasty.  My friend had the LOBSTER RAVIOLI with Saffron Cream Sauce for $30 also very good.  The ravioli was tender and well seasoned and the filling had a nice texture to it.  The saffron cream sauce was very tasty.  The presentation was great with a very tender lobster claw on top. The server was attentive and kept our water glasses full.  From my review it seems like I should have given them five stars, each dish was very good but there just wasn't that memorable dish that deserves five stars.

69CVGNN-JGALhelaU0cdcA.review_text: You're luck if you get a Friday night table.  We went at 8:00 and waited 35 minutes (not bad!) Great Chioppino, but I disagree with the last Yelp review, the dessert was great! Got the bread pudding and seemed like a reasonable dish.  Good wine prices as well.  Its a see and be seen place!

RD1EXrH8qMJaGSgfNjycUQ.review_text: Clams are greats! Don't get the filet of sole. Wasn't that good. For 30$ I should have got the whole crab....

FtGEpYCF6DYwiBL4zFMfRA.review_text: So my parents flew out to visit me for Mother's Day and she requested that we go to Scoma's because she loves seafood and had heard that it's a classic. As a trendy foodie-type I rolled my eyes disdainfully of anything up in that darn touristy area, but ultimately acquiesced. When we walked in the door, it was packed to the gills (fish pun!) and I was wishing that I had been able to sway my mother earlier. It looked like it was straight out of the sixties and reminded me of restaurants we'd end up going to when visiting my grandparents.  I shall scoff no more at Scoma's. They're still in business for a reason. All the seafood was fresh and excellent, and I was able to pick good wines by the glass to go with. I don't remember what I chose w/ the cioppino other than it was red, but I recommend the Grgich Hills Fume Blanc w/ the mixed seafood plate. It's a sauv blanc that has spent some time in oak, so it's light, yet has some body.

RSM8buemcnx4t03roVomOg.review_text: I keep it simple at Scoma's and have never come away un-amazed;  1. Roasted whole Dungeness crab 2. Classic crab Louie salad with avo  Waste your money elsewhere if you must, but for crab in SF you best dollar is spent here.

E_liLDoiGAWdEByYrnKCIw.review_text: Scomas is a San Francisco institution. It's located in crazy touristy area of Fisherman's Wharf, but it's tucked away from the hustle and bustle right on the water. They have a great happy hour in the bar. All their bar menu items are made in smaller sizes, but it's only $5 each plate. I ordered the clam chowder in a bread bowl and oysters, along with a Brancott Sauvignon Blanc ($9). The only open bar was facing the parking lot and pier, which was a bummer. They have another bar with a better bay view, but it wasn't open yet.   I arrived at 4:30 on a Wednesday, the bar was full. The service was quick and attentive. As soon as I sat down, the bartender took my order. The clam chowder bread bowl was excellent and quite substantial. The non happy hour price is $11, for $5 this is the best deal in town. The chowder was thick, full of clams, sourdough was fabulous and oh so tasty!   My oysters were great. For the happy hour, you get 3 nicely sized oysters.  I can't wait to come back for dinner!

vdMJFmbbDe0nDQr9-CjiGw.review_text: The place gets a five star for location and a one star for density of patrons. They took a plan from the airlines play book and stuck as many micro tables as possible within their footprint. It is very cramped. I was practically leaning into the window waiting for the exit procedures to be announced.  Waited for the seat at the bar. Very cool. The bartender was one of the best. I had a cable car to get an "authentic drink". It was amazing even though I'm not a tequila fan. My friend on this business trip had a bloody mary which he said was perfect.   The host really was pushing us to get our seats, which was funny. Told him to tell the bartender and the two should work it out as we were waiting for him to make our drinks and then to close out the tab.  The waiter (as all of them appeared to be) probably had worked there 30 years. Very knowledgeable, confident and humorous. He gave us a rapid tour of one of the most ambiguous menus I've ever seen. Unlike Cheesecake Factories encyclopedias, this was a couple pages of bullet notes. I kid you not, my choice was "Mixed Shellfish $40." I also ordered the Lobster Bisque.  At these prices, my quality meter went way up. I don't mind paying, but now I'm expecting. I love Captain D's cause for bucks you get $5.  The Lobster Bisque was fantastic, but I think a lobster may have bathed in the pot two years ago. I don't remember anything solid bumping into my teeth. The mixed shellfish was a huge plate. Half of it crisp vegetables (quite a "mix") and a third was rice and pasta. The pasta was incredible and the sauce was very good. The mixed seafood consisted of  3 scallops, 3 shrimp, and two chunks of micro lobster tail that made me think they were fishing in the crustaceans' preschool.  The fantastic waiter practically disappeared after serving us long after our order. If I had my wife on a romantic evening, the alone time would have been welcome. On an airline with a business friend, it only reinforced how uncomfortable this was. The bill eventually came back. I thought the food was very good (not exceptional), but totally not at the same level as the bill.  Would I go again? If someone else was buying and if I wasn't choosing. San Fran has thousands of other untried restaurants that I would rather check out. I can understand ANY rating between 1 and 5 depending on how crowded/busy and what's ordered.

DIVCwTUoJ9AHuk4EBn_r7w.review_text: Fantastic fine dining.  App: ahi tuna (good,but pricey for amount) Entree: Whole dungeness crab was fresh and flavorful. Two thumbs up! Dessert: rasberry cheescake...wonderful! Drinks: my wine was good, but my colleagues old fashion was terrible Service: good

NUgkzQlwmLeXbLBOuRBSkQ.review_text: The food is good. Very filling and enjoyable. Nothing over the top. Large portions. Would definitely come back!

zUEoXNjUReZ8Rjpea7JU1w.review_text: In the past five years, I've been privileged to visit San Francisco quite often. It was a Californian/German friend that recommended this place. I owe him big time. Yes, there are several great restaurants in this town, but Scoma's is really "something else". First, it is not a tourist trap, as I see and hear most of the guests are locals. Then, the overall feeling - elegance yet unpretentious, quality yet not snobbish, efficient yet not pushy.  Tonight, I was "party of one" - probably least interesting type of guest. Perhaps I was lucky, but I got excellent table, and no waiting.... I'm pretty sure that they don't recognize me from before, so this is luck and/or standard practice. As for the food, I ate all. The portions are not "amerikanski" XXL, nor French "taste a spoonful" - this is genuine Italian - you get decent size meal. This evening it was Mr Sonny, but service was very decent any time before as well. So, price/performance this place is a true Gem. Yes, there is better food to get in restaurants that are significantly more expensive, but hey I've had more expensive "stuff" that is far behind what Scoma's delivers. Consistency, quality, style. Clear winner.

F4PWEzITzUUfxZQsS_cIpA.review_text: Very disappointed. ... 55 minute wait to discover that the 2nd day of crab season ... This place is OUT OF CRAB ! !  Fortunately we walked less than one block to have a good laugh with the manager and waiter of neighboring restaurant.   What a joke ... I am embarrassed for them.  But trust the me the crab at the other restaurant was great!

54TicaQMeLzd8qK8o9W0aQ.review_text: I heard great things about this place, so we decided to try it late one night after visiting the Academy of Sciences.  The atmosphere was just OK (no spectacular view), and the food was mediocre at best.  I did appreciate that they had their gluten-free items noted on their menu.  I ordered the crispy polenta w/ cheese sauce, and it had the weirdest taste I had ever experienced.  The shrimp risotto was OK, but a little salty.  My husband's fish was good, but nothing spectacular.  Not worth the hype or expense.

h-fQmJSo_dlqEO748oZfbA.review_text: Great service, great view, great food.  Went here for lunch.  Not cheap, but worth it.

-XZ4PxcGK2232Yb9HsoYfw.review_text: I'm giving this two stars because I'm over the hype. Frankly, I'm just confused about it. They say this is a "local favorite." By that I think "they" mean that a lot of old people come here. Which is cool, I have grandparents; I'm down with the old folks.  However, it's pretty pricey and the menu is standard. All the classic meats, pastas, and seafood. Nothing unique. I could have gone to a restaurant with the same quality of food for a lower price.   We were not impressed and regretted spending so much money here for average food.

mS-4O56dx6wt5fWxbbx-LQ.review_text: It's been a while since I've been to a restaurant that is a solid 4 stars, no borderline 5 or borderline 3.   Scoma's is an upscale and classy seafood spot in the heart of Fisherman's Wharf with a staff well versed in everything seafood and wine and an impressively extensive menu. The servers can sometimes feel a bit lethargic and come across as a tad pretentious but given the upscale ambiance and old-SF vibe, it fits right in.   My friend and I headed here to celebrate the crab season and thus ordered the Crab Risotto and Garlic Roasted Dungeness Crab. We also prefaced the meal with some calamari as an appetizer. All three items were fabulously solid in their own exclusive way - the risotto was creamy in a tomato-based broth with large chunks of fresh crab meat spread evenly throughout. The dungeness crab was fresh, tender and came with some butter for dipping pleasure. And the calamari was crispy and fried to perfection. We paired all of the above with a some Prosecco and it matched perfectly.   The food gets 4.5 stars, service gets 3.5 - 4 stars and ambiance gets 4 stars - hence the 4 star average.   If you're in the Fisherman's Wharf area and are in the mood for an upscale seafood dining experience, definitely consider Scoma's.

4XH7ynmxjmcsMdCseNuRHA.review_text: Been here multiple times and tried various dishes, but.... Nothing to write home about it. The food is average. Otherwise, the place is nice, busy and expensive. Staff is friendly.

W-Y-vrNyufeKqWifoY1ppA.review_text: We love to eat at Scoma's when we go to the city.  Had lunch there yesterday. As always it was awesome.  Our waiter Jean Marc was attentive and knowledgeable. I had the Pasta diplomatica and my daughter had the yellow fin ahi.  Both were delicious. I have eaten here many times and always a fabulous meal. Thank you Scoma's.

tSeWl6LU6vvTjBDXCf-P4Q.review_text: We were very disappointed with the reception we received at Scomas. After getting many recommendations for this restaurant, we made a reservation for a window table a week in advance. We showed up at our reserved time and waited for our window table. Hostess said there would be a wait... But we were next up.   We then witnessed the hostess giving OUR table to a later couple b/c they complained about waiting!!! I told the hostess I saw that and she denied it. Baaaaaad   Food was very good and our waiter, Bruce, was outstanding. If he had been at the front desk this would have been a great experience instead of just "good".

rw3HhZEQdEc1YcMNYNvBLQ.review_text: I just tried this place with my family while on vacay in SF. I read about this place on Yelp and thought we'd give it a shot. And boy... I was not disappointed. =)  Being on a family fare budget, we all got their special $35 three course meal. It was great because we got to try a little of everything. I had the lobster bisque with crab, then the jumbo prawns with linguine and pesto sauce. To top it off I had the tiramisu and sourdough bread pudding.   Overall the service was awesome and I loved the food. I never saw the bottom of my water glass even though it was busy (even on a Tuesday night). It was quite a dining experience. I really enjoyed this place and I can't wait to try it again in the near future.

JY-63Oca1am9NTpwS5q4kw.review_text: Great little place tucked away on a side street on the wharf area. Had the Triple Play where you choose app, entree and dessert for $40.  Lobster bisque was creamy goodness, lamb bones cooked just right, and sourdough bread pudding was a treat.   Take advantage of the complimentary parking.

m8TnxdbnXeI_Wywl8I40HQ.review_text: Great atmosphere! Getting to this location has the feel of a place only a local would know about as it is down an unassuming alley with only a small sign. Inside feels upscale but folks in all sorts of dress are dining.  We had a problem with our reservation as the hostess could not find the details. The 6p reservation ended up being 620p after she found a table and then had to find another for 7 instead of 2. The questions she asked me made it seem like this was a problem they'd had before with phone reservations.  Other than that it was great! The waiter was super friendly and great with the kids. The food, though pricey, was excellent! I had a sort of combination platter with steamed vegetables and rice pilaf along side a mix of scallops, lobster tail, crab claws and shrimp. It was quite the load of seafood. Even at $40 I'd have it again.  Save for the hiccup getting started I'd highly recommend it and will return when I get the opportunity!

hgWgaJWa9Q5wGrOcLpXy8w.review_text: So the first 4 out of 8 in our party to arrive, hostess invited us to wait at the bar, but also informed us that the last seating is at 9:30pm.  We waited about 20-30 minutes for our party to arrive, (our fault), but she was very rude about trying to sit and if they come they just can't eat type of thing.   Anyway, the waiter was little off key, but very nice older gentleman. I had the linguini w/ clams. David had the cioppino. He said it was just ok. I eventually found a hair in my pasta, not a fiber. Chef came out to apologize, that was pretty nice.  Did not have any other kind of appetite after that.   Unsure if I would return. A little pricey as well.

ZmEVWKz1IHk-cCbPb27xlw.review_text: Came here for my birthday last year... the hubby still talks about the cioppino! I keep wishing I had ordered the lobster rather then whatever fish dish I did order that day..  Nonetheless, it was a good meal and they served good drinks!

M5wRswBgy3Bo-IifRXq5Zg.review_text: I hadn't been to Scomas in years. My friend and I ordered King Salmon that came with mash potatoes and beans. Salmon was cooked too long so it was dry and potatoes were full of salt.  Service was terrible.  We should have sent the order back.  I would not go back and neither would my friend  JB

xqVr9_O0hXqxzDbJrQlhoQ.review_text: Review is only for the Clam Chowder.   On the hunt for the best Clam chowder in town, we stumbled upon Scoma's. If you are not looking for Scoma's, you wouldn't find it easily as you have to go in to the alley to get to it but once you are in front of the restaurant, you can see a bunch of people mulling around to be called for their names.   Scoma's located on (very close by) the Fisherman Wharf area and yet, there were plenty of locals eating at Scoma's which was a good sign.    We got there just in time right before the happy hour at the bar ends, and so we ordered a bowl of clam chowder and stood around since all the chairs were taken. :)  Scoma's does have the best of Clam Chowder, even though it is pricey ($10/happy hour, $11 regular price), it is legit!

NO0DNuFm36oRyu8AMgRi6A.review_text: Love at first sight ! My hubby took me to this place for our first American date, he knows about this place because his family has been coming here for 30 years! We had the Fried Pacific Oysters with Wasabi Aioli which is just fantastic ,and for the main dish we had the Seared Yellowfin Tuna !  This place is just amazing !
