I Must say that after a month from our dinner date , he proposed to me ! we have been happily married for the past four years !

IXAYirFUR2Gs0zNkJi0rXA.review_text: I actually want to give it 4.5 stars due to the wonderful service.  A last minute and wonderful dinner fell from the sky and into my lap. Me and two really old people that I dearly love ! I'm definitely not being politically correct tonight ! They're people I dearly love and they definitely have the greatest sense of humor in the world !  Food was very good. We all ordered swordfish steaks with different side dishes and we loved our food.  No reservations mean't  that we made sure to be seated before 6:30 pm.  Fine, considering my friends were coming in from Menlo Park and were between 67years old and mmmmm ! .I didn't pick it for this evening, they insisted.    Hey, I'm not about to disagree with a 70 year old who wanted to relive his youth at Fishermans Wharf !  Entrees 27-35, a bit steep IMO.  Juicier Swordfish at Hayes Street Grill , Mortons, and Fifth floor.  And a constant and common request is always the same...  Katherine ... When are you getting married !

x8XTq_OUM03-bn4-PFhCjA.review_text: My first stop in my 24 hour stay in San Francisco, and boy was I in for a surprise. My friend suggested lunch at Scoma's, a place he and his family have been going to since he was a boy. The seafood here is apparently so fresh and cooked so well, anything on the menu will come out tasting delicious. There were so many things to choose from, I didn't know where to begin.  It probably took 10 minutes until I finally decided to go with the prix-fixe lunch menu for $23.95.  I opted for the cup of clam chowder soup, the dry pack sea scallops with garlic mashed potatoes and mixed veggies, and the chef selection dessert. My friend had the same, but ordered the pasta garibaldi for his entree instead.   Best... clam chowder.. EVERRRR! I salivated and savored each scoop of soup. The clam meats were endless. The taste to die for. So rich in clam juice goodness that I was genuinely saddened when I got to the bottom of my soup cup.  I simply don't think I can look at any other clam chowder soup the same after having this one. In fact, as I am writing this review, my taste buds are salivating for some more.   The scallops were super tender, not in the least bit undercooked or overcooked. Sadly there were only 4 medium sized scallops for me to savor (my friend ate my 5th one to try). The garlic mashed potatoes and mixed veggies were delicious, nothing out of the ordinary.  Picked off my friend's pasta garibaldi for a bit while he was trying my plate, and I loved his plate too! The pasta sauce is creamy, rich, and has a hint of wine hidden within the tomato goodness. The mixed seafood in the pasta was amazing too--tender, juicy chunks of salmon and tasty mussels.  I couldn't spot any scallops but I'm sure it was delicious too. Yum, yum, yum.   Finally, for dessert, they served us a chocolate marquise with raspberry coulis. This was absolutely too chocolate-y rich for my taste so I only manage to finish half of it.   Overall, the food is a little pricey and the portions are healthy sized (which, I understand many consider this to be small) and the service is excellent. To top it off, you get a gorgeous view of the wharf and boats. I'd recommend this place to anyone looking for to-die-for seafood. Bon appetit.

f81Y2EzuRqefayCrL1Ra3Q.review_text: Great view, great service but food was definitely lacking. We came in on a random Tuesday night, it was pretty dead inside and was hoping for a really good meal.  I ordered the Lazy Man's Cioppino (yes, sometimes, it's just that kind of night) and I mostly thought it tasted like ketchup and definitely not flavorful enough for the price it was commanding. Maybe it was my fault but down the street, I have definitely gotten a better cioppino from a place name just that...  I'm tempted to try Scoma's again because I feel like it can redeem itself food-wise. I just have to order the right things is what I'm thinking. So Yelpers, look for the best dish that everyone loves and gets that but stay away from the cioppino!

x0i6NgHySrXWgb17gVMTuQ.review_text: Been here a couple times and have been pleasantly surprised by the quality of their seafood. Yes, it is a bit pricey as some of the other reviews noted, but if you want a sit down restaurant in SF, this is not an outrageous price. DO NOT compare it to In & Out across the street...I suspect the person who did don't even know what seafood is...=p  I have had oysters, clam chowder, halibut, bay shrimp cocktail, bay shrimp and crab louie, and other various things from here. I've always liked what I've had -- the food is fresh and prepared well. A friend who's visiting has been hunting down for crab places in SF and found the roasted whole dungeness crab "very very delicious although a bit pricey". My picky boyfriend (picky about clam chowder =p) who's been to chowderfest in Boston a few times raved about how fresh the clams in the clam chowder is.  With the location of the restaurant (with the decent view), you would expect the portions to be more "European" even though they do charge quite a bit for the food. In fact, that is what I would have liked (with a slightly cheaper price) because I stuff myself every time I'm here. For example, the bay shrimp and crab louie is served with a mountain of shrimp and crab such that the beets and avocado seem to be almost falling off the plate. I had to bring half of it home in order to be able to fit in dessert.  Their desserts are also a delight, so maybe sure not to miss them if you have any appetite left (or save up some appetite for it!). Their wine list is decent with some local selections that we like, and I've also enjoyed their dessert wines very much.  Service is not spectacular but I can live with it. If the service were any better, this would have been a 5-star restaurant.

7yZuSx3Wla8wVCmy9thkIg.review_text: I've been a frequent of Scoma's for years. I've traveled quite a bit and have been privileged enough to truly experience fine dining. Always at the top of the list is Scoma's. No fluff. Just all around great food and a great experience.

sktAlsn5d0bBh1UOevRwMg.review_text: Ha, so the first day in SF walking around the Fisherman's Wharf, we picked out Lou's to get my fresh seafood fix but the whole time sitting there I seen droves of people walking down this side street. Fast fwd to the next day and we went down said side street to take a look. Wow, what a great setting, all these little boats moored up and this great looking restaurant overlooking the bay and harbor. Walking up I see the white table cloths so you know its gonna be fancy and then looking at the menu outside the prices confirmed it but you get what you pay for and I wanted more than bar food. Quite posh inside, we get seated at nice window table and our waiter, Jose A and his helper were quick with menus, bread & water. He was very helpful as I couldn't decide which fish to go for tho ended up on the Alaskan Halibut. He was also great help with some of the beers that I was not familiar with and I tried Anchor Steam and Liberty Ale.  The fish was awesome, cooked to perfection and I wiped the plate clean with the extra bread. Best dining experience in a long time and the bill wasn't that bad!

YqkNBzWJ4LJV2gdGJcbBhQ.review_text: So I would love to give this place five stars because the food was amazing, the waiter was very nice and made sure we were satisfied , plus the food was ready within probably 10 minutes which was surprising due to how crowded it was. The down fall was that we were told we would have to wait 45 mins for a table which was no biggie until we ended up waiting an hour and 45 minutes. When I went to ask how much longer it would be the hosted lied to our faces as if we were already called , this wasn't possible because we were standing inside the whole time within ten feet from where she was standing and would have heard her, when I told her this she got really offended at us and told us in a very loud tone not to argue with her, which we werent doing. and which was sort of embarssing because there were so many people around us  Besides that I would recommend this place because the food was amazing. I couldnt eat much see food because I am pregnant but I did try the crap cakes and they were delicious. I just got pasta which was probably some of the best pasta I had ate. my boyfriend got a plate that was all sea food and he loved it! Just go on a week day when it's not so crazy.  Also, they say no reservations but we seen her tell a few different people she would  "take care of them" and somehow these people would be called infront of other people who had been wating.

s8U7i_eK1dSwnMyhfsuogw.review_text: Let me start by saying that this would have been a five star review, but for mediocre service.   Some reviewers note that the prices are on the high side, even if worth it.  Scoma's does have a three course price fixe for $45, a great option for those on a budget.   Ok-now about the food. Amazing lobster bisque, and this is coming from a New Englander. The price fixe version comes with a deconstructed lobster salad on the side. I added the lobster meat from that into the bisque and was in heaven. The main course was a scallop and pasta dish in a light cream sauce. Everything about it was perfect. Dessert was a brownie and ice cream duo. The brownie was mediocre at best. BUT, the homemade caramel sauce that accompanied the ice cream was pure heaven, so I didn't mind not eating the brownie at all.   I would definitely recommend.   We went on a Sunday night, without reservations. They were very busy, but the wait was less than half an hour. It is down a small side street, so you have to have an idea of where you are going.

8GrlLiPVkrpv-Yc1mtKMCA.review_text: When I work in san Francisco area I always try to make it here for dinner at some point, I usually order the same thing everytime (the lazy man) when my son is with me he usually tries something new everytime we go and he is never disappointed. The staff is always very attentive, the wine selection is good, the restaurant is always busy but always clean and the waiters are always very kind. If your ever in the san Fran area scoma's is a must try restaurant!

IWR1GOgIg0LELF0YXjPhLw.review_text: I was completely impressed with the food and the service. Our waiter, Kevin, was the best waiter I have every had in my entire life! He was incredibly helpful, knew when to clear plates, bring more bread or water, answer any questions we might have, and help my mom...who has some physical challenges. He was extraordinarily kind. We enjoyed the appetizers (crab cakes, calamar, shrimp), and the clam chowder (get the bowl, it is only $1 more.) Two of us shared the cioppino (over the top!), and the risotto - with scallops or shrimp - was tasty. Ah, and the view from our table of the SF port was beautiful/relaxing. The decor is definitely from another era, but it is still a great place to eat. Ah, and park there. I believe all you have to pay is a tip to the valet.

Xriu7aQUa86OWLvJILaBjg.review_text: Stopped in here for lunch today seeing as how I was in the area. Didn't have as much trouble finding it as the last time. They seated me right away and I ordered the same dish as last time. Guess I'm a creature of habit. The service was very fast which amazed me due to the fact that the place was packed. I really like this place. The food is amazing and the prices match the quality of the food.

Kckxk3jXvNIQ4tktTVokpw.review_text: I went to scomas with such an open heart... With such great expectations, and an empty stomach.... ughhh such disappointment.  We went on both a recommendation and on yelp reviews.  :(  I don't even know what to say.  We walked in... Old school, 70's style decor, very wharf style.  I was ready.  Got the menu and my excitement fell... Shot.... Down the drain. Prices were out of this world.  Soup for $15.... Ughhh.... But I trucked on.  I spotted what I wanted, the crab risotto.  The waiter was interesting to say the least.  No other way to describe him. If you don't like fancy waiters with white coats, and lavish talk, walk away.  So I ordered my risotto and a bloody mary.  The rest of my group got the squid salad, lobster bisque, and lobster ravioli.    We waited for our food, that came very quickly.  I tried the squid salad..... It was delicious.  Then I got my meal. hmmmmm..... Lets see.  So the risotto was way under cooked.  I mean, I was crunching on risotto.  not much wine flavor, which is key to risotto.  I mean, there were large pieces of crab.... But, I was so disappointed.  I was so sad.  I wanted to like this place... It was so highly recommended. The lobster ravioli was a hit. But here is the bottom line.  Over priced, over hyped.  I guess I need to give it another go, but I just wasn't impressed.

KmHtoogKhK-ID7FWGOPvag.review_text: My fiancée and I were visiting San Francisco and our friend recommended Scoma's and we were definitely not disappointed! The restaurant itself is located right off of pier 39 in the fisherman wharfs area. The decor is very underwhelming compared to the food.   We started with the some fresh oysters which were very fresh and went down well. My fiancée ordered the market special, it was scallops on on spinach and potatoe purée. The scallops were large and flavourful. I ordered the wild king salmon on lobster ravioli. The wild king salmon was so fresh it had a dark pink colour and the lobster ravioli was perfection.   Overall the food was delicious and we would definitely revisit if we go to San Francisco again.   The only negative we had was the server we had was a little too slow. But she was nice and pleasant. Just not attentive enough.   A must go!

QZSkofjBvMm1E0t2mEyrbQ.review_text: I've been coming to this place since I was a little kid. My favorite thing to get has stayed the same..... The lazy man's cioppino, extra spicy. It's pretty much the standard of what to get here. But also the seafood saute sec. is amazing. The pier is always a nice to walk after a hefty meal.

rePK2UDOw-KyJACzesknrg.review_text: the location is ok, but not much of a view of the water. valet for free is great! they will not seat you, because of "house policy," if your group is not complete. there were 10 adults and 3 kids in our group. five of us arrived earlier and captain will not seat us. until now i cannot see the rationale why they cannot a table if we are not complete. the restaurant was not even full.  the food: i had the $10 bowl of lobster bisque. it was so-so. the kitchen should have used about another 2 lbs. of shellfish to make the stock & should not have chopped the lobster into tiny pieces. the bread was not even warm. and you have to ask for balsamic vinegar to mix with the olive oil on the table.  the $37 cioppino was very different- i like mine with clear stock not marinara-based. it was tomatoey for me. it's a good thing there was an abundance of seafood- four plus pieces each of scallops, shrimps, clams, whitefish. although it would have been better if bay shrimp was not use for fillers. the garlic bread is great although you only get one.  others in my party took advantage of the prixe fix 3-course meal. the steak looked good. the sole looked dry. the cup of soup was really small. more like 4-5 nice soup spoonful only.   other than nicolo, our server and the free valet, i have nothing good to say about this place. even the $3 coffee was nothing special.

Syt_iQqW_c9T2_lrvsddqQ.review_text: The other day I met a 4th generation San Franciscan who left the city in 1976 for points north. Not so far away that he and the mrs. couldn't come into town once in a while to see a show or visit relatives.  On visits to our fair city they go to Lucca's on Chestnut  to get sandwiches, then to the Marina Green to park in a special spot, with the car angled just so, to enjoy a view that hasn't changed in years, where they used to park and make out. Or they go to the Wharf, and choose a restaurant with a table angled just so, with fishing boats in full view, seeing what they saw during their courting days.   Scomas is made for these sweet people. It's not the place for a jaded palate. Their nod to keeping up with the times is the beer selection, so points for that. And high prices, negative points for that. Otherwise, time stands still, and it's easy to imagine a gentler, more romantic city while you're sitting on Al Scoma Way, with the fishing boats swaying in the bay.

4ALOxfvxnnWyun5B9Txmww.review_text: Scoma's is one of our special occasion restaurants. Ordered my favorite seafood Louie salad today and was a little disappointed to see it stashed for ten minutes in the busser's station while waiting for my husband's order to come out. All those dirty dishes piled next to my salad was a little unappetizing.

dcjrPcU-q7sxF0L_E1YqdA.review_text: Very attentive wait staff and fresh seafood. Sand dabs were delicious!  A bit overpriced, but really enjoyed our meal. The decor is outdated, but it works.

nvQGyze0HQxstrgQqJ2k8A.review_text: Food was mediocre (greasy) and way to expensive for the quality. My wife ordered the special (Halibut with Polenta) the Halibut was dry and the Polenta overcooked. Not very special. My dish, Sole with Penne was greasy and the Penne was of the lowest quality and to aldente. Overheard a couple behind us complaining to the manager. They too were disappointed with the food that evening. The only thing I really enjoyed was my draft Stella and the fresh bread from the bakery around the corner which is the reason for the 2nd star. As far as I am concerned this is a tourist trap and nothing more. Will not dine here again period

aEcbA9rgeGM7Bb473-BlqQ.review_text: It just does not get any better. This is the very best food on Fisherman's Wharf, or Sausalito for that matter. The service is highly professional in all aspects, from the maître d'hôtel, to the bus boy the entire staff operates at an avante garde of culinary excellence. You can count on a long wait to get inside, and that speaks volumes about them. Fortunately a quick stroll of the pier to look at the boats or sea lions helps the time to pass quickly, or a drink at the bar. The cioppino is not to be topped by anyone anywhere, period, so don't let the price scare you, you will get your monies worth, I guarantee it. I forgot to tell you, it is hidden up an alley out on the water, so you have to put yourself out a little to find it.

VFgHy8C8EYpxd5_EcmlMag.review_text: Came here on my boyfriends birthday, had made a reservation a week in advance noting that. The hostess sat us and said happy birthday but it wasn't acknowledged by our server at all, disappointing. On top of that, my lobster was overlooked and tough. All the side dishes were no good, cold pasta with no sauce or any seasoning, bad veggies looked like they were cooked out of a frozen pre packaged bag. You could find way better places in San Fran.  The wasabi fried oysters were good though.

yPeC8x0NXSih2-oSqBWFQA.review_text: Food was about average; the ambience is great for a couple if you want to kill time or have nothing to do. The wait wasn't bad however, nothing else was worth waiting for.  We had a group of ten and they just weren't accommodating as we expected. When the meal came, we played alot of 'that's not what I ordered' game. We were crammed in this little room like sardines; oh yea did I mention it was actually roasting hot in there!  I'd say don't knock yourself out on this one. There's other places to go worth your while.

FDMl5am0sisi1n7mR7hvzA.review_text: Just went back a few weeks ago, hadn't been here in years.  During the week it is easy to park in the street since it is winter.  We had cocktails first, this is appropriate here and then had wonderful seafood entrees.  Our waiter was terrific and the food was good.   Loved the old time feel of the place, it is one of the few decent waterfront restaurants left in this town that has not become terribly expensive or trendy.   Thank the gods.   Give me my martini and a basket of sourdough.

c2gSfgFQcR3k_USm228DZg.review_text: Tucked away from the main drag, is this spot. Really fresh dungeness crab and soft sourdough bread. Ordered the crab sandwich with salad and fries. Service is friendly.

vQqX5xI6rrtzdeVKt1knIQ.review_text: This place is Super Duper Tasty! There is a party in your mouth with every bite you take of anything you order in here, YUMMY!!!! Thank you yelp for helping me find this amazing place!

WRLPpHbEBjgf160n5pfdoQ.review_text: We were looking to find a good seafood spot around Fisherman's Warf trying to avoid chain restaurants or over the top trendy & pricey places. A friend told us try out Scoma's, they have been there forever and continue to add on due to great business.  My wife and I split the salad, some oysters, and the Shellfish Saute.  it was all great.  They did not have saltines for the Oysters but they were fresh and good enough to have out of the shell. The prices are not cheap but good value for great seafood and what little you might save at a chain is not worth it.  Live Life !!!

jFnmh5tfjLJFBiG7rMg5yg.review_text: When searching for 'best crab in SF',Scoma's comes up. Be advised that this is not a place for a hearty lunch in your sightseeing clothes. Although the ambiance was similar to that of a wood paneled 60's ranch looking out on an industrial park.we felt out of place. This is more of a planned dinner destination. The wait staff was professional and the food was good. My bf started with clam chowder which he loved, my lobster bisque tasted tomato-y and not at all of lobster. We ordered the cold seafood platter which had two oysters , 4 pieces of dungeness and 4 shrimp that were all delicious.  Pricey and the raw clams were iffy.   Def recommend coming  not on a whim

xkLRTaTDoZr20Lk-kKp18Q.review_text: food was below average.  wait staff was miserable.  too stuffy for me and the food wasn't worth it.  So many other places to eat.  don't eat here

a_2gCpEv6AeQNw4TJDiFjA.review_text: Oh Scoma's...My love... my mistress. You are truly on an unmatched level in just about every area in fine dining in the city. This is one of my favorite restaurants ever - let alone just the Wharf. If you are headed to the wharf in search of seafood and happen to pass up Scoma's... shame on you. You have committed a food sin, and your palette will be punished. Don't even stop at Guardino's for a crab cake before hand. Tempting as it is, you are going to need to save every inch of space inside your stomach for what's in store.  Well what is in store you ask?  How about waterside dining? Not that the interior of the restaurant in all it's beauty should be ignored, but when you have giant windows to look outside at the swaying fishing boats...it's hard to look else where. It is also placed a bit away from the main street, so the big eyed tourist and crazies won't bother you. That said, this place does have a lot of tourist in it, but who cares. The locals come here too. When the food is this good, everyone hears about it.  The service at Scoma's is just as excellent as its location. The waiters/waitresses are both extremely knowledgeable and friendly. I've had many different servers during my visits and every time I felt the same wisdom and charm from each of them. They know the food is good, they love to work there, and even more importantly, they love to share the experience with you.  The menu is pretty daunting, but you can't go wrong here. That is unless you are one of "those types" and order a hamburger or something. If that's the case, head next door to the N and Out. But if you have some sense in you and want some of the best seafood in the city, here are some of my favorite items to help you out:  Depending on your party size, you're going to want to start out with either a cup of the Lobster Bisque or the Hot Appetizer Sampler Plate.   After that, the MUST HAVE item that someone in your party has to get (but warn them that once others try it that they might not be getting much), is the Shellfish Sautee. Remember these words - Shellfish Sautee. Write it on your hand if need be - but for the love of god, remember to order this. The Shellfish Sautee.  Another top notch thing to get is the Cioppino. Serving about 2-3 people, the Cioppiano is pretty massive, but so is its deliciousness.  Other than these must haves, the other seafood options are bound to be fantastic as well.   Enjoy!

ar_UdO8bU_jknaXSM6ytNw.review_text: We found Scoma's on Yelp and not disappointed. The Seafood we had fresh oyster, Garlic Dungeness crab, Sand Dab Fish, and clam chowder are really fresh and tasty. good sourdough as well. Our server "Lillian" is knowledgeble in the menu list, and helpful. We all enjoy the food, service, and our trip to the Fisherman's Wharf.

tMT6ICot_b1cAeZPvG7JxQ.review_text: We came to Scoma's on a recent trip to SF to visit family, and wanted to try some local seafood. They suggested this place - so we figured if the locals thought it was good - it's probably pretty solid.   It's definitely really old-school - both in terms of the atmosphere and the food. The service was great, they helped us navigate a somewhat vague food menu. The food was also really good. My scallops were outstanding, but my prawns were a bit dry. Everyone else at my table really enjoyed their meals as well. One person we were with - who is originally from SF - swears by the Cioppino and made all of us try it. It's HUGE, and despite four people trying bites, and her giving it her all, she still took a boatload home.   It's pretty pricey, but it feels like one of those classic, old-school seafood restaurants that you have to try. Why change if it's still good, right?

W-k23QYJjbWmieyH6sWAMw.review_text: WOW! SCOMASSSSSS!!!!!!   You have made me a fan. A fannnnnnn. I can't wait to come back. With complimentary parking. You're a winner already! Who likes looking for parking at the wharf? Geez... that's the reason why I never go! Not at Scomas! Scomas does comp parking! Just gotta tip the guy... but shoot... still a deal if you ask me!  They have a prefix deal as well... and it's very well rounded. They have a big variety and choices to pick from. However, all 4 members of our party got the lobster bisque and lobster salad for appetizer... and that's all we still talk about!  It was theeeeeeeeeeeeeee best lobster bisque I've had. And I had lobster bisque in Boston.. where the lobster is fresh! And no. this still wins hands down. Hands and feet down. Throughout the night.. all 4 of us couldn't wait to burp so we could taste that creamy slightly mild lobster bisque again!   The entree was suuuuuper delicious... and dessert was great as well!  I truly have found a new seafood stop for me in SF. And I am super picky being in the culinary field of my options.   Come to Scoma's and get the Lobster Bisque and you will die and go to heaven and not want to return. PROMISE.

HZWazB3ytabge9E5YKmRoQ.review_text: I used to live in the Bay Area/SF and I'd always make a trip here once a month or at least whenever I'm up to visit. My Expectations were surpassed, not only by the food, but the service as well.  Though the price points are fairly higher, you definitely get what you pay for. San Fran is known for it's great restaurants and though the destination is a little hidden off of the tourist run Fishermans Wharf, it's worth the wait in traffic and anxiety from those lacking the driving skills to maneuver through a city. I highly recommend the Crab Louie Salad and the clam chowder.

nL2lx_DKWp0QTJ1t17dATg.review_text: Love the atmosphere and the food was great - perfect portions.   The staff is EXCELLENT. From the host to the waiter, everyone in the restaurant was friendly, informed and genuinely very nice. They were very nice to my kids and the children's meals are actually very generous. Loved the fact our waiter was so nice when my son asked for shredded cheese on his french fries!  Also, you can't beat the location on a small pier on the water. Gorgeous.

XSs6zVmiwH_r5D5QQ7b-sw.review_text: I cannot believe people wil wait 30, 40, 60 minutes to eat here.  We had a reservation, were seated 35 minutes late, and sorry, the food  is NOT good enough to justify any sort of wait. We  had a fantastic server who single-handedly saved the evening, but the hostess-on-a-power-trip was just awful to deal with.  No explanation, certainly no apology.  Just a sour, smug blemish on our celebratory evening.  We will not be back.  Life is too short, and San Francisco is too wonderful to waste on this outdated and grossly over-rated restaurant.

s2mC8x80m86Vzs62Z8fbHA.review_text: We decided to give this place a try since it had 4 stars...  I'm quite disappointed at the service we received here. The waiter took forever to come and acknowledge that we sat down. He brought water with him but took forever to bring out the beverages we asked for. He even forgot to bring an alcoholic beverage that we ordered.  We finally knew what we wanted to order so we placed it. 2 whole crabs, halibut, calamari, lazy man ciopinno, clam chowder and a ceasar salad.  When my brother said he wanted the whole crab and then ordered the halibut the waiter said so you don't want the whole crab?? And we all looked at him crazy!  My brother said he wanted both and the waiter said oh that a lot of food and told us the market price for the crab, making us feel like we couldn't afford it or something.... This guy was pissing us off! Maybe because he serviced the Caucasian people a lot faster then he did us brown folk!  Everything took forever to come out!!! Our drinks were empty and our waiter was nowhere to be found!  The food was honestly mediocre... The ciopinno is nothing fancy at all. For our bill being $230 for only 3 of us wouldn't have been bad if the waiter didn't take so long! We still left him a decent tip even though he made us feel like we weren't worthy to dine here.  I usually go to Pompei's Grotto which is a lot better and the service is amazing!! The food is also better in flavor than Scoma's.

p17RL64aEv2u0-rM8Rnjzg.review_text: Whenever I'm in Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco, I make it a point to stop at Scoma's. Mainly because the food is decent and the parking is convenient. You can drive right up to the restaurant and valet your car which sure beats parking in the public lot. We were craving fresh caught crab, but apparently the crabbers are negotiating prices with the buyers.The crab and consumer is caught in the middle, well maybe lucky for the crab because they get to live a little while longer until the two sides agree on a price. We had to settle for flash frozen crab from Alaskan waters. The crab was sautéed in a scrumptious garlic-olive oil sauce that just begged to be sopped up with the chewy, tangy sourdough bread that they give out. Waiters are efficient and honest. I like that they don't try to oversell the most expensive item on the menu.

v4bqDR4Mi70VtYRRGaoSyg.review_text: Scoma's. This place is a landmark of landmarks for San Franciscans. It's been here for over fifty years, and as an older friend of mine who grew up here says, it hasn't changed the entire time. It's on Fisherman's Wharf, but it's not ON the Wharf... you have to know where it is in order to find it. It's to the side and behind the other storefronts. It has an excellent bar, and carries some local microbrews.  Last time I was here, I went with a few friends. We sat at the bar chugging local brews while waiting for our seats--about 20 minutes total. Then our names were called and we were seated at a nice table by the window. Scoma's isn't a boat, but it feels like you're on a boat. You can look out and see the water and I'm pretty sure I can feel the restaurant rocking with the waves.  I got the Cioppino a la Pescatore (Lazy Man's). It very good. I have had better though. Scoma's Cioppino comes in a thin broth, and the amount of finfish is almost overwhelming compared with the scant amount of Clams, Scallops and Prawns. And the fish chunks are very large--you'll probably end up awkwardly cutting it with your spoon like I did. It's still very good though. We had some white wine, and I can't recall what it was--probably Sauv Blanc or Pinot Grigio. Either way, it was paired very nicely. Overall, the server was very good and took care of us without being overly attentive.  Tiramisu? You bet. And it's darn good, too. It even comes with a little tiny chocolate spoon. (I'm not sure what for... you can't eat with it, but it's a nice touch). Overall, an excellent experience.

P7Z8zXZDDrxY9P14Znjc-g.review_text: Because of Yelp's high reviews we decided to eat at Scoma's for lunch.  I ordered the Fix Petrale which was baked sole and vegetables. Included in this order was a small bowl of chowder.  The clam chowder was the best item that was served. The baked sole  was dry and  not very tasty. The vegetables were also undercooked and cold. The service was alright but not great.  I understand the chowder on the street is as good if not better than Scoma's. I wouldn't eat here again.

bztV18ThPu9_94kS4lMeRA.review_text: Hello,  My name is Shelly and my family and I have been coming to Scomas for several years.  We have always said Scomas was our favorite restaurant in the city to dine at and we would always make the drive from San Jose to San Francisco to enjoy our favorite foods and see the wonderful staff who have become friends to my family and I.  Yesterday was my Mom's 67th Birthday, so we all came to Scomas for lunch to celebrate her special day.  We found out yesterday that Scomas is not the same anymore and we are so very sad because we will not be returning.  My husband and I would always order the cioppino and yesterday we were shocked to see that the portion size was cut in half and the price remained the same.  No one in our party had the chunks of crab legs in our food like we always were served.....the crab was a small portion and shredded.  I ordered the vegetables because I have always loved your sauteed veggies and yesterday I was served grilled veggies that were horrible.  Everyone in our party was so upset to see their lunch entrees were not the same anymore.  It is very sad to know that your menu has changed and the food we have always loved for the past 20 years is no more.  It saddens us to know we will not see our favorite servers anymore.  You were like a family to us.

Q6cB7t4wHNMCK5HR8aagXA.review_text: The food was just ok, but I was expecting something amazing for all the rave reviews all the tour places gave it. They must be paid off.   My wife had lobster ravioli and it was bland. I had shellfish sec and it was still just ok. Bland.  Way overpriced for what you get. Blue mermaid was much better and cheaper.

5piB75GyRvlhCOSxfnhwWg.review_text: This place is out of its prime.... We had 4 different entrees, each for nearly $40 a pop, and all were "ok" at best. 3 of the 4 were downright disappointing. I had he "Lazy Mans Ciopinno" - I should have taken the hint. It tasted like Campbell's tomato soup with some seafood. Portions are huge, but it doesn't matter if the food isn't good.

IZYaYYP3tZXWMgw863JPBw.review_text: This place will forever and always remind me of my dad who loved their shrimp Louie so much.  I have tons of memories of meals at Scoma's every time we would fly back from the East Coast to visit family out here.  Now that I am a Bay Area resident, I couldn't wait to take my BFF here when he came to visit from Atlanta.  I hadn't been back in years, but not much has changed, and I mean that in the best of ways.  It's all still there -- the dressed up host, bartenders, servers, and staff, the view, the old school-ness of it all.  I had the calamari fritti Calabrese style to start, which was billed as being spicy but fell short of that.  It was nonetheless delicious and tender topped with tomato and onion-y good sauce.  My friend had the clam chowder, which he loved.  I had the happy fortune of choosing the "lazy man's" cioppino, which proved to be a huge, pipingly hot bowl of seafood-in-tomato-sauce goodness.  It was chock full of shrimp, scallops, clams, crab, and white fish with a hunk of good bread for sopping up the tasty sauce.  I filled up quickly and had almost a full quart of leftovers to take home!  We shared the Jack Daniels and dried cherry sourdough bread pudding with caramel sauce for dessert.  Three words:  A-MAZ-ING.  The caramel sauce was deliciously sweet and the cherries were a great addition to the bread pudding.  Once again, Scoma's earned a lifelong place in my heart.

o90ISifiq4OqOmBWTYJPdQ.review_text: This was my second time at Scomas and we're 2 for 2 here!  A little pricey but generous sized portions and good, fresh seafood. The wait staff is great, Waiman was helpful in answering any questions we had and helped pick some great wine. We showed up without a reservation and had a little wait, but its a perfect excuse to have a drink at the bar. Ask for a table by the window-you may luck out!

fn-MfiHCeO30EA_R4p_Xhg.review_text: Food is good and very well made. Just seems lacking something to me. My dad loves it and we go all the time. it's out of the way so tourists won't really find it but somehow it's always packed.

BGDIspFceI6OcvBIQIlZ0A.review_text: Went here for the cioppino based on all the reviews. Maybe it was an "off" night but I and my dining companion found the cioppino lacking in flavor and agreed that the abundant white fish in our bowls was more reminiscent of the rubbery white erasers from grade school and less like fresh seafood we so expected to have.  The service was good, friendly and attentive, but I hope my review balances out those that raved over the cioppino which like a siren song, lured us to Scoma's.

FVk12H4Cz4DkRzl8N5-PGQ.review_text: Great chowder! Expensive but was amazingly delicious. My husband had the swordfish and really enjoyed it. I had the sand dabs and was also very happy. It seems like all the signed celebrity photographs on the walls are from the baby boomer generation but the food was worth the price tag.

YWsTDtw-tSVjD0nAV_h1jw.review_text: Holy cow, what a great dining experience.  Garlic roasted dungeons crab were great, as was the Firecracker shrip and clam chowder. The service was absolutely phenomenal.  And they actually made my martini better than I would've at home!

akiwx5YXUtgVLWi3q0SlJw.review_text: Great place to eat. Take the wife and kids here every xmas - it's became a tradition. Service is always superb!

xS13aAa2HqgIiHFOvrIJXQ.review_text: This review is from my lunch experience ONLY! I gather this must be the hotspot for dinner.  High off of the best clam chowder of my life at Vivolo's Chowder House (in Pacific Grove), I was determined to find another establishment that matched. I scoured yelp high and low and came upon Scoma and decided to give it a try.  My seester and I came here just to try to the clam chowder and lobster bisque - nothing else. We wanted something light in preparation for the dinner show we were going to attend. The reviews said the lobster bisque was phenomenal, so I was excited to try it. But I didn't find it magical. The clam chowder wasn't all that either. I found both rather tasteless.   I'm sure everything else off the menu must be good. But nix the bisque and chowder.

LYu1i818sRwZIf8Atany4Q.review_text: Have been here a few times but this was our first time ordering the shellfish saute. Incredible mix of lobster, crab, shrimp, and scallops. Drinks were okay, dungeness crab cocktail was also incredible.

wE_BzyibHCASTjEpMVRq-g.review_text: I came to Scoma's to purchase one of their souvenirs.  I arrived before the dinner rush, so I hoped to run in and run out with my purchase.  When I walked in, there were a few parties waiting to be seated.  I told the person at the podium I wasn't there to dine but I wanted to purchase the olive oil dripper I had my eye on during my last visit.  He told me he would send someone out to help me.    Then...I...was...completely...ignored...by...­their...entire...staff.    The person I spoke with never made eye contact with me again.  In fact he avoided it.  I had a dinner reservation elsewhere, so I could not wait forever.    So I left empty-handed.

Qy4I6PJ2edNmremj4GlnBQ.review_text: THIS REVIEW IS FOR THE CIOPPINO!!!!!  If you are searching for the best Cioppino in California, then Scoma's is your spot!!!! This hearty bowl of seafood goodness is the best you will ever have, guaranteed!!!! I am from LA, and every time I visit the Bay Area I absolutely must have Scoma's cioppino. Try it for yourself!!

7Wsd6EZ6GQhyvvrNJSHkkA.review_text: My all time favorite place for a delicious meal at this fabulous restaurant.  My boyfriend took me in a romantic date to Scoma's.  I ordered the Cioppino and my boyfriend mixed seafood grill, as well as lobster bisque and oysters.  Fresh and wonderfully prepared.  Excellent!  And well worth the price.  I also suggest going for lunch or happy hour at the bar. They have a great selection of appetizers at more wallet friendly prices.  Love this place!

-yvTqaj9Zt603oeKTFaWng.review_text: Favorite spot when we were dating. So it was fun recently to take our girls for their first Scoma's meal. The best.   Love the kind, adorable servers in their sharp white uniforms. Seafood... yes please. We love their crab and pasta dishes. The clam chowder... all of it. Shovel it in please.  It does get crowded close to dinner time - so take a stroll while you wait. Or... do what we do - go before the dinner hour...and walk right on in.  I know there's no dress code per se - but come on...be classy.

xsj5n0v2p-_tND7q9K25ag.review_text: A very food savvy friend from Vegas recommended Scoma. It was very good! The decor is from the 70's but somehow it works. The staff are veterans and very knowledgable. We sat and had views of SF Bay while eating the freshest seafood I can remember. Good food and reasonably priced wine list. The only detraction would be that they are a busy popular spot and they want to get you in and out which had us feel a little rushed towards the end of dinner.

fjrym7CX6prOoK04eet2WQ.review_text: 3.5 stars   My family's been going to Scoma's since before I can remember. Biggest negatives about the place are the parking and the wait. They do NOT take reservations.   Also it seems that the menu's downsized quite a bit over the past few years, as well as the portions. Dishes are very expensive, but the seafood is fresh, and the sourdough bread is delicious. Keep asking for more, and eat it with the clam chowder.   We usually get the King Louie salad, the pasta diplomatica with white sauce, and the clam chowder (always get the bowl, not the cup -- only $1 more!).   They have a lunch prix-fixe for $24.95 that's a good deal. Portions are large. Order to share.

OExAE3SpYNpWL6cHNV0jPg.review_text: Went here for the first time recently, and had the best salmon I have ever had!  Seriously, worth the price for a special treat lunch or dinner out.  Unfortunately, our server was not on top of her game, so not a 5 star meal for me, but the food was fantastic.  Oh, if you go, don't forget that they have complimentary valet parking.  Otherwise, parking in that area costs way more than the tip to the valet.

eoiKkHye1DOp-TDEClLe4A.review_text: Scoma's is one of those hidden gems of San Francisco's Wharf area. If it wasn't for my dad, I would not have known this place existed. It's off the beaten path, barely visible from the street.  Based on my last visit: The service starts as soon as you drive in. I don't think I have the greatest car, but the valet guy seemed to like my Subie STi way more than the Porche Carrera which was parked right in front. He went about parking my car. When I later came outside to get something out of the car, I noticed the Porche was moved up further and my car was closest to the door. Big ups to the valey guy!!  As you come in, you're greeted by the Maitre d'. The wait usually isn't longer than 15 minutes. Scoma's is a fairly large restaurant. The bar is to the left of the Maitre d' podium, so I usually grab a quick drink before being seated. Last time, my father and I didnt even have a chance to take a sip and they were already calling our name for the table.   We were seated in one of the back dining rooms with great views of the pier. You can watch local fisherman dock up and unload their daily catch. You could not ask for a better backdrop when you're about to enjoy some seafood!  I usually always order the Swordfish at Scoma's. You can order it blackened or Cajun stylye. The cajun style is the best in my opinion. The seasoning goes great with the fish. Each plate comes with a generous serving of veggies and your choice of a potato or rice pilaf. My dad swears by the Cioppino. It has a whole array of seafood all mixed up in a tomato based soup.  Did I mention they serve endless supplies of SF Sourdough bread as an appetizer??   Scoma's is a great place for a good lunch or a nice date. I try to always make a stop when I'm in the city and don't have any eating plans.

JqHQMojDCOsLWSAtVkIJiQ.review_text: This restaurant came highly recommended and it did not disappoint. The wait staff seated us quickly and were patient as we reviewed the extensive menu. The food was deliciously excellent. The fish dishes were cooked to perfection. The tables were a bit too close for comfort as the place was packed. Reservations are highly recommended.

pn37BspOeuIvDtp1S4xbBw.review_text: YUM YUM YUM! The seafood pasta, I forgot the exact name but it has two mini lobters in it. AHH.. to die for. Fat ass portions, good for two. This place hits the spot when you are hungry. It's expensive but it's worth the price. The crab and calamari are great too.  The service is superb! The servants know what they are talking about when I asked for suggestions on what to order.  Two Thumbs Up!

vjcX3R3oSWASn5ge18KzGw.review_text: Wonderful seafood!  Ordered Cioppini and a shellfish which included rice pasta and veggies.  The food was absolutely wonderful.  A bit pricey, so I expected a more updated environment but I'm assuming they wanted to keep with the boat theme.  It would be nice if they made it a bit more spacious, it seems a little cramped.  Long wait to be seated but once seated it wasn't long for the food to come out.  I wouldn't mind going again.

rEBYbz6q2XXwNhzHZsBoKQ.review_text: Recently visited Scoma with friends in town from Europe.  Excellent meal.  Joey the waiter provided great service and enhanced the dining experience with his personal touch and recommendations.  Definitely recommend and will be back next time in SF

vKZocUdzyTfNH7yDjeKZeQ.review_text: Free complementary parking (+tip) is best.  Food: 3 Service: 4.5 Atmosphere: 3 (touristy)  Value: 2  It's a great place to take out of town visitors if they are into touristy stuff.   Food isn't too bad but not worth of price you are paying for.  Scenery? Well? It's beautiful if you are from where cow roam around where you live. There's no exposure to the bay...just a small docking area.

gBgQPUil0lYyOcBsMwebvw.review_text: Not bad..but not great. A bit over priced and super old school. The oyster sampler was good.

rmwyZXSoyjIgw_q18bzjjA.review_text: Very classy and very fresh. Valet parking is awesome.   Scoma has been around for a while and still standing strong. With fresh seafood, great service, and appropriate pricing.. I see why.   For the appetizers, we started off with half a dozen raw oysters. There were 3 varieties and 2 of each kind. It was a cool way of trying out different types of oysters to see which ones we like best so that we can order more of that kind.   I had the the wild caught king Salmon and it was divine. The outside has been seared nicely and the inside was pink. Served with some mashed potatoes and seasonal veggies, its a winner's dish. I can really taste the freshness of the salmon.   My partner in crime had the pasta with the little clams and holy jebus there was a lot of clams. We counted at least two and a half dozens of clams in that pasta.. which wasn't a bad thing. The juice of the clams imparted a lot of flavor that the pasta soaked up which was just great.

7w3wy6oBwre3Bilc1cTOEw.review_text: Go here for your authentic local San Franciscan night out.  Recommended to us by one of the locals, my husband and I were so glad... I repeat SO GLAD we decided to eat here for dinner. The wait was about one hour for a table of two . We enjoyed conversation with our bartender. We did not mind. However, if you are the type that does....then I recommend doing a reservation. Awesome 1960's vibe.  Feels like you've stepped back in time. Now, I'm SUPER into that sort of thing. If you are uppity & wanting something super modern ...... steer clear of this place because you will give a buzz kill to everyone else attending this beloved establishment.

kYlL3EGY_YtiYjsoODBUpw.review_text: I went here knowing full-well of Scoma's reputation of being a tourist trap being in the middle of the Wharf but who cares?  They serve Dungeness crab and that's all I needed to know.    I had a very pleasant and positive experience here.  I was walking around the area and stopped by to check out their menu and hours and ran into a couple who gave me a hint about arriving really early to avoid the crowds since they don't take reservations.  They apparently are very faithful customers.  Well, I heeded their advice and thank gawd I did.  We arrived about 5:15 and there was already a line.  By 6pm, there was such a massive crowd and an awful wait, I couldn't even imagine had we arrived later what the wait would have been.   What's the deal with no reservations anyhow?!  The ambiance is surprisingly very cozy and intimate, once you leave the waiting area and go into the actual dining area.  We didn't feel cramped at all.  It also has quite a nice view which added to the ambiance.  The food was awesome!  We had the calamari which was literally a taste explosion in my mouth.  Geezuz, that was seriously some of the best calamari I've ever had (sorry Loca Luna in Atlanta!).   I, unsurprisingly, had the HUGE Dungeness crab.  My buddy had to sit there and wait for me to finish it.   That monster was massive and delicious and hit all the right spots in my tummy.    Service was exceptional.  Our server, Bruce, was extremely friendly and good-natured.  He knew the menu inside and out and was very efficient throughout the evening even with the restaurant being super busy.  It was obvious he took pride in his job and did it well.  Kudos to Bruce!  All in all, I'd definitely come back here.  It'll just be with the early birds.

uRdmfjer9cTfYLmP0ky93A.review_text: very good pasta / seafood combinations.  You can change your sauce if you prefer a different one.  staff is very knowledgeable and helpful. calculate a 40 min wait even on a Monday night if you don't have a reservation

SKgxEbarnBIEn3POYrzS7g.review_text: One of the best seafood restaurants at Fisherman's Wharf. The Lobster Bisque and Cioppinos were outstanding and the service was fast and very accommodating. We recommend it to all our friends. It can be very busy at times so we go during the week, not on weekends.

N8y88JlpXyOrDIDEKkQDGA.review_text: Meh. Pretty forgettable. Ordered catch of the day scallops and filet mignon, both dishes were bland. They tasted fine but we were hoping for a little more effort or creativity with the cooking. Too expensive to not be wowed.

zb2fInenB8EvJiimC8n2sw.review_text: If you can fight through the tourists and score the kitchen on a "good" day, then Scomas is a four star spot. But for every time I've had a four star experience here I've had two three stars. Big portions of pastas and seafood, but if it's busy the food feels rushed, like it's thrown together. I've had great meals like the crab linguine and crab louie salad, I've had awful meals like their mahi-mahi and seafood pastas.  It's worth checking out once, or if you have visitors in town that MUST see Pier 39, but otherwise there are better places to check out.

s3bY53dDTJomRRusjsRwcA.review_text: 2nd time in San Fran, 2nd time at Scomas. Ridic amazing perfect clam chowder, literally headed straight there when I got to the city. Such a great location and classic feel to the place, overlooking the bay the fish were caught in while you eat. Chowder is incredibly spiced and I smile the entire time I eat it haha go get some

GaOAj-hzkiV6bDEJszLCPQ.review_text: Husband brought me here for my birthday! It was sooooo good!  We had a bowl of clam chowder.  The waitress asked if we were sharing and she brought us two cups of clam chowder.  Got the appetizer combo and it was good! I got the seafood stir fry dish and man was it big.  There was so much seafood and it was so yummy! Husband got pasta and it ws pretty good.   We ordered this non-alcoholic wine and we want it again! It was so good! It was $16 for non-alcoholic but would definitely get it again!!  Will come back!!!

7fH5EOeSEnQxRf4evoNeZA.review_text: Spent our family dinner here and had a delightful time. The service is friendly, and the food is absolutely delicious. It may look like an ordinary small restaurant by the bay, but the interior is as if I'm on a nice ship. You could definitely come dressed casually but the atmosphere allows you to go dressed up as well.

oToWv_fWchGa20Y1Ro3J2Q.review_text: Loved this place! Had the DUNGENESS CRAB LOUIS, CLAM CHOWDER, & PRAWNS ANNUZZI and loved it all! The coffee there is pipping hot and delish!   For dessert, i had the Spumoni. It was OK. Not the best :/   I wish I could live closer  to Scoma's but I promised myself to give it a visit every time I come back to SF.   Warning: It is a tad bit pricey. BUT I didnt order off the lunch menu as I hate fix menus. My order alone (foods i listed) cost about $80 but it was money well spent!

4oACTtCJkVG8pgs5S5NV6g.review_text: I have been going to Scoma's for almost 10 years.  It is never a let down.  As a native San Franciscan, it carries its' share of both nostalgia and touristy bits all at the same time.  It's classic bar, with bartender's wearing black vests and crisp white shirts helps turn back the hands of time.  The wait staff, and their no frills attitude lets the food stand on its' own.  I have been with friends, my partner, and my mom over the years and had the lion share of the menu.  The prix fixe menu is the only thing I have not had.  The valet parking is awesome, and if not, it is a very short walk from street parking.  If you are in the city, and want a non-pretentious eating establishment with great food, then please visit Scoma's.  One thought though, there is no reservations taken, so have a drink or two at the bar, you'll be fine  :-)

RpC1JbCcl7iMUWosF5EsWg.review_text: Lobster bisque was amazing and so were the crab cakes. Great location on pier with a great atmosphere. Not ridiculously expensive.

3Wwf7byw8fq_ew_MA1xzzA.review_text: Based on all the hype and reviews, Scoma's was a complete let down.    Let's star t with the location, on an old pier at the end of Fisherman's Wharf.  Located down a little alley, with a terrible view - on one side is a view of another wharf and a bunch of junky old fishing boats.  On the other side is the fish processing shack and a view of another pier and some cars in the parking lot.  Inside the building, the rooms are small....cut up, and the celings low.  A lot of old pictures on the walls.  The tables are so close together that you not only bump the people next to you, but you have to listen to their conversations all night.    Prices are HIGH.....they don't justify what you get.    Menu is extensive and confusing......some very strange selections.    We were all 'pleased' with our food, but nobody was really that excited.    The drinks were 'small'......and over priced.   Anyway, can you tell where this is going.......Scoma's is not that great, not a place we would go again, and was a pretty big disappointment.  With all the choices in San Fran, we're sure we can find a better value and more creative menu somewhere else.

RIjYnor7g7hk7AGsi1mWqw.review_text: Seafood This is the place to go in SF.  All the food is fresh and great.  You will get your fill of Seafood whatever you order.   The clam chowder is as good as it is going to get.  lots of Seafood.    Price Around $25 which is about right for seafood.

m3f1x02-81PfN-3LnIzOlg.review_text: Lazy men's cioppino is the best!!  I LOVE our server, he's probably in his 60s, looking like an italian mafia in Godfather. He know everything on the menu, every wine on the list, and built a delicious, perfectly paced meal for us.  Picky parents were happy, so was I.

B4hUj7DsgbHcckJ3Yl2FFQ.review_text: If you consider yourself a foodie tourist, be sure you take the extra little hike to Scoma's. You won't be disappointed, and you will avoid the less educated tourists wasting their time and money by the seafood shacks closer to the Fisherman's Wharf tourist traps.  Went here for lunch on a Friday. The lobster bisque rivals the best I've had in Boston. The flavor is perfect, not too creamy, not salty at all. Just fresh lobster goodness. I also tried the Grilled Tuna Steak sandwich. It was moist, and tasted super fresh. My companions had the Cioppino. It was the best I have ever tried. The broth was sweet from the tomatoes, but the natural seafood flavor added just the right amount of flavor without once making me think it was salty. Everything was cooked perfectly. The scallops had that snap and texture that is the mark of true freshness. Wow.  Our server Sean was great, very friendly and welcoming. In fact, the entire waitstaff here is all over the place (in a very good way), always attentive to the customers.  My only regret is that I got full. They have a great wine and draught beer selection as well.  Don't be a tourist, go to Scoma's!

MZuvl0oUK3QSv7faGx9i5w.review_text: We stopped in for a meal after passing a sign for this place on Jefferson Street. You'll need to walk/drive down an alleyway to get here. Don't mind the raccoons that live in the alley, they are as afraid of you as you are of them.  I started to see a trend that if you walk into any restaurant that has been opened for any length of time on the bay, it will be known as a "tourist trap." This is another one of those places. Tourist trap or not, it wouldn't still be open if the food wasn't good. I didn't identify where everyone was from in the place, so from a qualified standpoint I can say it was busy without the known tourist status of the visitors.  The place appears small, but deceitfully seats more people than you'd expect.  We sat at the bar and had their Seahorse cocktail, in other circles this would be known as a Moscow Mule in glassware. The drinks were refreshing and our bartender was extremely helpful during our visit.  From the menu, my fiancée ordered a cup of the clam chowder and the dungeoness crab cocktail. She said both were excellent. I had the dungeoness crab risotto. It is served in a generous portion and is a tasteful mixture of vegetables, crab, and risotto.  For those with gluten intolerance, the menu has an asterisk next to the options that are safe for you.  Scoma is a great seafood restaurant that is worth a visit if you're in the area!

hfZn7un8OZoT6B8JRTlMSA.review_text: If you are wanting wonderful cioppino on the wharf with a sunset view, this is the place.   The cioppino was full of delicious seafood and had a broth worth sopping up with the sourdough rolls.  Service was friendly and fast.

_UlHec4GXUpNkYIXoWTkMg.review_text: Everything here is manna from heavan. Food is some of the best on SF. NOBODY makes clam chowder like this. Ciopinno is a religious experience. All the fish is fresh and perfct. There is NOTHING you can go wrong with ordering. Its a San Francisco tradition, a favorite of locals who shun the more touristy spots. TRY THIS PLACE. YOU WILL BE GLAD YOU DID

_s8WSfOQcQBbrMseusEweA.review_text: I had high regards for this place, it was a total let down. I'm not sure what all the good reviews are about, but to me the plate my wife and I had was just an awful mess. We had their signature dish Scoma's Sautés. It was haphazardly slapped together, all of the seafood was over cooked and lacked any real flavor. This place seems to rest on it's laurels, do your self a favor and try some place else. By the way it's small, extremely busy and very crowded to the point of suffocating.

yzus_OrSfGNdmVYmOTcfBw.review_text: Good food, good location. Beautiful view.  Had discussed several different options near our Fisherman's Wharf hotel, and finally decided on Scoma's after reviewing our options on Yelp. It was my husband's birthday during our visit to SF and this was a great choice. We were a party of 3 adults and 3 kids and everyone was happy with their meals. Service was very good.  I'm holding back 1 star because the place needs an upgrade. The menu could be updated a bit and the decor/ambience could be improved a lot. It would take this place over the top especially in the location they're in.

meKdJ1NunUhcR2ezjlEHXw.review_text: Great food! Awful service. Our waitress kept forgetting us. She also brought out the wrong salad order and was not clear on the "special". We were seated next to some very drunk couples who were so loud we could not talk to each other.

ew9IiI39GyH2vGyVhKSqaw.review_text: Best Tiramisu ever ! Drooollll The seafood was very fresh.On the expensive side. The menu had great variety.  The ambience is a little on the quieter side, with lots of senior citizens.Our server was very sweet and helpful . I have to try the lobster ravioli next time .

YdDbRhI1PS18MMttxQTVjA.review_text: This not only one of the best restaurants in San Francisco, it's one of the best restaurants I've ever been to!  It's a nice place right down by the water kind of hidden among the touristy Fisherman's Wharf.  I was here for lunch and the dress was pretty casual.  The wait staff was very friendly and helpful in explaining the menu and any special they happen to be offering. Their seafood is amazingly good.  Their bisque is the best you will ever have.

Upg5HRyeAxJtNT7P2PDavA.review_text: Hands down best Seafood I've ever had.  Also, best restaurant experience I ever had. It was extremely packed but the dozens of waiters in white tuxedos kept the wine flowing and the courses coming. First time I had lobster tail and I am now addicted.   It's a great place by the water, very classy, VERY busy (elbow to elbow in the bar area and almost like that in the dining room), and did a great job keeping our 14 person group happy.  5 STARS!

I2htluZX8zFT28zyZxUBcw.review_text: I feel like saying it's expensive is just obvious and a waste of time so let's move on. We got the Calamari appetizer and then split two different pasta dishes between three of us. One Alfredo and one red sauce seafood pasta that were both completely worth the money. On top of which the service and our waiter in particular was fantastic. We even ended the night in a group hug.

WF1o6AyXm6-NovD5dFnMOg.review_text: Hidden at the deep end of a pier, Scoma's is a shrine to the sea.  Behind the tourist curtain of Fisherman's wharf, the easy to miss alley leading to this secret is an enchanting trip down history.   Fishing boats sway on either side, as the Gates leading to the bay provide a spectacular backdrop.  Similar to Tadich, Scoma's has a staff that is as much a part of the institution as the food. Old humor, quick sarcasm, and a hefty laugh; these guys will put you in your place, leave you with a smile, and age better than wine.  The night started out with a dozen oysters and steamed mussels. Horse radish with ammo will clear your nostrils, but the oysters would have it no other way.  The family was on a Dungeness crab kick, while I ventured with the famous Scoma's Shellfish Saute.  This dish is a monster.  It's as if the Chef seasoned the sea, took a scoop of it and delivered it to you.  Prawns, scallops, chunks of crab and 2 lobster tails adorn the plate. All resting on a bed of rice and pasta that will leave your stomach feeling like it just left the gym. You want seafood. The answer's right here.  Scoma's is a gem, and another great find within the soul of our great city. Just when you think you know SF, it'll teach you a lesson to never stop looking.

Wmh9vK9LX-sxeuTb6vzM2A.review_text: Scoma's is one of the rare places where I've had an expensive meal and thought it was definitely worth it. Granted, I've been twice and didn't pay either time but it was still really good, some of the best cooked seafood I've ever had. Service is a bit slow but this is the kind of place you want to have a long meal at anyway. This was apparently my grandmother's favorite restaurant back in the day and I can see why.  The Oysters Rockefeller are amazingggg. I normally don't love this dish as much as I do here. So, so tasty. Crab stuffed mushroom is also a favorite.  The first time I came here I had the Alaskan Halibut Siciliana, which was perfectly cooked and so flavorful.   The second time had the Mixed Shellfish Sautee and Oh my goodness was that amazing. It comes with prawns, scallops, crab meat and lobster - ridiculous amounts and again cooked perfectly. Well worth the price. This dish was huge and delicious.   I've also tried (through people that I was eating with) the Lobster Ravioli, Prawns and Scallops Alla Gannon and the steamed clams platter. Not to be repetitive but all were amazing as well.   Pro tip: go later if you can, at ~9:30 pm. They don't take reservations and for obvious reasons this place is crazy popular but by this time it seems like there's not really a wait. Tried it out on a Thursday and a Saturday.

NybkJNwr7Hn6wagoL9BIFg.review_text: Our party really enjoyed the risotto and the lobster ravioli. Friendly and attentive service. The view and decor are sort of old fishing dock quaint. I would return to try a catch of the day.

rxi66uVFxghqaO6qu3DWDA.review_text: "I need to have crab legs and clam chowder while we are here in SF!" exclaimed my beautiful wife. Alrighty Yelp, be my guide, help me find the way! Hmmm, The Fanciscan Crab Restaurant at Fisherman's Wharf looks like prospect. Made reservations, headed out to Fisherman's Wharf, parked in the main lot like an idiotic tourist and walked to The Franciscan or so we thought. "The dumb GPS says it's right here!" There was nothing there, just an alley. The GPS lied, Yelp lied! We kept walking and lo and behold, Scoma's!  We had no reservations, but lucky for us, they seated us really quickly.   I ordered the Prix Fixe Menus: starter of a small cup of clam chowder and a small side of caesar salad=5 entree of Blackened Prawns over Pasta Vodka; Brown Rice Penne Pasta, Pancetta, Tito's Vodka Sauce=5 desert of vanilla ice cream and warm brownie=5  My wife ordered 1/2 a crab, guess what? She ended up eating half my food! If you go on a date, guys, make sure you order the whole crab and pretend that you're Diamond Jim, you'll impress her, but in actuality she won't be eating your food!

L43BT3hd0QuVWqA5kPqVJQ.review_text: Nice old school feel and great service from  the veteran waiting staff. The food was delicious, you'll certainly pay a premium for this place but it's worth it.  Started with the grilled artichoke and steamed clams, both very tasty. Entree the balsamic crusted salmon (something along those lines), it was perfectly cooked and just the right portion.

MSRq1PRc0HBHjSH5SlaFmQ.review_text: This place is the only reason I ever wade through tourists down at Fisherman's Wharf... well, this and for the occasional In-And-Out burger.   Everything I've ever had on the menu was delicious, except I had the swordfish once, and it was too dense for my liking. All time favorite things to get: the crab cakes, the clam chowder, and the lobster bisque. They also have a good lunch special where you get an app, main course, and dessert- I don't remember the price, but it's a good deal. Portions are large. Mmmm, my mouth is watering just thinking about Scoma's.   Try it. You won't be disappointed.

3hJTWVOWYB0b9x9PKffNVQ.review_text: Very overrated. We're from out of town and were counting on Yelp to get us to the best restaurant in town. 4 stars for Scoma's is very deceiving. It's not terrible, but it is a far cry from great. It is mediocre seafood that is overpriced. Pick somewhere else!!

U7YCRdXHUKvaS0iT1hvq0w.review_text: I have been waiting to eat at Scomas - heard so much about it.  I and two of my friends were in the City with friends Wednesday 1-15-14.  We were all excited to try the food!   We arrived about 6:30pm and were seated after about 45 minutes.  We were seated in an alcove at a table that would have nicely seated 2 people however with 3 in our party, it was cramped.  The staff kept bumping into two of our party guests - a bit uncomfortable but not a deal breaker! However, the end result was that the service and kitchen was soooo slow!  Once our dinners were ordered, the dishes took forever to come out of the kitchen - the starter dishes came out about a half hour after the order was taken!  I had the Lobster Bisque - great tasting however very small portion.  And when my entree dish did come out, the pasta was cold!  I ordered the prix fixes of blackened shrimp with organic brown rice penne pasta.  3 tasty but small shrimps - Really??!!  After I shared with my two other dinner partners, I had 1 shrimp - and remember, this wasn't a starter dish - it was an entree dish!  We then had dessert - I had tiramisu - extremely small portion! For spending over $200+ we felt that it was well overpriced, and coupled with  the lacking service and attention, we thought the experience was very disappointing.  Sadly, we could not recommend this restaurant.

_C_SRY9VLivoYHReKbaaAQ.review_text: Cioppino was good but clams were as sandy as I've ever had (extremely unappetizing and disappointing). Told the waiter and got a scoop of unwanted ice cream as "compensation"...hard to recommend it after that.   Had a few bites of the risotto which seemed average to me.   The fried calamari appetizer was probably the best dish overall, but nothing remarkable or extremely memorable (you cant serve it with anything better than cocktail sauce and tartar sauce?).  The place has potential and I'm not shocked others like it, but based on my experience, I wouldn't personally recommend it.

53ZHvp6xgqNQxcmssYEYEQ.review_text: Delicious fresh seafood! Valet parking is free and you're on the water. While it is a little pricey, you get what you pay for because the food, service, and environment is great. The jumbo prawns and scallops are some of the most fresh and large I've ever had. I've always left satisfied.

vAS046IKV1teS_SQ_VFsZg.review_text: Just sat at the bar for dinner. Spent over 120.00 service sucked had to ask for water utensils etc. Bottom line poor. I am shocked how bad the experience was. Inventory was more important than the customer!!!! Been coming here for 30 years may be the last time!!!

3138MStlsCBZUlQHIZjbPQ.review_text: This is a tourist trap. They have excellent service, funky ambiance, and ludicrous location. On the other hand, the food, while fresh, is not up to par to the price. I paid thirty some dollars for the swordfish lunch and I got a soggy fillet which was half grilled and half finished in the oven (a bit overcooked probably becaue the amount of food they have to move), and mashed potatoes and boiled veggie medley that you probably can find at walmart in the frozen section. Same thing with three other entrees...good seafood, really poor execution, and questionalble sides. C'mon guys, for the price you're asking for I should be getting a little more attention...I don't wanna think about the dinner prices...  For the same money, you can have amazing three course dinner a little up the hill.  Recommendation: no way...you can look a bit more and find ten-times better food

Zgdl_zDXb6eBtl2wXPNSuw.review_text: Scoma's was a great way to end my San Francisco vacation.  The menu changes seasonally so it'll be different every time you go. I had the Halibut with mashed potatoes and veges and it was great.   There is a wait as this restaurant is very popular, but there is a nice sized bar/lounge area where you can take in cocktails and hors d'ouvers as you await your table.

qTUJzyNeORGlT_I7zUwqEQ.review_text: My parents and I heard so much hype about how amazing this restaurant was, but were extremely disappointed.  The portions are super small but expensive. We knew this place would be pricey but we expected the food to be worth it.  We ordered the stuffed portobello mushroom and what we got was just one small portobello mushroom with barely anything in it.  I ordered a lobster salad and bisque, what I got was a tiny cup of tomato soup and a tiny clump of lobster meat. However, The entree portions were much better and cioppino was very good. But when it came time to dessert we were treated to a tiramisu inside an espresso cup. I seriously ate it in one bite it was that tiny.  I think I might have been able to over look all of this had our server not been horrible. He was very dull and unfriendly. It felt like he didn't care if we were there or not. There was another server there talking and being entertaining with all of his tables. I might have given this place 3 stars if we had him. Overall I was really excited for this restaurant but ended up leaving broke and hungry. Pretty disappointed.

QpzP2Odkk2UX_mlxeXOQzA.review_text: This place is consistently good. The cioppino is ALWAYS good. It's so large that it will feed both my bf and me and maybe even have leftovers. But no, we never do that, because how can you come to Scoma's and not get another dish? That is just absurd.  My new fav dish, only when in season from Nov-June, is the crab louie salad. A plate piled high of dungeness crab meat. Seriously, PILED HIGH. It's accompanied by some lettuce, thickly sliced and crunchy carrots, slices of tomatoes, wedges of lemon, and a thousand island dressing on the side. It's so good you won't even need the dressing.  We've been here so many times and have had a number of different items on the menu and nothing ever disappoints.   I also love that there's free valet parking (aside from what you tip) and the waiters here are all so pleasant. They are professional, friendly, and very experienced. Always a great time at Scoma's!

ztAjPFZezR1Yd7syCQp60Q.review_text: Not a seafood lover, so please take my review for a grain of salt.  I was invited to this place for dinner! We were a bit late and my buddies already swallowed 2 dozen uncooked mussles/clams (whatever the proper word is). apparently there was another 2 dozen left for us. Not raw or uncooked clam/mussle guy, I only had 2 of them.   Other things: - Rib Eye Steak! - Clam Chowder - Garlic Bread - Fish cake? (i think that's what it was) - 4 dozen clams/mussles!   Bill was $500+20%? I stuffed my self with Garlic Bread! hmmm....  I've had better Rib Eye at other places. The Clam Chowder was awesome! The Garlic Bread was the only thing filling!   Would I come back? I don't know!

hb73dpe0nk336UXLyp8YZQ.review_text: Scoma's is the best in SF. There are other great places to eat, but Scoma's feels like home. Great food, great service (ask for David) and that old charm of a place that feels like family. No better swordfish on the west coast.

wlPklTJrjf_8t_W1TmeBPg.review_text: Cool place because of its history, and place to see and be seen. Friendly serving staff even though we came in for lunch dressed extreme casual. The San Francisco Calemari Club was in for lunch that day, so it was extremely busy around the bar area as we entered. We heard that Vida Blue was among them, and a cute old couple (definitely regulars) were brought an autographed baseball from Vida. They were striking up conversation with the servers like they were old friends. Our server told us she was one of the new ones, only been there thirteen years. Definite charm to this San Francisco institution. The french bread was amazing, of course. Our server recommended the crab louie that had crab fresh off their boat. I got the shrimp/crab Louie lunch that came with a cup of clam chowder. Great chowder. A large amount of food in the Louie, but more that a couple bites had me fishing crab shell out of my mouth. That nuisance knocked down a star on this review. My wife got the clams, and she loved them. The price knocked off another star. Fun to go here, but we will likely try other restaurant options the next time in the area.

Kg_uuwTYqmyhIWMdjkYALQ.review_text: Service was a bit substandard for caliber of restaurant (cold hostess who erased our name on wait list, overly cutesy but not attentive waitress) except for support staff (busboys and water refill guys were superb!) wait was much longer than quoted and option of sitting In secondary bar was not shared by hostess. But, alas, food was absolutely stupendous!  The cioppino was out of this world!  Sand Dabs good, too, but green bean side needed to be steamed a few more minutes (too raw for this hot dish)

sAkKh8gOo2fW1qRy2eAp-A.review_text: Fantastic dinner here (August 2012)! Recommended by local riding cable car home after work and it was a hit w/my friends and me. Overall atmosphere is definitely niche and incredibly authentic, dated SF. We all ordered from prix fixe menu and were incredibly pleased w/meal.  Old school dining experience (think wood paneling, wait staff uniforms) as far as cocktails, wait staff, etc. Great mix of people and didn't feel too 'touristy'.

nVG9eKOOQoWHCOus8aCjlA.review_text: Such an wonderful experience at the classiest place.  I love the view of the Bay, and yes, the old wooden piers.  I love hearing about the many family traditions here.  My son became an instant foodie after being introduced to excellence here many years ago.  He's now 17, and he KNOWS how good crab and the best french bread should taste.  He can also recommend the Shirley Temple drinks!

duTsJOMfYx_r9HpogrIw6w.review_text: Went to Napa/San Francisco this past weekend and was unable to get a reservation at Scoma's...boo!  But, I did end up having lunch there before my flight! Win!  I had the clam chowder, which was fantastic, like yumso!  Then, something amazing happened, an entire broken down crab in a butter garlic sauce to be ripped apart by my hands! IT WAS AMAZING!!  Don't get anyhting else, it's delicious! The crab was cut into peices which made it easy to handle.  They also have a grilled crab, didn't try it, but the garlic, butter, crab, was a fantastic combo!  My husband had the sole, my mom had the sand dabs and my step father had the cod and all were impressed!   The waitress let us try the lobster bisque and it was fantastic as well. This place isn't well rated for nothin.

k2jH-UirzoElLdLIujb9FA.review_text: Steak was nicely cooked but overpriced. Nothing exciting about this joint apart from our waiter who was a gent. Real character this guy. great interaction with the customers as were all of the waiters.   One customer thought he was rude but at the end of the night was his best friend!!! Very funny.  My tip is to drop the spicy prices boys! Ur living off an outdated 80's celeb hangout tag.

XUYZrC0YGTOPD5sadtDA0w.review_text: Had an early supper here on a Sept. Mon night. Some locals gave us their recommendation to come here. I should have known by the white jackets, it may be a "stuffy" kind of establishment to eat in. We first were seated in an "awkward" part of the restaurant, but asked to be relocated.
