The hostess, somewhat unwillingly, brought us to a "better table". She definitely had an attitude. Sorry, but we don't like sitting next to the "hangout" spot for the servers, especially if Im paying the prices they charge to eat here. Food was ok. I got a sampler from the appetizer menu. I believe my boyfriend got whatever the fish special was. It was just ok, that I can't recall exactly which one he got. Our waiter was nice, a little eccentric, but friendly enough. I forget his name. Im sure this place has many return, local customers and then of course, the tourist types, such as ourselves. I was not impressed, at all, with this restaurant. The whole experience, from the moment I walked in, to the end of the meal, I felt very uncomfortable and this place is just not "my cup of tea". Honestly, we do better w/ "hole in the wall" type of restaurants, where staff is more down to earth, food is really good, along with reasonable prices. Not saying the food is "bad" here, just the whole dining experience was a big turn off for me. I was very disappointed on being our last meal on our trip.

p0Fh5Cp7s9FNmOOyoSCwyg.review_text: I grew up coming here.  This was my family's place for special occasions or fancy dinners.  It seems to have lost some of its charm in recent years though, which is sad.  Maybe I just grew up, or maybe the standards have slipped slightly-- and I do mean just very slightly.  It sounds silly, but some of the magic has gone out of this special place for me.  As a kid, everyone was in dresses and suits... today people are in jeans.  It's just a different atmosphere now.  From being a picky eater as a kid to a more adventurous adult, Scoma's has always been a delicious experience.  I love that it's tucked away down an alleyway on the water.  It's quiet and feels rather private, which is nice.

M3vDI_iVatX9muk7-RB3_g.review_text: This was possibly one of the best meals--if not the best meal--I have ever had. The wine list was extensive and I chose a Malbec which suited the evening. Their sourdough bread was exceptional. I had the crab ravioli which was indeed the best and freshest pasta I have ever tasted. Their bread pudding is insane.

XWbNCxpN51cfvMhPlW7nSg.review_text: The hubs and I were told by the concierge at our hotel that scoma was the place to go! After reading the reviews we thought sounds good! We got here and we were starving. Hubs ordered the scallops and prawns. He said the prawns were over cooked and the scallops were like chewing on rubber ( and he loves scallops). The vegetables that he got were also under cooked. I ordered the filet medium I got it well done. It was over cooked and under seasoned. The vegetables tastes like they had been cooked in fish sauce. I was so disappointed  that we wasted $70 on dinner here when we could have walked to the wharf and eaten at aliotos! If u like handing your money over for less than adequate food at high prices then come to. Scomas!

766lm0M5kqX3Dd5lSkP2Sw.review_text: My son and 2 granddaughters went to Scomas for lunch on a weekday.  We had to wait over an hour because we added another person to our party. We were told the fifth person couldn't even sit down at a 4top . No one would tell us when exactly the table would be ready.    No one was gracious.  No one offered us cold drinks or the bread basket.  No one updated us on our table.  No one would even give us eye contact.  The food is good but the taste is ruined by rudeness.  Count me out as a returning customer and yes, I'm spreading the word!

jXuYKE2Bdy4OfCMNrrbdNQ.review_text: The food was good quality and very tasty... With that taste came the pricing... It was pretty pricey for a decent meal. Although the cost of our two person dinner exceeded the $140 mark, it was still an enjoyable experience.

iVPmgnlF0_XCAwGz3JHAUg.review_text: I think I would rate this place FANTASTIC/EXCELLENT if it was not for the snotty service we received.  Scoma's came HIGHLY recommended by family, friends, and fellow travelers on our recent trip to Fisherman's Wharf. We were prepared to enjoy a fabulous meal. We didn't make a reservation but put our name on the waiting list and took a walk around Ghiradelli Square. We arrive back in about 45mins and were promptly seated. So far so good right?  No... Our waitress quickly profiled the three 20-something professional women sitting at the table as not her priority. We asked for specials and got a short hand version of "scallops with rice" without any further explanation or offering (this was also not the special). When we asked for her recommendation on wine, she picked the cheapest bottle on the menu after stating she can't recommend a bottle because she "does not know us" and her choice was unrelated to our meal choices (we chose a different bottle). She only came back to our table to bring us food and collect the check. Not the type of service I EXPECT when I'm paying $30 a plate and buying a bottle of wine for the table.  But, on to better things! I hope others can report a better time with service and this review does not deter you from trying to AMAZING food Scoma's has to offer. First off, the Salmon was fabulous in a butter dill sauce paired with garlic mashed potatoes. The calamari was fried to perfection and melted in my mouth. And the crab cakes are a must! Hands down the best crab cake I have EVER tasted. The crab stuffed portabella mushroom is a worthy appetizer but a small portion if you want more than 2 bites.  Overall a great tasting meal, and I would return for the food alone. I'll over look the service this time, but don't burn me twice, and if the Scoma's Manager/Owner is reading this... I recommend a chat with your staff on profiling. We may have looked young but we still walked out of your restaurant with a $150 bill :)

-IGAqMovnic1Mj1ZGwYcmw.review_text: The food was ok, but the service was amazing.

uQifz4CeUJ0Uyn69BRi3bQ.review_text: Came here just recently and had the greatest time! This place was the icing o the cake for my SF weekend. Food and service are great, a little pricey but you get what you pay for. Our server, Laurie was wonderful! Lobster ravioli was out of this world and the dessert was on the house as it was my girlfriends birthday. Tip- come a little later (we went around 9:15 on a Sunday) so you don't have wait for a table. Restaurant is a little down further on pier 47, I would totally come back to this place!

U4sJcmUUoIRfFaiVlzyPKQ.review_text: They seriously have the best Calamari and mussels. I crave it all the time but try to treat my self once in a while. Excellent service. Excellent food, very high quality! They get very busy at times, so try making a your reservation ..

agvD4eQC7lP4N9GpNGlUTA.review_text: I met a former co-worker for dinner here on a Wednesday night.  This place was humming along.  Our server was a very nice gentleman named Sal.  He was very attentive and made killer recommendations.  The garlic grilled Dungeness crab is absolutely the best thing I've had in a long time.  Fantastic!  The menu has a good selection of gluten free items (I really pay attention now since my vegan wife is also gluten free).  Atmosphere is really neat and even being sat next to the kitchen, I didn't feel like there was a lot of wait staff traffic in and out.  Great wine selection and their cocktails are really well made.  Had the apple crisp for dessert with a couple of scotches.  It was a greatest and a great place to eat.  Will come back next time I'm in town.  Highly recommended.

7j06R8z6M8jTI8anwfjemA.review_text: Clam chowder was REALLY GOOD!  Also tried the Lazy Man's Cioppino, it was good.  The fish in the Cioppino was fresh.

oNeyHF8MKilKZOUENpTk3Q.review_text: I was loving the lady out front at Scoma's last Saturday night. With her coke-bottle glasses and frizzy hair, she looked like she'd been sitting in that seat for about 50 years, since Al Scoma first started running the joint. (I saw a picture of Al on the wall and was pleasantly surprised to observe that he could be Jerry Stiller's twin brother.) This lady seemed precariously perched on the border of professional and curt, experienced and jaded, more of a cariacature than a real human being. She kept me entertained while we waited to be seated. See, Scoma's doesn't accept reservations, so we waited about an hour to be seated, which was, I think, not unconscionable for a group of six on a Saturday night.  Our waiter was great: helpful, but unintrusive. We hardly noticed him, and that's a sign of a truly great waiter, in my opinion. We started with the sampler plate, which included possibly the best calamari I have ever had, yummy crab cakes, and scrimp scampi.  For my entree, I ordered the cioppino, which I would recommend to anyone! The tomato broth had a fantastic flavor, and the broth was filled with fish, clams, crab, prawns, shrimp... all fresh and perfectly cooked. A slice of garlic bread on the side topped it off. Yeah, it was $35, but I ate it while watching the sun set ever so slowly over the water and the unimaginably large boats roll in and out of the Bay. It's not just a meal; it's an experience.  Everyone else seemed to love their food as well. I would absolutely return here for more excellent Italian-style seafood on the Wharf.

BgAL7CCy38LTO6Pm58Os5A.review_text: Awesome Classic San Fran Restaurant.   Scenery and ambiance most definitely worth the price!

K8eob8S6ZaMLgyVmPgg-Iw.review_text: This is a nice restaurant if you want something a little more upscale. Most of the surrounding restaurants are touristy, but Scomas has charm and excellent food. Great fresh seafood!

1xkQbblvQ7nT3nTS2LSidw.review_text: Wanting to try as many restaurants as possible without stuffing ourselves, my husband and I would get a couple small dishes to share at each place. So at Scoma's, instead of ordering an entree we tried a couple of hot appetizers and sides. First was the lobster bisque and it was amazing! Then we had crab cakes and a side of asparagus with bacon, Parmesan and a balsamic reduction and both were amazing!! I think the asparagus was my favorite. Don't be turned off by the out of the way location or aging appearance, the food is awesome.

c-77cBhyhKI1rpjycFM5yQ.review_text: I heard lots about this place beforehand just to be let down.   The group I traveled with makes Scoma's a paramount stop each trek up to San Fran. However, after eating there this time, everyone agreed that we will put it on the "skip it" list.  The quality of good was pretty good, but pricey. No one was wowed by their order. It's San Francisco, you can get good seafood just about anywhere. But, we wanted outstanding.    Heros was server. At first, I thought he was pretty much a jerk - wouldn't let us finish our order and kept walking away. But, by the end he was pretty funny and telling us silly jokes.  He has been there forever.  The place was dying down pretty early. Not sure if it was due to the nasty weather or declining quality of dining experience.   BOTTOM LINE: Probably best to skip and try something else.

H40laLp0uu_iTHd4K3by0Q.review_text: I knew i wanted to try a real chioppino while in san francisco and so i picked this place after yelping around.  When we first walked in, i just got the feeling this was the kind of place my grandfather would love...wood paneling on the walls, waiters wearing bowties and suspenders.  I guess i would call it old school....and pretty touristy.  Justin G and I were pretty much the youngest people there by about 30 years or so.  They sat us right away (although it was about 4:00 in the afternoon, there was definitely a decent amount of people eating).  Our waiter greets us right away and tells about where all of the seafood has come from today which i love.  I was absolutely feeling ravenous  and a little chilly after an afternoon at alcatraz and didn't want anything more than to eat a hot and delicious meal. We started with the hot sampler appetizer which was: rock shrimp scampi, calamari, and crab cakes.  To be honest, justin G picked this and i was only looking forward to the crab cakes as i don't usually care for shrimp or calamari due to their textures.  Well i was eating my words when they brought it out because the rock shrimp were so tiny and delicious, and although it was a scampi, it was a think i bit tomato based which was so tasty.  The calamari was awesome...fried but not greasy, not rubbery, just very light.  And the crab cakes were good too.  Served with three different sauces on the side - all of them were delicious.  Then we got the chioppino to share.  $39 dollars for an enormous steaming hot bowl of chioppino.  For everyone that doesn't know, it's a fish stew with a tomoto and white wine base.  Our waiter asked us how spicy we like things so we went with level two of five and it was perfect for me.  Huge chunks of swordfish, musscles, clams, huge chunks of crab meat, enormous shrimp, and plenty of other types of seafood i can't even recall.  The flavors were freaking delicious...all of the seafood was so so good.  While i don't normally love all seafood because of texture, i loved everything that was in my bowl.  Maybe i'm just not used to seafood this fresh? Either way, this meal was awesome.  I felt like i was in such a happy food daze for the entire night just thinking about this meal.  While Scoma's is not the trendiest place out there, i sure thinks its worth a try while in fisherman's wharf.  I would certainly love to return if i'm ever back in SF.

AFSpLArexc1h0QLOjvUdeA.review_text: If your looking for a sit down meal around the wharf, this is probably the only place I will go for seafood.  Of course you will see a lot of visitors and tourists, but what else do you expect?  Do get: The crab cakes kumamoto oysters crab louis salad  The interior and servers are a little bit dated, but hey, service is always up to par.  Plenty of seating in the bar area, and the main dining.  Beware: Parking can be difficult though, and prices are a bit steep.

PS4Qx8SzSt-bmRuTiz32oA.review_text: Personally, I enjoyed this place. What I really liked about it was that it was in a touristy location, but everyone there seemed to be locals. The vibe in there is nice as well, it was a busy Sunday evening when I went and they have very limited reservations, so I had to wait about an hour to get seated.   As for the dinner, I started off with a very tasty bloody mary and the BLACK-N-BLUE AHI, which was perfectly seared. My main course was the SHRIMP AND SCALLOPS ALLA GANNON which came with a side of veggies, mashed potatoes, and rice. The shrimp and scallops were really great; you can tell the seafood was fresh.   Overall, I would recommend this place to dine in at least once. The menu has many options, if I end up there again I'll be going for the Lobster ravioli.

AoAUWW6gyXF22zrWBVQOjw.review_text: This review is really more of 3.5 stars but the service and appetizer were just amazing. So 4 stars it is.  We came on a Sunday at around 4:30pm and the wait was already about 45 minutes. It was highly recommended by a friend so we decided to just stick it out. The place itself is kind of dim and has a sort of old-school-class feel to it. We took a look at the menu beforehand and I was blown away by the prices. We were seated in a section that I think had just opened up for dinner because we were the first ones there but it filled up quickly. Our server was beyond friendly and knowledgeable, answered all our questions and patiently waited as we debated what to ordered.  We got an appetizer, Oyster Rockefeller Alla Scoma (cheese, lemon, and spinach on oysters), which were SO GOOD, so flavorful and really just blew me away even more than the menu prices. My main dish was the Pasta Alla Scoma (garlic butter sauce linguini with clams) and it was filled with lots of clams (which it better be for the price). It was pretty good.  Again the appetizer and server are what have me really liking this place. I want to really love Scoma's but I'm just not sure the price lives up to it. If you do stop by though, definitely try the Oyster Rockefeller Alla Scoma (if you're into that)!

jAiGoRmj3eAkeH_3KfudXg.review_text: So, my manfriend had been waxing poetic about a place he dined while at a conference in San Francisco ages ago. The way he described it, it sounded like an unknown diamond in the rough. Separately, I had bookmarked Scoma's as a place we might want to go for a nice dinner. Lo and behold, they were one in the same.  We hadn't planned to hit Scoma's in advance, so the best we could do with Open Table was an 8:45 reservation. After a day of walking around and an impromptu bar crawl, we decided to try our luck for an earlier table. We grabbed a drink at the bar after  putting our name in; definitely a happening place with a friendly crowd. For him, The Dinghy and for me, The Calm Before the Storm, a tasty, spicy take on a margarita.  Scoma's is tucked away from the madness of Jefferson and the Embarcadero, but the secret is out, so make reservations. The ambiance reminded me of a steak house; waiters in white coats, attentive service, large portions and the absence of any gimmicky seafood decor (nets, plastic crabs and lobsters, etc.).  To start we had Black and Blue Ahi, a crusted and seared ahi served with greens, which was just as tasty as it looked. We struggled choosing entrees, everything sounded delicious. I will say though, if you abstain from pork, let your server know. There were a couple of dishes that didn't list panchetta in the menu description that I scrapped from my list. He ended up going with the swordfish piccata, which was perfectly cooked and flaorful. I went wit the scallop risotto, so wonderfully decadent. The scallops were cooked beautifully.  With limited time in the city, I keep a short list of places I make a point of returning to. Scoma's has easily made that list. The steakhouse ambiance makes it an easy choice for a nice date, business meeting or fancier meal.

xQHHmSV9cwfi6gu4iwDrLg.review_text: Excellent food.  I ordered the fresh catch of the day and it was cooked to perfection.  My husband ordered the linguine al diplomatico. His dish had so much fish in it. This was a dish recommended by our waiter and it was a terrific choice.   Our friends we went with aren't big fish fans and they enjoyed their steaks as well. They were juicy and cooked to perfection according to them. So there is something for fish lovers and non-fish lovers.

_bBU-MAP3OEel00aU37MdA.review_text: Kumamoto oysters, lobster bisque and clam chowder.  Bartender Steve was making fresh mint mojitos. Love this place!!

9sxvJvvTtw8y2YRDcaL9nw.review_text: 4.5 stars   One word: Touristy   Sometimes it's ok to go to a touristy place in your hometown. It's kind of fun. Had some friends visiting from the midwest. They wanted to go to Scoma's. So we went. Restaurant does not take reservations. We waited for about 45 minutes. During that time, we hung out at the bar. Bartenders were really helpful and friendly. Got a chardonnay to start and bartender poured a lot into my glass. WOW. Thanks!  Menu covered everything you can imagine in an Italian Seafood restaurant. It took me a while to read through the whole thing. I had a hard time deciding what I wanted. They also had a prix-fixe menu which 100% proceeds go to the oil disaster relief. I didn't find out about this until AFTER I ordered. Thank you waiter for telling us. I was not happy. We ordered the Pasta Diplomatica that comes with lobster tails, prawns, clams, and sea scallops on linguine; can be served in cream sauce or marinara sauce. We also ordered the popular Cioppino Alla Pescatore that included prawns, clams, shrimp, sea scallops, fresh fish, and Dungeness crab in a tomato broth. It comes with a bib. Nice. Another dish that was ordered was the broiled king salmon on crab ravioli. Ravioli was superb! All the dishes were wonderfully prepared. Although, the cioppino looked slightly water-down. Ingredients were fresh and flavorful. Portions are huge. I had leftovers for lunch today.  Scoma's surprised me. I really enjoyed my meal. The service was extraordinary. They have complimentary valet parking. This is a big plus in the hustle and bustle of Fisherman's Wharf. Prices are on the steeper side but expected for a seafood restaurant in a tourist area. It's a great place for out-of-town guests.

7VE9IHnRMokkuPic6OMThA.review_text: As good as it gets!!  Great fresh fish and shellfish dishes...Easily best on the Wharf and in San Francisco as well.  The fish comes right off the boats at their back door and into the kitchen.  Make a reservation, and your table will be waiting for you.  Sit in Sergio's section for menu knowledge and great service!!

Xk4CO2zXLjdr3l4y7eo9fg.review_text: I love this place with a 50's style look inside and old school waiters in jackets and ties.  Love the dinner rolls and clam chowder. Have enjoyed a few good entrees here as well. For a touristy spot in a heavy traffic area, this place does a great job with their seafood. I always enjoy going to Scoma's on any visit to San Francisco.

aqWMdkCaLgWvp_-Q0-1RtQ.review_text: I sing of lobster bisque's at Scomas.    I am here to sing the praises of the Lobster Bisque.  I went with some friends on a business trip.  One of the people ordered the lobster bisque and was kind enough to let me taste it.    For the rest of the meal, while eating my lazy man's chioppino, I felt gipped, cheated, like I had a dagger in my heart, that bisque was mocking me as my friend ate it, saying, "I am tastier than what you are eating, nah nah nah!"    I could not wait to get back to Scomas and have my own bowl of that lobster bisque.  It must of launched ships!  This bisque!  Wars were probably fought over it!  Good lord!

-H6cTbVxeIRYR-atxdielQ.review_text: While visiting San Fran, we had one day to enjoy a nice seafood meal.  Oh, but my better half doesn't like seafood but he does love pasta!   Scoma's was the best of both our worlds!   We went for lunch based on a recommendation from our segway tour operator.   It was wonderful, the bread, the appetizers, the meal, and of course dessert, were all great!    They offer a prix fix lunch special, which I chose, and my husband chose the ala carte menu.  I could not stop eating the fresh sourdough bread.  We both had separate appetizers of shrimp and chowder.  The chowder was had plenty of clams and other seafood which set them apart from other places I had tried.  My husband's pasta dish was enough to feed a couple and he devoured it.    Definitely recommend!

le3q1LEoDlI5wSsWUvAE7w.review_text: My favorite San Francisco restaurant. Lump crabmeat cocktail and pasta diplomatica are my favorites!!  The whole Scoma's experience is fantastic. Starting with crowded, sectioned-off eating areas, wood-paneled walls that have seen better days, out-dated lounge chairs - the whole place needs an over-haul, but they still serve on white table cloths and the servers are white-jacketed formal. I wouldn't want them to change one thing about this place. And it appears everyone else feels the same. The place is packed every night. And they don't take reservations, but Marianne can always get you a table quickly. For the best Fisherman's Wharf experience, you must try Scoma's

aVrAAkQ2_Zb3zLAdTvttxA.review_text: If I come back here, maybe I'll be able to update my rating, but based on my experience I just can't give it more than three stars. The good part was that we hadn't made a reservation, but we were seated right away. The not so good part was that the service kind of ruined my experience of the place. I was really excited to try this place out, but it felt like our server was turning his nose up at us the whole time. It made me feel inferior and I really didn't appreciate it. The scallops I ordered were cooked perfectly -- I just wish I could have enjoyed them in a friendlier environment.

AZpe6d09WtEMlwWV9FqxzQ.review_text: I am giving this place five stars because everything, with the exception of my main course, was delicious. But I'll get to that later.  So this place was recommended to us, and I was suspicious, based on it's location (touristy and cliched.) But it was recommended to us by a couple of serious food snobs, so we decided to have a little faith. We were not disappointed (except in one area, as mentioned before.)  My husband started with clam chowder. He said that it was delicious. Then came the fried calamari. So good. I ate most of it! Then his cioppino, which he said was the best thing he's ever eaten. Which is saying something, 'cause he's very picky and rarely raves about anything. Along with the cioppino came my main course...  It's my own fault: I should've known better than to order the crab risotto. Those of us that love risotto know that it must be made a certain way. And this one wasn't. But everything else had been so good, I thought "How can I go wrong?" It was oh-so wrong. Blech. No creamy-ness whatsoever, the texture of the rice was terrible and it seemed as if no wine had been used at all. A total disappointment for $34!! If you love good risotto, DON'T ORDER RISOTTO HERE!     That being said, we will definitely return and I will definitely order something else! Lesson learned.  I almost forgot to mention the outdated decor and wait staff uniforms, which some people will find a turn-off, but I found it quaint.

kY2qz3daZYe3rnq8PAEF5A.review_text: We ate at Scoma's yesterday October 9 2014.  It was the WORST food ever!  My mother and I ordered the lunch special, fish and chips.  The fish was over cooked and very dry.  The fries were a mix of sweet potato and regular.  HORRIBLE!!!  The only thing that was good was the bread and the clam chowder.  The service wasn't up to par either.  There was 4 of us and 3 of us got our food while the 4th had to wait a few minutes.  You'd think that the fact that we ordered an 82.00 bottle of champagne that alone would have prompted us good service.  NOT HAPPY AT ALL!!  We had guests from out of town with us and bragged how wonderful Scoma's is only to be disappointed like that.  I have never had such a terrible experience there.  I don't know if we will ever go back there again when in the city.  Might try Grotto next time.  VERY VERY DISAPPOINTED SCOMAS!!!  I don't know what happened.

tFyMN6_SJzXPQYVxzoKI-A.review_text: Last time I visited Scoma's was about 15 years ago and I've wanted to go back ever since. I thought ahead and made reservations a couple of weeks in advance. We were seated 5 minutes ahead of schedule.  We ordered the cold seafood appetizer for two with clams, oysters, crab claws , and shrimp. It was okay but not outstanding for $29.  We ordered the Shellfish Sauté ($40) and Scoma's Pasta. I have never seen so many clams in one dish--I counted 32!  The pasta was average other than the vast amount if clams, it needed more garlic to my taste .  The Shellfish Sauté included shrimp, two small lobster tails, juicy sweet scallops and other seafood goodies. It was worth the price but a huge amount of food.   Scoma's is a great place for tasty seafood but a bit on the pricy side. Our total was $137 for dinner for two with one glass of wine.

otRk7mNeYSLghvxRretahQ.review_text: I highly recommend the clam chowder, fried calamari, and the pasta diplomatica. Other than that, I don't think the place is worth coming to if you don't order those dishes.   Tonight, I ordered a bowl of clam chowder, pasta diplomatica, pasta bolognese, dungeness crab spoon bread, and the salmon on lobster ravioli with saffron sauce. Of course I loved the clam chowder and pasta diplomatica, but the rest were only okay. The pasta bolognese was good, but not to die for. I was really excited to try the dungeness crab spoon bread, but it wasn't good. The bread was very, very soft and the crab tasted like microwaved food. I wasn't a huge fan of the salmon on lobster ravioli with saffron sauce, but maybe that's because I had such a strong taste in my mouth after the crab spoon bread so I wasn't tasting properly.   Great, friendly, fast service.

opriCoc_FL94AJcmNuiQHQ.review_text: I don't understand what the draw is about this place.  It's seriously seen better days - dingy carpet, cheap tables/chair & decor.  Yes, it's got that (tired out) swank rat pack thing going on (as do the waiters) but this place is seriously DINGY.   The food:  clam chowder, tuna steak, fish & chips and steak sandwhich - was ok - it's food like you'd get at a truck stop, but for much higher prices.  Just because it's an institution in San Fran - doesn't make it good!

JszEAaiAE_dff7TR9d4hFA.review_text: A San Francisco Institution. Great service, views and food.

g-f_06makc0qfm2F-JTCIQ.review_text: This place struck me as average. It's a bit of tourist trap since it's on fisherman's wharf. It carries a big name, which attracts a lot of people to it, but for price, it is not worth it.  I had scallops. They were fresh and tasty. The meal was filling, but the scallops were imported from the east coast, which kind of made me wonder, what's the point of eating west coast sea food?   We got bread with oil and the wait staff was as attentive as they needed to be. Nothing over the top and they only stuck around to get drink orders and returned regularly, but were never engaging or conversational. Just sort of there to bring us food and that was it. Almost robot like really.  Family member had some dungeness crab with her salad and that was good, but outrageously priced.

3j3cwYo_h4vcBldmBKoBNw.review_text: A friend came into town for business wanted to visit Fisherman's wharf and sample some of the Bay Area's native cuisine.  The first thing I thought about was Cioppino and knew exactly where to go...we ended up at Scoma's!  The bowl of Cioppino consisted a variety of seafood in spicy tomato broth and served with savory garlic bread.  The service was good and friendly.    I definitely recommend to anyone to visit Scoma's and chow down on a bowl of cioppino!

fxEo8P2QS2anNnhWF0r1tg.review_text: So, so sad. The boyfriend and I booked reservations for Scoma's for our nice evening out while in San Fran. I initially was concerned since the place is in such a touristy area and that usually signals sub-par food to me...but after seeing the reviews on here and getting a recommendation from a friend thought we would try it out. Upsetting.  We started with a bottle of wine and the calamari. It was so-so....I was really expecting the best calamari I've ever had...but then again when the fish is fried, I guess it doesn't really matter how fresh it is anyways.   For my entree, I asked the waiter what his favorite risotto was...he said the Prawn Risotto, so I went with it. So disappointing. It was so FISHY! The entire dish was, not even just the prawns. I will give them credit that the risotto was cooked properly, but still...just a disappointment.  Boyfriend had some fish dish...I did try it, but don't recall what it was, so it must have not been that memorable...or perhaps it was just the second bottle of wine that is making my mind so fuzzy...but even if so, you'd think I'd enjoy the food then, right? ;]  Anyways...had it not been for the wine and the really outstanding service, Tim was his name, I would probably give Scoma's only one star. Will not be returning on my next trip to SF.

B8c17RLH6AaglKN-jW4RwQ.review_text: My favorite restaurant in California, the most delicious meal ever! the service was excellent (thanks Andrea! your a doll) this is a 5 star all around! can't wait to go back again!  Awesome seafood and steaks.

vvLV-Fi_cQPqAlzCe8AB6w.review_text: The place to go in San Francisco for seafood. Even though it is in the Fisherman's Wharf tourist area, and I am a SF native, we go here all the time. The seafood is just damn good. The lobster bisque, clam chowder, calamari, crab cakes, sand dabs, scallops, crab Louis are just the best around. In fact, we hold the Scoma's calamari (get it with the red sauce for something spicy & different) as a benchmark for all others.  Waiters are great, and the cocktails well made. The prices are high, but you get so much high quality food, and everyone leaves with a take home box, that you actually have two meals. They have valet parking as a plus, at NO CHARGE, just give them a tip.

lhyNuR1HIZ0Ym7A0ydLzmA.review_text: We were told about this hidden gem from some ex-locals. If you love seafood, you need to eat here. It is a San Francisco experience you must have.   I started out with a bloody cesear. They made it extra spicy (just the way I love) with a whole bunch of olives. Very good start!  I came in a large group, so I was able to try a lot of things off the menu. Every thing was amazing. Pretty much, with every bite, you are having the best seafood experience of your life. If you are a fan of dungeness crab, but you do not like fighting them for every spec of meat, you must get the King Louis salad. It is basically a couple of leaves of lettuce, covered with a mountain of fresh crab meat that someone else fought to get out on your behalf. A serious mountain. The crabcakes are to die for; or at least flying back (5 hours each way) for. The lobster ravioli, amazing. Everything, amazing.  Bottom line, what ever you choose off the menu, you will not be disappointed. Our group was certainly not.

Z7to1WbyW8ogdRev0Zfk8g.review_text: After trying to eat at Scoma's on a Wednesday night during September and told the wait would be over an hour we decided to eat lunch there on Thursday.  Plenty of seats around 3:30pm, nice staff who seem to have been working there for 30 years.  To the food.  The Chioppino was excellent as was the Halibut. We took the leftovers to the Hotel, refrigerated them and then brought them home to Orange County for Friday night's dinner at home, still very tasty eating it with rice not the sourdough bread that was served at the restaurant.  The Crab Cakes were good, not great. They just didn't meet my expectations. The Clam Chowder was good as well, just not the best.  Expensive but tasted very good overall. Also had a full dinner the next night at home with the leftovers.  Will return one of these years when back in San Francisco.

OAmoNqiW9Kf41seGFb9cOQ.review_text: While on a vacation to SF I visited this place after my uncle had recommended it.  It was a bit pricey, but worth it I suppose.  The interior was pretty boring, however, the food was pretty awesome.  My only gripe was when I called, the hostess was rather rude when telling me that they DON'T TAKE RESERVATIONS.  However, everyone else on the staff that i encountered when i went in was really friendly.  After reading everyone's posts about the LOBSTER BISQUE I figured they couldn't all be wrong so I tried it.  It was absolutely delish!! I also shared the "lazy man's ciopinno" with my mom.  This was definitely a serving for two -- there's no way anyone could finish this on their own (this too was very good!)  After my serving of bisque and ciopinno I was stuffed!  Somehow though, the waiter managed to trick me & my mom into dessert.  We had an the espresso ice cream with a brownie -- I also must recommend this, it was awesome!  Needless to say, I think the delicious food here contributed to my 5 lb weight gain on my vacation!

woze1dgnRc52vAecaK36lg.review_text: Not as good as 4 stars so someone needs to balance with a REAL review here:    The servers are very nice!   My sister and I split an entry and had a cup of soup each and & a couple glasses of wine for about $100 including tip. They offered to put cheez on my seafood. My theory is that tourists aren't as critical of food as the locals because they must be so excited to be in San Francisco with it's famously excellent restaurants.   Call me a snob but Scoma's serves traditional tourist food at tourist prices. it is an institution that caters to tourists. This was not an inspired dinning experience whats-so-ever. No surprises.   Might as well been in a MALL! We were disappointed.   Read the reviews! They are over-the-top: I wonder if they were paid to make such claims...they read like infomercials. Fish Stew (cioppino) for $37? give me a break. It better taste good!

x7cN2viCydTW7U9srbP7kw.review_text: Tucked away in Fishermans Wharf but that didn't stop many from finding this wonderful old school restaurant.  We didn't have reservations but I don't think that would have minimized the wait. The hostess was spot in with the wait time - about 30 minutes. We enjoyed a cocktail and then seated on the upper floor of the restaurant. Thats where we were greeted by Tim, our sever. We were seated at a table flanked closely by other diners. We didn't complain but Tim noticed and immediately reseated us at a spacious booth.  He guided us through the menu and selection of appetizers as well as entrees.  We were so happy with our meals. The swordfish piccata was delicious as was the halibut. Of course you can't be at the wharf and skip clam chowder. It was excellent.  Definitely worth the wait and ask for Tim.

vtServ1aY-isQ0qJ6TZfJg.review_text: The best seafood restaurant in San Francisco!! -Most consistent menu and everything is yummy. -Great service and good atmosphere .  -No reservations taken so the only bad part is waiting...but you can drink at bar while you are waiting :)  I've been here a bunch of times and I can tell you that these are amazing: -Clam Chower -Lobster Bisque -Crab Louie -Shrimp Cocktail -Crab Cocktail -Fried Calamari -Petrale Dore -Lobster Thermidor -Cioppino -Lobster Newburg -Dungeness Crab  So many choices and so much good food...a staple in SF for SURE!

1wznt1BOXSQBuJnQcLHLiw.review_text: Dee - lish! Fresh seafood at the wharf. Great crab and fish hit the spot. Been around a long time but staff very attentive and food prepared to your liking. Don't take reservations but didn't wait long and bar is large and friendly. Great views of the marina.

DAaj_ai_5AVQQXlZ8fX8Tg.review_text: Best Bloody Marys I've ever had.  Crab cakes were delicious.  I had the filet and lobster.  The filet was great, and the lobster was okay.  The ship-style ambiance was wonderfully unique, and our server was perfectly attentive.  I would love to go back next time I'm in town.

Lsh4ybS2Mk0SrNozTvwfug.review_text: the roasted crab awesome - Jean our Server was just the best and I can not wait to get back to San Fran and enjoy again

wMk62l3ILf7TKenpbw9PeQ.review_text: Christopher M. and I decided to come here for Restaurant Week lunch, but they always have lunch specials here.  After a nice walk around Fisherman's Wharf, we found this place through the handy dandy Yelp.  We were seated right away, which is always a plus.  Unfortunately our waiter did not pay much attention to us and preferred to spend his time fawning over a larger table.  Ho hum.  At least the food was good.  Chowder is always a plus in my book.  The lunch specials are great and affordable, I think.  I got the seafood pasta, and it was delicious.  Dessert looked good and tasted good.  Besides the service, this place is great for lunch and a tour of Fisherman's Wharf.

CQUDh80m48xnzUkx-X5NAw.review_text: So when we got back from Alcatraz we were starving!  We had heard good reviews from this Seafood place.  Whenever I travel I make sure to stop by at least 1 fine dining type of place.  This time due to financial crisis we chose to eat a moderate type place.  We read yelp and it all suggested the lazy man, I REPEAT DO NOT GET THE LAZY MAN!!!  It's not bad but it's basically a bunch of meat all mixed together in a tomato type soup.  You could barely tell what meat was what also it was full of fish instead of the other better seafoods I was expecting.  However, my friend Mike W. got the shellfish saute.  It looked and smelled wonderful and from his account was amazing.  It was full of the seafood I was hoping for, Lobster, shrimp, and scallops.  If you stop by make sure to get the SHELLFISH SAUTE instead.

tomfu0FxcBYnzPep6fBRpQ.review_text: First time at Scoma's.  Very highly recommended by trusted locals. Everybody knows the prices fall in line with the you get what you pay for addage.  Enjoyed the sampler fried calamari -- Very light, fresh and delicious.    Crab cake -- Fresh, light, and light on crab meat, but it is an appetizer, fair.  Dressings / Dips taste made in house.  Nice garlic in the garlic dip for the sampler along with the house thousand and not too great cocktail sauce.  Whole dungeoness crab roasted in Garlic butter.  What a treat that was.  Full of crab meat and lovely garlic butter sauce.  Uncle ordered the " lazy man's chippino " .  More less tomato soup with fish and shellfish.  --Average.  Nice meal.  High price.  Great service.  Summarily, Scomas met my expectation.

ABgBS-exY_H1whm7PG_umQ.review_text: I visit San Francisco about twice a year and I have to eat a Scoma's every time I do. The service and food is wonderful. Now if I can only figure out their Scallop recipe then life would be complete. I'll see you again in 2015!

ycY6H7FoIkvTs4DWfTnR2w.review_text: The food was outstanding. We tried it all and it did not disappoint. Staff was very friendly and service was great. Would definitely go back.

DOj9NanlJP3xntULCy5Uow.review_text: I absolutely love this restaurant.  It's tucked away on Fisherman's  Wharf and you could easily miss it if you took a wrong turn.  It's authentic italian w/ the love of San Francisco.  They have the best Cioppino I've ever had!  It's a huge plate of high quality seafood and it's just plain heaven to me.  You could easily sit there for 2-3 hours to enjoy your meail and watch the sun set.  Scoma's is always busy and I'm not sure that they take reservations so I'd suggest visiting them on an off night during the week.  The #1 place for Cioppino!!

dxx_AkChOxEl8yI5NqEuPw.review_text: Love Scoma's!!  The best Crab Louie on the planet.  A little pricey, but certainly well worth the money.  Very generous portion of crab. Impeccable   old school service by veteran staff. Would recommend this to anyone.

UOZNKvZ4pMtOsZr7QSQALA.review_text: I don't make it Scoma's often, but I try any time I'm near the wharf. They never fail to impress. From the white jacket service to top of the line fresh sea food it's definately a do not miss for me.   This trip included a beautiful Burrata served over balsamic covered heirloom tomatoes, and cup of their awesome clam chowder. If your looking for something heartier try the cioppino

mX84lBw8jwS2uQqdgKu_aA.review_text: 4* for food ----- 2* for atmosphere  Stepping into this place was like stepping back to the 70's.  Uniforms are terrible, tables are close together and there is no view.    But the food is great.  Cioppino was top notch and so was the seafood saute.  Everything was fresh and had good taste to it.  Also had no complaints about the service.

DrwAFRWZ7MhjB3n5zyx9Kw.review_text: Had dinner here on my one night in SF.  Everything in Fisherman's Wharf felt very touristy, but I was a tourist, so I can't complain.  The place was packed with about an hour long wait for a table, and no seat at the bar.  We went around the corner and had a drink and came back just in time to get our table.    For appetizers we had oysters on the half and dungeness crab cocktail, both were excellent.  My entree was lobster ravioli which was great, the cream sauce was not too heavy and there were a lot of chunks of lobster in it.  Everyone else at the table was pleased with their entrees as well.  Service was very good and I would definitely recommend to anyone looking to have dinner in the Fisherman's Wharf area.  Can't wait to go back to SF, saw a lot of great looking restaurants.

AxqpR1dFg4lbKYNF_qR4JQ.review_text: This is a bit of a landmark restaurant in the San Francisco area.These days it is a bit overrun by tourists but a lot don't know where it is which helps.  You can order things other than the seafood, but then why did you come here? Order the seafood, it is all very fresh and very yummy. This restaurant is a bit expensive and waits can be quite long without a reservation. The sourdough bread is really yummy. Service could be better. Overall a good place to try if you have never been and you can get in easily.

qsAyKhiwPXyUg_iwTsGwew.review_text: Very subpar. Sooooo disappointing!! Food was not very good at all...and bland. The clam chowder taste like it came out of the can.  Only reason I give two stars is because the calamari was excellent  (we should have just had that) and the scenery - being right by the water - is relaxing

_VyOQXRZnowxvad1K_SyBQ.review_text: Wow. Very good. It is pricy, but the service is second to none and the food is unreal. Cioppino was very good (but definitely could feed 2) and the calamari was nice as well. Big portions and for a guy who doesn't like to waste food, wasted some expensive food. But 5STAR none the less.

_O8i06dJM4NTIVHy26bjuQ.review_text: Pros:  Free valet parking, decent wine prices, rock shrimp scampi, calamari, New England clam chowder, and lobster tail  Cons:  No reservations, had a couple of the lunch specials that I wouldn't recommend - swordfish and ahi sandwich were just "okay"

mq6Ik-CAPyVUNn-T0R0CSQ.review_text: Get the ciopinno.    Crab cakes, clam chowder and bread are also delicious.  You don't need to order anything else.  This is a nice restaurant away from the tourist crowds, and it has a valet so parking isn't an issue.  Oh, and the food is to die for.

6s-g2vFu12OemhiK3FJuOQ.review_text: Scoma's is somewhat touristy, but always popular, serving Italian cuisine. If you consider their prime location on the wharf, along with a pleasant view of the water, pretty palatable pasta (you can't turn down linguine and crab meat balls) and satisfyingly skilled service, you get a place that is worth trying. Prices are high, but the (sea)food is worth it - at least this once, right?  Obviously your mileage may vary, so take my experience with a grain of salt; it has been quite a while since I had dinner there.

qGi0xjK3HM3Lfr6kSwKZdw.review_text: Scoma's makes it easy for you to join them.  If you want to experience Fishermen's Wharf, but do not want to deal with bullshit tourists--they have free valet. And plus with a view that you get, it's pretty unique to anywhere else in SF.  My friend is in love with this place. One. due to her favorite waiter Chris (which we will get into later) and two, this apparently is the best lazy man's cioppino she's ever had. And both were definitely true.   Chris is a waiter of another caliber. If you go here, you should ask her for him--because in the quaint quarters, you will see that a lot of the others paled in comparison. He's warm, inviting, and just equipped with the skills that make his customer service unique to anyone else. He brought us all the delicious bread we wanted, and this spicy tomato sauce to dip it in. He also didn't look at us crazy when we wanted to dip in their lobster bisque, too. ZOMG, my favorite.  I indulged in all of it until for a split second I realized I was trying to still be somewhat skinny for Hawaii.  The friends I were with got the cioppino and OH MY, it is worth the $37. The sauce is not overbearing, but consistent enough to carry all the seafood in it. I abstained from it, because I didn't want to do some clams and stuff (I'm weird). I paid for it though when I got the lobster ravioli with the king salmon. Each item was good on it's own, but together it didn't marry well to me. The salmon was delicious, the lobster ravioli was yummy, but the sauce didn't marry them well. It felt like I was eating two separate dishes.  But the fat girl, I am, I still satisfied myself in some sort of small way by eating it all.  Tiramisu was delicious, rich and slightly heavy--but still made me want to lick the cup. Chris was gracious enough to bring it even when I declined it, because he knew my birthday was coming up.  Overall, a wonderful experience. Now that winter is coming up, cioppino timed right with a paycheck--will make for an excellent winter evening.

NZiwwULo15SKuIT9K2yk0Q.review_text: We were dying for some good seafood and two people recommended this place near the Wharf. We got there just before the dinner rush and our table had an awesome view of the wharf and Coit Tower, where we saw the most amazing rainbow while waiting for our drinks.  Our waiter Joey was quite a character, and I bet he wasn't even trying. My husband had the Ciopino (sp?) and it was one of the best I've ever tried. I split a crab with my son and while it was delicious, it was served cold, which I wasn't expecting. It might have been overcooked as well because it fell apart in my vat of melted butter, but really, I didn't mind because it was still so damn good! We'd definitely go back!

z_b-hPr0d-Qhsb4VoLa2uQ.review_text: I really like the location and food, but service was horrible - one of the servants cannot put the water straight in the glass, the location of the table was near the cashier, waiters station - all evening they were standing near a looking at us or worse - talking loud it was new year eve and we were feeling that everyone who works at the restaurant was rushing and wants us to leave ASAP... When I booked the restaurant, I mentioned that we will be celebrating birthday , nobody even ask or propose something...  Overall I would not go there unless you know someone from the inside...

YjFHjrPPcDTjsNdjfRH9BQ.review_text: We had reservations well in advance of coming to San Francisco,  but still had to wait 10 min to be seated. I had the seafood mixture.  Lobster tails, scallops,  shrimp,  with rice and swiss chard. The lobster tails were gritty and not completely cleaned. The scallops and shrimp were cooked well. My wife had a similar dish with the same problems.  It was our main honeymoon dinner, fancy and what not, but the restraunt kinda sucked. The tables were super close together,  it was loud, the service was ok, but not great. I would Not recommend this place. The prices are high, and the quality was not.

a__k1tpAjtCnlsm1PE6heA.review_text: Minuses: outdated decor and some very high menu prices  Pluses: best clam chowder of my life... My life.

m47_RxS0o2gGmb0HNxQNVQ.review_text: What can I say? I was never a fan of seafood. Usually dry and tasteless. One of my buddies suggested we come here one night. When we walked in I wasn't too sure. There are all these levels and cubbyholes. Panelling on the walls. The front of the house is crowded. The bar fills up quickly. That said they make a mighty strong gin and tonic. Once seated I looked out one window towards the Wharf, then the other at the Golden Gate Bridge. It was a sunny day. The view, alone was priceless. Then we got our bowl of chowder. Man, that was some good chowder. Next up the calamari. I think it melted in my mouth like butter. How do they make calamari that's not rubbery? And the dipping sauces. Holy Marinara! I ordered the salmon and I think I died, went to heaven, talked to God and the Fishermen Angels and we all agreed that while the food was good enough for me to spend eternity on a white cloud, it was time for me to go  back and live out my last days extolling the virtues of Scoma's. Back in the booth I ordered dessert. Best bread pudding ever. I looked skyward but his Holiness already knew it was that good. Not only that but the service is impeccable. Our server knew exactly what wine would go well with our various dishes but he cracked a few jokes and provided just enough attention to not feel abandoned or rushed to leave. This is a great date place, a place to come with friends or family to show off our fair city and the great seafood we enjoy here in the 'Sco. PS: Even valet parking is worth it.

VyWLGUQsPzTB4X_6yFdTAA.review_text: Tucked away from the main street, Scomas gets plenty of traffic.  Beware!  They don't take reservations, but I think this restaurant is worth the wait!  Five stars if they stick to fish/seafood, 4 for the overall experience and very disappointing desserts.   When I went this past Sunday, I was happy to find not only a pre-fixe dinner menu, but one that had Dungeness crab options!  I got a 3 course meal at $35 was a steal!  I started with the crab cakes, which were sweet, light and had very little filler.  For my entree I had the  freshly grilled swordfish with Dungeness crab ravioli in a creamy garlic sauce.  The swordfish was cooked just right so it was juicy, tender, and literally melted in my mouth.  The portions were very generous and I couldn't finish my fish or ravioli.  I finished my meal with a sourdough bread pudding and tirimisu duo.  I'll be back, but I'll pass on the dessert and eat more fish!

ef99zSAFzmEGYF0Uh58JbQ.review_text: I've lived in the Bay area most all of my life and never heard of Scoma's restaurant till someone mentioned that it is an Icon of Fishermans Wharf. So feeling out of contact with the world I mentioned to my family that we should go there. Being a Chef myself and knowing what the food cost is on a plate.   I have to say that this restaurant was rather expensive for the quantity and quality  of the food. The food did not receive a 'Wow' moment but the final Bill did! I regret not just grabbing something to eat from the food vendors off the walkway. It would've saved me $150! Next time we go to SF we will go to our usual and yummy Nona Rose's.  This place is very very pricey and pretentious.  I don't mind paying the price if the food 'Wowed' me but it didn't, we walked away very disappointed.

1Th9Ly4ogmR6PzntFC3y6A.review_text: By far the best restaurant at Fisherman's Wharf, Scoma's is one of San Francisco's best kept secrets. Hidden away on the "working" side of the Wharf, Scoma's features fresh crab and fish direct from the boat.

PI31c_wcFj5JPNnuKl8vKQ.review_text: Maybe we hit an 'off' night, based on some of the other reviews, but neither the service, the food, or the atmosphere was worth the cost.  Group of 5 colleagues, ordered 5 different meals, and only 1 out of the group was complimnetary about their meal.  I ordered broiled cod which was served in a bath of yellow oil, with a side of overcooked pasta, and reheated mixed vegetables...a real disappointment for $29.  5 entrees, no appetizers, no desserts, and 1 shared bottle of the lowest price point wine...$220 before gratuity.  We will not be returning.

NTjEz7uDGpNQqg9APpQcWA.review_text: People wait in long lines. The mixed shrimp, crab and shellfish is too creamy for a Chinese stomach.

hiGQEwKRqUjXRKBoFHJ3cA.review_text: Always satisfied here. Excellent service by C.C. and all staff. Mixed shellfish to start, chowder to die for. Sauté seafood was perfect chock full of crab, prawns, scallop, and lobster tails in a wonderful sauce. Addictive sourdough bread a plenty. Great wine list, even by the glass (Grgich Sav Blanc hit the spot!) Definitely a destination dining spot

5cWPgytHCuPq0poBz7r5sw.review_text: My husband and I have walked by Scoma's many a time, but have never had the opportunity to eat there until last night with some friends that were visiting from out of town. We were a party of 6 for dinner and didn't have to wait long for a table which was nice. My only complaint about the seating was the half circle booth they put us in. It makes for uncomfortable seating and difficult for discussions. If I would have known they were going to sit us there, I would have suggested that we wait for another table. Our food was delicious. We ordered: trio of Pacific oysters on the half shell, oyster Rockefeller Alla Scoma, lobster bisque, swordfish with white wine sauce, lobster ravioli, seared Ahi tuna, 2 pound king crab with an 8 oz filet and the special which was Fettuccine Del Mar. My lobster ravioli was rich and creamy. The ravioli was stuffed full of lobster meat which was nice. John was our server and was knowledgeable and accommodating. I would definitely recommend to locals and visitors!!

SNqEU9SodT4EAWgi_K34zA.review_text: We always enjoy Scoma's, but this time was a wee bit off.  It won't detract from my long-time love though.

LpFimKlykCfouBKMbJ18kA.review_text: Tucked away out on the pier behind the more touristy places. It looks a little sketchy on the outside, but is all white table cloths and good views on the inside. As far as the quality of the seafood, the restaurant has a fish receiving station outside in the pier. If they didn't get it on the dock, they can tell you exactly where it came from.  I had the clam chowder, which is New England style. It was very rich and thick with distinguishable chunks of clam. I liked it more with every bite that I took. The seafood salad had a ton of meat, much more than I could eat after polishing off the chowder. That was fine though since I wasn't too thrilled with the salad itself. At least the seafood on top was good. I had chocolate tort for  dessert. It was served with a raspberry purée, which made the dish sort of tasty. In this case "sort of tasty" isn't a dig on the dessert so much as a statement about the fact that I don't typically like chocolate tort, but since the lunch special included a Chef's choice dessert, it was his selection not mine. I was surprised at how much of the tort I ate before the richness of the chocolate began to wear on me.  All in all I was very happy with Scoma's. It was a little pricey for lunch, but the food was worth it. If I had paid much more though, I probably would have dropped a star.

c3N1eHE5CFdlQw7u4Y6DoA.review_text: Seafood heaven.  I'll never forget the crabmeat sandwich.   Somedays at work around lunchtime I'll be craving that sandwich.  Love the interior of the restaurant as well.  Lots of character.  If you are in the area and like seafood this place is an absolute must!

h8ojg0Tj_pbljI44GFTnwQ.review_text: Scoma's is always my "go-to" place for out of town guests who need to experience a real San Francisco treat.  Made last minute reservations for Saturday night and they couldn't have been more helpful or accommodating.  We waited a bit, but had a terrific table.  The food and service were fantastic as always and my guests were delighted.  I cannot recommend this San Francisco tradition more highly!!!!

l2X0-Q__CHqufsWLWaDvrw.review_text: 3,5 stars.  Their location is first of all strange, you feel like you're driving into a dark alley, but once you get inside the view is great. You can't tell by the outside what's hiding inside, their food is pretty good, not great.  Their lobster bisque is a MUST! So delicious!! We also had the clam chowder, which was okay, I've had better. Their crab cocktail was good and their mussels okay. I honestly wanted them to be better.  For the prices I expected more. The service was great, I do think the tables are placed too close together though. Maybe to fit more people in there, but I'm not a fan of having to hear other conversations than the one I'm having.  Plus for free valley parking!

K-YPGA6Wt-n4DQGhJkFKCw.review_text: Decided to eat here after family visiting from out of state had been here years ago and said the food was great.  We were seated in the most cramped dinning room I have ever experienced. We were literally 6 inches away from the other table. Water was brought out and I made a complaint to our server that there was food on my water glass. I was then brought another glass and there was food on that one too! If they can't clean their glassware properly, I'm worried if they clean anything else right...  I ordered the shrimp annuzzi and couldn't be more unimpressed, especially for $30. The pasta was drowning in garlic butter and the rice pilaf was extremely dry. I can make better rice from a box of Rice-A-Roni. The shrimp also tasted very fishy...not fresh at all.  I sadly won't be returning.

CEQsj9pdpmCZ8xY81o60xQ.review_text: We stumbled upon Scoma's while we were out and about one evening; we decided to have lunch the day of our departure.  The experience was really lovely. Signore Salvatore waited on our table and we received top notch service.  We each ordered the prix fixe lunch,of the offerings we selected the stuffed trout: perfectly seasoned and grilled. We look forward to returning to SF and seeing Signore Salvatore again. A side note, perhaps it can be classified as a tourist trap, but we gladly rub elbows with the tourists to dine at such a fine establishment.

ixAzWY0pBHd-1P0gUPFcTw.review_text: My overall thought is that if you are going to pay tourist trap prices - you might as well get something good - come here!  The ambiance was a classy dim-lit scene from an old movie - really cool.  The service was okay - I don't think our waitress liked us - as we had the impression she probably pre-judged us.  But, there was a big guy singing around the restaurant - which we thought was really fun - and it kind of made up for the waitress.    But, the food...the food was really good.  We had oysters to start - delicous and came with the tiniest bottle of tabasco - you ever saw.  I had for my entree the lazy man ciopinni (or something like that) and it was so delicious - great tomato broth and all of the seafood was cooked perfectly.

z1dGHTNf7wOoyGuWSoq8SA.review_text: This is the first time that I have actually checked in on Yelp during a visit to Scoma's. My boss was in-town and asked to have lunch at a great restaurant. The first place I thought was Scoma's in Fisherman's Wharf.  Although it is in the tourist mecca that is the Wharf, Scoma's is set apart and "hidden" down an alley where you have to know where you are going. My boss ordered the halibut and I got my usual combo louis salad. She was pleased with the taste and preparation. She commented on how well it was cooked. I started with the tasty lobster bisque. It was My combo salad was overflowing with shrimp and fresh crab. The louis dressing was delicious as always. I only had enough room to finish the seafood before I gave up. I would also like to thank and commend Chris for his great service and conversation. I always enjoy a restaurant when the server is genuine and a courteous. 5 stars for Scoma's all the way.

KDYkhR8883fSwrszKzbKwA.review_text: Love this place. every time i visit San Francisco, i go to this place.

sAN9b5IxryuN9EyqcDyhSA.review_text: This place was so amazing I have to write a review about it! I'm a seafood lover (especially when it comes to shrimp) and my dad said this was the place to go for great seafood. They dont take reservations so I thought my dad and I would have to wait a long time for a table because it was a Friday night. When I walked in I liked the old school atmosphere. To my surprise we were able to be seated right away, which made me very happy. We were starving after the 6 hour drive to San Fran.  Our waiter was very professional and nice. We ordered our drinks and the trio appetizer which was shrimp, calamari, and crab cakes. I was already VERY impressed just by the appetizer it was delicious! I could not decide what to order for my entree because everything sounded soo good. I asked the waiters opinion on the 2 options I was stuck on, and he convinced me to go with the lobster ravioli and white mexican prawns. I was not disappointed when I got this dish, it was even better than the first one!  The sauce on the raviolis was creamy but not too rich to the point where you feel sick after you eat it. The prawns were huge and grilled to perfection. Overall this is probably one of the best dinners I've ever had. I was also satisfied with the service, (I cant stand lousy customer service). The only downside were the drinks were expensive but pretty weak (according to my dad) Whenever I come back to San Francisco I will for sure return here to try the other dishes.

h4oxO0E8PUm3hFsyTHkkNQ.review_text: Scoma's needs new blood to run the place. Frank Sinatra is dead, get over yourselves. Take your good stuff (petrale, some of the other fish entrees) and loose the rest and start over. You already have the location but you are stuck in the sixties. Wait staff is always looking for the high rollers and the people you need to pay attention to are walking away disappointed. They need retraining. Will not be back and will not recommend.

wDQxP1Qc2kdkRTs_FuUJEQ.review_text: I am giving 4 stars because of the service and the desert. The seafood itself was very bland. Nothing remarkable. Good but don't worth the price. We got bread pudding for desert and i have to say I'd come Back there for that. The service was outstanding too.

WYX_NXU_0UjLwihc0B1_Vw.review_text: Maybe it just wasn't a good weekend for me, but I went here with high hopes based on the other Yelp reviews, and I was disappointed. I wanted to try abalone, but it wasn't on the menu. I got a cup of clam chowder (had to salt it to add flavor and the clams were chewy), and I got seared ahi tuna that had no seasoning whatsoever. My daughter got a hamburger and wouldn't eat a bite of it after her first taste. It wasn't just that it didn't meet my expectations, it just didn't meet basic good food quality. I have had better ahi tuna in many a place in San Jose.  Our server didn't show up for quite some time after we sat and was not attentive at first, then he noticed how cute my daughter is and started to engage with us, but it was too little too late.

jpvMnToAIQtcw-dNi5EUkw.review_text: I try to hit Scoma's on every other trip to SF.  You have to fight through the tourists on Fisherman's Warf to get here but it's worthwhile.  The best bet is just to order the freshest alternative they have.  Usually this means watching the guys clean the fish in the little house outside the restaurant (on your right as you walk up)  Inside you'll find 70s quaint but ask for a window.  This means that going with parties of 4 or fewer is important, if you want to get a view.  The wine by the glass menus is respectable.

xRbBt5MVKZ5-_8HhhfI26g.review_text: A restaurant hidden away in the back of fisherman's wharf. I heard this place has great oyster based on the recommendation of my cab driver. I wouldn't have found this place if it wasn't for the recommendation. The average age of the customer is in their old 50's. so it's a older crowd kinda place. I think you'll have more fun eating outside where all the buzz are happening if younger than 50.   This was my 4th meal of the day (it's about 5:00pm at this time), so I only crabbed a half dozen oyster and a cup of clam chowder. For $18.00, you get 6 oysters on your plate. It's definitely not the best oyster I have, but satisfy the craving at that time. The claim chowder is not special at all either; just like any other claim chowder.   Now, on to the service here, it SUCKS. It's an old old restaurant trying to "pretend" they're a high class restaurant; trying a little too hard to be an expensive restaurant. The average age of the waiter is around 50 years old too, which suits the average age of the customers. The host; however, were younger (early 20's). They talked and talked and talked among themselves the whole time rather than informing their customers why they had to wait so long for a table. I waited 20 minutes at 4:00pm for a table when more than half of the restaurant is empty.   Tip: Don't come here, no need to come here. It's boring and suffocating in here. Much more fun sitting on the busy street eating and watch the crowd.

rFYUPjgPzJWEipMjxQSXmQ.review_text: For an outstanding food city by the ocean, I still haven't found that amazing seafood restaurant here in SF. After my third time visiting Scoma's, I have come to the realization that this isn't "it".  The Lazy Man's Chioppino was very, very good. It's big enough for two people (I eat like a Javelina) so it's worth the $. Loaded with yummy ocean scraps! The Diplomat pasta was disappointing. I found the sauce to be quite bland and felt like I could have done better at home. Overall it's a good meal for the experience, but I'm not dying to go back like I was wishing.

mwSGMrH1Mv9mKq_qSRy17Q.review_text: I give 0 stars to this racist restaurant. You have old white men serving yet they think they're better than Mexicans who have money. I guess I needed to be with white people to be served. Terrible. I came once on my anniversary with my husband years ago. This time I brought my 2 year old daughter. No water no food nothing. Who starves a 2 year old. Never coming back.

f4chSy9hAc1dampwEuuU0Q.review_text: AMAZING! The best hands down! Got calamari, salmon and chowder. Best I've ever had of all pricey but no that going in was worth every penny

9wlUBq5mGXyt1VoMPhTffg.review_text: This is place is amazing. The seafood can't get any fresher. We had the crab louis salad, with which you receive a mound of crab that is well worth the price. We also had the crab risotto. Amazing. Cooked perfectly and extremely tasty. The staff was very attentive and the desert, the white chocolate raspberry cheesecake was delicious as well. The decor is consistent with the rich history of the restaurant. Enjoy the experience. I highly recommend it to anyone.

fUSsb6zgdAWAAYxvTapr2g.review_text: My family has been coming to Scoma's since I was young. Every time I am in San Francisco I make sure to stop by here. Normally I order the lobster bisque and shrimp louie, but I was feeling adventurous on my most recent visit here and got the Cioppino...beyond amazing! Pretty pricey so a good special occasion restaurant, but I always make sure to recommend Scoma's to any friends visit SF. Food, service, ambiance, and the view are all phenomenal!

oMrI1VlYPTNzstOz6kELug.review_text: It's been a few weeks since I went for the first time for my birthday dinner, But I feel like I need to give this place a hand for the awesome birthday dinner I had. After a very long wait a Saturday night (30+minutes), they generously gave us a window table so we could see a bit of the bay/sunset.  Appetizer  Calamari- best ever and best dish of the night to me!!! So perfectly crispy and well-seasoned without being too heavy.  Comes with a very delicious tartar sauce and spicy tomato-based sauce.   Entrees  Mussels in white wine/garlic sauce instead of a tomato-base- very very good, the sauce was more of an afterthought but the mussels were very fresh. I liked this base much more than the cioppino.  Cioppino- Great seafood, but not the best tomato sauce (too watery, not memorable in terms of taste). Since the sauce was so bland and the dish was hyped so much I had really high expectations and though the seafood itself was steamed/cooked well I would not order it again. Nothing in the soupy sauce enhanced the seafood to me.   Wonderful free Birthday dessert:)!!!! Splendidly rich fudge cake with some whip cream, raspberry sauce, and powdered sugar.  Fantastic serivce once we were seated (water filled all the time, wonderfully kind waitress) and ambiance overall. Will come back for the Calamari whenever I'm in SF:)!!

rIlKbwT4_CGq5ghWuwUVYQ.review_text: When I was looking up places to eat in San Francisco, this place had me with the fact is overseeing the pier. So romantic (I'm a sucker, I know)! The place is a bit hard to find but It looks very classy once you do. The interior decor could use some updating because it has an antique feel to it. The service here was outstanding. Just when I was running out of bread, fresh bread appeared.   I had the lobster bisque to start and it was so good. Creamy. I wanted more. For the main course, I ordered the Salmon on lobster ravioli and it had distinct hints of lime that made it one of the best seafood dishes I've ever had.   It is a bit pricey but we came for my birthday so it was worth it.

aGUZKSRPA-MHHj6b8GhOww.review_text: When in San Francisco, go with seafood. On a referral from my boss, Scoma's was the place to go. Situated in the wharf area, Scoma's is tucked away from the street, almost secluded. They process the seafood on premises - cleaning, filleting, etc. You can watch them through a picture-glass window right next to the restaurant. The interior design is nautically themed, yet classic. A long bar is near the entrance where you can have a libation while waiting for your table. The dining room is beautiful with glass on both sides of the restaurant. While there's not much to see at night, we did watch seagulls perch on the wooden wharf beams outside watching us eat our dinner. I love clam chowder and it is usually one of my staples that I use to test the level of the food. This has to be the best clam chowder I've ever had! It's creamy, buttery, and chocked full of clams. It was held and served at the perfect temperature so the cream didn't break. I worked with clam chowder for 9 years at Disneyland and you really had to watch the holding temperature. Once the cream breaks, the soup loses its creamy texture (almost like curdled milk) and needs to be discarded. The fresh cracked black pepper on top sealed the deal. Scoma's, you had me at "clam chowder"! I decided to try something off of their daily special menu, Lobster Raviolis topped with lobster tail and salmon fillet. It was pretty good. The salmon needed a little more seasoning, but had a nice buttery flavor and soft texture. The lobster tail was tender and perfectly cooked. The raviolis were okay. I would have liked more herbs like tarragon, rosemary, and/or oregano to punch up the sauce as it was a little heavy.  My mom ordered the Dungeness Crab.  As it was summer, it was out of season so it was "fresh frozen". She was a little disappointed that she couldn't have the insides (miso or mustard of the crab) as they are cleaned out when prepped. Our server assured us that if we came back during Dungeness crab season that we could order it with the "miso" intact. She enjoyed every bit of it as it came out steaming hot and ate it to make our ohana proud, bib and all. Our meal ended with roses. A man proposed to his future bride that night. They were leaving on a flight back to China and couldn't take them. The staff gave us a couple to take back to our hotel room. They were beautiful!

6xH5ZQ80KWAJk81lLRI3HA.review_text: Very friendly staff and awesome selection of dishes. The portions are large and well prepared. However, the sauces are somewhat generic and lack authenticity.   Upon arrival, the friendly staff seated us immediately. The waiter was awesome and offered great insight into the menu selections. The service was prompt and people came by frequently to check on us.  The food looked absolutely amazing, but the generic tasting sauces damper the plentiful seafood selections offered. The seafood was fresh and varied in selection.   All-in-all, good food at a not so great price. For what you should be getting and all the hype this restaurant has, you don't receive that level.

xsq_bpGYLoPpuzUTDbifDw.review_text: Service was good, food was so-so.  The garlic-roasted crab didn't have as much flavor as I was expecting.  Nice that it's on the water, but the view isn't as good as some of the other places in the Wharf.

obYOl9fLdlvU_0nRmGY1Bg.review_text: The place is old school italian place which I love....You get the mom and pops vibe right away. The food was amazing. The Deep fried calamari is the best. I ordered salmon on veggies, it was amazing. Better than any Seattle salmon I have had. The staff  is very nice. Free bread.

p3sTKtdZp5WriTptjd5XpA.review_text: Everything about this place was underwhelming. 4 stars with over 1000 reviews must mean a great place right? Nope - one of the rare occasions that Yelp led me astray.  The restaurant was an average looking building, average decor with rickity cheap tables and chairs. Their highly rated lobster bisque was very mediocre with zero traces of real lobster. The calamari had way too much breading for how thinly sliced the actual squid was. The $17 shrimp cocktail with "jumbo" shrimp came with 6 average sized shrimp. While their fish was fresh, they made zero effort into cooking a good meal with it. We got the mixed platter with (teeny pieces of) swordfish, salmon and halibut. Each fish tasted exactly the same because it was purely just grilled - no spices, no sauces, just literally plain pieces of fish. It really says something about a seafood restaurant when my favorite thing of the meal was the mashed potatoes. Overall, just a big tourist trap getting you to pay double/triple the price for measly portions of very bland, generic food.  I don't mind shelling out for a good meal but when I spend more than $50 on dinner per person, I expect the quality of the food to match the price tag. I'm assuming most places around Fisherman's Wharf have fresh fish and I'd much rather go a chain like Joe's crab shack or Bubba Gump for a more fun experience at a fraction of the cost.

mIo2cFs_89a7i0DWHT9F-w.review_text: After multiple trips to Scoma's I still can't give this San Francisco institution more than three stars. I know I am going against the grain but I can't compromise my honesty.  Here is how I came to this conclusion:  - Pricey: $190 for a bad Louis salad, one good entree, two mediocre entrees and a glass of house white wine -Seating: The chairs remind me on banquet chair.  There isn't much space between tables either. -Views:  Old fishing trawlers and assorted other beat up boats with an occasional seal. -Food: Swordfish piccata was yummy. The rest of it was unremarkable (Louis salad, crab cakes, seared tuna). Seared tuna was overdone.

TQ42P2aYySg7PMJi37okaA.review_text: This is my go-to seafood restaurant in the city, and one locals and other chefs go to. The others in the Wharf are tourist traps.  Get the Cioppino altho all the fish dishes are fresh.  Pricey, but worth it, unlike the other ripoffs nearby.

xVVPna8jYyCE0wXutPJBeQ.review_text: Second time here, and I am still lovin it!!!  I love Tomato sauce and pesto...  A lot of people think only tourists go cuz it's at the middle of Fisherman's wharf...but NO-NO-NO! everytime I go I see a lot of californians, plus the servers look like they have been workin there FOREVER! That is another good point, they KNOW what they are serving, some of them you may need to talk a bit louder cuz they are so old but that is another cute point..LOL  Oh the seafood....you can tell they are FRESH!!! it just taste different than frozen ones!

on-Qrl1jinXhI0MNMo8MvQ.review_text: This place is just plain good.  I know it's in a tourist area, but don't hold that fact against the food.  My favorite is the shellfish Saute Sec.  A heap of seafood sauteed and served with pasta.  The lazy man's chioppino is also a favorite.  You can't go wrong though...I've had several meals here.   The roasted dungeness crab is also very good. Come as you are.  There will be t-shirts and business suits.  Just enjoy the food.    The wine list is very good.  Might I recommend the Cakebread chardonnay to go with your fish??

2a2oNBUWM8PXDdJihIRNsg.review_text: one of my favorite seafood restaurants.... i always order; triple saute sec (crab, jumbo prawns, scallops) calamari clam chowder

q7kebVCt7dfxYmDsweRmuQ.review_text: Exactly what I expected from a fisherman's wharf experience. This might be my only time in San Francisco and I wanted a great meal...I got it here. Service was very understated and unobtrusive. No surprises and I feel like I got my moneys worth.

JbDKGivaU6jdVGYjv7ekjQ.review_text: The seafood is spectacular. It's a bit on the pricey side, but if can spend it, it's well worth it. Each main course averages $28, but a assure you, it won't be regretted.

Baow2ccooo19HoCO7cNXbw.review_text: Sits by itself on one of the quieter piers, tucked away safely from the hordes of tourists with their shopping bags full of fake jade and Chinatown souvenirs that were made in Japan.
