Once inside, you can't help but feel like a SF insider.  The long bar at the front can get a little crowded with diners waiting to be seated.  Our wait at prime time on a Thursday was 40 minutes, but the bartenders were both busy and attentive, so no problem.  My Clams (in the shell) over Linguine with white sauce was the best I'v had in recent years.  Zero grit.  If you're a clam lover you know how rare that is.  My dining companion was extermely pleased with her salmon.  You must have the bread.  It's San Francisco after all.  The wait staff were polished professionals.

NeTXy5d4as9xpZOCBgELCQ.review_text: I have been fortunate to have been going to Scoma's for the last 30 years and recently had the opportunity to introduce the experience to my son and fiancé.  Scoma's still has the same retro feel, '50's charm without being pretentious ........ Professional waiters in jackets, white tablecloths and napkins.  You, also, cannot beat the location - amongst the fishing boats at end of a pier in Fisherman's Wharf.  The food ........ was, as always, SPECTACULAR!  The best in Seafood! With so many restaurants to choose from in San Francisco, whether visiting or looking for a special night out - check out this gem!

F262q88zc7zsdEeNCzcA0A.review_text: Popped into Scoma's on a warm Thursday evening with some friends from out of town in an effort to avoid some of the more 'touristy' locales. I called to make a reservation on our walk over but they were fully booked so they recommended walking in as it looked like they'd be able to accommodate our group of six with a 15 - 20 minute wait. We were pleasantly surprised to find that they actually had a table for us immediately when we walked into the restaurant.   Our server greeted us promptly and got us set up with a round of cocktails that we enjoyed while we decided what to order.   The beau and I shared a mixed green salad to start. For my main I ordered one of their daily catches, broiled (Halibut) and he ordered a bowl of their Clam Chowder. Mine was served with a side of seasoned veggies and a walloping scoop of roasted garlic mashed potatoes. His chowder was jam packed full of fresh clams and the bowl sized portion wasn't too gigantic.   The rest of the table ordered a Wild Caught Salmon entree and a Shrimp & Smoked Salmon Linguine which looked amazing.   Everything was well prepared and I was a big fan of how fresh the fish was!   I don't know that I'd race back to Scoma's any time soon because it does feel a bit touristy (and maybe a little dated -- don't pop in expecting some super innovative gastronomic-hipster menu), but for being on the Wharf you can expect a good fresh meal, attentive servers and a classy ambiance.

PBCG_JpmsVNHoU6y-ojFfg.review_text: Went for a last minute meal, sat at the bar, Steve was awesome, oysters Rockefeller... JAM!!!

oBpWAd-xV0_7xX0ZLYd8GA.review_text: Didn't even make it to the table. Walked in at about 11:05 (apparently they don't serve food till 11:30). What looked like a manager and a server stood about 3 feet from us and had a casual conversation which each other for about 3 minutes without even looking at us or acknowledging us. There was another woman who walked in at the same time we did, we assume a local regular. This woman made a comment about the hostess MAYBE getting to us eventually. Then the hostess popped up out of the hostess stand and made a rude comment to the woman and rolled her eyes.  She told us she could seat us but they don't serve food till 11:30. We said NOPE and went elsewhere. Talk about rude hospitality. I don't care how good the food is supposed to be...with unfriendly service like that as soon as you walk in the door, I'm moving on.

WxwHJRntzBg3VumBYfVhZA.review_text: Had a truly fantastic experience at this place the first time I visited San Francisco. Mostly due to great company, but the seafood was very tasty and they had a great wine selection. After 47 years of making clam chowder, you would hope they would be good at it, and they are! Expensive and tourist-y, but if you're exploring Fisherman's Warf and are in the market for a not-a-suit-and-tie but not a jeans-and-a-t-shirt place then Scoma's is the one! I'd like to think this is a place I would take my parents if they were paying ;) I won't be having any birthdays or lunch dates here but I definitely think it was an integral part of my first trip to San Francisco.

s2o_JsABvrZVm_T03qrBUw.review_text: It was a grand meal to finish off our one day in San Francisco!  I began with a bowl of a superior creamy and luscious New England Clam Chowder, followed by a Mixed Greens Salad with light Thousand Island Dressing.  The greens were mixed with rich red tomato slices, Black Olives, beets, and Radicchio.  Moist Sourdough Bread and butter added a splendid touch to these preliminaries.  Server Waiman over-peppered the salad, but otherwise provided great service, including new silverware for each course.  He dissuaded me from ordering Potatoes au Gratin, and gave me Sauteed Spinach as a vegetable accompaniment to my chosen entree of grilled Petrale Dore Sole.  The delicate fish was fork tender, golden, lightly battered, and super-tasty adorned with some drips of heavenly ultra-fine and mild homemade Tartar Sauce.  Also on the plate was some oily Penne, which did not have much flavor.    Diane very much liked her Lobster Newburg made with Provolone Cheese.  And,  both of our entree portions were quite large.  While dining, we had a nice view of moored fishing fleet vessels just outside.    An excellent seafood dinner from start to finish!  Expensive, but worth it!

iw7k_JJhDn8PkV9w-aM_ww.review_text: Ok so this would be more of a 4.5/5 stars, but yelp doesn't allow for it. This restaurant has been here for as long as I can remember. We used to come here every year. It was our go to place to bring family from out of town and it never failed to impress. If you want to eat at a decent time, make a reservation!! The wait on any given day can be 30 min to 2 hours.   If and when you do come you ABSOLUTELY MUST get the clam chowder because it is quite honestly the BEST I've ever had here in CA. The lobster bisque is also to die for (if I were any less civilized I would have licked the bowl). Their grilled scallops were amazing, fresh, and cooked to perfection. Personally I'm a sucker for cioppino and the one here is super tasty and loaded with seafood. Fish here is cooked perfectly - flaky and fresh (can't really go wrong with any fish you order). The seafood pastas here are enough to feed 2 comfortably and they are def not stingy on the seafood. Another must get is the calamari (they have spicy or regular) - so GOOD!! Perfectly crispy/seasoned on the outside and tender on the inside.    Cons:  - Possible long wait times for tables  - On the pricey side (BUT totally worth the splurge - trust me!)  Pros: - Giant portion sizes  - Seafood is very fresh - Great atmosphere (slightly old fashioned, but classy) - Service is always top notch  - Free valet parking

b6armaswyJDiEYZKQHnYsg.review_text: This was absolutely marvelous! Worth of waiting for 40 minutes in the bar, worth of waiting 40 minutes of cooking! Our 1/2 spicy garlic crab and mix of sea-creatures was absolutely awesome! 5 star!   Ah, waiters! Worth of extra twenty :) great guys!

53bZ_EsXH71L7iFs5MP9_w.review_text: The drive down the Embaradero was excruciating.  Took 20 minutes to get down 1 mile of road, we finally turned on a side street and followed the parallel road.    So happy to find FREE valet in one of the most crowded areas in the city.    Our party of four was told the wait was going to be about 20 minutes, but it ended up being about 45 minutes, it was 5pm on a Saturday.    I can understand why it would be painful waiting outside in the cold, but really grab a stool and just order a cocktail.  It made EVERYTHING rosy.  The bartenders are quite warm.    Scoma's doesn't do revolutionary food, but well executed fresh seafood.  Take advantage of the $35 tasting menu, a special menu offered after 5pm, appetizer, entree and dessert, there is a pretty good selection.  One in our party ordered, while the rest of us ordered ala carte.  Very flexible.    Flowing freebies: water was a plenty and the bread was always filled.  Kind of old school with the refrigerated butter wrapped in foil, but the EVOO was a welcome relief.    The cioppino was gargantuan, I was kind of put off by the $37 pricetag, when it came to the table, it definitely changed my mind, I can make 4 meals out of the bowl.  So many fresh ingredients and bucketloads of it.  I'm used to a dainty portion.  What I would have liked more of was the toasted garlic bread.  Soaking it in the tomato based broth was heavenly.  The filet was served with sides, hearty portions and a great sear.  The desserts were good, I especially enjoyed my tiramisu, fluffy and strong espresso flavor.      It was a fun meal hosting out of town guests, but I wouldn't put myself through the ringer to eat here on a regular basis.

BUeueHeX3mzlyEBEEK9quQ.review_text: Father's Day 2014...  My wife and daughters brought me to Scoma's Restaurant because they thought I am the coolest Dad in the world, beating the likes of Cliff Huxtable, Tim Taylor, and Al Bundy.  I know they are just being kind because that distinction belongs to the one and only Homer Jay Simpson.  I probably am a distant second, but I don't mind taking a backseat to one S-M-R-T man.  For our dinner, we ordered a bowl of Scoma's Famous Clam Chowder, Calamari Fritti, the Prix Fixe Dinner, and the much heralded Lazy Man's Cioppino.  Scoma's Famous Clam Chowder is one of the better clam chowders not served in a sourdough bread.  It is the creamy kind with plenty of chopped up clams.  The Calamari Fritti was tender with a well-seasoned and crusty exterior.  The Prix Fixe Dinner consisted of Lobster Bisque with Lobster Salad and Chive Aioli as the appetizer, Calico Scallops and Fettuccini as the entrée, and Chocolate Brownie with Vanilla Bean Ice Cream as the dessert.  The appetizer was good but very minimal.  My daughter seemed to enjoy the entrée which had sun-dried tomato and cream.  Everybody shared the dessert in a hurry to prevent the warm brownie from melting the ice cream.  The contrast in temperature made this so enjoyable.  Saving the best for the last, I have to give them props for their Lazy Man's Cioppino.  From the freshness of the ingredients to the taste of the broth, this has been the best of all the cioppinos we have tried.  This is a notch above my favorite at Woodhouse Fish Co. and I will pick this over Sotto Mare's self-proclaimed "Best Damn Crab Cioppino" any day.  Cioppino's at Jefferson St. has their lazy man's version as well but it is definitely not in the same class.  I have also recently tried the cioppino at Sam's Chowder House at Half Moon Bay, Vivolo's Chowder House at Pacific Grove, and Brophy Brothers at Santa Barbara and none of them came close.  I have yet to try Tadich Grill, Anchor Oyster Bar, or Crab House at Pier 39 so I will have to update this  when I get the chance to try theirs.  Dining at Scoma's can be costly but it is well worth the price especially when celebrating a special occasion.  This is worthy of a 5-star rating but I had to take away a star because they have that "controversial" 4% surcharge that some of the San Francisco restaurants collect supposedly for the health and welfare of their staff.  I think we have paid more than enough for the food, the tax, the tip, and even the to-go container that we don't want to see anymore surcharges on our bill.  Other than that, everything else went very well...

DUXIpVywYq63USg4kdF1RA.review_text: Sometimes old school italian like you would see in the movies sounds good, but sometimes it's just like a bad restaurant in a touristy area of town with pictures of famous italian actors from the 70's.  Sadly Scoma's falls in to the latter of the two groups.  The food looked like something between cafeteria food and something you would get from a restaurant just off the jersey turnpike.  I'll stop there...

v8v20odlEnoGEhnbAtJ0qw.review_text: I went here recently and felt compelled to write a review on it. We had a great week in Wine Country and San Francisco and ate at some great places.  The Cioppino at Scomas was the most expensive of the meals that we ate. I have to say that it ranked towards the middle or bottom of meals that we ate that week.  The place is nice enough, beautifully placed and very quaint. We enjoyed the wine at the bar whilst waiting for our table.  We just went right into the meal and I had the cioppino and my wife had another seafood dish. It wasn't until after we had ordered that I was informed that there were no clams left. That meant there was no shell fish in the dish at all.  It was tasty enough, not fantastic, but for $37 I definitely felt short changed.

xvIk2MWmxZhXhgJzqx6shQ.review_text: Ate at several restaurants while in SF this weekend, very disappointed until dining at Scomas!  Totally the "wow" we have been waiting for! From seating, to bus staff, wait staff to end of meal. WOW! Meal was excellent, service was  great and meal was awesome!  Totally recommend Scoma's!  John B was the BOMB!

53d21ffI9ReM7L6iO5EN1w.review_text: Shellfish sauté sec  The boyfriend decided to take me to the city for a day of "fun". After shopping in Union Square, he decided to take me to Scoma's for dinner. We tried calling for reservation, but they weren't taking any. The wait was going to be 30 mins. Trust me it was totally worth it. I got the shellfish sauté sec along with a glass of merlot. It was so worth it. We didn't talk much because I was too busy eating. It's amazing and we got the window table,too. The service was great and I honestly couldn't ask for more. It was a great way to end our day.

q3I9eS1_Smr5-zGFeLff6g.review_text: We all had a good time . The food was good and filling.  The clam chowder was delicious as was the clams on the half shell.  The steamed lobster was ok. The Shrimp Louis was good and they served my wife's allergy need for no gluten and no dairy well.  I'm ready for the next Bay Area trip.

ZS1SinwKRtKp59QFPUDB_g.review_text: This is an awesome old school seafood restaurant in San Francisco. its out on the wharf and they dont take reservations.   The lobster Thermidor is the best and i have tried it in several other countries and no one comes close to making it better.  A great place to take someone special! Service is prompt and always professional with a smile.

qR81na-L8R84KAtcLdc_SA.review_text: lunch prefix~ clam chowder and bread were good~ crab and shrimp salad was OK chocolate cake was good (a little sweet)

0BA8Hgj47MH_KcRALF8EIw.review_text: My favorite SFO restaurant.  They don't have the crab sandwich on their menu but are more than happy to make it for you.  White table cloth, real napkins, real silverware, nicely dressed waters, super friendly service, and out of the tourist rush just add to the total experience.

eWLfQTpl53Tuo7_BSMlT2Q.review_text: We went on a recommendation from a friend who, incidentally, left us a gift certificate there. My first impression was relief at the fact that the restaurant sits far back from the craziness that is fisherman's wharf. We were promptly seated at a window table. The service was top-notch; our water glasses were always full. The martinis were excellent and the food was even better.  Loved it.

HXaTtrixwuGKVGfO6o-ppQ.review_text: This is my second visit to SF and I've done as much as can be expected of a tourist, from Giants baseball to local bar hotspots. Being from Hawaii, where tourism is an important industry, I understand attractions, cost, service, and other factors that go into making a visit a quality experience. So my humble opinion here comes a background that gives perspective.  SCOMA is located on a pier jutting out into SF Bay, away (behind) everything else at Fisherman's Wharf. If you're not looking for it, you'll probably miss it. The view of the bay and Golden Gate Bridge is fantastic from Fisherman's Wharf. Location: 4.5 Star.  Note, if you grab a seat at the bar, you'll have to clear the tab separate from your meal. SCOMA will improve it's service if customers can do a one-time-pay. When we were seated, Maitre d' and bar waitress miscommunicated and our transition from the bar area to sitting area was confusing. I ended up carrying our drinks to our table. Suggestion for SCOMA: When a customer is told there is a wait, offer the bar immediately as an option. Have a waithelp sit them and communicate with the wait help when the table is ready and allow the bar tab to be transferred to the meal tab. Pre-meal experience: 3 Star.  Now the highlight: Dinner. Our waiter, Simon, knows what it takes to put a smile on people's faces. He is very knowledgeable of the menu, pairings, and gifted at making people feel at ease. Simon, you ROCK!Service: 5 Star.  The overall experience was very good. The meal was very tasty; portions were HUGE. The price is a little high (est. @ $50 per person for one drink, appetizer, entree, dessert, and tip), but heck, you're on vacation, so plan on a splurge and this, in my humble opinion, is worth it.

EnwaphnOTnhaRfMIS7hMMA.review_text: 3.5 stars --     I love the location (fisherman's wharf - yay!) and liked that the restaurant was nice and clean.  The service was great and the menu had plenty of options, but nothing about our meal really stood out.  The bf ordered the lobster and I, the lazy man's cioppino.  Initially we were really impressed with the presentation.  The serving sizes were generous and everything looked so flavorful.  However, after taking a few bites, we were both left unimpressed.  The best thing about the meal was that the cioppino came with a buttered piece of toast that when combined with the cioppino's broth was AMAZING.  But isn't it kind of sad that the best thing about our seafood dinner was the buttery bread?    I would still go back and give Scoma's another chance because the seafood did taste fresh and our overall experience was nice.  However, I think our money would be better spent on some of their other dishes.  We shall see...

yAA4i2O5APHbJJpxh26I6g.review_text: I have been here quite a bit. The last time the crab legs smelled fishey. They are supper expensive so I was really disappointed. They have usually really good seafood so maybe this was just a one time event. The overall feal of the restaurant is nice and clean. The staff is usually freindly and warm.

ivY2lVOdYFVq_v0qu81ckg.review_text: My wife's aunt used to love this place so we had to try it when we came into town.  We were not disappointed.  I had the Cioppino.  While I did like the Cioppino at Cioppino's around the corner, this was much better.   It was a huge bowl and absolutely loaded with delicious seafood.  Would definately come back on the next trip

QZNLJ68kuS51Tlqljvf3ow.review_text: It is off the beaten path, but it's worth the walk off the main drag.  The food is excellent and the service is solid.  Old school and a family favorite for many years.

iZ4kRJm0ghqZJ5w2EPY4KQ.review_text: Great calamari! Some of the best I have had and I don't eat seafood! Artichoke and spinach salad were great too

vPw0gHjjFRzklcekC5qlgw.review_text: I ordered the seafood pasta from the pre fixe lunch menu.  The food was delicious, was a great value.  The decor is definitely outdated but I know some people like that.

yR-6YxGdgNJTBfJtQ5CmRw.review_text: Ahhh another SF great spot. I've been coming here since I was little kid. Totally touristy for the most part but it reminds me of old San Francisco. I like to play tourist once and a while and come to the Warf. The dishes come with big portions of whatever you get. I usually get the halibut or sea food pasta and it is always so good. Yes its full of butter goodness but its OK to eat like that once in a while.. DON'T JUDGE ME! :-)   The service is almost always great and the waiters are so nice and cheerful. Tourist or not this is a great place to get some food and enjoy San Francisco.

_97mETTo80KxClh1sOV36Q.review_text: I have returned to Scoma's again and once again I was very happy. I felt that an additional review was in order and to encourage Scoma's to keep doing what they do. One of the most pleasant experiences is having good food and consistent food each time you eat at one of your fav restaurants. Thanks once again.  Don't hesitate to give Scoma's a try. The prices are about consistent with other restaurants in the area but I do feel the food is top notch here. I wish I could eat here more often but grateful each time that I can.   I believe if you make the right choice on food that you will be happy with your experience at Scoma's. I'm not the only one that raves about Scoma's as is evident by AAA, TripAdvisor, Local Tour Guide Brochures, and even Yelp. Bravo Scoma's.

1q5cgaoa8k4Rxn6ZoAT8og.review_text: We only had 2 days to spend in San Fran and were looking for one of the best non-commercial places to get fresh delicious seafood!  After a recommendation from our cab driver we decided to check this place out.  WE ARE SO GLAD WE DID!  Their service was wonderful, everyone was very nice and accommodating.  Servers were prompt to refill drinks and remove plates etc... but the real gem of this wonderful restaurant was of course the food!  It was amazing!  The portions were great, the flavor was perfect!  If we lived in San Francisco we would be regulars.  We will be eating at Scoma's again when in SF.

mVVKTOLK1qt0hxNNh_UCIg.review_text: First of all,I love Scoma's. I have been eating here for close to 20 years, and the food has always been excellent. However on my most recent visit I was disappointed to learn that they had replaced their excellent rice pilaf with a chewy risotto and rice mix that  has very little flavor. They have also gotten rid of the vegetable mix of broccoli, cauliflower, and carrots! These accompanied one of my favorite entrees, the prawns and scallops alla Gannon which I will no longer order until they return to serving it with the rice pilaf and vegetable mix.

FjoX_MlzeWijmwkpfjFCSw.review_text: Haven't had a lot of fresh seafood in such a while so my wife and I indulged in shrimp cocktail and fresh calamari (best calamari ever!), we shared Halibut and the Salmon over lobster raviolli. Both were great but the Halobut here rocks!

A6otCnofv6GXDh7Ib7TTjA.review_text: We had lunch here on a Saturday and were not very impressed. The prices were high, food was average, and the decor was really in need of an update. However, our waiter Heros was very friendly, entertaining, and helpful! His conversation was the best part.

aCzl4NTQhboRsQe_BVP2FA.review_text: My company went here for our Christmas party.  It was on Pier 47.  The view was really nice.  The ambiance was nice as well.  It wasn't too upscale so I felt comfortable.  The waiters were really helpful and friendly.  I ordered the Dungeness Crabcake and Tiramisu for dessert.  The crabcake melted in my mouth.  It was delicious and the Tiramisu was delicious as well.  The price was a little too high for me to go on a regular basis, but if you are looking for a romantic night out it would be worth every penny.  They have valet parking as well because you know in  SF, parking sucks.

zaojrY1aTjOE0-VCsMOLIQ.review_text: I know it's a touristy place, but in many ways it's a relatively quiet respite from the crazies in the fisherman's wharf area. I love the great views, the food is excellent and convenient, free parking! Tough to beat for value, food and ambience!

we12CxrV1tgXtp2W1DNlpA.review_text: The service was great but the food could've been better. The crab wasn't anything spectacular (good, but not great) and there was no clam chowder in a bread bowl! (They only had bread on the side).  The location of the restaurant is past a small little alley which is a bit iffy at night, but the place was pretty crowded.   I ordered the "ARANCINI DI RISO CON GRANCHI" and thought that it was actually crab (legs), but it was just 2 small meatball type of things that was not worth $16. Probably my fault for being foolish listening to the waiter's recommendation.   Overall, everything is just too expensive here for what it's worth!

sO1VpoTPs8TRj2WEMRpV7A.review_text: We are huge fans of Scomas.  Why?  The food is superb and most of the time the service is excellent.  This is old school San Francisco. No reservations, so you have to be willing to wait, but it's worth it.  Amazing soups (including the crab-corn chowder)  Dwayne loves the Chippino- the best in the world.  I ususally get a shellfish dinner, but on Saturday had the Lobster Thermador and it was one of the most delicious things I've ever eaten.  You always get fresh veggies and pasta or rice with dinner.  The wine list is very  nice- you can easily find an affordable but nice bottle.  We're ususally too full for desert.  The place is usually packed and noisy but the food is amazing and Scomas is always a must everything we're in San Francisco.

ZotHaGopBt4WRZv3pi_N6w.review_text: Let me start by saying that if this place wasn't so pricey it would have gotten 2 stars, even though that isn't really saying anything good.   My husband and I essentially just paid $80 for soup and iced tea, because those are the only two things we enjoyed.   We ordered the Swordfish and the Petrale Dore.   The Swordfish was slightly better than the Dore, but it tasted exactly like the pancetta it was cooked with. No one wants their fish to taste like pork.   My Dore was exactly what the menu said, so I guess it's my fault for thinking that they would make a fried piece of fish with lemon butter sauce in an inventive way and worthy of a $30 price tag...silly me. The sides also added absolutely nothing to the meal. They were steamed veggies and plain boiled penne pasta. I mean plain as in nothing on them, not even olive oil.   How this place has the reviews it has, I don't understand. Maybe we ordered the wrong things from the menu, but in my opinion, a restaurant at this price range and with this level of hype shouldn't have "the wrong thing".  Our waiter was pleasant, however, he only stopped by our table 4 times and 3 of them were to bring food and the check. He practically spent the entire length of our dinner in the corner with another table. It was a 6 top vs our 2, so I guess that was the smart move on his part in regards to tips. Oh and just a side note, my water glass was very very dirty, but I just switched with my hubby since he didn't drink his.  I am a true foodie at heart...and I absolutely will spend top dollar for a great meal without a second thought. But this meal actually ruined my night. I had my hopes set so high and was so excited, but was so let down. You can ask my husband...he even said I looked like someone stole my puppy (I told you a true foodie). I in no way, based on my experience, can recommend anyone to go here for anything other than the clam chowder. It, my husband said, was better than any he has had on the east coast. So that is the one star this place gets.   Lastly, if I haven't convinced you enough, another group walking from the restaurant down Jones actually gave away their leftovers to a homeless man, and he said it felt like an entire plate of food in the to-go box. So, I guess they didn't enjoy theirs either. We didn't even bother taking ours to-go.  Moral of this story: Save your money and time, go to Aliotos crab stand, and order a crab salad sandwich for $7. We had that for lunch today, and it was 10X's better and 10X's cheaper than what we were just served at Scoma's.

RtgCT46nnIJkDNJM1FpaJQ.review_text: Ordered the lobster bisque and the whole crab.  The lobster bisque was amped up with cream to make up for the lack of lobster.  The whole crab was disappointing - like this restaurant buys the crabs which are too small for the street vendors to try to sell.  Also, where's the head?  The whole crab was 2 sets of legs without the crab body.  Overall, food was a disappointment, especially for a place with such good reviews.  If you want crab then buy it on the street, because you'll see what you get.

Nn6QP-y8truHGi18WSmj_Q.review_text: Scoma's is amazing! The food is outstanding and the service is great. This place is a fine restaurant to head out to if you're looking for an amazing place to have a dinner in Fisherman's Wharf with class and elegance. The proportions are generous and are what you could expect from the best of the Wharf. Forget the touristy crap in the area and head here for an enjoyable evening in a great location.

YGbj097watzBh1XAn7HTew.review_text: Get here before rush hours or be sorry!  The Swordfish is SUPER, as is the chowder.  Vegetables tasted fresh and were steamed to perfection.  Oysters Rockefeller were perfect.  Be prepared to pay a price for what you get.  Well worth the spluge.  Have ate here a number of times and had co-workers and family eat here and all we happy.  Service is second to none.

VwUG8ifJNsyROCBKFpBxhA.review_text: I friggin love this place. Been here 2 times before but have to come when in SF. I was in Sonoma and rented a car to drive here with my wife.  We started with the calamari fritti which is fresh, lightly fried and delicious. The horseradish is light so even my wife didnt think spicy.   She had half dungeness crab which was perfect for her. I had cup of clam chowder which was hot, fresh and very flavorful. I had the lobster tails which were 12oz and very tender, with green beans and wild rice. I eagerly finished all but the rice. We paired with the 2012  Benizinger Chardonnay which worked well, though we finished a bottle.  We saved a little room and had brownie and vanilla ice cream. I worked Tue ice cream and my wife said the brownie was excellent. Always awesome here.

rUP76_8OJclekKlui7OJ0A.review_text: Been a faithful at Scoma's for years but unfortunately, after I noticed a charge of 4% FOR EMPLOYEE HEALTH AND WELFARE, I will no longer be dining there.  Enough is enough and I don't feel like contributing another cent to this administration and how they  run things! Excellent food however.  Valet is great.  No less than a 45 minute wait.

45LqjHBFm5wgz9e2-vB1sQ.review_text: Delicious food and good service. Freshest fish I have ever eaten that I did not catch myself.

YFegpu5QfkPummn9qRYhpg.review_text: My wife and I arrived on Sunday afternoon, around 1:30pm. We were guided to a table with a view of a small, dingy, dirty marina with boats that didn't appear "sea worthy" and so we asked to be seated at a table with a better view of the bay. Three were open but the host stated they were reserved, so we reluctantly accepted our seating fate... Now for the good news- Our service was quite good; our  waiter was knowledgeable and helpful. The timing of the delivery of our orders was superior. We shared the cold seafood sampler appetizer, a bowl of clam chowder and the "lazy man's" cioppino and all were delicious. The pricing is not cheap, but given the location on Fisherman's Wharf and the excellent quality of the food, it is a fair price. We'll go back and encourage our friends to enjoy Scoma's as well!

2T75R18Ds51BiPVS-iQg9g.review_text: I have never not been able to finish my meal because i was disgusted. However, After i saw the jumbo shrimp was NOT deveined, i nearly yacked.

anHzk1C0oQRtfuDj74p2RQ.review_text: Popped in right before they were closing to grab a couple glasses of wine and some calamari. Best part of the evening is the fact we were driven here in a brand new Bentley flying spur, which was awesome, so it began with us leaving AT&T park after watching USC crush CAL (Fight On), so we proceeded to try and catch a cab, but with no luck we walked down to the  St. Regis to catch a drink and instead were greeted by the doormen offering the house car for a tour of San Francisco. We accepted.   The driver opened the doors to the beautiful car, we got in, and drove us all over the city showing us different sites and telling us a little history about each location, while my fiance and I sat in back worried that we smelled funny after our rooftop tailgate before the game with friends, but he didn't seem to notice, and we certainly weren't going to bring it up. After he took us to a few wine bars he inquired about our lust for seafood and asked if he could suggest a spot, so we obliged and he took us to Scoma, but not before making sure a table was ready for us. We arrived and were greeted by an amazing staff and enjoyed some great bites to eat while sipping a fantastic Malbec. The long and short of it is this, we had a great evening with great food and wine, whcih cannot be beat by much.

tB8K22NTv8HXHysFnyrYqw.review_text: At pier 39 my gal pal and I decided to ask locals to find out where the best clam chowder was. At the info center there was a woman dressed in uniform. We asked her "Excuse where can we find the best clam chower?" Her answer: I am a vegetarian but I heard Scoma's has good chowder, gentleman bystander a few feet away overheard and interjected his $0.02, "I used to deliver seafood and scoma's has the best".   WHo were we to ignore not one but two mutual suggestions, so off we were to search for Scoma's. To get here you had to walk past the tempting crab and chowder stands. Scoma's is kinda hidden but you'll see an alley and it over at the right by the docks.   What we ballers on a budget had a cup of chowder each, relatively small portion for $6, the next step up was a bowl for $8. We also had a sampler plate of appetizers. It was our version of what we would have ordered at the stands except in a nice sit down restaurant.  The chowder: I could see why Scoma's was recommended, the chowder had big chunk of tender red clams, potatoes, celery bits and I believed scallops as well. It was definitely very chunky.  Good flavor and just the right amount of seasoning.  The appetizer plate: crab cakes, deep fried calamari, shrimp scampi. $16.  Service was very attentive with just the right amount of negligence for personal freedom. Do I recommend this place? Yes, but don't expect to find a divey diner, it's a fine establishment.

6lS5-2TYITCAL2snIqMx7g.review_text: I have been here several times, although I never checked in here.  All I can say, is this place rocks!!!!!!  I have never had a bad meal here, the service is always great, the food is consistently great, and for San Francisco, they offer free valet parking, and that is huge.  The seafood is great, the steaks will melt in your mouth, and the oysters are fabulous...  I strongly suggest you try this place if you have never been here....

0Od3PvCzzVfbX-RDR7G1rA.review_text: So gross overpriced tourist trough. I can't believe some of the 4 and 5 star reviews..!?!?!? Mediocre food (and that is being generous), scuzzy cheap atmosphere. I ordered the sand dabs that were slimy while somehow still being overcooked. Eew!   I got dragged here by my ever-desperate-to-be-classy stepmother...who thinks class is wearing coordinated denim 'outfits' and triple dangle earrings on each ear.   SF natives or long-time residents would never, dream of eating at Fisherman's Wharf, but I was way too tolerant and acquiesced.

xwlHo-QHxB8BM9jb2ITirg.review_text: This was my second stop for Cioppino tour of San Francisco. We ordered crab cakes and the cioppino for a sunday lunch. Didnt order the shelled kind. I like getting my hands dirty.   So far this is the best one Ive had yet in SF. The stew had a whole bunch of fish, crab, mussels, clams, shirimp. The broth must have been made with a fish stock. Not just a watery marinara. The only down side was I really like a good garlic bread with the cioppino. The bread was a nice crusty sourdough. Still good.   So far this is where I would go for Cioppino!

u8jjbJTtYPNjhTzQgloDTw.review_text: Sourdough bread was served cold not warm- gross - we Ordered a salad and calamari for an appetizer - salad was weak on flavor and dressing and calamari wasn't impressive at all- I would recommend switching from fritters to calamari strips - And dinner we had the lobster ravioli and blackened salmon. It Was decent good flavor. Small portions for such high prices. Our waiter was good though. Waste of  $100 in my mind.

PEkp7T-uOgUq5AIQ5obt2A.review_text: Best seafood place in the city. It's been said again and again and needs repeating.  However, on my trip today I wanted a steak. The lunch price fix menu was $23.00 and included a cup of their delicious clam chowder, a 6oz New York Strip and a chocolate torte with raspberry sauce and whipped cream. How could I turn that down? I was the only one to order from the lunch menu and I was the only one to finish my meal. This lunch special runs until 3:30pm and offers many choices for the main meal, crab salad, swordfish, steak and seafood pasta. A great way to get a taste of Scoma's without spending $40 on an entree.  My mom insists on coming here every time she visits. She's paying so it's all good!

DGszSnRNWoAOtD8WGf9wpg.review_text: After my mother told me this was my father's favorite place to eat in SF period! I knew I had to come to this place and see what he loved so much. You see my dad passed away in the 80's and this place is still around.   Crab cocktail was our starter dish and it was right up there as the freshest crab I've eaten.  The dish we were told to order that my dad always loved was the Cioppino or as the bill says One Lazy Cioppino. It is a fisherman's stew of many fish, scallops, shrimps, crab, clams and mussels with a tomato base. It is thick and full of flavor. We split it between us and still have left overs for a few hours later while at Alcatraz.   Classy place with a blend of young folks and blue hairs alike. Go check it out if you are at the Wharf.

o0UY3pee1b09na7jTSCFwA.review_text: I had the Losbter with cheese. It was good, very fresh sea food, and there was A LOT of food.  Too much.   I give it 4 stars because:  - there was way too much cheese in the lobster - the presentation was sloppy as you can see in the photo,  - the bread was totally cold.  I even joked that it could be used as a cold pack.  The service was proper. Overall I had higher expectations for this place based on recommendations.  I  will go back and try a more simple sea food without all the cheese.

BAtfVLQ_NstAh7TNan30DQ.review_text: Great, quiet location with very good food and atmosphere.  The service is what I remember most, they were very knowledgeable and classy.  Even though I was a tourist, they did not make me feel like one.  Not a pretentious vibe at all even though it is a very nice restaurant.   The seafood was good, I had the Lazy Mans Ciopinno, which was good, but I felt it was a bit overpriced.  I'd probably give the restaurant five stars if I was more of a seafood fan.

jZ4Qraxd7vH-Fc2to3MR_g.review_text: Ok, we have traveled a bit and yes, it's touristy and crowded etc. yet tonight I had the best meal I'd had in forever!  The lobster bisque ranks right up there; we split a heart of romaine/blue cheese/balsamic salad, and then scallops/shrimp and my husband the Ahi- just delicious! Our waiter wasn't very warm but to hell with that. We had a GREAT time!  Go - its an icon.

Au58CnEF8fX5memBGDGEFw.review_text: Was referred to this restaurant. When we walked in I fell in love with the atmosphere. It was an intimate setting. The wait was only 45 mins which we were fine with. We sat in the bar and enjoyed some drinks with the best bartender. Once we were seated we got the five star service. Got lots of info from the waiter which helped us decide what to order. Overall great atmosphere and great food. We will be back!!!

r-udHOpqo67mPjaL_A99Rw.review_text: This was my first time here and I was very pleased. We made reservations and we only had to wait 20 minutes, well at least for today.  Very clean restaurant, narrow walking space but it's kinda big.   Large seafood menu and there's a giant wine selection.   The servers are really nice. When you order crab, they also put on bibs for you.  Come here for the clam chowder! It's amazing! Not too creamy or too watery. I was going to take a picture of it but I ended up just eating the whole thing. They chop up the clams, potatoes, and celery into small pieces so with every spoonful you get like a mouthful of everything. There was other ingredients in there too but I was way too hungry to observe. You can tell everything is fresh and didn't just plop it out of a can. I got the bowl for $10 which they do give a large portion. They have the cup for $9 but there's a total size difference. So I would recommend to just get the bowl, it's much more worth it since they give you much more.  We also got two orders of the dungeness crab, which tasted alright. It wasn't anything special, but it tasted fresh and that's always good in my book.  Every thing arrived pretty fast, we didn't wait too long which was good. But then again, I guess it depends on the day.  I would have to come back here in the future to try other seafood dishes.  But yes, come for the clam chowder and you'll be happy you did!

f36Ec1f_qQ-ABkiR1KKscA.review_text: I loved the green salad the dressing was dilicious also the staff is great the view the fish and fried is very big dish i like it but better to order smaller portion the clam chowder is great and tasety

VLDZJMUd5VBBD-OF7EdN6g.review_text: When a group of friends come in town, I played the role of host quite well, I would say. We did lots of touristy things including a LONG day at Napa, followed by dinner at Scomas. I had never been but heard it was a SF staple and thought it'd be a perfect time to try it out.  When we first got there, we had to wait for our table...not a big deal. We decided to take shots at the tiny bar (naturally because we're classy like that) to kill time. Nothing too great here, except a funny moment when we ordered lemon drops with sugar and after shooting them, realized they were tequila and sugar...barf.  dinner was OKAY. nothing to write back home about. I couldn't decide between pasta and another dish and I asked our waiter which he would recommend. He said pasta, I said okay. It was NOT good. Not bad, but so super plain...I sincerely think they might have forgotten to put ANY seasoning on it...it tasted like oily noodles...not cool for a $22 plate.   It was a cute little restaurant and they seated us next to a very pretty view of SF. The atmosphere was fun and very laid back...I enjoyed it even though I ate mostly bread and my fiance's meal.

-fVK7Otn6ctuR6mrQGHmvw.review_text: I looked up High-End on Yelp and this was one of the places that came up. We don't do the high-end very often (at least not intentionally) but the reviews were good and we had to try someplace new.  What a great place! Nice sharply dressed waiters with style! We went for lunch and wandered until 11:30. They were already packed and seating people. We didn't have to wait long and still got a good table. We ordered the Bloody Mary (which I never do) and it was fantastic. Our server Sean came over and he was very professional. Showed us several of the top dishes all at about $35 a plate. :) I thought that was kind cute (because there was no way I was going to get any of those dishes). Since it was lunch and our first meal, we were going strictly lunch fare. The BF asked about their salmon and shrimp cake sandwich and in that conversation Sean mentioned they can also do a crab cake sandwich - HOLD IT! That's what I'm ordering - yummy! BF got the ahi instead. Both sammies were fantastic. They also gave us a half loaf of sourdough bread. Literally, half the round loaf! I was thinking we needed to get some before we leave the city; but not after that. We took it home and it was good.  I would love to come back for dinner and have one of the $35 dishes; but for now I'm still loving the crab cake and of course we were stuffed. No dessert for us :)

x832VqO1rwUFgTXWaozjFQ.review_text: 9/16/10: Scoma's was highly recommended by one of my older clients. He's a regular and raves about the "Lazy Man's Ciopinno." Decided to try it out on my b-day. Checked the menu out online before hand.. Everything looked good and made my mouth water. Any seafood restaurant that's located right off the Pier of the ocean is pretty much guaranteed a fresher than fresh selection of a variety of fish. You seriously have to pay close attention to where you are going if you've never been here before... It's tucked away in a side street so if you blink, you'll miss it!! Scoma's does not take reservations, so we made sure we got there right when dinner started, which was 5PM. This place gets a big phat star for FREE valet parking. Free valet in the city is un-heard of. We could tell that this place has been established from the smell, aged sea ship decor to the majority crowd of "seasoned business men" and "old money" types.  I was a little perturbed at the hostess, I was waiting patiently in line for my turn to put my name on the list for a table... I was standing right in front of her... She overlooked me... and tried to help the older couple BEHIND me. I had to raise my voice in order for her to aknowledge me. We waited for 25 minutes to get seated, but we were ok w/ it, they were really busy. I just made sure that the hostess didn't try to give our table to anyone that came in after us.   We decided to order from the pre-fix menu ($39.95 pp)  Me:  Appetizer - Lobster Bisque with Lobster Salad Entree - Broiled Colossal Prawns, Linguine Pomodoro w/ Pesto Garnish Dessert - Pumpkin Cheesecake with Pumpkin Seed Brittle  Man Friend: Appetizer -  Dungeness Crab Cake on Watercress Salad with Lemon Vinaigrette & Remoulade Sauce Entree - Broiled Wild Pacific Swordfish with Tuscan White Beans, Pancetta, Tomatoes & Organic Rainbow Chard Dessert - Walnut Brownie & Triple Espresso Ice Cream with Caramel Sauce  The food was FANTASTIC and the service was more than exceptional. My brother and I treated our parents here for their 33rd Wedding Anniversary, they are huge fans of the food as well. So if you are ever in S.F and have a  tasting for some quality seafood, come to Scoma's.. you'll be glad you did.

lQXbo83bGxE7l6SOT_CpVQ.review_text: meh  The Looks: Dated The Cost: Pricy The Service: Prompt, but far from stellar. The Food Quality: That was fresh caught?? The Location: Very Good  Well, I stopped in on a night with a coworker and we ordered the calamari, lobster ravioli, and burger.  Lobster ravioli was so so, nothing special.  Calamari was a bit on the chewy side, how is this, i dunno...  Burger was surprisingly the best thing on the table, even though it was basically a single patty big mac. Same type of bun, lettuce, special sauce. The beef was actually pretty good. A shame they didn't spring for better bread.  Will I return, not likely.

uEvusDwoSymbJJ0auR3muQ.review_text: The hubby and I celebrated his birthday here many moons ago before kids, so our nostalgic visit back was nice.  This old school charming seafood restaurant is tricky to get to.  You walk down a little alley just off Fisherman's Wharf. Some seating areas are tight so if you can get a booth try to do so.  Views of the wharf are nice.  Waiter's have been here forever!  White tablecloth service but down home atmosphere.  We brought the kids and a kids menu was available.  We didn't have much time so we ordered just a few items.  If you come here at least taste the Clam chowder, oh my!  And for goodness sake, have some crab cakes!   They have a sister restaurant in Sausalito, a ferry will take you there. A must if you're in the bay area!

1ddvgi35Kp3Cw6FBxra2AA.review_text: I am not a seafood person and generally try to avoid the touristy spots. But I ended up at Scoma's when my dad came into town and requested seafood. Sadly it was too crowded for us to get a table with a view.   The clam chowder is quite good, def one of the top 3 I've had in the city.  The crabcakes (which I did not order, but ended up stealing bite after bite) were a perfect 10. Big compliment coming from someone that finds 90% of ocean product "too fishy".  I've been meaning to bring the crab-o-phile boyfriend to see whether it's actually a good crabcake. Will update with the verdict.

gB2yyRhYZJN24dHOQeOQ0w.review_text: This was a recommended restaurant by a couple we met at the airport and I wish I could thank them for such a great recommendation. San Francisco was first point on our honeymoon and we wanted to have a nice, romantic dinner so we made reservations at this place. It sits on a pier and does not look like much, but the food was phenomenal. My husband does not really eat fish, but he had local cod which he enjoyed very much. I had salmon caught by Scoma's own boat, which was magnificant. We also shared a bottle of Scoma's brand wine which was pretty good and we received a complimentary dessert since we were on our honeymoon. The place is pricey, but every bit worth it. The wait staff is very curtious and professional and a poster child for how a waiter should look and behave. My husband collects pint glasses and asked the waiter how he can get a glass with their name on it. The waiter said that he will see what he can do and gave him the glass for free. This was a great start to our honeymoon!

aIWXZ3MCfehI-LbxCN4arg.review_text: So the fiancee got a mini windfall and decided that dinner here was a must. We arrived and our car was quickly taken by the valet. We were seated immediately in a funky little corner, but it beats waiting. After a few minutes of perusing the menus, the waiter came out and took our order.   We decided to have the sampler appetizer which had scampi, calamari, and crab cakes. I wasn't crazy about the crab cakes but the calamari was BOMB. The scampi was pretty good too, but the calamari had my taste buds in its little tentacles.  We were really hungry so we were also chomping away at the delicious sourdough bread they brought out.  After that, our dinner came. I got the crab, which was delicious. The shell was easy to crack which I love b/c crab cracking is not a specialty of mine. The man got the lobster thermador, and OMG it's a thing of beauty. It's a lobster tail with vegetables, scallions, and pasta covered in provolone cheese. It sounded strange to me so I didn't get it, but trust me, it works. I'm getting that next time!!   Service is very prompt, we didn't have any long waits at all. I will be back for you my beautiful lobster.

_yZksxi1FX-nIfqq5GBCDg.review_text: Had half a caesar salad, cup of chowder, and the halibut. Very nice atmosphere. The food was good but not worth the price. Bill for two (teas for drink) $110.

s8j7xv_fO3XKQWrcSQs3uQ.review_text: Everyone in my party loved their plates!! Excellent food!! Specially the salmon with lobster ravioli, mixed seafood and lobster! The service wasn't that great but probably we just has bad luck with the waiter. Defenitely a must try in SF!

ezT6lCVaxVEltUtPT4uUSg.review_text: San Francisco Food Fantasy Trip... take one.  Ok... so the Mrs. and I planned a 3 day trip to San Francisco... let's see... what's on the list... Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz, the Wharf??? NOPE.. this is a food only trip.  No tourist stuff here.. no time for that.... JUST FOOD, FOOD, and more FOOD... plus 12 hours of sleep to take breaks between the food.  Since our hotel was close by, we decided to pull from our best of Yelp SF list a reasonably priced seafood restaurant nearby.  Enter Scomas.  A kind of out of the way place near all the Pier 39 crap.. but far enough away where the food actually has to be good to attract people to come.  You could tell this was mainly a local's only kind of place... which is always a good sign.  Expect to pay $35-$50 per person here.. which is reasonable considering the food... fresh lobster, clams, scallops, crab, tuna, you get the idea... flavors aren't anything special... but the food is very fresh so not much needs to be added anyway.  As most white places often do.. the seafood is over-seasoned with way too much butter.  Kind of makes you feel a little ill after the meal.  What is it with non-asian restaurants and butter and seafood.  Enough already.     Ambiance was nice... the place sits upon it's own Pier.. Pier 47 to be exact.. (that's 8 piers and 5,000 tourists north-west of Pier 39 if you are counting). SF bay on one side... and docked boats on the other - a kind of rustic oceanic feel.. the smell of the seawater helps prepare you for the seafood.  I think a nice place for a date... but nothing too fancy.. wouldn't go here for an anniversary or anything like that... just a nice night out.    Service was really good... server was very knowledgeable and always was in the area if we needed anything.   Overall... food was good, price was reasonable, service was really good... 3.7 stars.  If you are in the area of the Wharf, and looking for a nice dinner out - avoid the tourist holes.   Scomas is a decent choice.

f641mHQCC_DgBcgFJPQfpQ.review_text: Four stars is generous...  A+ when it comes to food B- for the service

MiuY-2LZIdCjhZRVf34AJQ.review_text: My wife and I, along with another couple, had dinner at Scoma's at 6:00pm on a Saturday.  The food was fresh and tasty, obviously high quality ingredients.  Beyond that, the meal and overall experience was just "okay".  For what we paid, it didn't feel like we received a very good value.  No real complaints, per se, but probably wouldn't return.

TRm1Ah4zAN5qkYBZzd1gaA.review_text: Excellent service and food. We were afraid Scoma's would be touristy. It was not (well, we dined here during a vacation).  Bruce, our waiter, was professional as can be and charming. Highly recommended.

YtdTM3_u-vPaaMDcklIikA.review_text: This place feels super old school.  Service was very friendly.  Probably my biggest complaint: the prices, but it's to be expected from the location.  There is free valet parking, which is a plus (though remember most of these guys do rely on your tips :)).  They're right on the dock, and they have an area for collecting their catches (ensuring fresh seafood!).  The meals come with pasta and veggies.  Pasta is a bit bland, in my opinion.  The seafood (had the crab cakes) is really delicious.  Probably, you can split each meal (I ended up taking half of mine home, especially since I pigged out on the sourdough bread).

odf4O_Klrv3pt0LZmcttJQ.review_text: Scoma's was a great dinner choice for my wife and myself last night. Thanks Yelp friends for the help making the decision. John, our waiter, took great care of us and made the dinner experience very nice. I had the lazy man's cioppino and it was a huge bowls of seafoody deliciousness. The best cioppino that I've ever had (and I'm a cioppino junky). You won't be disappointed choosing Scoma's for dinner.

lp2f1viw61OKUTs7z08ecQ.review_text: This restaurant was recommended to us by our hotels manager, who was kind enough to make us a reservation later in the evening.  This is a nice little restaurant at the Wharf with great views of the city.  When we first arrived, we went to check in while the rest of the family was around the corner on their way.  They said they had a table ready, but wouldn't let us sit down until everyone was there.  Kind of disappointed because we ended up losing our table after we told them they would be here in two minutes.  We were seated in a small room with about 5 other tables, of course tight on space which is pretty annoying.  The menu was packed full of delicious food, though a little pricey.  But you get what you pay for, delicious dinner meals and deserts.  Recommend to try the Jack Daniels cake for desert.  The waiter was friendly, prompt and knowledgeable with everything on the menu.  Overall would come back for dinner here again, but would make sure to make reservations well in advance.

CZFHZ1E0QUQsoeNoASWnbA.review_text: Awesome place for seafood in the wharf!  This is a fantastic restaurant offering delicous dishes.  The blackened swordfish was to die for!!  Yummy.  A little pricey, but everything in San Francisco CA is expensive.  Very touristy place, but that's ok!

EfFAODw7oep9KwXu6FgVMg.review_text: On my first trip to San Fran many years ago, I came to Scoma's.  Even though I eat at fancier and more trendy restaurants when I return to San Francisco, I always find my way back here to get some cioppino.    I'll admit the last time I was here the cioppino was not up to par.  I was even afraid that the law of diminishing return had finally set in.  Nope, it was just as good this time as it was the first.    To be there in time for dungeness crab season is a double wind fall.  Yum!  I never have room for dessert because we head to Buena Vista for an Irish Coffee.  Or two.  Scomas & the Buena Vista.  Two tourist traps that are a part of my SF pilgrimage.

oFvXDf62a7DMQZzd2wc7xw.review_text: Went here on a recommendation from a friend.  Had the grilled Ahi, delicious.  My wife had the rock shrimp pasta pesto and loved it.  I had a glass of Prohibition ale with my fish, and the pairing was great.  A little pricey (based on how we typically dine out, dinners were $35 ea), but the wife and I were here for a special occasion so we splurged.

d-WDfKTTwmThJKwOR5qDqw.review_text: Off the beaten path, so you do't have to worry about tourists. The seafood is very fresh and the staff is very attentive. Jean Marc took very good care of us. I highly recommend the clam chowder.

53d4qjoAw3XVlFbpfRS5TQ.review_text: I was somewhat skeptical about going, after reading some of the negative reviews. The  Scoma Seafood Saute was incredible - I am so glad I went! Great food, service and location.

eyZMVULSReESQsweVBrrZw.review_text: Great ambiance, killer view, friendly and professional service, and fresh seafood.  This place is a great combination of the best of Fisherman's Wharf.  They have a happy hour at the bar that features several good appetizers, worth trying them all!

sjUTGmYB3XB7EHvrGX2zyA.review_text: Went to SF in August with my hubby and this place was recommended by my boss. I had the crab, my husband had the burger. We were both thrilled with our selections. The view is great, though it was kind of weird to find it all the way at the end of a row of boat slips. Service was on-par, and they even offer you any recipes of your favorite dishes to take home!

YvCpJnzUmIK0e3R6PKjBEg.review_text: Great food and service was outstanding. I had the cioppino and it was great. Portion size is huge.

0oDdGsGqgCdllvFVPNuIKQ.review_text: I must echo the comment on the lazy man's Cioppino. It is to die for.   I love this place and I am basing my dining experience on a single visit.  On this single visit I was blown away and it is THE seafood place on the wharf.

mcKtgUI5euf-VNzXmSVzvw.review_text: I love going to Scoma's. It's really old school SF. The waiters are old school too. There's one old guy waiter I love with a Greek first name (I wish I could remember it, maybe it's Cyril) he's very cool and efficient. Too bad there's another old guy waiter, in a different room, who can take forever to take your order. He doesn't thrill me, but, I still love being at Scoma's.   One night a table of older ladies from Florida sitting next to us were freaked out by the expensive prices on the menu, I'm sure seafood in Florida is cheaper. In addition, the wine-by-the glass list was too challenging for them because of the many choices and prices. The  waiter I like got frustrated with these unsophisticated ladies so in order to speed up their ordering (this restaurant is BUSY) he brought the complaining lady a glass of sauvignon blanc on-the-house and that shut them up enough to finally place their order. I loved that scene and had a giggle with my girlfriend about it. These Florida ladies were quite talkative with us about all kinds touristy things.  That's part of the fun of the place, there's always a boatload of tourists there intermingled among the locals. This restaurant is good enough to attract a local crowd too. I just love this place, despite its very expensive price tag. Some dishes on the menu are in the $30.00 range. It's an expensive price tag, but it's so fun.  I almost always order the roasted crab (lots of yummy butter, garlic and parsley). Sometimes I get the clams. I've never ordered desert, but they look large and decadent (old school things like brownies and ice cream). The food is NOT fancy modern California/French influenced stuff like you'd get in most great SF restaurants (which I love too), its just old school goodness. There's always a place in my heart for SF sentamentality.  You can't go wrong with the scenery either. I love Fisherman's Wharf because it feels like I'm on vacation even though I live in SF. It reminds me of my childhood driving from Berkeley with my family on special occasions with visiting out-of-town guests.   The bar is fun too, and you will inevitably be having at least one drink while waiting for your table. The bartender is a wisecracker with his constant puns - very corny but friendly. I've never made a reservation, I just walk in and wait for a table. Sometimes we walk around the Wharf while waiting for a table. It's a lot of fun.   Try Scoma's for your seafood cravings and pretend you're on vacation in your own sweet little crazy city. Then don't forget to go to Ripley's Believe It Or Not Museum for a childish laugh afterwards.

5FHcqmuyvK-OkTw7akqiUw.review_text: Got there around dinner time and was informed there would be a thirty minute wait. At 40 minutes I came in to ask how much longer and the hostess looked at the list and couldn't even find our names. They sat us within two minutes. I had the lobster stuffed ravioli topped with a grilled salmon steak. My friend had some pasta concoction with so called blackened jumbo shrimp, and a bowl of lobster bisque. His chowder came in an incredibly small cup, but he said it was delicious. My meal was sent on the wings of angels. The flavor of the ravioli was lovely, the salmon was perfection. My friend however, got a mound of pasta and some cocktail sized shrimp. He was sorely disappointed and kept looking at my dish with envy. I gave him some which only increased his disappointment. The desert was a chocolate brownie, delicious, and vanilla bean ice cream which was divine. In the end though, you really want your company to be enjoying themselves as much as you are. The whole dinner was a little sad, though it had many bright spots, shining like little gems.

zjcSGQUgiCz50LFJoRzd7g.review_text: We loved our meals!! The Shrimp & Crab Louie was excellent. My favorite although is the sandabs. If you have never had them you must try. Buttery smooth and not fishy tasting. The service was very attentive.

VqRKdMSsKfQrmcMdqkDqbw.review_text: Not the place it used to be.  Great for the tourists who don't know better seafood. My "Seafood risotto" was way overcooked bulked up with peas and zucchini, found a few bits of crab along with the prawns.  And no porcini mushrooms, they substitute shitakes.  My friends seafood pasta at $38.00 !!! was a ripoff.  Pasta with a handfull of bay shrimp and prawns and shitake mushrooms. .  Yikes !

c5Wt7ktEQkUDEBXKqphlkQ.review_text: Amazing seafood, even better people that work here what more could you ask for? Oh maybe some old celebrity photos on the wall? Yeah this place has that too. If you are eating here and have room get the Clam Chowder, Cioppino, or the Grilled Salmon with Lobster Ravioli. Every time I have eaten here it was great and I am going to be making another reservation to come here in the next week or two.

VtNCQX1H00Uq_0Kg89XuMw.review_text: Awesome place to eat. I'm very picky about my clam chowder and theirs is fabulous. Great little place. Our meals were wonderful. I never would have known about this place if not for Yelp!!

6F0uGYwpJUGxhlMO6C3r_g.review_text: My first visit to Scoma was 15 years ago.  15 years later it's still one of the best seafood places in San Fran - if not the best.   Lunch for two was about $150 bucks.  The appetizers were to die for.  The crab Louie salad is incredible. The Lobster Thermidore - equally stupendous.  It's a bit old school and old looking.  It's also a little touch to find (look for Scoma Way off the main street), but be prepared to drop some coin here.  At lunch time it was filled with locals who appear to visit several times a week.  We know why.

6JjlLEqhRViGt2Ut1LJBDA.review_text: Quick Tip: Best place for seafood :)  A couple of years ago, my friends and I were walking along Fisherman's Wharf and we saw the sign for "Scoma's." My friend said that it was on the Food Channel or something, and that it is highly rated so we decided to check it out. Fortunately, we were there for Dine About Town and were able to get a three course meal for a discounted price.  Ever since then, my boyfriend and I make it a point to go to Scoma's during Dine About Town. Why? Because 1.) It is the best seafood I have ever had. The clam chowder is awesome (and Boyfriend loves the lobster bisque), 2.) it's inexpensive for a three course meal and 3.) great setting. The waiters/waitresses are dressed in white tuxedo-like outfits. Very nice.  Despite the Dine About Town, if we were able to afford their dishes on a regular basis, I'd probably go there whenever I crave seafood. All the dishes are spunky, and they even suggest wine that goes well with your meal when you ask.   Portion size is excellent, so I have never left this place feeling disgustingly full or with a to-go bag. I always finish my meal.   After lunch/dinner, you can take a stroll along the wharf and admire the other places. Maybe buy a souvenir while you're at it :)

2L1DMOauI-qmQLX8riFi5w.review_text: A little too expensive but the food is worth it.

_iDZGLPlIpYiZfC03oRCpA.review_text: Our favorite all around seafood in SF. I lived in SF for 14 yrs and knew the warf restaurants pretty well.  Scoma's has always been my favorite.  Being a somewhat small place, I've dined side by side with the likes of Joe Montana and other celebs there before.  Ask for the special lunch menu if there at lunch time.

jwEUp3xugtPcA7fUnrzFmQ.review_text: Lobster bisque was very good as was the clam chowder. The lobster risotto was a great dish to share and my scallops with pasta was excellent.

ZuCP8O71LHKl6tlXkS7Ziw.review_text: i really wanted to like this place, especially since a friend of mine ravesss about this place, but i was pretty disappointed. i think im done trying out places around the pier, all the restaurants ive been in the area just seem like tourist traps.  the restaurant does not take reservations, so expect at least a 25 minute wait even on a weekday. at least it has complimentary valet parking so you dont have to worry about that.   it's a good thing the boyfriend and i came for DAT because the dishes itself definitely was not worth its normal price... and as good as a deal it was for DAT, i still did not think it was worth it overall  from the DAT menu we got the lobster bisque and crab cakes for appetizers, scallop pasta and charbroiled ahi tuna for entree, brownie and espresso ice cream and raspberry cheesecake for dessert.  ive only had lobster bisque one other place (mccromick) and the one here at scoma's does not compare at all. i cant exactly determine what was different about it, but it didnt taste as good as the one before and i didnt like how the crab meat was minced. mccromick's bisque came with huge chunks of crab meat  the crab cakes were good. i did find a small piece of shell in it though.  i don't really recall what was in the scallop pasta, but i remember it was some kind of tomato based sauce which was a little too sour for my liking, but the scallops were so good! i don't really like scallops because all the ones i've tasted had rough textures, but this one was so soft!  now for the tuna.... on the DAT menu i wanted the tuna with blackened rice but i guess they changed it by the time i went. the tuna was really bland and you could completely taste the char. it was probably one of the worse ahi tuna dishes i've had.  the desserts were good, but nothing exceptional.  scoma's is a nice restaurant by the water, but with its price and mediocre food, i won't be returning here again nor recommending the place. sorry, i definitely had better seafood.

P9zAPcJiqlxFzQscvnqAcg.review_text: Amazingly fresh seafood with super-huge portions.  The service was exceptional as well.  Would definitely recommend Scoma's to anyone looking for great seafood in San Fran.

KPnZvJ3yQ1AUj6qsp4yXmw.review_text: We were excited based on the Yelp reviews but were disappointed after trying. I think I must have made a poor selection (lobster ravioli), but my husband got the everything platter and said there wasn't anything special about it flavor-wise. No real special attention to the dish. The wine selection was good but bottles were priced a little high-grant it we'd just purchased 4 cases at a local vineyard and were not in the mood to spend $68 on a bottle you can get for $20 down the road (so we didn't). We were also a little put out at how crass our waitress came across - she was up-selling every chance she got-and actually looking away when we didn't choose 5 courses with the highest dollar. The lobster bisque was good and so was the bread and the view was a tourist's dream. But if you're in it for the food, then you can get better flavors without paying Scoma's $120 (before tip) for two people. In fact, we had a delicious lunch at another nearby restaurant in Fisherman's Wharf the next day for about $30.

3eTizQ3IU-PihPGJpx6BuA.review_text: This is my favorite place for clam chowder. They have the best and I'm not lying. It has a perfect potato-cream-clams ratio. They cut up their clams pretty well so it's easy to eat. I've eaten a lot of clam chowder in my years and I will still say Scoma's has the best. Their raw platter is yummy. I love the raw clams and oysters. Very fresh and delightful.  and the crab louie - HUGE and delicious! I personally feel it can feed 4 people. So if you order this, expect a to go box. They use a lot of fresh crab.  I've been coming here for over 10 years and it hasn't disappointed me yet. I highly recommend Scoma's. Oh, the lobster bisque is fantastic too!

ZtLuIXst2ubmAFeRnYeEBw.review_text: I found jesus in the cioppino. I will come here to get this every time I find myself in San Francisco.

Lx-s5OayOrCrbDrneCw3jg.review_text: I'd rate this restaurant a 4.5 star. It doesn't get the coveted 5 star rating although it may surprise me the second time around. This restaurant has superb location and parking. Don't worry about paying $30 to park 1 mile away on embarcaderro and some rip-off lot. Nope. Scoma's comes with their own valet lot right on the water. It's also tucked away from all the tourists. Heck, I've been to the wharf so many times, it took a local to tell me about it.   The plates of food are fabulously delicious.   Any joint that has their own fishing boat is an automatic 4 star. And I didn't even have to pay the Host an extra 20 to get a great view of the bay.   Bottom-line: Pretty darn good but nothing I haven't seen before.

KeiOUdpKz3hOn8ncAeddjg.review_text: Had a delicious meal here but beware- the entree portions are huge! My boyfriend and I each got a cup of their famous clam chowder which was tasty but very rich/creamy. For entree, I had the mixed shellfish saute and my boyfriend and had the diplomatica pasta. We definitely could have shared one of the entrees. There was so much seafood which was refreshing because most restaurants skimp on the seafood. For dessert, we shared the apple crisp a la mode which was just okay. The place is a great location being right on the water. I would recommend this restaurant to anyone coming to the Wharf.

RXaDwsFHvYDliwQJu_sYGg.review_text: I have been going to SCOMA's for years whenever I'm in the San Francisco area.  Their waiters are well trained and have been there for years.  They really know how to treat customers.  The food is always outstanding and the portions are large.  The ambiance is great overlooking the fishing boats on the pier.  Make sure you include SCOMA's in your travels.

-6xc_eq_OoxWZyySM9BN8w.review_text: On the recommendation of my godparents, my husband and I decided to try Scoma's; however, it took us a while to actually find it! We went looking for it in the afternoon so we would know where it was for dinner, thank goodness we took the time to do that.  We put our names in later that evening and sat the bar for cocktails. Once we were seated, the dining experience was amazing. The portions are good sized and the quality of seafood was fantastic, as it should be since it is right on the water!  This will be a place to return to over and over again!

RFpnfgB2dSLfGY00FppcAg.review_text: We were very much looking forward to eating at this restaurant because of word of mouth but weren't that impressed with the food. We like the feel of the place of an old school type of place with a touch of class with waiters in white jackets. The soups that we had were both very good, the lobster bisque and the clam chowder. Had the appetizer platter with calamari- good, crab cakes-below average and the shrimp- very good. The steamed crab was good but the dish I had was pasta noodles, rice, vegetables with very little seafood, and was covered with way too many mushrooms and for 40 dollars? The service was very good though.

6MyvPw0c7uJ26Ap0ztElJg.review_text: We had an absolutely wonderful meal here. It was so hard to decide, but we settled on the Pasta Diplomatica and Shellfish Saute Sec. Both were delicious. Cioppino is a specialty and many around us were having it. We also tried a squash soup special that was great. The bread is heavenly. Our waiter added to the experience because he was very properly friendly, helpful with answers and suggestions and always there when needed. The atmosphere is very old school with black and white photos of celebrities from the 60'-80's covering the walls. I would go here any time.

j5tT6tiNmz5NVEND1glbaQ.review_text: Every-time we go to San Francisco the must stop is Scoma's . We always order their Dungeness Crab sandwich that is like no others. This time we went and it was no longer on menu, but we asked  the very professional waiter ( waitstaff high marks) and she said no problem . The sandwich came out with heaping amounts of crab (no fillers) a under a thick slice of sour-dough bread served with fries and a great salad . Dinner is also a gem .

q6LVjbqDtumSoDrSU7vRnA.review_text: This is how I picture seafood perfection as far as "cooked" seafood goes.  In old-school fashion, the service is top notch and food, exquisite!  For the quality on all levels, I think their dishes are well-priced.  I can't help but get their scallops many of the times, and their lobster bisque is the best I've had.  Aside from their excellent shellfish, they take no shortcuts when it comes to my favorite fish dishes.  It's amazing how they can conjure up such a vast amount of quality food for their restaurant from such a small kitchen.  I hope they can afford to maintain their private fishing fleet during these hard times... We've got to have something equivalent to what my mom calls "East Coast Seafood" here on the West Coast!  *although i selected 'not sure' for the Attire, I like to think of it as something between Casual and Dressy.

c9-jEIfBnLa4iNHxVmXAHA.review_text: My parents have been dragging me to Scoma's for years and every time I come away happy, but not that impressed.   Granted, my parents have been coming here for over 40 years but I feel like in that time, the food hasn't changed.   Sure I understand...that's an admirable quality with a restaurant "if it ain't broke, don't fix it" but some of the items....at least for today's younger diners like myself, seem bland and dated.   I feel that with a couple of modern tweaks to the menu to bring the food up to 2013 standards the place would erupt....but then again that's only my opinion.  Still a solid SF staple, just don't lose your mind with the FW tourists.

xd0gn5Mm7k7fLyqo28Hr6g.review_text: Expensive but worth it. Wonderful views and interesting fish dishes. Fantastic service as well.

f-Pi9Kw6NGeELr6nbZJ9yQ.review_text: Scomas has always been one of our favorites, can't go wrong.  Love the garlic roasted crab!  Food is always fresh and well prepared.  Been coming here for years and will continue! Love it's historical charm.

ogp45WFbN4Z6R_I5RiTjSQ.review_text: If you like fresh seafood, Scoma's is the place to be. I love their Lobster's Bisque. But the scallops, salmon and crab are the best in the world.

sSwNEr1LELuogaxFfWqjtw.review_text: Our  place to eat in SF!  Amazing food, wonderful service.  My family love the lobster ravioli, I'm a fan of the cioppino. I've never had a meal there that was anything but excellent.

qbsz_UN9B9ACkTftJrH0Tg.review_text: It was a bit pricey for my taste. If you want good cioppino go to Sotto Mare.

27oxT_nG1BG0bTFurvysQQ.review_text: I love Scoma's restaurant. Their food is great and the service is good too. Friendly staff and most of the people that are there have been there for some time. The only unfortunate thing is it is a touristy area. I love the clam chowder and unfortunately they took my favorite item off of the menu, oyster's Suasolito- oysters on the half shell baked with cheese and spinach... yum!  I don't recommend bringing kids unless you are coming with a group and they will be entertained. A perfect spot for a date night, try to get a table out on the water, it's beautiful

yjqybvIvxrrhGH0zzJGXEw.review_text: Don't remember what I got but it was something with an assortment of lobster, crab, scallops, penne pasta, and clams?  It was insanely good! If only I lived closer. :/

lt9vlWEaHsILoBBOEwX4MA.review_text: During the city sight seeing tour, it was mentioned that Scoma's was thee place to go;  Since it was my last night in San Francisco with my brother and my friends we decided to check out Scoma's.  My brother called to make reservations (Sunday) at 7 PM, but the hostess mentioned they weren't taking reservations at that time.  The hostess mentioned it was a 30 minute wait.  We finally got to the restaurant, put our name on the list for a party of 4 and the wait was 30-45 minutes.  The longer we waited the more and more people were coming in.  45 minutes later, we got sat down.  We had:  -Scoma's Famous Clam Chowder (Bowl $9): OH EM GEE, the BESSSST clam chowder I've ever had.  My brother and I shared the Bowl, and I think I would have finished the bowl alone! haha!  -Broiled King Salmon ($34): I decided to go for it and get the broiled salmon that came with garlic mashed potatoes and veggies.  The salmon was perfectly cooked, it wasn't dry at all but could use a little flavor. The salmon was a pretty good size and I could not finish if.   -ALASKAN HALIBUT SICILIANA  ($30): Topped with Sicilian Olives, Tomato, Capers, Anchovies - My best friend ordered the Halibut and he and his sister really liked it.  I had a little taste of it and it was just okay for me.  -Prawns over Linguine Pomodoro (I think!): My brother went on Yelp before dinner and saw this picture that he wanted to try.  He realized that it wasn't on the menu, so he showed out waiter the picture and did his thing and suggested it's prawns over Linguine Pomodoro (which I'm not sure if that's exactly what he said).  I tried a little bit of his pasta, and it was just okay for me. I think their other pastas would have been better?
