The bonus fifth star for treating mom right on her 71st birthday.  A lovely staff serenade of "Happy Birthday" and a slice of chocolate cake.  The free valet is also a huge lure given the location.

jnJf26dkmW6vowC4eh70PQ.review_text: We enjoyed our visit. The service by Ray was excellent. The two person appetizer with calamari, shrimp and crab cakes was good. It would have been better if the crab cakes were lump crab instead of leg meat. The scallops were well prepared and delicious. The risotto with a tomato base was disappointing. Thanks for reading. The Bike Chaplain

WecuAsHBDZGj7Z6_sJcQAw.review_text: "See you again next year."  Last year we were sitting at the exact same table celebrating my Grandparent's 60th wedding anniversary. This year we were back for #61. Our waitress had remembered us.  Another thing that stayed the same: excellent food. The Cioppino is not cheap, but that's because it is two meals. Almost three. So much seafood. It was amazing.  As is celebrating 61 years of marriage. Love you Grandma & Grandpa! Let's plan for next year, same time, same place!

ZZ0fsmQf-VLTrSv0T9_cZA.review_text: Rated highly, out of the way in a very cool way, surrounded by working boats, short but interesting walk off the main street, great big windows looking out onto San Fran marina and view, tuxedo coat waiters and very tempting menu... but the dungeoness crab risotto at $39 was nearly bland and otherwise unremarkable. The $29 pesto pasta was mostly pesto _colored_. The service was good, the food edible, but badly missed our expectations and overpriced itself.

Xh79opoIHM9v9AEJkyKUGQ.review_text: YUMMY! This our favorite place in San Fran. The Louis salad is fit for a king with tons of crab and crisp lettuce. The penne pasta that comes with the entrees is luscious And we always order MORE! We had lobster bisque, lobster newburg, Louis salad, and crab bake. The crab bake was disappointing with very little crab and mostly bread that tasted watered down, but the salad that accompanied it was stellar. The reason it gets only four stars is because the wait to get service and food to table is way too long.

REkqzfacqtEHoCOzWDEKGw.review_text: Was here twice on 09/23/14 & 09/25/14; the last time was around 2005.  I always order the lazy man's cioppino, and it is still great!  This seafood in this stew tastes so fresh.  The lobster bisque is pretty good too.  The other night I had teh salmon which was good, but the roasted vegetables it came with was really good.  If they just had this as a vegetable dish, I would order it.  But if you like tomato based sauces, get the lazy man's cioppino; it is worth the price, and soak up the bread in the sauce as well!   :)

Yv9UmSFKj9f48fQg_yyPAw.review_text: We love our trips to San Francisco and part of our love for this town is Scoma's. This is not just another restaurant on the wharf catering to the unsuspecting tourist.....this is an honest to goodness SF institution.   Locals and tourists alike flock to Scoma's for some of the best seafood in San Francisco........surely the best Dungeness Crab.    The waitstaff and bar tenders are always attentive and make me feel like I'm home.  Ask for a table in the "old section" on the window and order up some beautifully thick chowder and a whole cracked crab......now that's SF.

4TtY37CFL1JWM4cQuVk2cw.review_text: Scoma's served the finest Seafood I've ever eaten. I had the "Mix" Salmon, Swordfish and Rock Cod.  Put Scoma's on the top of your list for Surf and Turf in San Francisco.

98ayax82c8mMTgxgkIw3Zw.review_text: I hadn't been to Scoma's in over 20 years so I was curious what it would be like today when a friend visiting from Los Angeles asked me to make a reservation. I was afraid the food and service might have declined as locals often refer to Scoma's as a place for grandparents and tourists. Not so! The food and service were excellent! We came at 5:30 pm, the time of our reservation and had our table of four until the place was nearly closed. Staff understood that I was having a "reunion" with a friend I had not seen since graduating girl's school 40 years ago. So they just let us and our families feel right at home without trying to push us out of our table to accommodate another set of diners.Surprising ,since the place was packed that night. One other notable aspect of service: the waitpersons are trained in proper wine service which includes wine pairing, presentation, opening and pouring...and by wine pairing I mean not only pairing to the food but also to what they perceive as your price point without asking. Our server got it all correct. I am a Court of Master Sommeliers (Level 2) Certified Sommelier and am Advanced Certified by WSET (Wine & Spirit Education Trust). I am so tired of going out to dine in San Francisco and watching servers who know nothing about wine or wine service try to upsell me on wine...and then botching service Thanks, Scoma's and Mathew (our server) for getting it right! My partner and I are locals and we will be back dining at your wonderful restaurant!

Nb-fJ4KsTGfNK3ZfdQRN6g.review_text: Crab season!  I'm not a big fan of shelling my own crab, but the wood fires dungeness(sp?) was worth the effort. Shelled it all and mopped it up with the shallot sauce with the buttery bread!  I will dream about this stuff!.  A nice visit from the owner and a shout out from the bar as we left-- great place where the owners work the restaurant and really care about customers.

PA76JerfXDf5V1QgUyLN3A.review_text: Best seafood this is the first place the fishing boats stop.  Free valet parking always great,

axIEJL6nbzARJn_xMa-Thw.review_text: I am sad to say this but this restaurant had made it to my top 10 places to avoid to eat.   Spending 200.00 for crappy service and food save your money and go to joes crab shack at least there you get what you pay for.  Buyer beware !!!!!!!!

ILqacRX-ka2Wi8i_9jTGmA.review_text: I love this place.  Great southern seafood.  I recommended this place to everyone. Walk-in only, No reservations accepted.   Just real food with real people at real prices. Give it a try.

UVO0vrdc8Jfm00p7ixuf7A.review_text: Did I already review this place? My favorite in the city? I dont know! Anyway, the staff is extremely helpful and kind. Personal. I believe I had a 3months anniversary celebration here.. well not celebration but date. you know.   it's a lovely place. you can enter casual or you can dress up. whatever you want and you can feel comfortable with it! that's one thing i love about them.   clam chowder is so much better than boudin's, so please do come.   scallops and pasta O my GOSH. heaven. enjoy bread and butter before the meal too. full bar. O THE DESSERT. must try!

IVV2kzualGCvT21HayokDA.review_text: Restuarant was highly recommend to me, and it turned out to be quite disappointing. Food was very average especially considering the price.

niKu4se6xtf-ctlm0udr1w.review_text: Solid seafood fare.  Nothing spectacular.. I had the lobster ravioli which was very nice with good portion.  The clams were solid.  The tuna was a bit more cooked than i expected.   Oysters were great.  Appetizer platter was a good choice, we got to try calamari, crab cakes and some kinda shrimp thing.  Overall the food and experience is pretty good, to be expected by the pricing.  If you're looking to impress or have a nice dinner, i would recommend this establishment.

TCs-B9w1lstAzvsIKXIWqA.review_text: Goodness, my friend and I drove 1 and 1/2 hour, waited  1 hour and 10 min for the table to get an overpriced $30 FRIED fish dish even though on the menu stated that "GRILLED COD"!  It also tasted buttery and salty.  So disappointed.  And since this place is busy, the service is crappy.  The waiter kept forgetting our requests.

5Tc0YXgYDvTTlps0e8xTNg.review_text: Two words for Scoma's. Tourist. Trap. In a flight of idiocy I decided to take the boyfriend here while he was visiting for two weeks. What a mistake. Both of us were disappointed and at $115, I was also pissed off.  You can have way better seafood elsewhere and in great abundance. They charge an absurd amount of money for mediocrity. You would be better off hitting up one of the crab stands. It also bears mentioning that they had no crab on the menu (the sole reason for coming there) but it was in various items including my cioppino (not remarkable at all) and I can definitely say it wasn't fresh. If you tout yourself as a seafood restaurant and even ONE of your seafood ingredients is frozen then you have failed.  And that is my third word for Scoma's.  Fail.

X8EaFdIcMn3hYdlH0hJQ7w.review_text: It was actually surprising that this place had good food at reasonable prices considering it's location.   Restaurants by or near the ocean are usually overpriced joints serving mediocre food...and what you are really paying for is the view/location.  This place seems like it's always busy so luckily I had made reservations.  Our waiter was very friendly and quite entertaining - A+  I ordered the mixed seafood grill which came with  I believe 4 small filets of different fishes.   It was quite good,  not amazing but definitely enjoyable.    My wife got the dungeness crab risotto which was really more of a rice/stew concoction then a traditional risotto.   It was quite wet for a risotto and came with a lot of green peas.   I thought it was an OK dish although whenever i order risotto i expect traditional style risotto that's pretty much dry and infused with sticks of butter.  Several of my friends got the cioppino and they loved it.   It was quite a large bowl filled with plenty of seafood.   Personally I felt the cioppino was a little too thick....they put a whole boatload of tomato paste in it.  Overall,  I would definitely recommend this place if you are looking for good seafood in SF.   The excellent location also means you can traverse through Fisherman's Wharf either before or after your meal.

BQIISvsItoqclDOFOnQlsw.review_text: When visiting San Francisco, they say you gotta have cioppino.  And considering mixed shellfish in a tomato broth is one of the best dishes ever invented, it wasn't long before I was asking where one of the best places to get it might be when visiting the Bay area.  Enter Scoma's.  I'm sure they have a lot of outstanding seafood here, including Dungeness crab, but this place is all about the Lazy Man's Cioppino.  Cod, scallops, clams, shrimp, crab, mussels.  It's all here in a tomato based broth. THIS is the best stew I've ever had in any form.  They serve it with a big wedge of San Francisco sour dough for dipping but, if you're lucky, as I was, your waiter might just bring you a little side of pasta on the house to further soak up all that broth.  After all, those of us here in the east are used to melding our fish based stews with tomato sauce and pasta!  It's the ideal way to go!  Scoma's also has a 1970's based decor because it looks like they've never updated anything since then.  That's OK.  I love 70's style chic.  But you're not here to be comforted by the decor.  The Lazy Man's cioppino will do that for you and do it very well.

wku4DoyLzZBnPV-ZOKwojg.review_text: There are tons of reviews for this place here, so let me try to break it down from an overall view and based on the reviews here and my experience at lunch - Scoma's is the kind of place that if you're not in the mood for their particular style or ambiance at that moment, you'll probably dock it stars.  It's a "yes, but" place.  Is it kind of too expensive? Yes, but the seafood is cooked expertly.  Is it kind of a tourist trap? Yes, but if you're at the wharf, you're much better off at Scoma's than anywhere else.  Is this waterfront view actually of a parking lot? Yes, but the scene is dripping with nostalgia, as if Frank Sinatra was mere seconds away from whisking in and ordering a Dungeoness Crabs Louis.  If you are looking for solid seafood, old school charmers of waiters in a location that is patronized by the retired set, for a classy lunch or dinner, this is the place for you.  Sometimes you want a Big Mac and sometimes you want Chateaubriand - this is not the place to hit up when you are craving a bread bowl of clam chowder or a deal on a seafood plate.  We came for an early lunch and enjoyed the stroll down the pier to get to the place, passing boats in their slips and a few picturesque views of the bay.  We were seated immediately, although I could see how this place would warrant a reservation in the evenings.  Our waiter was prompt and charming, but definitely trying to upsell us on the dishes.  We didn't choose the Prix Fixe Lunch Menu (which is a steal if there is something that you want on there - still, why the hell would I go to Scoma's for a club sandwich???) but we didn't think that a $50 mixed seafood plate was what we wanted either, even though the waiter was pushing us to get it.  We ended up getting cups of the clam chowder (Excellent balance of cream and a multitude of tender clams), the crab cake appetizer (Good with not too much filler - I like my crab cakes held together by sheer will instead of any filler, so these don't get an A, particularly for the price), the oysters rockefeller (Cheesy, lemony spinach goodness over plump oysters - but wait! They aren't in shells? I'm guessing these oysters came to the kitchen pre-shucked.  Again, not bad but these should be freshly shucked for the price) and a Mixed Seafood Pasta Dish that I think the waiter just made up.  It was linguine with clams, crab, shrimp, scallops and baby lobster in a garlic cream sauce.  Turns out the pasta was wholly irrelevant, and especially if you live for solid Italian food.  The sauce tasted of no garlic whatsoever, but featured strange chunks of onion instead.  I ended up pushing most of it to the side to get at the expertly cooked shellfish - it was truly the first time that I felt that the price tag was warranted in that my dish contained a hell of a lot of seafood, all with varied cooking times, and each and every piece was perfectly tender.    Our bill was around $90 for the two of us for lunch - steep, but completely in line with what we were looking for for lunch and I have to say, I was so full that the treats on the pier didn't tempt me once and I was still pretty full come dinner time.  I'd probably return, but only if I was looking for a splurge and was in the area, and if I did, I would make sure to only order the strict seafood dishes.

WW_oh8NfnHH32L_H5Kn1Ig.review_text: Scomas, as the man and I agreed, is just "aight"....Came here on a Sat. night and waited at the bar for our table for no more than half an hour, as promised. The place is very cute an the bartenders are friendly. I love how it's kind hidden off teh wharf and right next to the water oh a pier. We started out with a half dozen oysters. I had the cioppino and my bf had half a roast garlic dungeness crab and some clam chowder.  The oysters: Delicious. For $3 a piece, they better be!!!!! Clam chowder: YUM!!!  Now on to the bigger better things.. the Cioppino: Good, but Fish Market in San Mateo makes MUCH better cioppino. As much as I LOVE anything tomato, the consistency was more like that of a pasta sauce rather than a soup or stew. Though yummy, a little too hearty and takes away from the flavor of the seafood. For $40, I wasn't floored...  Roast garlic crab: Good, but better at Thanh Long....  I really liked the atmosphere of the place, and loved our Italian waiter who called me "Bella", didn't catch his name, but he was great.  Overall, Scomas is good, but not as good as I expected. We'll probably stick to our usual favorite spots for Cioppino (Fish Market) and crab (Thanh Long).

TmhFYYTHodJnrubq9IeFNA.review_text: The most expensive dinner my partner and I had in San Francisco. This place is not cheap. But the food!!! WOW! Amazing.   The appetizer sampler with crab cakes and shrimp and calamari was to die for. The calamari literally melted in my mouth. The cioppino was awesome. We had a great Malbec to go with dinner. Service was impeccable. The location on the waterfront was romantic and beautiful. And best of all, it was casual dress. I love love love Scoma's! Never thought I'd ever eat anywhere near Fisherman's Wharf (even though I am a tourist, I do not like tourist traps).  I cannot wait to go back on our next San Francisco visit.

D9mgcl6MFE3vRKTVadFFdQ.review_text: YUMMY! My parents and I love this place. We've been going here since I was 15. And their portions are HUGE!!!! The only thing that sucks about Scoma's is that they don't take reservations. So if you don't show up when they open and go during the dinner hour, be warned that you will be waiting for sometimes up to 2 hours! I always get their filet mignon cooked medium - medium rare. They always cook it perfectly. And how can I knock the place where my mom bought me my first cocktail (well a bar cocktail that is). I wasn't near 21 at the time so Scoma's will always hold a special place in my heart. It was my bday so I deserved it. Now that I'm well over the legal age, I will be ordering many cocktails to go with my filet!

nikZWRNWo3kMVelRk3vIvQ.review_text: The staff was friendly and attentive.  The front desk person who announced the people waiting for a table asked me on the correct pronunciation of my name after I spelled it for him, wrote it down, and pronounced it correctly.  Kudos!  The bar poured stiff drinks, which made the wait for my table ultra-bearable.  The front desk told me 30 minutes, but it was really only 15.  There were buttloads of people waiting for a table, but it's usually easy to seat just one.  In fact, they had two tables set up for single diners.    My server was amazing.  She took several minutes to go through the menu when I asked her what her favorites were, and made good suggestions (and not just the most expensive things on the menu).  I settled on the Cioppino, which she said is one of her favorites in the winter.  I decided that I couldn't come to the Fisherman's Wharf without having some...  ...and boy was I right.  This was the most delicious, most fish-filled incredible soup.  The portion was huge, and after eating to the point of bursting, I still had plenty left in the bowl.  There were several mussels, many scallops, large pieces of fish, prawns... it was like a gigantic cornucopia of seafood goodness.  The tomato broth was chock full of meat... but surprisingly not fishy.  Afterward, I joked with my server that I wanted some horseradish, celery salt, and Worcestershire sauce to make the most delicious Bloody Mary possible.  The dish was expensive, almost $40 if I remember correctly, but I felt it was worth every penny of it.  Less remarkable was my dinner salad, which was great... but paled in comparison to my Cioppino.  The balsamic dressing was tangy and delicious.  Also worth mention -- the bread.  My server dropped off a gigantic loaf of delicious sour-dough bread.  If youuu're gooooiiinnnng to Saaan Frannncisssco, be sure you stop in at Scoma's.  It's an absolute must... but plan for plenty of time as you're probably going to wait.

LrhjmL1JfX-tH6crOvjuvg.review_text: Really was expecting much more. Food was ok, nothing great and overpriced for what you get.  I wouldn't go back.

M2pQCtwl8ypwMV6BjKnOmA.review_text: ouch! this place was crowded on a Tuesday night!  For the looks of it and the reviews, we thought we were in for a treat.  For the price and the poor quality of the service, your seafood dollars are best spent elsewhere.  We started with the cold seafood appetizer for two (oysters, crab meat, shrimp), for 26$.  When our waiter brought us the hot appetizer and we corrected him, he looked like we had just ruined his life and didn't even apologize for it!   The seafood was great, but for 26$, you think youd get mroe than 3 shrimp and 4 oysters and a few hunks of crab.    We had the pasta girabaldi, which was great - the salmon was fantastic in this dish.  We had the risotto with crab - eh, risotto was under cooked and the crab bits were so small you couldn't tell if you got one.    The halibut, well cooked but under seasoned.    Moral of the story, go elsewhere for your fancy seafood dinner.

27JQ4nnrkJeBZOfZ2_MJjg.review_text: Scoma's is one of the best restaurants of any kind you can eat at! Their seafood is tops-- bar none! The service is always terrific too. My wife and I have been eating here when in San Francisco for more than twenty years, and it is consistently very good.

NNMbPWrFM9O5KPbs-oeD6g.review_text: If a party of 1 expect to be put in the corner in a tiny table, even though several other tables with a view are available...  Staff was not overly friendly...but have to admit the clam chowder and crab cakes were phenomenal (which is why such a high score)...

cgrT4GWEiyQDEW49VRP98w.review_text: Ordered Crab cake Mixed seafood gill Lobster Laeiloi  Cram chowder  Good taste! Friendly waiters! A little bit experience but it's worth.  You do not need to book for window seat because .... It's all the same.

GyFw7b5_fclAS3HhNM23hQ.review_text: Went with the reviews I had read here about the clam chowder. It definitely didn't disappoint. Also had a taste of the Lazy Man's Cioppino; didn't disappoint either. Ordered the dungeness crabcakes, romaine salad, and mixed green salad. Really enjoyed the romaine salad. For dessert went with the lemon and pecan tart. The lemon tart was YUMMY! Service was good considering that they were busy.

FarlUOxHOJ1NRMg9FwLAdQ.review_text: I took my wife out for her birthday here and we had the dungeness crabcakes and the sea scallop risotto. The food was spectacular and the server was more than able to point us to an amazing Zinfandel to go with it. The view of the harbor was nice especially as the sun set and the lights came on, but it was not a view of the bay, instead the seats face in toward the city.  This is a great place to come for a special occasion, but it was missing that little extra something to get the fifth star in my book. It certainly did not disappoint despite being $120 for two people with dinner, drinks, tax and tip, but it didn't knock my socks off either.

rT_eYTdxqlAX_nRzglQFUw.review_text: Awesome Dungeness crab my wife and I have ever had. So glad we asked the locals and found out about this place. Gonna come back here on our next trip to frisco.

AWye-gCYuGO4oqYN2IrMbQ.review_text: The food: Scoma's is where you go for non pretentious, deliciously fresh seafood. Since there are so many reviews, I'll keep this short; unless you have a particular fish or seafood that you love (salmon, shrimp, etc.) you should go with the more mixture based dishes like the Shellfish Saute or the Cioppino- both absolutely delicious and top notch quality.  The good: You can really go to Scoma's in jeans and a dress shirt and you'll blend right in with the tourists. Servers are all nicely clad in ties and crisp white shirts, and everything from the fresh sourdough to the ocean smelling seafood is absolutely worth the higher price.  The bad: It's a long wait with no reservations taken, so get there early! Also, the desserts are meh but that's ok because they're not the main attraction.  Ambiance: Comfortable Italian restaurant. The focus is the food!  What to know: this is a place tourists are aware of, so beware going for dinner on weekend nights! If you're lucky enough to grab a table by the bar, you can munch on appetizers or enjoy some drinks to survive the wait.  Good for: family, friends, and out of towners.   In short: Scoma's serves super fresh and tasty sea food for a slightly hefty but very worth it place. One of my go to's for bay area vacations!

7XXJvnppKOenm7W2vlVCuA.review_text: Food and ambiance can't be beat.  The server was fabulous.  Try the Petrale Dore!

G4CoJrk_IpLe2Q7xJBjqKw.review_text: Probably one of the best lobster bisque I've ever had! The entree  was fairly decent , but the soup was by far the star! A must-try

FqAoUALHzZuRH216wa_bxg.review_text: My favorite restaurant on Earth. My Dad's been coming here for more than 40 years. Whenever he comes to visit SF from Detroit, he always jokingly says, "I'm coming to SF to go to Scomas, if I have time, I'll see you!"   Have the sautee'd calamari. There's two styles that aren't on the menu anymore (but will still make!). Sautéed in tomato sauce, or fried in breading with white sauce (bianci). Both will blow your mind.  My 30th birthday party here was an event I'll never forget.

LeBme68V-ZCZft38sW6cTw.review_text: Had higher hopes for the place but the experience was just okay. The decor's just really outdated and wait staff not very warm.  Came for Dine About Town and within our group we tried: Lobster bisque - 3 stars - not much lobster taste but a nice soup Crab cakes with watercress salad - 4 stars - best appetizer  with good amount of crab meat Ahi tuna steak - 3 stars - nothing to write home about Lamb T-bone - 4 stars - best entree dish, even the sides (polenta and spinach) were delicious Seared scallops with pasta pomodoro - 3 stars - scallops were seared very nicely, but the pasta was so blah Pumpkin cheesecake - 3 stars Tiramisu - 5 stars - best dish of the night - yum! Brownie and espresso ice cream - 3 stars - brownie was dry and not dense but not in a good way  One additional dish we had was a shrimp louie salad which was good but at a whopping $29...everything else on the menu was REALLY pricey too.  Would not return again unless for DAT which was $34.95 for 3 courses.

Mc0JPaPGUL9vYF08qLc0YA.review_text: Food was served luke warm in an untimely manner (food took 30 minutes to serve clam chowder and salad) - portions were of sufficient size.  Quality of food was mediocre at best.  Service was okay - nothing good or bad to report on.  Overall experience: I would definitely try other places before ever coming back.  I don't understand how Scoma has an overall four star rating on Yelp.

qkRAvTnkVqSUOkKhvY9COw.review_text: My wife, kids and I looked on Yelp for good place to have dinner on a Friday night, while we were in San Francisco. We decided on Scoma's. We walked in, and were told that the wait would be 30 minutes.  After 35 minutes, I walked to the hostess stand to find out how much longer.  I was told "just a few minutes longer".  After 45 minutes, the hostess said "just another few minutes".  After an hour of waiting, we were seated in the back portion of the restaurant, near a bus station. The bad part about this area is that there is a door that the waiters use to step outside and smoke. Unfortunately, they don't shut this door when they smoke and the smoke travels back into the restaurant. I mentioned this to our waiter, who basically ignored me.  The food was average. The experience was not good, and we will not go back.

5a6-pk-rnHGF6edZKoCFiw.review_text: I came here with my family on a Wednesday night.  There was quite a waiting line, but the wait wasn't unreasonable.    The service staff was very pleasant and attentive.  The cioppino was delicious and flavorful.  The Crab Risotto was wonderful as well.  They used plenty of spices and it was to a good consistency.  The only knock I have against the risotto was that is wasn't made with arborio rice or other typical risotto rices, but with some generic, short grain rice.  This meant that it wasn't a nice creamy consistency, but was more like some east-west rice dish concoction and expected a bit more for the price.    I wouldn't come back for the risotto, but the cioppino would be worth the trip back.

5K9yqInZGhwRWn6dxwiw8w.review_text: Wow, I hate to disagree (two stars worth!) with my beloved yelp community, but Scoma's was a huge disappointment and I honestly feel like I dined in a different restaurant than some of these reviews.    Let's see, where to begin ... we went for lunch and got there 10 mins before official opening time, but they kindly allowed us early birds to park at the bar while the restaurant was readied for the hungry hordes.  I had a glass of wine, companion had water ... I asked the 'keep if he needed us to settle or if we could carry the check to our table.  He looked at me like I had three heads and told me no, I needed to pay for my drink here.  ok ... so I ask for a check.  I got this gruff attitude, and he sticks the check in a plastic cup in front of the two of us and turns his back.  We know we are about to be called, so I put a bill in the cup.  From the size of the bill, I clearly had change coming, but the guy ignored it.  the cup sat.  our name was called and I was forced to flag him down.  It all felt kind of icky.  What can I say ... gut feeling.  Lunch itself was also a letdown.  I had crab cakes (they don't have this as an entree, only an app, so no sides for me.)  The crab was tiny slivers in too much filler and there were several shells.  Nothing turns off crab-cake love faster than shells.  His fish was .... meh.  Literally nothing to mention one way or the other, totally forgettable.  And if I can't even remember dessert (I can't, even looking at the menu) I can promise you it's bad.  b-a-n-a-n-a-s bad.    Prices are just too high for the quality and service.  Scoma's is really not what it pretends to be.  There is so much potential ... a magnificent view if you are lucky to snag a window table, and a better than prime location.  but other than that, Scoma's feels run down and in need of some reworking.

d8zp3ILsDnjx986RsC3R1g.review_text: Bread is good!  Way over priced, I mean WAY!  You get crappy sides with your meal and you are crammed into a TINY place.  If you are sitting behind a tall or large person you can forget about being able to go use the restroom - you're locked in!  For this amount of money per plate you should at least be able to stretch out or relax at your table - not here!  Oh ya and the dock is way dangerous! Kids can totally fall right through the side rails!  But good bread.

9R3lxxazCr17WXCIgk2xMA.review_text: Solely based on the service and cleanliness alone, I can't even bring myself to give it 3 stars. While the food was write-home-and-tell-the-folks-about-it phenomenal, the RUDE bartender during our HOUR PAST RESERVATION TIME plus the wait staff (one of whom kept putting her arm ON MY FRIENDS HEAD to reach over and fill our glasses, the 2nd, 3rd and sometimes 4th reminders to be brought a drink or food item ordered, was just ridiculous. The bathrooms were DISGUSTING! I had mentioned it to them during our waiting, and than half way through the meal, went again and they were WORSE! Toilet paper EVERYWHERE! For a place that has such amazing food (I had the porta bella mushroom appetizer and the smoked salmon and shrimp fettuccini), i was severely disappointed in the numerous staff we came into contact with! Maybe just get your food to go and avoid the staff as much as possible!

B2ByQNX8NczCpkj5EpqXRA.review_text: We cannot help ourselves.  For 20 years we have gone here annually for crab.  It's delicious.   The ambiance is old-fashioned tourism - red carpets, dark walls. But the views are fantastic -- you're out on a pier so you are facing either the SF Bay or the City -- win, win.  No reservations, they take your name and you wait in the old bar that faces the water.  That's half the fun!   A mixture of seafood-loving locals and tourists.  If you have the time you'll not be disappointed by this fish house on the bay!

lKPDTuoakpbWuOT8r9DOAg.review_text: The **best** seafood restaurant in SF. It's where the LOCALS go. I take my friends, my relatives and business relationships (but only the ones I REALLY like!).  I typically get the Cioppino. Sometimes I go hard core with the regular Cioppino (get the bib!!!), cracking all the crab myself, and sometimes I go with the Lazy Man's Cioppino (bib recommended). The seafood saute is also excellent. For the dainty women in the group, have them opt for the open-face crab sandwich.They'll probably take some home anyway.  As a native Seattelite., I know my Dungeness Crab. You can't go wrong at Scoma's when it is in season.   Get ready to wait, but it is FULLY worth it.

du4opprO3OVLJjFfDw_IeQ.review_text: I came off of a recommendation.  I wasn't impressed.  It didn't knock my socks off and I wasn't impressed with the location, old decor, facility, etc   I guess it's better than really touristy food, but I regretted coming here.

HO9VpfYRzD0QFom85uYNDQ.review_text: Great food and service. We arrived at 1:00 Saturday afternoon and waited about 20 minutes for the table. You can sit at the bar and wait. It is comfortable. Thanks to Yelp we learned they have free valet parking. It is convenient. We were seated at a window table. Great atmosphere. The waiters are excellent and take time to point out highlights and explain the menu. The food is fabulous.  I had the LAZY MAN'S CIOPPINO.   The broth was seasoned perfect with an abundance of shellfish and fresh fish.  My wife had SWORDFISH CON FAGIOLI. That, I strongly recommend.  The fish is broiled, with white beans, swiss chard and pancetta. It is incredible! My son had their version of Surf & Turf. A perfectly cooked NY Strip with colossal prawns. They were so good and taste like lobster. I cannot say enough good things about Scoma's. It will be a part of every visit I make to the Bay Area from now on.

RTcuhbxDIWFBUN335JPhsw.review_text: Scoma's is a nice old time restaurant.  We decided to go to try their Cioppino.  The place sits right on the water.  We ordered the Clam Chowder, Cioppino, and Garlic Crab.    The chowder was very tasty and had a lot of clams.  The cioppino was very good.  They cracked all the crab shells so you could enjoy the crab meat without all the work.  The cioppino had a nice flavor but was a little too thick for me.  The garlic crab has a good flavor with the garlic and lemon.  It was very fresh.  This is a good place for a family to go and enjoy some fresh seafood!

-F_nkJiaARGv5tsLZPw4uA.review_text: One of my favorite places to go when I am in San Fran, My Dad loved this place and we carry on the tradition when we come to town, the food is fantastic and the service is impeccable. Just be prepared to spend some money.

VNkEB5PlrESiPP6-3JR-xg.review_text: As with any restaurant on the wharf, I'm a bit skeptical but have to try it at least once. Scomas is a real icon in San Francisco and my experience there was better than anticipated- even entertaining.  All I could think of after being seated was the Seinfeld episode, "I'll have the Clams Casino"!  The waitstaff is wearing white tux jackets with glistening name tags to showcase names like Wu and CC. With a veteran staff like this don't expect your iced tea to go dry or your empty plate to sit there staring back at you. The minute you place your fork down the plate will mysteriously disappear and after you've gulped down the last of your tea, its full again.  With a fully attentive staff our lunch was quick and easy. The food was good but not extraordinary.

BYvjvN7Wgxbhd9ZvDRIlUg.review_text: Seems like a haven for tourists -- us being a couple of them ;) but very yummy food with ridiculously large portions. The calamari were very good, though it is hard to mess up on traditional Calamari. For my entree - I had the Salmon atop a bed of crab ravioli...Oh My Lord...So good, but oh so filling. The piece of Salmon was HUGE which was surprising considering the dish also included ravioli....  The atmosphere reminded me of a traditional old school Italian place which is I guess what it is ...cute...though I wouldn't come here for the vibe. We waited at the bar and had a glass of wine before being seated which didn't seem to take long (we didn't have reservations).  Service was friendly and the food very satisfying and filling...we had no room for dessert. It is a little pricey but for the amount of food you are getting -- seems fair.

feMaeSkjKoJY1m29BdDvQg.review_text: This should be taken as the place of group fun and some we come here about 6/7 together. Peking duck, shrimp, chowmein, noodles, fried fish and so many can be found here with decent pricing. But I am actually not fully satisfied with their food quality specially the last I had bad concept of their lobster. It was sad little sad but overall other service is OK.

VgfD-RPmhM71rNs0GmSXoA.review_text: Several other reviews have noted the general aesthetics of this restaurant as particularly dated. They are not inaccurate but with good company old can become charming. It is old but it does have some charm. The location is right in the heart of the tourist area but using the restaurant front free valet is great once you get there. The front desk host quickly seated us a few minutes before our scheduled reservation and the waitress and buss staff were very attentive throughout our meal. No hard drinks tonight but our waters and iced tea never went much below half with very timely refills. Our server did not make any recommendations but did compliment our choices. To start we shared the crab cocktail, it was terrific and the small additional "mix your own" cocktail sauce on the side was perfect for us as I liked a bit heavier hand with the horseradish. We then both decided on the lazy man's dish. 3 clams, 3 large scallops, 3 jumbo shrimp, lots of bay shrimp and crab meat and lots of fish made for an especially large portion neither of us finished. The crusty, buttery, sourdough bread half slice crouton was very good also. The stew base was a bit too one-note tomato-ey especially since there was just so much of it but it wasn't bad...just too much to finish without other flavor. Nothing on the dessert menu really called to us but we split the ice cream and brownie dessert anyway as this outing was a special occasion. The brownie was forgettable but the ice cream was really good. The total bill was what we would have expected for the tourist area and the fresh fish, pricey but not terrible. Service throughout the evening was terrific. The valet was prompt getting our car and we were headed home. My wife and I enjoyed Scoma's and both agreed we would come back but we'd likely someplace else we love or someplace new first. Additional note: because the dining rooms are tight, smaller parties might have a better overall experience than larger ones. In the room we dined there was only 2 tables for 2 and 2 tables for 4 so the noise was a dull din and the space between parties was acceptable. Bigger groups will make this impossible and I would imagine trying to have a cross table conversation would be impossible.  Perhaps you could specify where you would prefer to sit in your reservations...also reservations highly recommended.

Z36BYCEwIa16SBq4lK9AfQ.review_text: This rating would be higher, if it wasn't for the host. I know that Scoma's is a San Francisco tradition, but the host on the afternoon of July 4th, 2010 at 1:15 pm was quite rude. First off, my girlfriend and I had to make an emergency restroom break at Starbuck's  on Beach & Hyde. Consequently, we purchased drinks there so we wouldn't take advantage of their generosity in having a "public" restroom available.   We took our drinks to Scoma's and upon our arrival, the host said that we couldn't bring our drinks from Starbuck's in with us. No sign stating "NO OUTSIDE DRINKS ALLOWED" was visible. Once we explained the situation that we were in, the host reluctantly allowed us to bring our drinks, provided that we didn't consume them during our meal.  Additionally, the host spoke to us in a manner befitting young children! I'm 38 and my girlfriend is 32. It was a very embarrassing way to be treated by a restaurant that's hosted celebrities from Alan Shepard and Cheech Marin to the great Frank Sinatra! Not very hospitable!!!   The food was very good, and the service provided by the wait staff was fine. The host, in spite of being a relative of the late Al Scoma, needs a lesson in being warm and welcoming to all, visitors and tourists alike.

N4z5DoPKQyU-6iCnMTvjaA.review_text: This review is based off of my experience from a few years ago, but the lasting impression and impressive food make my 5-start rating justified.   I went to Scoma's a few years back. Since then, i've recommended many friends, colleagues and family members to stop by and all have left impressed by the quality of food and overall experience. Each time I've mentioned the restaurant, i've told people about how our waiter essentially punked me and my table-mates into our order. The waiter came by, looked at our indecisive faces and told us what we were gong to eat. It wasn't a reccomendation... he told us what we were going to eat. Obviously taken back by it, my uncle who is a repeat customer indicated that this is normal (I still think that's a lie) and that we'd enjoy the meal or he would foot the bill. Damned if it wasn't the best seafood pasta i'd ever eaten. The quality of food was fresh and top notch. The restaurant is very busy, so reservations are a must and I would recommend nicer attire. I can't wait to go back and enjoy my next meal there... whatever it is that the waiter feels like ordering for me.

F9QvUzHpqzIHcFSU07fvEw.review_text: Fair, but not worth the cost. Ordered a filet medium., came out well and took another 30 minutes to get a new one. Our fish was good but cold by the time the steak was right.

oVzxncUXhuebyj8HH0fpfA.review_text: I have been eating at Scoma's for over 30 years and it continues to be one of my favorite places to eat when I come to San Francisco.  My wife and I drove up from Sacramento just to enjoy a 30th Anniversary dinner at Scoma's.  I had the Dungeness Crab Spoon Bread, it was excellent.  My wife had the Lazy Man's Cioppino, she said it was good, but not as well seasoned as it was last time we visited the Restaurant.  As always the service was great.

F8Zm1Dg6mRQHWTTZADb-Jg.review_text: Crowds of people at this restaurant, which can only mean one thing:  the food must be good!  I looked forward to satisfying my fresh seafood cravings here.    The food is pretty pricey.  But their plates do come with A LOT of seafood.  I ordered the clam chowder and a pasta dish which came with scallops, shrimp, TWO lobster tails, and clams. My husband ordered the lobster bisque and Lazy Man's Cioppino.  The clam chowder was delicious.  The lobster bisque was also good, but I thought it lacked lobster meat.  My pasta was very bland!  I completely regret even eating as much pasta as I did since it filled me up and I had a hard time eating the most important things on my plate...the seafood!  I thought the Cioppino was great.  Lots of fresh seafood and the broth/soup was tasty with a little kick.    The service is quick and attentive.  There's also free parking in the back of the restaurant, so you don't have to pay for pricey parking in the Fisherman's Wharf area.

2_1FxCMLvK46Vt81VlIS7A.review_text: I haven't been here in several years. Had a business trip in the area and had to stop in for dinner. Scoma's didn't disappoint! The food was outstanding and the presentation was great. My wife and I enjoyed it all, we also saw several others from our  group there as well!

n_5wXXk3-IfqbHn3Ea03pQ.review_text: Scoma should definitely be on everyone's TRY before you DIE list...    The menu changes seasonally so it'll be different every time you go.  Everything you try - you'll LOVE.  There is a nice sized bar area where you can grab cocktails and hors d'ouvers can be ordered as you await your table.   REMINDER:  This place is first come, first serve and very popular - please keep that in mind :)

9_qDqQ30TGd9gzGHgSprCw.review_text: The cute shops and boutiques really gives this restaurant major points, but I think I had higher expectations for this reputable restaurant. Oh, and the view is fantastic during sunset hours!  Also, not good for groups!

orIcZwRR8fJkxMRI6-POlg.review_text: I came here last month for Dine About Town lunch special on a Saturday. It was not crowded, and we were seated right away upon my arrival. All members of the party have to be there to be seated.  The service was excellent. I ordered the scallops, and it was well prepared.   The staff is very courteous and attentive. A friend of mine went to feed the meter or move her car a little while before her food was served, and they were so worried for her that she wouldn't be able to eat it while it was hot.   If it were not for the special, I don't think I would have made it out there. But it was a good experience.

mXA4uFvAo3sW0kSlY-xftw.review_text: Scoma's is a classic Fisherman's Wharf must eat if you are willing to spend a bit more.  The food is highly worth it.  Everyone has to try here at least once.

eaEj6tTIRBRHbXhvQfwEYQ.review_text: Different than what I expected, in a good way. My clam chowder came with no bread or crackers, but instead had visible CHUNKS of clam. I expected a creamy subtle plate for my crab risotto, but receieved a robust bowl with mushrooms and peas and tomatoes and large pieces of crab.   I had to wait a while, even though I dined alone. I think that's a good sign.

T7ko9V7ceVMJlMFbsihpzw.review_text: I came here with a friend during the dine about town. For appetizers we got the lobster bisque and crab cakes both were excellent. The entrees were okay, which is why I only gave it 3 stars, I had the lamb chops and my friend had the swordfish (maybe it was their dine about town menu? but not impressed at all)  The desserts were actually very good, we had the cheesecake and the bread pudding. The bread pudding was our favorite, it was warm and made with sour dough bread. If you like contrasting textures and flavors this is a most.  Another reason for the4 3 star was because I felt that the podium where you checked in was crazy tall, I mean I know I'm short but I had to be on my tip toes to give my name... ..

xy_BYX2jniJyQpVLGMTpIQ.review_text: great dinner! Seafood heaven!!! Looking for a good dinner, come here! Been around since 1965. Pricey but worth it.

EIWpCT54fxYgwri-8Ct5cA.review_text: On a recent work trip to San Francisco, we decided to follow the recommendation of several locals to dine at Scoma's.  We parked in front of Doubin bread and walked to the restaurant.  From the outside, the restaurant looks small, but once you walk in you are immediately transported into a wonderful, roomy restaurant with a warm vintage feel to it.  We thought we were going to have to wait for quite a while, however our table for two was ready within minutes.    Our waiter was a pleasant gentleman named Ray.  He took our drink order and then gave us plenty of time to look over the menu.  I decided to order the cup of clam chowder and the cracked dungeness crab.  As we waited for our meal, Ray brought fresh sourdough bread to our table.    I am very picky about clam chowder, so I was apprehensive about ordering it.  That clam chowder was the BEST clam chowder I have ever had.  Ever.  I could eat it for lunch or dinner every day.  If you like clam chowder - REAL clam chowder - do yourself a favor and order a cup of it.  For $9.00, you are getting a true taste of heaven.  The Dungeness crab was very good. Having grown up on the Chesapeake Bay, I've never had "roasted" crab, so this was a fun treat.    I would definitely eat there again, if I ever make my way back out to San Francisco!

451QHuyThn2ggLzq81cvcw.review_text: I was in SFO 2 years ago and some local guy took me to this restaurant. The dungeness crab is superb and nowhere else to be found! Though I forgot the restaurant's name, I google mapped the path and found it.  Last week I waited 1 hour in line and it's absolutely worth it because the dungeness crab season is just back! Order the Garlic-Roasted dungeness crab and it never fails you, never!

1G7tKAJfR8J4s9BAOV0_Qw.review_text: Our favorite place to eat.  I always love the sand dabs and probably a good thing they seem to run out from time to time because then I get to try more items on the menu.  Baked Crab=amazing Oysters= nice variety and for oyster lover its awesome Cioppino=amazing (and very large good for 2 people) Scallops= cooked to perfection Calamari-amazing  maybe the dirty martinis helped but this place is worth the wait everytime
